PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 60 citizens), Senator Giles (from 465 citizens), and Senator Vanstone (from 59 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex 1991
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX '91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/ Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX '91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX '91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will every pray. God save The Queen.

SPEECH.PARA: CASH TRANSACTION REPORTS
AMENDMENT BILL 1991
Mr President, this Bill proposes amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 to provide for the reporting and analysis of international telegraphic transfer data.

The reporting of international telegraphic transfers will complement the existing requirements under the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 for cash dealers to report to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA) those transactions which are either suspect or involve cash in excess of $10,000 and for individuals to report the export and import of currency in excess of $5,000. The existing reporting system fills a gap left by the removal of a system of tax screening arrangements and foreign currency controls which ceased to operate from 1 July 1990. The successes of the CTRA, as described in its recently tabled Annual Report have been impressive. The degree of effectiveness of the agency, still in its infancy, reflects the enormous good-will and cooperation of the financial sector in assisting law enforcement, and the growing expertise of our revenue and law enforcement agencies in dealing with the financial aspects of illegal activity.

This measure now proposed will assist in combating large scale tax evasion and organised crime. The trend in tax evasion and corporate crime is to internationalise illicit profits, and international telegraphic transfers are the principal means by which funds are channelled from Australia overseas. The reporting of the data to the CTRA will allow the easy collection, analysis and immediate dissemination to law enforcement agencies of accurate information relating to international telegraphic transfers of funds.

In March 1991, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial and Public Administration (Martin Committee) in considering the issue of international profit shifting found evidence of the perpetration of large scale revenue evasion, possibly of the order of $100-250 million, and recommended that a system of monitoring and reporting international telegraphic transfers of funds be implemented, with the CTRA responsible for the establishment and administration of such a system.

The Martin Committee has indicated that the capture and analysis of telegraphic transfer data would add a significant dimension to the ability of the Australian Taxation Office and law enforcement agencies to strike at financial gain which is the major incentive of international organised crime.

Existing reporting systems do not adequately provide for the monitoring of international transactions. This is a serious deficiency since it deprives the Australian Tax Office of an important source of intelligence in its efforts to combat international profit shifting to avoid tax liability.

Some international telegraphic transfers have been reported to the CTRA in the form of suspect transactions. However, this is only the "tip of the iceberg" in international profit shifting activities. Telegraphic transfers are effected in a very impersonal manner without the counter contact which brings the staff member face to face with the customer in circumstances where he or she might notice something peculiar about the transaction. As pointed out in the Martin Report, because of the sophistication of the abuse of withholding tax arrangements, the likelihood of the associated transactions being reported through the CTRA's current reporting arrangements is minimal.

On the issue of tax avoidance, the Martin Committee received evidence indicating that arrangements or schemes are operating in Australia which allow Australian residents to avoid their taxation obligations by paying 10% withholding tax instead of personal or company rates of income tax. Some of the schemes are extremely complex and difficult to detect, involving circuitous routes through various countries, including tax havens, and can often reappear as legitimate transactions.

A feasibility study has shown not only the real need for law enforcement agencies to have access to information about such transfers to trace the profits of criminal activity, for taxation and confiscation purposes, but also that many cash dealers are in a position to readily provide much of this information. The remainder is transmitted by telex. While the proposed legislation will require the reporting of transfers transmitted by telex, the Government is conscious of the burden that this could impose on those cash dealers who conduct a high volume of telex transfers and whose systems are not computerised. It is therefore proposed to exempt those cash dealers from reporting telex transfers until the telex systems are computerised. International telegraphic transfer data is already in electronic form for transmission through the SWIFT System (Society for World-wide International Financial Telecommunication) and can be duplicated by cash dealers and transmitted on line to the CTRA.

As I said earlier, the measures in the Bill will provide a necessary tool for detecting off-shore tax rorts, which are believed to be flourishing, and for assisting in the appropriate assessment of tax liability. Conservative estimates are of revenue gains in excess of $37 million per annum. The CTRA considers that 85% of non-cash funds transfers are remitted off-shore through the telegraphic transfer system. The Taxation Institute of Australia indicates how a substantial sum can slip through the reporting system as it currently operates. One instance is where, for example, $1 million, perhaps proceeds of a successful drug importation in the process of being laundered, is remitted to a tax haven by telegraphic transfer. This would not be reported since it is not in the form of cash. In this respect the current system is narrower in its scope than the previous tax screening system. Lost taxation revenue may, in fact, exceed $100 million per year, according to the Martin Report, with additional lost Customs revenue estimated at $10 million per year and proceeds of crime at $30 million.

In contrast the cost of implementing the proposal is relatively modest. The outlay in the first two years will be $13.08 million because of the capital investment in information technology facilities, but will be less than $5 million in subsequent years. There will also be costs to cash dealers, principally in the modification of computer equipment to duplicate existing data for transmission to the CTRA.

The Australian Bankers' Association and representatives of other major cash dealers groups have worked closely with officers of my Department and the CTRA in the development of this initiative, and I wish to thank them for their cooperation and support. This cooperation is continuing in the development of appropriate technology to permit the monitoring of such transfers to ensure the effectiveness of the scheme and its appropriateness to the practices of the finance industry.

The Bill will make provision to protect banks (whether Australian or foreign) operating in Australia from any possible legal action which may arise in Australia from the banks complying with the reporting requirements.

I also propose two minor amendments to the CTR Act: First to clarify the last point in time when a person is able to make a report to a customs officer when bringing currency into, or taking it out of, Australia, and secondly, to change the name of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) and, the name of the Act to the Financial Transaction Reports Act.

The Bill clarifies the obligation to report in section 15 of the Act. That section requires a person bringing into, or taking out of, Australia currency of a value greater than $A5,000 to make a report in a prescribed form to a Customs officer. An uncertainty was brought to light in a recent South Australian Supreme Court decision which held that a report could still be filed during a Customs baggage search without breach of the provision. The amendment clarifies this obligation by defining the last point in time when reports of such transfers can be made, namely prior to baggage search or prior to being given permission to leave the Customs control area without search for inwards passengers, and the point where Customs officers inspect passports for outwards passengers. Provision is also made in relation to persons other than passengers (crew, for example).

The Bill will also amend the name of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre. This title will more accurately reflect the nature of the Agency's major operations since, particularly with the addition of the reporting of international telegraphic transfers, only a minor proportion of the Agency's operations will relate to cash transactions. For the same reason, the name of the Act will also be changed to the Financial Transaction Reports Act.

In conclusion, I stress that the country cannot afford to continue to suffer the vast revenue losses through tax and customs evasion or tolerate the removal off-shore of the proceeds of some of our most serious crimes. The average Australian is tired of seeing the high-flyers rort the system. The shareholders of this country are tired of seeing their investments moved off-shore, seemingly without trace and certainly beyond their reach, but no doubt to the personal gain of unscrupulous manipulators exploiting a loop-hole in the system which must now be closed off.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET
LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 contains amendments to a number of Acts administered within the portfolio of the Prime Minister and to Acts containing provisions which relate to Public Service matters.

An amendment to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 will make it possible, where the Ombudsman or the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police is investigating a complaint, for the Ombudsman to refer a question to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for an advisory opinion. The Ombudsman is already able to recommend to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police that such a question be referred.

This Bill also amends the Governor-General Act 1974 to remove a limitation on the entitlement of the surviving spouse of a former Governor-General to an allowance. The surviving spouse currently loses the entitlement to an allowance on remarriage. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that a similar limitation in the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 is inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 as it discriminates on the basis of marital status.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986

SPEECH.PARA: Three amendments are proposed to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986. Two of these are administrative in nature, and are intended to bring the Office of the Inspector-General into line with other statutory bodies. Provision is now made for the appointment of an acting Inspector-General in the event of the absence of the Inspector-General or of a temporary vacancy in that office. A second amendment ensures that, should a person appointed to act as Inspector-General also hold a judicial office, that person may continue to enjoy the rights and privileges of that judicial office while acting as Inspector-General.

The final amendment provides the Inspector-General with right of access to the annual or periodic reports of the intelligence and security agencies, and to Ministerial directions or guidelines given to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Defence Signals Directorate of the Department of Defence. Although the agencies have voluntarily provided the Inspector-General with copies of such documents in the past, it is considered expedient to formalise access in legislation. This will further enhance the Inspector-General's ability to monitor the activities of the intelligence agencies, to ensure that they act within the law, with propriety and with regard for human rights. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 already provides the Inspector-General with the right of access to directions or guidelines given to ASIO by the Attorney-General.

This amendment to the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973 is intended to implement an interim decision of the Public Service Board in 1987 that a woman on maternity leave without pay should not become an unattached officer without her consent.
Three substantive amendments are proposed to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984.

The first of these is designed to give the Agency flexibility in the manner in which it conducts meetings. It is often inconvenient, or unnecessary, for Agency members to meet in person to conduct the Agency's business. The amendment will enable meetings of the agency to be conducted by electronic means—for example by conference telephone.

The other amendments are proposed in consequence of findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in April 1988. The amendments will enable a pecuniary penalty to be imposed for breach of an order of a Disciplinary Appeal Committee or of a Retirement and Redeployment Appeal Committee prohibiting or restricting the publication of evidence. The Merit Protection Regulations enable the Committees to make such orders.
A number of minor amendments are made to the Ombudsman Act 1976 by the Bill for the purpose of clarifying the Ombudsman's powers.

One of these amendments will mirror the amendment made to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act previously referred to, empowering the Ombudsman to refer questions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for an advisory opinion.

Other amendments to the Ombudsman Act will clarify the powers of the Ombudsman by specifying that a claim of legal professional privilege cannot be used to deny the Ombudsman access to information, and ensuring that the Ombudsman's role is not exhausted by the presentation of a report to Parliament about an investigation, by providing that the Ombudsman may discuss any matter to which the report relates with the principal officer of the Department or authority concerned in order to resolve the matter.
The Bill makes a number of substantive amendments to the Public Service Act 1922.
The amendments are being made ahead of action being taken to bring forward in due course a Bill for a modernised Act aimed at simplifying and integrating procedures and practices.

The major amendments reflect the Government's agreement under the Structural Efficiency Principle to restructure the Senior Executive Service (SES) into three Bands and introduce the SES (Specialist) category. Other amendments relate to the role of the Public Service Commissioner in the termination of SES officers on probation and the extension of fixed term appointments.

A new three Band structure for the SES came into effect on 4 January 1990. One of the aims of the structure was to enhance the optimum use of resources by providing Secretaries and Heads of Agencies with flexibility in the allocation of SES resources and budget to meet changing priorities and issues at a particular time.

The amendments proposed will enable Secretaries and Heads of Agencies to transfer SES staff across positions within the same band irrespective of the salary points involved. Under current provisions, it is necessary for such filling action to be subject to a full selection process, as the movement to a higher salary point in such circumstances is currently regarded as a promotion.

During 1990 a separate SES (Specialist) category was established within the Senior Executive Service. Movement to the broad SES group from SES (Specialist) positions by promotion or transfer is on the basis of merit competition. The amendments proposed reflect the establishment of the new category and the role of the Public Service Commissioner in filling related positions.

An amendment is also included to enable the Public Service Commissioner rather than a Secretary to terminate probation of SES officers. This is consistent with the Commissioner's existing powers in relation to appointment, promotion and retirement for SES officers.

Another proposed amendment will enable the Commissioner, on the recommendation of a Secretary or Head of Agency, to extend the term of a fixed term SES appointee to a maximum period of 5 years. Currently, it is not possible to extend an initial engagement where the period concerned is of lesser duration.
In addition to the amendments relating to the SES, the Bill makes a number of other technical and procedural amendments to the Act.

The Bill also repeals a provision of the Public Service Reform Act 1984 which is unproclaimed and is no longer required. This repeal is in accordance with the view expressed by the Senate Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills that unproclaimed provisions should be repealed.

The Bill also provides for the removal of the requirement for a number of Government agencies and authorities to obtain approval from the Public Service Commissioner for terms and conditions of employment for staff (or, in some instances, certain categories of staff only).

Under the Administrative Arrangements Act 1987, the Public Service Board's statutory approval role became a role of the Public Service Commissioner. In accordance with the proposed administrative arrangements following abolition of the Board, officers of the Department of Industrial Relations are currently performing the function under delegation from the Commissioner.

This amendment is consistent with initiatives throughout Australian Government employment to devolve to agency management greater autonomy, and to make managers more accountable for their actions. Nonetheless, all statutory authorities will still remain covered by the Government's general industrial relations co-ordination arrangements, which ensure the consistent application of the Government's wages and industrial relations policies.

The Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989 is to be amended to remove the Administration of Norfolk Island from the definition of "Commonwealth authority". The Norfolk Island Government is deemed to be a "Commonwealth authority" by reason of its status as an incorporated body. As a result, a decision by the Norfolk Island Government on a resource matter can be referred to the Resource Assessment Commission. However, it was not intended that the Resource Assessment Commission be able to inquire into decisions of the Norfolk Island Government.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending 7 Acts administered, either wholly or partly, within the Transport and Communications portfolio. While none of the proposed amendments are highly significant, they are important for the functions of the Transport and Communications portfolio. Details of the major amendments follow.

Part 2 of this Bill amends the Australian National Railways Commission Act to ensure that the Commission has the power to enter into a number of financial management risk or hedging transactions. Many Government Business Enterprises routinely make use of such transactions, as do many private business organisations, to minimise their exposure to adverse interest rate variations.
The need for such an amendment was highlighted by a recent decision of the United Kingdom Court of Appeal which raised doubts about the power of similar government enterprises in the United Kingdom.
Part 3 of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Civil Aviation Act.
In the first place, the Act is amended in the same way as the Australian National Railways Commission Act mentioned above.

Secondly, the Bill gives effect to certain recommendations contained in the Second Report of the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force. The Task Force highlighted a number of serious offences currently within the regulations and recommended that they be elevated to the Act in order to highlight their significance to air safety. In particular, the task force noted that flying an aircraft without registration or a Certificate of Airworthiness attracted a maximum penalty of $5000. Such a breach constitutes a fundamental risk to air safety and the Task Force recommended its inclusion in the Act with a much more substantial penalty. The Task Force recommended that other more serious offences should be identified in the Act and maximum penalties be prescribed for each offence.

The Task Force also expressed concern about the Courts' powers in relation to a breach of the Act or the regulations. At present, Courts may only impose a fine or a term of imprisonment. Often this is not a sufficient deterrent. The Task Force recommended that the Court be empowered to suspend or cancel any licence, authority or certificate issued to the person under the regulations as a punitive alternative to the usual sanctions in serious cases. The Bill introduces a procedure whereby persons convicted of offences against the Act or the regulations may be excluded from any previously authorised activity.

Finally, the Bill makes a number of minor amendments which clarify the Authority's liability to pay income tax and its powers in relation to statutory liens, and remove any legal doubt about the Authority's power to delegate certain air safety functions under the regulations to industry bodies.

The principal purpose of this amendment is to enable the Commonwealth to transfer undeveloped sites which have been acquired for airport development to the Federal Airports Corporation and to empower the corporation to construct airports at those sites. This is achieved by introducing into the Act the concept of a "federal airport development site" which may be declared prior to its establishment as a federal airport.

This is a technical amendment which in no way derogates from the Commonwealth's primary responsibility for the national planning of airports, including the investigation of and the need for additional Federal airports and their location.
The Bill also clarifies an earlier amendment that the Authority is liable to pay income tax.

The Bill proposes a number of amendments to this Act. The most significant amendment places fishing fleet support vessels outside the ambit of the Act when not on an overseas voyage. Fishing fleet support vessels are presently trading vessels for the purposes of the Navigation Act, although the fishing vessels they serve are not. The Bill will correct this anomaly.

An agreement was recently reached that in certain parts of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Area, certain types of ships must carry a pilot. The Bill makes provision for the issue of appropriate pilot qualifications for this purpose.

Finally, there are a number of other amendments of the Navigation Act of a general "housekeeping" nature. In particular, the limits of the Australian jurisdiction on marine casualty inquiries are clarified; certain offence provisions are brought up to date; and some drafting errors are corrected.

The purpose of the amendments to this Act is to extend the privileges and protections afforded to radio broadcasts of Parliamentary proceedings to, firstly, television broadcasts of proceedings and, secondly, to radio and television broadcasting of proceedings of Parliamentary Committees.

The amendments give effect to recommendations contained in the recent report of the Select Committee of the House of Representatives on Televising, `The Eyes Have It'. The Select Committee recommended that the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to provide for televising the proceedings of the Senate, the House of Representatives and their Committees.

The amendments will also have the effect of exempting television broadcasters of proceedings of the House of Representatives and the Senate, and radio and television broadcasters of the proceedings of Parliamentary Committees, from the operation of section 117 of the Broadcasting Act 1942, which requires broadcasters to announce particulars of who authorised the broadcasting of political matter. This extends the existing exemption which applies to radio broadcasts of proceedings.

Part X of the Trade Practices Act 1974 provides shipping conferences with some limited exemptions from the competition provisions of Part IV of the Act. Among the various obligations imposed on conferences in exchange for these exemptions is the requirement to publicly register their anti-competitive agreements. Fees are charged to recover the administrative costs associated with processing such registration applications.

It has recently come to the Government's attention that the agreement registration provisions of Part X extend to the freight rates charged by the conferences. This means that every time conference members change even one of their many hundreds of freight rates they would have to register a varying conference agreement. The imposition of such an administrative and financial burden serves no useful purpose as conference freight rate schedules are already publicly available.
This Bill will remove the need for conference members to register their freight rates and their subsequent variation.

As I have already mentioned, fees are charged for administrative services provided under Part X. These fees are set by regulation. The fees currently charged are at or near the maximum levels stipulated in Section 10.90 of the Act. This Bill will increase those maximum levels to enable appropriate regulations to be made to fully recover the costs incurred in providing the Part X services.

In addition, the new maximum fee levels provide scope for future cost increases to be recovered which will make it unnecessary to amend Section 10.90 again for some years to come. The Bill also provides for a fee to be charged for the registration of a change to the particulars of an ocean carrier agent.

Finally the Bill repeals Sections 150-153 of the Act which relate to transitional provisions following the replacement of earlier legislation by the previous Part X of the Trade Practices Act 1974. With the repeal of the previous Part X in 1990, Sections 150-153 became redundant.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
CIVIL AVIATION (CARRIERS' LIABILITY)
AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill amends the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959. The main purpose of the amendments are: to enable ratification of Additional Protocol Number 3 (Montreal Protocol No 3) and Montreal Protocol Number 4; to ensure that the Montreal Protocol No 3 passenger limit applies immediately to Australian international air carriers engaged in carriage to which the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol apply; and, to convert the Poincare gold franc limits of the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol to Australian dollars through the medium of the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Right (SDR).

The major reasons for amending the Act are two-fold. Firstly, it is considered that the carriers' liability limits currently applying to the international carriage of passengers by air are insufficient. These are currently around $14,000 or $28,000 depending on whether carriage is covered by the Warsaw Convention or the Hague Protocol. The proposal to ratify Montreal Protocol Number 3 and immediately apply its 100,000 SDR passenger limit to Australia's international airlines will go some way to redress this situation. 100,000 SHEARS, when converted to Australian dollars, is consistent with the domestic carriers' liability limit of $180,000.

Australia has international obligations under the Warsaw Convention and is only able to increase passenger liability limits, without dissociating itself from the international aviation community (i.e. by denouncing the Warsaw Convention), by ratifying Montreal Protocol No. 3.

Secondly, since the abandonment of the internationally set price of gold in 1973 and the introduction of a fluctuating market price, there has been no agreed means of determining the Australian dollar equivalent of the Poincare gold franc and the courts have often called on the Government to resolve the problem. The conversion of the gold franc limits to SDR equivalents resolves this problem.

Given that the amount of passenger compensation encompassed by the 100,000 SDR limit may be considered insufficient, the Government is examining other options to provide equitable compensation to international airline passengers which will not affect the carriers' liability limits fixed by international instrument. This includes examination of the feasibility of a supplemental compensation scheme, perhaps similar to one under consideration in the United States.
Montreal Protocol Number 4 is specifically cargo oriented and introduces more modern cargo handling terminology and procedures, including the use of electronic data interchange (EDI).

While the passenger limit of Montreal Protocol Number 3 will be applicable immediately to Australian international carriers, the Protocols will only become generally applicable to airlines engaged in carriage to which they apply when they enter into force internationally.

It is my understanding that should the United States Senate accept the supplemental compensation scheme (called the S-Plan) referred to earlier, then it will support United States ratification of Montreal Protocols Numbers 3 and 4 by the President. It is also my understanding that this ratification may be accompanied by a denunciation of the Warsaw Convention. Unless Australia also ratifies the Montreal Protocols, this action could expose Australian carriers, particularly Qantas, to unlimited liability in the United States.

Since it is our firm belief that US ratification of the two Protocols will lead to their early entry into force, they will in the not too distant future apply to carriage between Australia and the majority of countries. I understand that the US Senate may be voting on the Protocols in the near future.
I turn now to a brief description of the Bill.

Since the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol will no doubt continue to apply to certain international carriage even after entry into force of the two Protocols, the Bill fixes their Poincare gold franc liability limits in SHEARS. The Reserve Bank provides a SDR/Australian dollar conversion rate on a daily basis so enabling the courts to easily convert the limits at the time of judgment.
The gold franc limits will have the following SDR equivalents:

PARA.TAB: Warsaw Convention
Passenger death/injury: 125,000 francs = 8300 SDR
Registered baggage/cargo: 250 francs/kg = 17 SDR/kg
Personal cabin baggage: 5000 francs = 330 SDR
Hague Protocol
Passenger death/injury: 250,000 francs = 16,600 SDR

SPEECH.PARA: The registered baggage and cargo and personal cabin baggage limits were not changed by the Hague Protocol.
The limits as fixed by the Bill in SHEARS are consistent with the move to ratify Montreal Protocols Numbers 3 and 4 with their SDR limits.

The SDR equivalents of the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol liability limits will apply to actions involving international carriers which occur on or after the date the Bill receives Royal Assent. Actions pre-dating this will still be covered by the current Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol gold franc limits, irrespective of the date of judgment.

Next the Bill specifies that for Australian carriers engaged in carriage to which the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol apply, the Montreal Protocol Number 3 passenger liability limit of 100,000 SDR will apply. This is consistent with Article 22 of the Warsaw Convention which permits the voluntary increase of liability limits.

Finally the Bill inserts two new Parts IIIB and IIIC into the Act covering carriage to which Montreal Protocol Number 3 and Montreal Protocol Number 4 respectively apply. These Parts will become law on dates no earlier than the entry into force of the Protocols.
For ease of reading, consolidations of the convention as amended by successive protocols have been prepared and included as schedules.
The amendments will have no effect on Government revenue or expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
