Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the Bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice given yesterday, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the matter referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on 19 June 1991 be amended to read as follows:
The management systems and program evaluation procedures of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: There are very good and cogent reasons for moving this motion. The proposition seeks to collapse the broad and vague terms of the original proposal that was placed before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration with very clear and specific terms of reference which are capable of precise assessment by the Committee for report and subsequent recommendations.

PARA.TAB: The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration works well. It works in a cooperative manner. That is largely because of the relationship which exists between the Chairman, Senator Coates, and the Deputy Chairman, Senator Watson. In order for the Committee to work well in this area, to undertake the responsibility which the Senate has conferred upon it, the change in the terms of reference is very necessary. The Committee will work much better in this area if the terms of reference are precise because it will enable a much greater focus upon matters of concern relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I will say a little about that and some of the progress made in a number of those areas in a very short while. Given that the focus becomes precise, in my view, the evaluation becomes very precise, as will the specific recommendations which will emerge from the Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

I will take a moment or two of the chamber's time in this brief series of observations and give some background to the Senate inquiry. On 19 June this year the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration the following terms of reference—it is in four parts:

SPEECH.PARA: The management and operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and whether that Department is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests, with particular regard to the following:
(a)management systems and program evaluation procedures;
(b)security procedures and custody of classified material;
(c)overseas conditions of service and their implications for efficiency and effectiveness; and
(d)morale, staff performance and accountability.

Since then, the Department appeared before Senate Estimates Committee B on 4 September 1991. The Department's appropriations were also considered by the Committee of the Whole in this chamber on 15 and 16 October this year.

PARA.TAB: It is also pertinent to add that since then we have seen a recommendation from United States Congressman Stephen Solarz for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to be nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. We have seen the success of our foreign policy initiative on Cambodia. These things are relevant when we are looking at a department which has a policy making function rather than being oriented, as so many other Commonwealth departments are, to a program of budgeting for a series of obligations.

To return to the Estimates committee process, at the Senate Estimates Committee B hearing on 4 September, Senator Evans raised with Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition, the desirability of reconsidering the question of a full-scale inquiry into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. To his credit, Senator Hill replied—and this is recorded in Hansard—that he would consider this and acknowledged that the Department had made considerable progress in several of the areas to be considered by the inquiry.

That positive initiative from the Minister was met initially with a positive response from the Leader of the Opposition. As I have said on a number of occasions in my brief period in the Senate, it is my firm view on matters of foreign policy, defence policy and trade policy that, wherever it is humanly possible within the chamber and among the parties, it is very desirable to reach a consensus view after the arguments have been dealt with in a thorough and responsible manner.

Senator Evans followed up that conversation in September with the Leader of the Opposition by writing to Senator Hill on 17 October suggesting that, if the terms of reference for the inquiry could not be withdrawn altogether, a reasonable compromise proposition could be offered to the Senate—that is, simply to truncate the terms of reference to cover the management systems and program evaluation procedures of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Again, I think that was a most reasonable initiative for the Minister to take. It would certainly serve the purposes of the Committee and the Senate and achieve a better series of results. That process has now led to the motion that I have moved this morning.

Lest there be any doubt, the view of the Government has always been that an inquiry into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is unnecessary. Senator Evans noted at the time the Senate was debating the inquiry's original terms of reference on 19 June that there was ample opportunity under the existing Estimates committee procedures to explore the kinds of issues covered in the inquiry's current terms of reference.

However, if an inquiry is to proceed, as is certain—whether under the terms of the original proposition or in line with the amendment which I have suggested this morning—the Government believes the terms of reference ought to reflect the very significant progress that has been made by the Department in addressing the various allegations of maladministration and corruption and leaks to the media which were the background against which Senator Hill first moved to establish the inquiry. Again, it is fair to note that the Leader of the Opposition has acknowledged the progress that has been made.

At the conclusion of an eight-hour session on 4 September 1991 at which Senate Estimates Committee B examined the operations of DFAT, Senator Hill acknowledged, firstly, that there had been `considerable improvements' in the area of leaks; secondly, that the number of new allegations about maladministration and corruption had been `significantly reduced'; and, finally, that the criticisms of lax acquittal procedures within the Department had been `largely overcome'. From memory, on reading the Hansard, Senator Evans made reference to Senator Hill's own experience. I add to that that on my return from Nepal I found the Department was very thorough, although very fair, in regard to acquittal procedures.

There has also been progress on the issue of conditions of overseas service, which is a part of the inquiry's current terms of reference. I concede that there are several outstanding issues remaining in this area but I think it is significant to note that it is no longer the subject of industrial action as it was in November of last year. Indeed, it may be of interest to the Committee to note that, with the exception of the 24-hour stoppage called by the Public Sector Union last June to protest against the offer by the Department of Industrial Relations on overseas living allowance, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not lost a single hour in industrial action over the last several years. I think that is a useful point to make and to note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since when?

—Over the last several years, with that exception I have made. With regard to the various allegations of maladministration and corruption—most of them made by a single officer of the Department who resigned earlier this year after he faced dismissal on eight counts of proven misconduct—an investigation by the Australian National Audit Office concluded that DFAT's processes for handling its investigations into the allegations had been effective. In fact, in all, 77 cases of fraud or misconduct were raised by the individual referred to above and by the anonymous and self-styled `Officers Revolutionary Council' within the Department. I, myself, find that to be an extraordinary title in an extraordinary circumstance. I am sure that a number of honourable senators around this chamber would share that view.

PARA.TAB: Of the 77 cases raised in this circumstance, 76 have been closed and only one is still with the Australian Federal Police. In no case was either improper or illegal conduct established; in no case was impropriety established. The one remaining outstanding case relates to allegations that moneys were stolen from the Department's social club. It does not impinge upon the Department's management or administration because the management of the Department does not control the social club, as I am sure people would readily appreciate.

Moreover, the Department's fraud detection efforts have not simply stopped with the investigation of these 77 cases. DFAT moved on to put in place strengthened procedures for investigating fraud, hard upon the claims that had been made last year and earlier this year. It has instituted a fraud prevention program aimed both at detecting fraud and inculcating high ethical standards among all of its officers. From the evidence overall—whether statistical or anecdotal—these procedures appear to be working.

DFAT's fraud prevention and discipline section currently has 28 cases under investigation and nine discipline cases in train. I think that is a measure of the effectiveness of the action taken. The fraud prevention program is further reinforced by a revamped audit system which, in the financial year 1990-91, included audits of 27 overseas posts and eight Canberra-based programs. A very broad and effective net has been established.

The existing terms of reference which I find unsatisfactory—and which I believe the Government finds unsatisfactory—refer to staff morale. This is a very complex issue. It is also very difficult, if not impossible, to measure. However, I think it is fair to say that any analysis of DFAT's very strong corporate identity and of objective indicators, such as the number of grievances, absenteeism, the number of disciplinary cases and rates of resignation and transfer, all suggest that DFAT does not have a serious morale problem.

For instance, sick leave rates are around half the Australian industry average. Resignations account for only 0.9 per cent of all Public Service resignations, despite DFAT accounting for 2 per cent of Federal Public Service numbers—all of this notwithstanding the stress, frustrations and disruptions which are an inevitable part of the nomadic lifestyle in a foreign service.

In short, whatever justification there may have been in June this year for conducting an inquiry into DFAT, the situation today is quite different. Moreover, the existing and exhaustive Senate Estimates process, I think it is conceded throughout the chamber, will continue to provide ample opportunities to follow up any questions that honourable senators may have about the Department's performance. I think it is fair to say that satisfaction was registered about this during the most recent Estimates committee round of proceedings.

We all support the principle of accountability—the Parliament does and the Government certainly does—but we should also acknowledge that inquiries of this kind are extremely time consuming for all those involved and are extremely costly. They also serve to divert resources. They are costly in terms of time not only for the Department but also for the Committee and the relevant Ministers. Of course, overall, there is a cost involved which cannot be ignored or denied. If the inquiry is to proceed, it should therefore focus on those areas where, in my view and in the view of the Government, it could be most useful.

In this case the Government considers that if the terms of reference are not to be withdrawn altogether—which obviously is not possible—they should be restricted to the management systems and program evaluation procedures of DFAT, where I am absolutely certain the Committee will come down with a series of very clear and reasonable recommendations, given the nature of the personnel and the nature of the other inquiries which we have conducted. I refer to the ongoing inquiry into the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

An inquiry along these lines will be a useful exercise in terms of public administration generally. It is not confining itself to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in its ramifications and applicability, not least because of the difficulty in devising appropriate evaluation procedures for a policy rather than a program focused department—a point I made at the outset. It would also enable the Committee to assess what we consider to be the significant improvements which DFAT has made to its management systems over the last few years and which are conceded at all levels in the Parliament and, I believe, beyond. It is for all those reasons that I moved the motion at the beginning of my address in the terms I outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the motion. We do so because the terms of reference have been advertised. They were advertised on 26 August, at least in the Australian Financial Review. I do not know where else they were advertised. Submissions have been prepared by those with an interest in the matter and they are to be put before the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration under these terms of reference. Senator Loosley now comes in here and asks that we change the terms of reference, in some way further limiting them, contrary to the work that has been done by those who have prepared submissions. I suggest that that would create a most undesirable precedent.

PARA.TAB: What I find more incredible is that Senator Loosley does this as an individual. It is not a case where the Committee has come back to the Senate querying the terms of reference or calling for a change in them. It is fair to say that he basically does it on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who is opposed to the inquiry and has been all along. That is not surprising; it is highly unusual for Ministers not to be opposed to inquiries into their departments. We have a situation where the inquiry is under way, has been advertised and made public and submissions prepared, and now one senator comes in and says that the terms of reference should be altered. As I said, that creates an undesirable precedent.

Senator Loosely has put his case in measured terms—and I appreciate that—although it is different from that which we would have received from the Minister this morning. Basically, Senator Loosely has argued that the terms of reference should now be varied because the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is performing better. Since the major public concerns were raised last year and since the terms of reference were first put down in my original notice of motion, which was far wider than that which was eventually agreed upon by the Senate, there has been considerable improvement in the performance of the Department. Therefore, the terms of reference should now be made.

I concede that in some areas, at least from my analysis—and of course I am not privy to internal or confidential information—there has been some improvement, particularly in the area of acquittals. We put before the Estimates Committee that very large sums of money had not been acquitted, in breach of the regulations. When we were last before the Estimates, those figures had considerably improved.

What I said to the Minister was that I think the process of acquittal should be looked at. The process is different in Foreign Affairs from, say, the Department of Administrative Services, which has a procedure much less cumbersome. It is embarrassing that senior Foreign Affairs officers have to go around collecting their bus tickets and so forth. There must be a better way. What I told the Minister is that the Committee can consider that.

I conceded at the time of the Estimates that there were now fewer leaks from the Department. If Senator Loosley looks at what I said he will see that I added the caveat that that was so, at least for the time being. Senator Loosley will remember that there was a series of leaks that were highly embarrassing to Australia coming from this Department.

One that I can remember related to a discussion between my own leader, Dr Hewson, and General Murdani in Indonesia in which the General expressed certain views on what was happening in Papua New Guinea and what he expected to be Australia's responsibility in that regard. It was highly embarrassing. The next thing is that we read about it in the press. A cable that had come from Jakarta to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade had been leaked. The Department and the Minister had not even shown Dr Hewson the courtesy of sending him a copy of the cable, yet we read about it in the press, to Australia's embarrassment.

There are others that I can remember without referring to my records. Singapore's allegations from DFAT cables on Singapore's arms trade with Burma is another example. It may be that that should be on the public record, but to get it on the public record in that way is highly embarrassing and creates difficulties for us in our relationship with Singapore. That country must really wonder how we do business in this Department.

I said to the Minister, as I conceded a moment ago, that there seemed to have been an improvement. Since the Estimates, unfortunately, I can tell Senator Loosley that the practice has deteriorated again. There has been a series of leaks from the Department. Perhaps the greatest irony in this debate is that one of them was a leak of the Department's view of this inquiry and what the Department intended to include in its submission to this inquiry. We read that in the newspapers, including Senator Evans's pencilled notes in the margin as to what he thinks of the inquiry, which he had told us previously in any event.That might be a matter of little consequence except that it was interesting that Mr Woolcott, the Secretary to the Department, did express the positive advantages that could come to the Department from the inquiry in which the Department will have an opportunity to put its case to the Committee. Apparently Senator Loosley in some way wants to remove that opportunity from the Department today.

Senator Coulter will be interested in the next leak and, in some ways, I think he would argue that this should be on the public record, but I would say that this is not the right way to do it. Of greater consequence have been leaks which involve the Department's criticism of the way in which another Department, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, was dealing with the MFP in Adelaide. In this case we find a leak from a cable from Tokyo that DFAT was accusing the other Department of dealing with an important national project in a way similar to the Keystone Cops.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mickey Mouse.
—Senator Coulter has very strong views on the MFP project as a whole. It is embarrassing in our relationships with Japan to find that sort of thing being published in the press.

PARA.TAB: Another leak came from the Department telling us that it had been told confidentially that the UNCTAD mission would not be commenced until next year. The next thing is that we read about that in the Australian press, the Australian Financial Review, on 31 October, to the embarrassment, no doubt, of Australia, as we take this information from the UN officers on a confidential basis.

On 31 October we further read that Malaysia had ruled out any direct Australian role in settling the Spratly Island dispute, as a result of a confidential cable from the Australian High Commission in Kuala Lumpur. So something is wrong within the Department. Certainly for a while there seemed to be some improvement, but something is wrong. Why should the Committee not examine what in fact is wrong? How are these matters, of considerable confidence and importance to Australia, suddenly appearing in the press out of a department which says that it has tightened its security as much as possible?

So the matter of leaks, which is included in the terms of reference, should be looked at by the Committee. The acquittal procedures should be looked at by the Committee. The important issues that have been raised with me by officers of the Department in relation to overseas allowances should be looked at by the Committee. The amended terms of reference as sought would presumably rule them out. I think the Committee should look at the unique procedures that the Department has for recruitment and promotion. The Parliament has a responsibility to look at these issues, particularly when departmental officers are complaining to members of parliament about the operations of the Department. We have a responsibility, therefore, to pursue these concerns.

As Senator Loosley pursued this matter in a measured way I will seek to reciprocate. My only slight divergence from that relates to his concern about the resources that have to be devoted by the Department to this inquiry. I would simply refer the honourable senator to the acknowledgments that appear at the front of the book, Australia's Foreign Relations, which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has just had published, in which he refers to a whole series of Foreign Affairs officers who have helped him, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are indebted to a great many people—particularly from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade—for contributing ideas, information and secretarial and other support.

PARA.TAB: In the first place there were the legions of officers from the department and AIDAB, not least speech writers Peter Varghese and David Ritchie . . . Then there were the individuals—again numbered in legions, and reaching out beyond the foreign service to other Departments . . . A further substantial contribution was made by the dozens of departmental officers, coordinated by Bill Farmer, who, in their areas of respective expertise, check-read each chapter as completed for factual errors, possible security sensitivities and egregious errors of judgment—

SPEECH.PARA: coming from the Minister, that is interesting—
although we of course accept responsibility for such problems as remain.

He goes on to talk about his debt to the people in the Department for their contributions in producing his book. This is a personal book, his personal work, which he had all these departmental officers working on, to his personal advantage. Yet Senator Loosley comes in today and says that one of his arguments against this reference is that the Department will be put to extra work. I have just been reminded of another leak, the one in the Financial Review of 7 November regarding the joint facilities. However, going back to my previous point, the Department has had plenty of time to work on Senator Evans's private work, his book. The Department has the time to do this job, which will enable the Parliament to conduct a proper inquiry into the affairs of the Department, and this is meeting the Parliament's responsibility to the Australian people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Loosley, for reasons which roughly align with those that have just been outlined by Senator Hill relating to the concern over the precedential nature of changing the terms of reference after those terms of reference have been laid down and have been well and truly advertised. People have prepared submissions, and we understand that at least one submission has already been received. To change the terms of reference at this stage would be to set an extremely dangerous precedent.

PARA.TAB: In his speech Senator Loosley canvassed some of the reasons why the terms of reference should be changed. But, having listened to the honourable senator, again it seems to me that that in itself is an extremely dangerous precedent to follow—that a Minister or a Minister's spokesperson would be able to explain away the reasons for an inquiry which had been agreed to quite some months before in this chamber, without the matter being properly and independently investigated as it would be by a committee. So, to some extent, whilst we would accept some of the factual information which Senator Loosley put before the chamber in relation to some of those terms of reference, in my view the processes by which he seeks to have the terms of reference changed again amount to the creation of a potentially quite dangerous precedent.

The proposed new reference differs from the present reference in the following ways. First, it omits consideration of whether the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests, thus preventing policy issues being considered. Secondly, it omits explicit consideration of security procedures, overseas conditions of service and staff morale and performance. What is retained is an examination of the Department's management systems and program evaluation procedures. The omission of the first item would seem appropriate, given that consideration of policy issues is beyond the brief of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, to which the reference was ultimately given. The Australian Democrats have many foreign policy differences with the Government—and not just in the foreign policy area, a matter which was alluded to by Senator Hill—but this is not the forum in which to examine them.

The omission of the second group of items is justified by several considerations. A spate of leaks which prompted the inclusion of security procedures and classified material has ended, as Senator Hill himself acknowledged in the hearing of Estimates Committee B on 4 September. As Senator Hill has just explained, while there may be fewer of those leaks, they have by no means completely dried up. Secondly, there is little concrete evidence to support the view that problems with overseas conditions of service are serious enough to warrant parliamentary scrutiny. Thirdly, the Democrats' contact with departmental staff suggest a high quality performance with no obvious morale problems, a matter that Senator Loosley alluded to, and we accept that. Finally, there remains some scope for those three issues to be considered under the proposed new terms of reference, in so far as they relate to or arise from departmental management systems and program evaluation procedures.

What we are hinting at there is that, even with the terms of reference being maintained, it is well within the ambit of the Committee itself to limit the width with which it considers particular terms of reference, the extent to which it accepts or does not accept particular submissions, and the extent to which it seeks to call witnesses from those who make submissions before it, and accept further evidence from them. So, in our view, the better way to proceed would be for the terms of reference to remain essentially the same, but for the Committee itself quite clearly to take into account those matters which Senator Loosley and Senator Hill have raised. During the September Estimates hearing, Senator Hill indicated a willingness to consider narrowing the reference, and he has alluded to that this morning. As we have heard, he has now reversed that view or at least given a higher priority to the question of creating a precedent. Our inquiry suggests that there has been no precedent in the past—no precedent at all—for a substantive change to a committee reference. We believe it is quite appropriate for the Committee largely to confine itself to the terms of the proposed amended reference, but we believe that, as an issue of public trust and in light of the possibility of creating a very significant precedent, the amendment should not be passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Loosely for his long and detailed explanation. As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I will endeavour to respond in the same measured and reasoned way as Senator Loosely put his submission to the Senate. From our point of view, the Committee works very harmoniously and does not seek to take overt political positions. Its report to the Parliament will certainly be in measured terms and will seek to overcome the perceived problems in the recommendations that will be put forward.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that the Government has introduced a notice of motion to amend the terms of reference applying to an inquiry that has already been agreed upon and for which a submission or two has already been received and for which others are in the course of preparation. I agree with my Leader that this is an unusual request. It creates a precedent that the Senate should be cautious of endorsing. Although it is unusual, it is understandable, given the attitude of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, all along the line and perhaps more latterly, towards the terms of reference of this inquiry. To withdraw or significantly change the terms of reference at this stage would raise questions of what is to be hidden and who has got at the Committee. It is basically an attack on the Senate committee system, which I believe we should be wary about accepting.

I remind the Senate that the terms of reference were widely advertised as early as 26 August and that we are now into November. We have to be careful that it does not lead to a degree of bewilderment out in the wider world as to why the Senate has suddenly changed these sorts of issues, who has got to the Committee and what is to be hidden. It is an unusual request in that, although the issues have been canvassed from person to person within the Committee, I do not believe—and I stand to be corrected—that this has been discussed formally and a resolution taken by the Committee.

In hindsight, it may be that, had this approach been taken, some of the objectives Senator Loosely was looking at may have been achieved in another way. At the Committee's discretion, he may be able to achieve some of the focus, or lack of focus, that he is seeking as a result of this amendment. It is up to the force of argument that particular members wish to put. We are winners and losers in this game. I hope that at all times we look at the issues objectively and that, on the basis of evidence and reason, we take our positions accordingly.

If we were to, as Senator Loosley said, `collapse the terms of reference' in order to focus attention, we would lose sight of what could happen. If we look at it a little more closely, this also implies that there would be an omission in the focus of the inquiry from certain areas which are considered to be fairly critical for the basis on which this inquiry was embarked upon in the first place.

The purpose of my rising on this occasion is to assure the Senate that, so far as the coalition Opposition is concerned, we will not waste our time in endlessly following frivolous allegations. It is always a concern when a Senate committee embarks upon a particular inquiry that sometimes whistle blowers and others who pretend to be whistle blowers wish to take unreasonable attitudes and positions and use the occasion to malign officials. We always regard such submissions with a degree of suspicion; naturally, we look at them.

The coalition will obviously wish to test the extent of the improvements that have been embarked upon, particularly those administrative arrangements that are alleged to have been tightened. Unfortunately, since the inquiry started, evidence has filtered through, at a level that is disturbing, which indicates that some of those administrative arrangements have not worked and that there are still problems in certain areas. In other words, the problems Senator Hill indicated earlier persist.

Finally, let me say that the Committee does not act frivolously, nor does it take overt political positions. Therefore, the extent of the focus, the width of the examination of each item of the terms of reference, remains very much with the Committee. I believe it should be that way and that goodwill and cooperation will ensure a good report.
Question resolved in the negative.
Consideration resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further questions on the Department of Industrial Relations, the Committee will move to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, subprogram 1.1, livestock and pastoral control. There are three reservations. Are there any questions?

—I asked a question in the Estimates Committee regarding the number of meat inspectors in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service who were on workers compensation. So far as I remember, I was told that the number of inspectors who were on reasonably long term or medium term workers compensation was 90. Bearing in mind the fact that meat inspectors do not really do much lifting or use instruments that they can injure themselves with, I was wondering why there was such a high trend of injury among them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Panizza is right to say that there is not a lot of heavy lifting involved in the duties performed by meat inspectors. But workers compensation is not related simply to back or other injuries arising from that cause. He is right to say that there are about 90 meat inspectors on workers compensation and, of those, 46 are short term cases, that is, on less than three weeks' workers compensation. The remainder—44—are longer term cases.

PARA.TAB: Abattoirs are places in which when carcasses are opened for inspection there is potential for disease. Unfortunately, a number of the longer term cases comprise people who are suffering from some disease problem. As for the causes of the longer term compensation cases, there are 16 with back injuries, 10 are suffering from zoonotic diseases, there are several anxiety cases and overuse syndrome cases, and a sprinkling of other things such as hernias, lacerations and things of that nature, including leg injuries. There is a representation that reflects the type of work, the exposure to disease and problems in meat inspection.

One always wants to keep these figures down. It is lost time for the Department, there is personal trauma and damage for the individual, and often costly medical expense is occasioned. I know that the Department is keen to keep those figures down and is working with the Commonwealth rehabilitation and compensation body, Comcare. Overall, time spent and number of people involved in workers compensation have declined in the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply. I would like to follow up the aspect of disease in this sphere. I thought that Australia had pretty well eliminated the risk, bearing in mind the fact that the health of Australian herds is pretty good. In other words, I would have thought that meat inspectors are at minimal risk from contracting diseases from animals they inspect. Could the Minister give more information as to the sorts of diseases inspectors could be contracting, and what measures could be taken to prevent inspectors getting diseases from carcasses. I presume that meat inspectors wear gloves, masks if necessary, and take preventive measures such as washing and cleaning. Therefore, it surprises me that so many inspectors are beset by these diseases.

PARA.TAB: I move to the other aspect of back problems, which I believe are always fairly hard to discern, having mentioned this topic to various medicos. I do not understand why there should be any such problems in view of the fact that no lifting is involved, as the Minister has already agreed.

Could the Minister also comment on the matter of stress? I find it a little hard to correlate stress with workers compensation. I can correlate stress as related to long term sickness benefits for workers who cannot attend the workplace because of sickness rather than injury. I understand that workers compensation covers accidents and similar sorts of things that happen in the workplace, and diseases that could be picked up at work. But I thought that stress per se was a different problem removed from workers compensation and should be covered by sickness benefits, which should be borne by the social security operation or by the community as a whole rather than channelled straight down into the costs of AQIS, which is 100 per cent funded by the exporters who use the services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza raises an interesting point. I appreciate the motivation for his concern as to the full recovery of costs. It is a concern to the Commonwealth too that we provide a healthy and safe workplace for Commonwealth employees. Therefore, Senator Panizza is right to say that protective clothing, hygienic preparation and cleanliness are high on our agenda, and by and large on the agenda of individual meat inspectors. No-one courts an exotic disease that might arise in an abattoir; they are often debilitating for a long time.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that despite the best protective measures and the most safety conscious and disease free environment that can be created, unfortunately people still contract diseases. Of the zoonotic diseases which, for longer term workers compensation recipients, amount to almost a quarter of the total number, 10 out of 44, fall into three major categories. These are brucellosis from cattle, Q-fever from goats and sheep, and leptospirosis from pigs. All I can report to Senator Panizza is that that is the incidence of the contracting of those diseases by people exposed to them for inspection purposes in the workplace.

A number of back injuries result from accidents in the workplace. If I have the question right, Senator Panizza is asking whether the injuries are real and genuine and whether stress should be included at all. Let me say this on the first point, as to whether these are genuine cases: in order to be entitled to workers compensation benefits, one must receive a certificate from a certified medical practitioner saying that a problem or disease exists. The disease must be traced to an event or an exposure which, for all intents and purposes, is the cause of it. If it is believed by Comcare, which acts on behalf of this division of the Department on workers compensation matters, that there is reason to suspect that the diagnosis by the medical practitioner concerned is not accurate, second and third medical opinions can be, and are, obtained to be certain that the problem exists.

All I can say is that we lay people are, in matters medical, in the hands of doctors in determining what is in fact the case. Not being competent to argue with members of the medical profession, I must say that we are bound to accept their opinions, and I do. Often these things are so manifestly obvious when the individual is spoken to that dispute does not arise. However, there is the protection that I referred to if it does.

Stress is a recognised medical condition that can arise in the workplace. It certainly can arise in the normal community. There is now a whole body of medical science available which considers the issue of stress. There are many causes of this condition. Often stress is related to the sense of responsibility and control which individuals have over their working life—whether they are, in fact, regulated by the rate of the slaughter chain and have no control over their daily existence and how that impacts on their psyche. Again, these are matters that I am not competent to discuss in medical detail as I am not a medical practitioner. However, stress is universally recognised in the private sector and the public sector and under Acts of Parliament introduced by both Liberal and Labor governments and, therefore, is an accepted element of workplace life. It is therefore a recognised category. Unfortunately, there is an element of stress in the working conditions under which our meat inspectors work and that is a compensable condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also do not question what the medial profession has to say. As the Minister correctly said, if Comcare, or the employer for that matter, is not satisfied, a second or third opinion can be obtained. My point is that all the costs have to be borne by the users of the meat inspection services. However, exporters should carry only the just costs associated with work injuries.

PARA.TAB: There is no argument that accidents occur in the workplace. Workers do suffer pain from back injuries. The Minister has said that there is stress in the workplace. I agree with that—there is even stress in this place. But how can we determine the degree of stress which results from the workplace, family life or some disappointment in life? I do not believe that anyone should have to bear the cost alone. If stress is caused by the pressures of family life or some other non-work related reason, the costs should be carried by the community as a whole, not necessarily by AQIS or by Comcare, which insures AQIS. That is the point I am trying to make.

I will not labour the point for much longer. However, I would like the Department to look at this matter and make sure that the costs against the meat inspection services for injuries or other illnesses relate only to workplace injuries. The cost of injuries which occur outside the workplace should be carried by the whole community. That is the basis of my argument.

There seem to me to be many meat inspectors within the division receiving a benefit through Comcare who could be on some other sort of benefit. If their illness is not work related, they should be receiving some other benefit that is paid by the community as a whole. I will leave the matter at that. Does the Minister have anything further to say about what I have raised?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some general observations. If one accepts—and all of the evidence is that one ought to—that stress is an element that can arise in a workplace and that it can have damaging effects on individual employees in different ways, the question of compensation arises. Senator Panizza suggested that there ought to be some way of measuring the degree of stress that arises in the workplace and in community life. With the greatest of respect to the honourable senator, I am not sure that there is. It depends on the circumstances of each individual case; it depends on a qualified medical practitioner making an assessment, finding a link and thus making a diagnosis. I am not sure that we can lay down criteria, other than that we ought not compensate for stress arising from non-work factors. That is certainly the qualification within our compensation system. As I say, we are in the hands of the diagnosticians in respect of causes. But, as I have said, it is true that in many workplaces there is considerable stress which gives rise to problems.

PARA.TAB: Since I have been invited to make some comments, let me conclude with this generality: the more articulate areas in the work force voice their concerns about stress more than the less articulate. Often blue collar workers are more heavily stressed than white collar workers but white collar workers tell us about it more often. Therefore, we get a disproportionate view about where the stress factors are in the working community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in a general sense two matters to do with presentation.
—Are we on a particular reservation?
—I am speaking generally.
—We finished the general section about 12 minutes ago but we can go back to it.

—The first question I raised at the Estimates Committee hearings has still not been answered satisfactorily; that is, the figures that are used to start and finish the financial affairs for the Department for the year are not the same in different publications. The full page answer that I received does not answer the question. I seek leave to incorporate the reply in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY INDUSTRIES
AND ENERGY

Senator Archer (Hansard page no F43) asked "So that we can start off from the right place, the appropriations for 1990-91 showed total outlays of $35.707m and the actual expenditure was $26.164m according to the program performance statements. According to the annual report, actual expenditure was $26.203m. So there is a bit of an adjustment there for a start. Which one is right?

The difference in the figures has occurred because of a change to the Department's program structure and, in conjunction, a change to how certain administrative functions within the Minerals and Fisheries Group are apportioned against sub-programs.

The program structure used in the Annual Report is that which has been in existence for a number of years whereas the PPS uses the new structure. The following table shows how sub-programs relevant to the Minerals and Fisheries Group are allocated within the two structures;

1.4Petroleum & Energy 1.4Petroleum
