SPEECH.PARA: Certain administrative functions are performed within the Group by organisational units which are not directly related to sub-programs. Major examples include personnel services, financial management, accommodation and property management, overseas travel arrangements and human resource management and training.

In order to present a complete picture of resources within the Group it is necessary to allocate a share of the administrative resources to each sub-program. The basis on which those resources are allocated to the sub-programs within the two program structures is slightly different and this has caused the difference in the actual expenditure figures. In both cases however, the total actual expenditure attributable to the Minerals and Fisheries Group has remained the same and therefore both figures are correct in the context in which they have been used.
The best reply that the Department could come up with in justifying the fact that the figures do not tally is contained in the last paragraph:

In both cases, however, the total actual expenditure attributable to the Minerals and Fisheries Group has remained the same and therefore both figures are correct in the context in which they are used.

We cannot have two sets of figures in two publications and say that they are both right: one is correct and one is not. I do not expect the Department to put this matter right this year. But next year I certainly expect that the figures in the annual report and the document that comes to us by way of explanatory memorandum should be the same. A few million dollars here and there may not be much to some people, but the figures must tally. I will leave that matter because, as I say, I do not expect to get any better explanation than the one that the Department has had a month to prepare.

PARA.TAB: The other matter is broader still: the presentation generally has not assisted the Estimates committees in their endeavours. In the 20 years or so since the Senate Estimates committees were established, they have been seen to perform an important role in subjecting Ministers and their departmental officers to detailed scrutiny and direct questioning by the Parliament. Before these committees were established, Estimates were debated in the Committee of the Whole for, on average, 42 hours. Today much more time is spent on the task of scrutiny. In the 1990-91 Budget sitting, Estimates committees met for 158 hours and the Committee of the Whole met for 40 hours—a total of about 200 hours.

On the face of it, this must seem to have been a step in the right direction. As one who has always been a strong supporter of the Estimates committee system since coming to the Senate, I nevertheless often ask myself whether the practice is coming as close to the theory as we may like it to. In other words, are the Estimates committees able to do the job they were set up to do? If not, why not? How can the situation be improved? I believe that the information and presentation should be better and the time taken to examine it could be reduced. Each year we seem to be provided with more and more voluminous information by departments for the Estimates committee hearings, and this in itself poses a problem: greater is not necessarily synonymous with better.

This year the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, for example, provided 293 pages in the form of a document now called—for some reason not explained to us—the program performance statement, and 591 pages of a draft annual report. While I realise that it is better to have ample information than not enough, the provision of this volume of material is ridiculous, especially when much of it becomes available only the day prior to the first hearing. How honourable senators are supposed to find the information they are interested in, let alone digest it and formulate questions, is a mystery to me. We have to ask more and more questions. Inevitably, that means more supplementary answers and more unsatisfactory responses.

As to the contents of the documents, when I attend a meeting of an Estimates committee my early concerns are to get access to the answers to a few fairly simple, basic questions. The answers to these may or may not prompt follow-up questions. The basic questions with respect to a particular program generally are: `Why, last year, was the allocation of funds underspent or overspent?'; `Why, this year, is the expenditure expected to be so much greater or less than last year?'; and, `Has the Department's efficiency and effectiveness improved or deteriorated, and how is it measured?'. Performance of stated goals is what it is all about.

Looking at the program performance statement for 1991-92 for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy—which I refer to not because it is the best or worst example but because it is a portfolio in which I have a particular interest—we find that for a particular subprogram an increase of over $24m, or 94.3 per cent, is shown in proposed outlays. This increase is considerable in anyone's language. The eight pages of text relating to the subprogram, no doubt carefully following the Finance guidelines, set out the subprogram objectives, who was responsible for the subprogram, what strategies were employed to meet the objectives, the performance indicators used to measure success, and the 1990-91 outcome, the outlook for 1991-92. In addition, there is even a section on compliance with the Government's social justice strategy. But nowhere is there a reference to, let alone an explanation for, the large variations in either outlays or revenue in the net program costs.

Is it too much to ask for a little less verbiage—much of which is available in strategic plans and annual reports—and more specifics? Could the resources summary table not be annotated in such a way as to provide brief but meaningful explanations for variations greater than, say, 15 per cent? I would think this would save everyone concerned a lot of time.

There are also some evergreen questions relating to expenditures on consultants and travel. I know that the annual reports list consultants engaged, their costs and the program they are related to, but it would save us a lot of trouble in sitting down and adding up all the figures if consultancy costs could be shown in the resources table. There is clearly no reason why this should not be done.

I and several of my colleagues also asked about travel expenditure and where we can quickly find out how much is spent under each subprogram. The answer was that this information is kept at a lower level in the financial system. Would it be too difficult to show such expenditure in the summary table to save the time involved in asking the same questions every year, to be taken on notice and provided later at additional cost?

When I raised this matter with departmental officers during the hearing, I was assured that the papers were prepared in accordance with the guidelines issued by the Department of Finance. It seems from this response that it is not a question of ensuring that committees have the sort of information they want and need, but rather that this is the way the rule makers in the bureaucracy want it and this is the way it has to be done. I do not believe this is acceptable. The purpose of the exercise is to ensure that all senators have ready access to the operations of the Department in the form of a clear, concise and unambiguous statement, whatever the Department of Finance says.

The result of this present approach is marathon sittings of the committees, at which much of the information has to be painfully dragged out of officials, sometimes because senators have been unable, or have had insufficient time, to identify the information they are seeking, and sometimes because the officials themselves are unable to answer questions from the papers before them. As a result, a large proportion of the questions are taken on notice, so generating significantly more work for the Department. Incidentally, I find it most extraordinary how often senior nominated officers have to take on notice routine questions on the policy, operation and/or detail of their areas of responsibility.

I hope the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), will pass on these points to the Department of Finance so that its guidelines for the preparation of program performance statements can be amended to produce documents that are more closely aligned to the basic purpose of the hearings.

In April this year the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration produced a report on Estimates committee documentation and procedures. Whilst making a number of recommendations on those specific aspects, the report also contained discussion on a number of other matters which I feel should be pursued. Possibly the most important matter was the comment in paragraph 5.39 of the report, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Depending on developments in 1991 in the areas discussed above, the Committee might undertake an inquiry into public service performance reporting later this year or in 1992.
It seems to me that this might be as good a place as any to start the job of bringing Estimates committee procedures closer to their full potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further questions on general matters, we move to subprogram 1.1—Livestock and Pastoral.

—I refer to the answers given to questions I asked at the Estimates Committee. The first question related to the cost of AQIS in 1991 on a State by State basis, the answer to which appears on page 178 of volume 1 of the answers. I asked an additional question on whether there was any cross-subsidisation between the States.

PARA.TAB: In the first answer I have been given a breakdown of the figures on expenditure and revenue received by AQIS on a State by State basis. In the second answer I have been given a breakdown of AQIS expenditure and revenue by region for 1990-91. The regions and the States happen to be the same—I guess this is building on Senator Archer's proposition—but the figures are very different. I cannot find any explanation as to why those figures are different. For example, the figure for the Australian Capital Territory, on a State by State breakdown, is $59,293,000; the figure for the Australian Capital Territory, by region, is $31m. I question why these figures are so substantially different. As I said, the regions and the States are one and the same thing, yet the figures are significantly different.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should acknowledge Senator Archer's contribution before I turn to what was said by Senator Crane. I understand precisely Senator Archer's problem. We on this side of the chamber often labour under the same difficulty. Senator Archer is saying that there is an immense volume of material, that one cannot always match the information one wants with the source of the answer, that it is a bit of a pain in the butt, one way or another, and that it takes a lot of our time.

PARA.TAB: There are obviously reasons for this and Senator Archer alluded to some of them in his remarks. He referred to the Department of Finance guidelines about how these things must be drawn up; the guidance given to departments by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; and the fact that often we are comparing performances as set out in the annual report with projections for the Estimates. Some of the programs may have changed somewhat in the interim and, therefore, it is not a comparison of like with like. I understand all of those points. Notwithstanding that, there must be a way in which we can get to the root of these things. I sympathise with Senator Archer's view, although I must say the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is a very big department and I do know that the departmental officers strive to be as concise and direct as they possibly can.

I understand that, as recorded at page F80 of Hansard, Senator Crane asked that details be provided to him of the total expenditure and revenue received by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service on a State by State basis in 1990-91. There are differences in terms of expenditure over revenue. I think the basis of Senator Crane's question is the reason this difference exists. It is my advice that there has been communication to Senator Crane from the Department which answers those questions.

Senator Crane asked what proportion of the 1989-90 and 1990-91 budget was sourced by industry funds. Perhaps Senator Crane can indicate whether I am in fact answering the question he wants me to answer, because I am not entirely sure of the precise issue that he wants me to address. Rather than taking up the time of the Committee by going into these details, perhaps Senator Crane could briefly repeat his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I look at these two sets of figures which were provided to me, it is not clear what they represent or whether they represent the same time period. My understanding was that during the past financial year we moved to a 100 per cent funding of AQIS. We have a collection of expenditure and revenue figures on a State by State basis and another collection of figures on a regional basis. Those two sets of figures relate to the same areas. But it is not clear to me how these two sets of figures are arrived at. The discrepancy is enormous. The Minister may wish to take this question on notice and come back with an answer. It is just not clear to me why there is a difference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that one document sets out the expenditure and revenue by region. The other document—which again was provided in answer to Senator Crane's questions—shows the 1989-90 AQIS budget of expenditure; that is to say, the items that were appropriated for. The other is actual expenditure. So the difference is that one relates to appropriations and the other to actual performance. If I were to anticipate Senator Crane's next question, he would ask why that is so and what caused that variation. I would have to take advice on that because that may well require a very complex answer.

—I thank the Minister. My follow-up question would be to ask why that is the case. However, I come back to the point that Senator Archer raised. Obviously there is an explanation for the difference but it is not clear from the answers. Had it been clear, I would not be standing here now pursuing this point. I made some comments last night when the Minister was in the chamber about the performances of some departments in terms of supplying answers to questions. I happened to give an accolade to the Department of Industrial Relations. I cannot give that accolade to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy because the answers it gave are not clear and many of them were slow in coming.

PARA.TAB: I would like this whole question of the differences in the figures and the reasons behind those differences to be followed up. I would like explanations provided as to why there are differences. If the answer is that one document shows estimations through the appropriations and the other shows actuals, I think the matter needs to be cleared up precisely. The differences are enormous; they run into many millions of dollars.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that appropriations versus actuals is the basis of the difference. If needed, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy can provide Senator Crane with a further explanation. I might enter a plea on behalf of the Department in this case. As Senator Crane rightly pointed out, I basked in his approval last night that my Department, the Department of Industrial Relations, had answered its questions on time. I have now been advised that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy actually beat my Department in providing answers. But answers to the questions that were posed were sent to the Canberra office. That may have happened during the period of recess and, as a result, Senator Crane did not receive the answers in his Perth office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis of my question is the reservation by Senator Crane to subprogram 1.1. The Minister might remember that when the cattle transaction levy was first introduced I voiced my concerns that it was a change from a slaughter levy. In an answer to Senator Crane, the Department said:

SPEECH.PARA: The rates of levy for the Cattle Transaction Levy and Beef Production Levy were struck with the objective that producers and processors would equally share the cost of funding marketing and the industry component of R & D. . .

I further expressed my concerns that the cost would certainly not be equally shared and that the producer would pay for the lot. There should have been a reaction in the marketplace to the changes in the levy. If the costs were being shared, the producer would not have to pay as much in terms of the slaughter levy. As I said, I do not believe that has happened.

PARA.TAB: Since the Estimates Committee hearings it has been predicted that the cattle transaction levy will drop. As I said when the legislation was first introduced, I believe that a cattle transaction levy should not apply, for instance, to transactions conducted on a walk-in, walk-out basis where cattle never leave a producer's place. I am talking here about cattle that are not killed and processed but are just paid for and left in the same place.

I cannot remember whether the Bill has been passed but there is now a move to reduce the rate of the cattle transaction levy. Can the Minister tell me whether he still believes that producers and processors are sharing this cost equally or somewhere near equally? Further, can he explain the reason for dropping the levy? I welcome a drop in any levy but this just shows that the concerns I had at the time of the debate were correct.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to plead that we are between a rock and a hard place on this matter. We in the Government are the front guys and we take advice from the industry on what is the best way of doing these things. The industry offers us advice and we take it. We get criticised for doing these things, but all we are doing is implementing the advice of the industry. I suppose we are big enough and tough enough to cop it, so we ought not to complain. However, there is a sense of unfairness in that.

PARA.TAB: This levy was the subject of some good economic news in that this is one of the imposts that have been reduced by the Government. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, made an announcement about that on 17 October—that is, since the Estimates committee stage. The purpose of the levy is to raise funds on behalf of the industry for meat marketing, research and animal disease control. The reason why we have been able to reduce the levy is that the BTEC program—the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign—has reduced in cost. The component cost has now reduced from $2.10 to 85c because we have had significant success in having Australia declared free of brucellosis in 1989.

We are now moving to a declaration of tuberculosis-free status and then into a monitoring period, so that by 1997 we can achieve a situation where we will be free of these diseases and will be given a clean bill of health. The fact that we have made significant progress in the brucellosis area means that the actual cost within that component of the levy can be reduced, and that is the reason for the reduction.
The honourable senator asked whether it was fair; whether the right people were paying it, in effect, or whether the poor old cocky copped the lot in the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's dead right.

—There are a few poor old ex-cockies across the way and I suppose their view is that they cop it all in the end. But I have to say that that is not quite a fair depiction of the circumstances in this case. On 17 October Minister Crean said that he had asked the Cattle Council and the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council to review the operation of the transaction levy. The levy was put up to replace the old slaughter fee. We introduced it on the advice of the industry at the time, in recognition that people other than those at the slaughter end should contribute to the promotion of marketing and research and to a healthier herd through a reduction in animal diseases.

PARA.TAB: I trust that answers the honourable senator's question. We have done better on the health front and that is why we can reduce the costs. The matter is under review by the industry organisations, whose advice we took in the first place. So if the honourable senator wants to criticise us, he should do so and we will cop it. But I have to say that our defence is that this is what we were advised to do and we did it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has made a few pertinent points that I would like to pick up. Perhaps I can give him or his Department some advice. He said in the first place that industry suggested it or that industry wanted it. That is the problem in the cattle industry and in many other primary industries: there are statements from the Minister that the industry wants it. But who in the industry wants it? In the case of the cattle industry it was the Cattle Council, and I can say the same about the Grains Council and the Wool Council. Maybe the Minister for Industrial Relations is not responsible for this, but all Ministers should be looking beyond what the industry wants to find out who in the industry wants it. Is it all the people in the industry or only a few in the peak body, who half the time are not elected democratically anyway? That is the danger. I believe the whole industry was not aware of what was going on, and that may be a debate for another day.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister has said, we have moved towards the eradication of brucellosis. That original cattle transaction levy—which changed from the slaughter levy—has not long been in place. Anyone with half an eye could see how the brucellosis eradication campaign was going. We did not get rid of brucellosis overnight; it had to be worked on. In fact, the Fraser Government provided some incentive towards it—I forget what it was exactly because that was quite some time ago. But there was an incentive for the brucellosis eradication program which started in the mid-1970s.

It seems peculiar that the Minister should now tell me that suddenly we have got rid of it. Someone should have known that we would be rid of it by this time when the transaction levy was put in place a matter of 12 months ago. The Government should have been able to see it. I have already made the point about what industry wants. I believe we should look beyond that. As to whether it is fair—whether the producer or the processor is getting it—I have my own reservations about that which I will debate in this place at another time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further questions on subprogram 1.1, we will turn to subprogram 2.1, `Natural resource management'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 September during the Estimates Committee hearing I raised a number of questions with regard to proposals by the Department to conduct a future development workshop in northern Australia. I understood that this workshop was to be held in October or November 1991. At that time I was advised that the financial provisions had not been finalised. Whilst the objectives were to look at land conservation activity, I am keen to establish what progress has taken place with regard to the planning of that project.

PARA.TAB: The Minister may recall that the questions I asked also related to the cross-portfolio references with the area covered by Senator Collins, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, and the various economic and associated studies that Senator Collins had initiated at James Cook University. Has the Department had any consultation with the study unit at James Cook University? Has it had any more success than I in obtaining copies of the economic reports that I believe have been undertaken at James Cook University?

Senator Collins informed me six or seven weeks ago that the report had been finalised and that a copy could be made available to me. My staff have pursued it several times a week since then and I believe they have been informed that only an interim report has been prepared at James Cook University. Certainly, on a daily basis we have been promised a copy of it, but it has still not turned up. Given the fact that I raised this matter with the Department at the Estimates hearing on 5 September, I hope it has also been able to conduct discussions with James Cook University. My questions relate specifically to the planning for the conference—when is it to take place?—and to what degree is there consultation between this portfolio and that of Senator Collins?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President.
—It is a different hat today.
—Sometimes I am never able to quite distinguish which hat it is.
—Like you couldn't get a grip of the Kambalda strike yesterday.

—Senator Panizza can debate that with me in Question Time if he likes. If he is not happy with the answer I gave yesterday, I will give him another one today, but it will be the same answer. The first question that Senator Tambling asked concerned when the conference is scheduled to be held. The answer is that no firm date has been selected as yet for the conference. A date is being canvassed tentatively for May next year, but at this stage that is not confirmed. Obviously we would like it to be settled as soon as can reasonably be done, but it is not a settled date at this stage; it is tentative.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling asked me next about whether the Department has a copy of the JCU report of its economic strategy for northern Australia. The Department does not have a copy at the moment, but when it does it will obviously help the Department in its preparation for participation in the conference that has been scheduled. The Department would obviously like to see that report because this issue under the land resources division is about soil conservation and it has been raised by the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee within the Department. Our participation in the seminar will depend a little—not entirely—on what that report says.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that the Department has obviously had the same problem as I have in soliciting the material out of James Cook University or through Senator Collins's office. That is indeed a pity, given that I am aware from Senator Collins that interim reports at least have been available as long ago as six or seven weeks. Why does the Minister now say that the conference will take place in May when the program performance indicator figures that were put to us at the Estimates committee hearings suggest that the conference was going to be held in October and November 1991? Why has there been a six-month slippage in conducting this conference?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should correct an impression implicit in that question. I did not say categorically that the conference would occur in May; I said that is a tentative date being canvassed. Obviously we would like it to occur at that time. Senator Tambling asked about the reasons for the slippage in the old target date to the new target date. The reason is simply that this is a very difficult conference to coordinate. To get everyone together at the one time has proved to be an extremely difficult job. Therefore, one is placed in the position of going ahead with a less representative conference at an earlier date or projecting ahead to a date when most people's diaries can at least be reasonably clear and they are available. The key reason for the slippage in time is simply the availability of the representative key people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It concerns me that the Department is taking this view. I would have hoped that, in the normal Budget cycles, a conference of this importance would have taken place earlier in a financial year. It was indicated to us in the performance notes that it was to take place in October or November 1991. If the conference is deferred until May 1991, any recommendations that participants in that conference may well have arrived at would then have extreme difficulty in being processed through the appropriate forums of the Department in the Budget Estimates, even for the 1992-93 financial year. I hope that such an important conference would also make recommendations to the appropriate ministerial council for consideration. In turn, that would again cause further delays if it has to end up at a ministerial conference as well as be subject to departmental and government responses.

PARA.TAB: It seems that in northern Australia we have had a record number of conferences in the past few years. There is another one that I will come to on the agenda shortly under subprogram 4.1 relating to a conference held last March in Alice Springs convened by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Snowdon, but under the auspices of this Department. It made a number of recommendations with regard to transport. Other conferences have been held in northern Australia, in Broome, under the auspices of the Government relating to problems of health administration in remote and northern parts of Australia. All these issues do impact on the lifestyle and the industry of northern Australia. The constant deferral of these issues is a matter for concern.

In both 1989 and 1990 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) convened special northern Australian conferences through the country task force. That task force made a number of recommendations both in 1989 and 1990 to which the Government has not yet responded in the normal and proper budgetary considerations. As I said, I will comment shortly on the transport ones, but again I highlight that this is an important issue. I would have thought that, with the Government's priorities relating to the environment, and particularly to land conservation, it would have been keen to have seen program and Budget activity at least in 1992. I am not really looking for any further response from the Minister, but I hope that the appropriate priority will be given and, if necessary, a big stick will be wielded in this regard to ensure that, if the conference is delayed until May, prompt action will then follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 2.1, we will move to program 2 and subprogram 2.2, which is entitled `Rural adjustment and services'. Are there any matters reserved in relation to that subprogram?

—I rise to raise some matters regarding the Rural Adjustment Authority and to endeavour to follow through some recent announcements that have been made. In doing so, and because I raised the matter in Estimates, I recognise the problems being experienced in Western Australia with the Rural Adjustment Authority and, in particular, the situation which existed with the operation of part B. It has not been activated over the last couple of years at a time when I believe it should have been activated because it is an area where carry-on financial assistance is provided.

PARA.TAB: A well known syndrome of `Get big or get out' has been operating throughout the Rural Adjustment Authority in Western Australia. As I said at the Estimates hearings, that attitude has become, in my view, totally self-defeating. In 1986 we saw those so-called farmers who were the efficient operators in 1982 being forced out of the industry because their debt was too high. We are now seeing a repeat of the restructuring process of the efficient producers that went on in 1986. They were restructured to take the inefficient people out. In that process their debt—and, of course, their land—built up. They are the people who are, by and large, experiencing serious financial problems today.

I want to examine part B, particularly with regard to the announcement by the Minister to increase the ratio of funding by the Commonwealth to $2 for every $1 contributed by the States. I certainly welcome that initiative. The Commonwealth is supplying the bulk of the money for the initiative; it is supplying all of it in parts A and C and a proportion in part B. I want to know, and it is important that it be answered, what action the Commonwealth will take to ensure that the States and, in particular, Western Australia activate part B. The Western Australian Government has been very neglectful in this regard, and it is not for a lack of representation by people like me and others. It has been very negligent and it must carry a lot of the blame for what has occurred in much of rural Western Australia.

It is absolutely crucial at this time that, if the Rural Adjustment Authority is to be in place and operate effectively, its sole role—as it has been in the past—of getting farmers out of the industry and in the process building up the debts of others, has to stop. It is just impossible with the current cost structures and commodity prices to service those debts for any period of time.

In speaking about this aspect of the Rural Adjustment Authority I note the announcement by Minister Crean in recent days with regard to the changes that have been made and the linkage to social security benefits. Senator Richardson, in answer to a question yesterday, made reference to those changes and some aspect of being underemployed. One of the problems in terms of a rural operation, particularly with stock, is that people just cannot get up and leave that operation and work in another job because of the necessary husbandry requirements of the stock. If that were to occur, the animal welfare people would be chasing them around in circles.

I note that the announcement was that these provisions will fit between RAS part B, which has been non-operative in Western Australia as I have already pointed out, and part C, which is the re-establishment assistance. Some of the questions that I want addressed in terms of this are as follows: how will the Commonwealth ensure that part B with the changed arrangements will be activated and not stay in the doldrums as in recent years? Under these new arrangements which will fit between RAS part B and part C, will individuals have to sign something saying that they will sell their property within a period of time or pay back the money, which they now have to do under part C?

In terms of qualifying for this assistance, will they have to, as they do under part A, provide budgets going back five years and estimates into the future for five years? I do not have a problem with going back five years, other than that I believe it is a fruitless exercise because what has happened in the previous five years—particularly years four and five—does not really have much impact on today's situation, but to draw up budgets for five years hence is a totally fruitless exercise. It is an expensive exercise. In most instances the budgets will be out of date within a month or two—sometimes less—of the time they are prepared. While I welcome the changes to part B, my fundamental questions concern how the Commonwealth knows that it will be activated, and the points regarding its sitting between the non-active part B, and part C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Winston Crane is right in saying that on 29 October this Government announced that it would increase rural assistance for Australia, specifically by injecting more than $60m in new funds into rural assistance over a full year, in recognition of the hardships that are currently being experienced in the farming sector. As he has said, earlier this year we increased funding to $160m; it has now gone up again by $30.64m for RAS and will increase to $41.81m in 1992-93. We have increased the ratio of one dollar Federal for one dollar State to two dollars Federal for one dollar State because of the need, under part B, for some special assistance.

PARA.TAB: As I understand Senator Crane's questions, they are: firstly, when will something be done to activate part B grants in Western Australia? My advice is that on Tuesday, 5 November—Tuesday of this week—part B was activated in Western Australia, so it is operational.

I understand that Senator Crane asked for information on farm build-up in Western Australia for the RAS authority for the years 1981-82 and 1982-83. I can tell him that for those years 47 loans were provided through RAS, of which 40 were paid out, one farmer left the industry, one farmer is slightly in arrears and five are being serviced. For 1985-86 and 1986-87, 58 loans were provided, of which 17 were paid out, one farmer went bankrupt, one farmer is unlikely to continue and 39 accounts are being serviced.
I understand the next question was: will individuals have to sign something saying that they will sell their properties or pay back the money under part C?

TALK.START.PARA: —The gap between the two.

—There is a six-month period after which that requirement is put upon the relevant person. I understand that has now been extended to 12 months until 3 June 1992, so that there is a 12-month breathing space. Senator Crane asked a fourth question, but in my flurry to do justice to the others I did not take a note of it. If he would ask it again, I will get an answer for him.

—In giving those answers, particularly the last part, I believe the Minister has misunderstood my question. The announcement by the Minister was that the provisions will target those farmers who fall between RAS part B, carry-on assistance, and part C, re-establishment assistance. Under part C, re-establishment of assistance, individuals have to sign something saying they will sell or pay back the money; under part B they do not have to. My question was that with this falling between the two—I am not sure whether to call it part B 1/2, 1/2C or what, and I guess it does not matter—will the provisions that apply to part B be applied in terms of that assistance; or will the provisions which apply to part C apply, where individuals have to sign something saying that they will sell within the period of time which, as the Minister rightly said, has been extended to 12 months, or they will pay back the money?
—My advice is that for social security assistance between B and C there will be no necessity to sell or repay. I think that is the clearest and most direct answer I can give you to that question.
—Even I understand that, and that is an improvement.
—Good. Even I understand it. I am glad you approve. If you ask your next question I will see if I can do as well again.

—No, I said that was an improvement—but I do approve as well. In terms of that area of assistance, what will be the budget preparation requirement to receive it? Will it be the same as part A, will it be the same as the current situation with part B or will there be another set of criteria introduced?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —On these technicalities I think we have reached a point at which one could say, `What are all the things that you always wanted to know about this but were afraid to ask?'—except that Senator Crane is not afraid to ask. This area relates to a statement that was made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) just last week, and the honourable senator probably has other follow-up questions.

PARA.TAB: I will answer this question now, but in order to meet the honourable senator's needs in relation to a clearer explanation about all the lingering worries or concerns that there might be about how this will operate, the most sensible thing for me to do is to put him in contact with the Department, and the officers there can answer each specific technical point as it is raised by him. There can be an ongoing availability on the part of the Department so that the operation of this scheme can be made very clear and so that no misunderstanding occurs for want of technical knowledge. Specifically, to answer the question, it will operate in the same way as part A and part B—with this one qualification, that it will not be possible to get any more money for carry-on finance from one's normal or usual bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has said that the scheme will operate the same as part A and part B, but the requirements under part A and part B in terms of application are quite different. However, I will pursue this matter with the officers at the table and the people to whom the Minister has referred me. In terms of the opening up of part B—I am pleased to note that it was opened up on 5 November, and I had not heard about that—will that now be handling the requirements in terms of those people who are in drought conditions? I refer particularly to the south-eastern portion of Western Australia and the drought areas in New South Wales and Queensland.
—There is a one word answer—yes.

—I do not have specific questions such as those that Senator Crane has asked, but I want to make some comments regarding subprogram 2.2, which deals with rural adjustment and services. I note that one of the objectives is to `redress barriers to rural people's access to the full range of government and other social, economic and rural services'. This area naturally covers a broad range of assistance measures, including the rural adjustment scheme. Only last week we finally saw the Government providing some sort of adjustment to the scheme, and other social and economic benefits are to be provided for rural families.

PARA.TAB: The rural assistance package announced by the Government has many commendable aspects, though it still amazes me that, with all the bureaucrats here in Canberra and all the task forces and committees that the Government establishes, it has taken until now to recognise the extent of suffering in rural areas. Indeed, the Government's own drought task force had reported 18 months ago but still the Government did not have a national drought policy, or even a definition of extreme drought or hardship. At that time the task force recommended the establishment of a part D to the rural adjustment scheme, to provide household support, equivalent to unemployment benefits, to farmers in extreme hardship.

It is astonishing to realise that the Government has only now appreciated that in various parts of Australia, and particularly in Queensland, we are in the middle of an extreme drought. Actually, the Labor Government in Queensland took a long time to come to that point of view as well. In some parts of Queensland and New South Wales it is the worst drought in memory. Already 55 per cent of New South Wales has been drought declared. Predictions are that 20 per cent of farmers in drought areas will fail. In my own State of Queensland, $500m of rural production has now been lost.

In the light of these depressing figures, the rural assistance package announced last week is for some, I regret to say, too little, too late in coming. However, the decision to offer social security benefits to farmers experiencing extreme hardship as a result of the rural downturn will help many farmers stay above the poverty line. I also welcome the extension of part C of the rural adjustment scheme, which will allow farmers up to six months to decide whether to leave their farms. However, I believe that the money that will be advanced in the way of household support should be by means of a grant rather than a loan. Indeed, the only way to fix the welfare gap is to provide farmers with either unemployment benefits or household support—but surely not another loan. I wonder whether there is any possibility of the Government looking into this matter.

I have also noted that the Government has recognised the way that it ruined the income equalisation deposit scheme. The Government needs to reintroduce some of the incentive that was present in the original scheme so that farmers can be more self-reliant in hard times. This is something that I believe to be very important and very worth while, particularly when we see so many people in rural Australia in financial difficulty at present. I am also pleased that the Government is still reviewing the natural disaster relief arrangements with a view to making Commonwealth assistance more readily available.

Many of these adjustments in relation to improving the access of farming and rural families to the various government social and economic services still do not go far enough. While it is fascinating that the Government has finally recognised the impact of extreme hardship on farmers, I believe that the measures that the Government has taken will still be inadequate. There will still be a number of areas that will fail to deliver in the provision of services to those from rural areas. As I said earlier, one of the objectives of the rural adjustment and services subprogram is to `redress barriers to rural people's access to the full range of government and other social, economic and rural services'. One area where rural families are still not receiving the full range of government services is in the provision of education and other facilities to rural families.

I am perhaps going a little beyond the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, as this involves the education portfolio as well, but I refer to the provision of assistance by the Government under the isolated children's scheme. I raised this matter in the Senate on Tuesday during Question Time, as many people in rural Australia are experiencing a real problem. In responding, Senator Bolkus did not seem to fully understand what my question meant. He did, though, give me a lecture on the rural assistance package. The Federal Government's refusal to change eligibility requirements for the isolated children's assistance scheme has already and will continue to force many rural families to withdraw their children from schools. The asset test provision for the scheme means that many rural families will not qualify and either will have to sell up, as is happening in many cases, or take their children out of school. I asked the Minister whether the Government would consider basing the eligibility criteria for this benefit on income alone. He refused to acknowledge that these problems exist and instead chose to give the Senate a lecture on the rural adjustment scheme.

Under the Government's current rural assistance package, some rural families will now qualify for social security and other benefits. However, the Government has still not recognised that unless a family does qualify it will not receive any assistance for education. That to me seems to be a real problem. It seems that the Minister knew no more about what the question meant than the Labor Party knows or cares about the problems that are confronting rural Australia. Many farmers have assets but no liquidity. They are asset rich but income poor. They cannot say that they will pay their bills with their stockyard. Perhaps they could pay them with the sale of stock—if they had some stock or crops that were of some value.

In fact, the Minister seems to be unaware that many farmers are currently experiencing circumstances in which they have no income or even negative income as a result of the disastrous drought and the rural downturn. It is for this reason that I believe that the eligibility requirements should be changed to a test on income and not on assets. That to me is a very important point. With no money coming into rural households and with farming families being refused those allowances, many young people are being denied the same opportunities as those available to people who live in the cities. It is now imperative that the Government set in place policies that will alleviate the huge cost burdens faced by primary producers. Perhaps some of those comments did not relate specifically to the subprogram, but this is all related to the rural adjustment scheme, and I wanted to put those points on the record.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—There being no questions under subprogram 2.3, Quarantine and Inspection, we move to program 4, Corporate Management and Policy, subprogram 1, Corporate Policy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate Estimates Committee, I asked a number of questions arising specifically from the conference convened in Alice Springs in March of this year by the Parliamentary Secretary for transport, Warren Snowdon, who is also the Federal member for the Northern Territory. The conference was subsequently convened under the joint auspices of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Transport and Communications. I have received a comprehensive reply to three questions I asked relating to the recommendations that arose from that particular conference. One of my questions was, `Will the response to the recommendations of the conference be tabled in the Parliament?'. I find it quite ironical that the answer to that question was, `It is not proposed to table the report of the conference in the Parliament'. Yet, attached to the document I have, which relates to that report, are the responses to the recommendations arising from the report. It is, in effect, attached to the answers that were made available to the Committee. There are detailed responses to some 24 recommendations and a further attachment of an additional two pages relating to government initiatives aimed at rural and remote Australia.

PARA.TAB: So, in effect, an 11-page response has been tabled in the Parliament through the mechanism of this Committee, yet the answer given is that it is not proposed to table the report of the conference itself. I find that rather ironical and, to some extent, stupid. I believe that the full conference report ought to be tabled. As a participant in that conference, I have received a copy of it and it is an important document. About 100 people attended that conference, the majority of whom were public servants or academics from elsewhere in Australia. I think there were also 20 or so people drawn from interest groups or the private sector.

However, the report was an important document, given that transport in rural and remote Australia is currently on the national agenda and is a very important and major issue which will proceed to the Special Premiers Conference to be held in Perth later this month. It concerns me that the Department and the Government do not propose to make available for public comment a conference report that obviously bears on the whole arrangements affecting transport industries in rural and remote Australia. We are all well aware that there is a degree of controversy between the Prime Minister and the Premiers and also between the Federal Government and the State governments about so many issues relating to transport policy development.

Given the 24 recommendations that have been responded to by the Government and the answers that were given to the Committee and are now being given to the Committee of the Whole, are any of those government responses inconsistent in any way with the proposals that are to be presented by the Prime Minister to the Special Premiers Conference this month? In what areas do they diverge from the agenda that has gone forward to the Premiers Conference? To what extent have matters of detail, which are to be determined by the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Ministers, already been, in effect, canvassed and addressed by the Government in this response before us?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that there is really no way that I can answer that question because the honourable senator is asking me to speculate on what the Prime Minister will be putting to the Premiers in a conference yet to be held, and whether that will be different in any material sense from the responses to these recommendations. At this stage I cannot say what the Prime Minister will put and therefore I cannot answer the second part of the question as to whether it will vary from these particular responses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the very officers who have been involved in the process of preparing documentation for the Special Premiers Conference later this month are in fact the same departmental officers of the relevant government departments—whether they be from the Prime Minister's Department, the Department of Transport and Communications or the Department of Primary Industries and Energy—who compiled the responses, which the Government itself in Cabinet has had to endorse.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it is of concern that the Minister at the table is not able to give any information about the Government's proposals. The Government made this response to the special conference that it convened in March of this year. Yet this same Government, which is now preparing a case for major consideration of transport initiatives as a fundamental issue to be addressed at the Premiers Conference, is not able to confirm or deny that it is varying in any way the fundamental principles it has established in this response in the documentation it is now taking forward to probably the most important conference of the year, the Premiers Conference on 21 November. It is an issue that is of major concern. It again highlights what I was alluding to earlier when I referred to the other conference being convened by the Government on land conservation. The Government is good at getting out into the community and running conferences. However, when it comes to picking up and taking forward the recommendations of those conferences, and responding to them as a government, it is then not able to say what its policy will be.

It is indicative of a government in a policy paralysis. The Prime Minister seems to be wandering off with alternative agendas that are dictated by Mr Keating or other people at different times. I want to know whether a report that has been tabled in this Parliament in the last month in response to questions in September and to which the Government made a response is the consistent basis that the Prime Minister will now put before the Premiers later this month.

The Government cannot tell me. The Minister is unable to inform me whether the work is consistent or in what areas there will be significant differences. What type of government are we dealing with? Where are we heading? What changes and impact will it have on the community? Remote and rural Australia really do feel the effect of the transport agenda, and that was certainly highlighted in the conference report.

I find the report itself to be a very good one. However, the Government has chosen not to table it, only its 24 responses, but is then not in a position to tell us whether those responses are the negotiating items that the Prime Minister wants to present. I assure the Government that I will assess every one of those 24 recommendations against what the Prime Minister publicly says in the next few weeks and against the results and the consequences that he is seeking to obtain between the Federal and State governments. I find it absolutely astounding that the Minister is unable to give this Committee any assurance that the Prime Minister is being consistent with a Government response that has obviously been made in the past month or so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a quick response to that. If I were Senator Tambling, I would not work myself up; the process is pretty straightforward. Senator Tambling can use this forum to give us a political biff or two and that is his prerogative, but it does not go to the issue.

PARA.TAB: The issue is that the recommendations of this conference and the responses that have now been seen are part of a policy development process. Senator Tambling asked me what the Prime Minister will tell the Premiers. I will not tell him what the Prime Minister will tell the Premiers. The Prime Minister will tell the Premiers first and not have me tell Senator Tambling what he, the Prime Minister, is to tell the Premiers before he has a chance, firstly, to make up his mind properly in consultation with the Cabinet what he will tell them; and, secondly, to give a courtesy to the Premiers that they should hear what he wants to say first and not through some back door, roundabout route.

So, fair go, if Senator Tambling wants to attack us, please do but do it on something of some substance. This is just a procedural issue; it is not a matter of any great import. The Premiers and indeed the Chief Minister of Senator Tambling's own Territory would be mightily offended if we as a government turned around and did not deal with him but dealt with Senator Tambling instead.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Is there anything further on program 4? That completes consideration of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We now move on to the Department of Transport and Communications. If there are no matters that honourable senators wish to raise, we will move to program 1, `Aviation', subprogram 1.5, `Federal Airports Corporation'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of issues on the Federal Airports Corporation that arise from questions that I placed before the Estimates Committee. These were commented upon in the report of the Committee as well as in a reservation that I expressed. On page 2 of the Committee's report, the Committee noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the FAC's management of Bankstown Airport, the Corporation was queried about its management of aircraft parking, the basis of its profit and dividend calculations, the gate access for Compass Airlines at terminal buildings, the application of parking fees, the progress in commercial leases at Darwin and Alice Springs, general aviation facilities at Darwin, its program to acquire works of art, the profitability of the airport terminal at Hobart and its handling of duty-free concessions that are tendered for at overseas terminals.

That paragraph refers to the general issues, about half of which were the ones that I specifically raised. I am concerned that I received what I consider to be a very inadequate series of answers on the issues that I raised. In effect, the answer that the Minister provided is that the Federal Airports Corporation has provided the following answer: `The matter is commercial-in-confidence and therefore not available'.

PARA.TAB: A question related to the extra charges for new lease sites on the northern side of the Darwin airport to general aviation operators as opposed to those they are currently paying on the southern side. Another one related to a request for a schedule of the names of the tenants and tenancies, the status of those leases that are signed and not signed at the new terminal at both Darwin and Alice Springs, and the third question asked for costs to the FAC budget for interest or other costs to compensate concessionaires for the delays in opening at Darwin and Alice Springs terminals.

I do not believe that answer is appropriate for this Committee to accept. After receiving that answer, very early in the piece I said to Senator Collins that it was totally inadequate and inappropriate. There is an important point of principle of a corporatised arm of the Government seeking to hide behind an answer that it is an issue of commercial-in-confidence. If the organisation was totally privatised, I could fully understand the extent of that answer. But, given that the FAC is not, it still has a strong responsibility that it must honour to this particular Parliament. The answers are inadequate; they are insulting. They are not matters that I believe would in any way affect the commercial operations of any individual or operation that would be embarrassing. All of the information ought to be available and publicly on the record, given the nature of the public service that these important airport terminals will serve.

I shall be looking for a response from the Minister on each of those areas in more detail for the public record. I mentioned this to the Minister many weeks ago and I hope that he is now in a position to give a response.

The other issue I raised, on which I have received some but I believe inadequate detail, related to the series of questions I asked about the remuneration and basis for engagement of Dr Battersby, who was a special art adviser to the Federal Airports Corporation. I asked for a rough annual Australia-wide appropriation for the acquisition of art for the financial years 1990-1991 and 1991-1992. I certainly received a satisfactory answer about the expenditure on art acquisitions for airports in 1990-1991, which was of the order of $370,000, and the estimated budget for expenditure on art acquisitions in the 1991-1992 financial year is $1.45m. That is an amount of money on which we can take whatever view we like as to whether it is proper, adequate or whatever.

I have heard Senator Collins give complimentary mention to some of the particular art that has been installed in the new terminals at Darwin and Alice Springs airports. I accept that it is probably of a good standard. Senator Collins knows full well that I had hoped previously that there would have been more local content and local involvement in the choice of that art for the respective terminals in Darwin and Alice Springs. However, I believe that the FAC has avoided answering the question relating to the remuneration of Dr Battersby, and I believe that there is no commercial confidentiality with regard to a consultancy of that nature.

To hide behind commercial-in-confidence in regard to the provision of the fees paid to Dr Battersby again links up with those previous questions for which I received a totally inappropriate and inadequate answer. I look to Senator Collins to provide that detail with regard to the full contract and financial details for Dr Battersby.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first matters raised by Senator Tambling, the individual negotiations between the Federal Airports Corporation and the individual concessionaires at Alice Springs and Darwin airports I regard as being commercially confidential, not for the sake of the FAC—
—I was only asking about compensation.

—It applies to compensation as well. As Senator Tambling knows, that matter is still being negotiated. I would have thought that he would have had a bit more sensitivity to the individual concerns of the concessionaires themselves. That is where my concern and the FAC's concern are in terms of having its business dealings laid out publicly. I do not accept Senator Tambling's suggestion, and the public record shows that this was precisely the same view I took when I was Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory on many of these issues connected with the Northern Territory Government.

PARA.TAB: It has been suggested that, because a corporation is fully funded publicly, the individuals who then deal with the matter are required to have all their business dealings laid out for the public gaze. I do not support that at all and never have, and I have been consistent on that matter for 15 years. Having said that, I can assure Senator Tambling that when he looks at these lists he will see that some of this information is sensitive. The individual companies concerned, some of whom are simply local small business people, would not appreciate having these things laid out for the public gaze.

I am prepared to take a decision on this outside of the FAC. I respect Senator Tambling's position over a long period of time as a Northern Territory senator and I am sure that he would not want to do anything to embarrass or hurt local business people. I have the information and, if Senator Tambling is prepared to give an undertaking that he will treat it as confidential, I am happy to provide it to him on that basis. In view of the hour, I would like to deal with the question of Jean Battersby separately. Perhaps I could ask for a response from Senator Tambling now as to whether he is prepared to accept the information on that basis. If he is, I will provide it to him now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have a discussion with Senator Collins on this matter before accepting his suggestion. I would like to discuss in detail those issues that he may believe to be commercial-in-confidence. Perhaps we could seek a resolution. There may be parts on which we can arrive at agreement and which would not embarrass anyone, so that it is then on the public record.
