TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I bring before the Senate a matter that I consider to be of extreme interest to people in Australia: the extraordinary comments made by Senator Graham Richardson this morning on the AM news program. This matter is of great importance to the people of Australia because it demonstrates the cause of the inertia and the paralysis that presently confront this Government.

PARA.TAB: The Government is unable to govern. It is unable to do what it was elected to do, because it is completely absorbed by the contest between Mr Keating and Mr Hawke for the prime ministership of Australia. It is absolutely extraordinary that that should be going on at this time. There are almost one million Australians out of work, and all this Government can do is fight about who should be the Prime Minister for the next few months until an election is called, when Dr Hewson will take over.

I am also concerned about the extraordinary attacks by Senator Richardson on those people constituting the present Government of Queensland. This morning, Senator Richardson said about the people that now run the Government of Queensland:

SPEECH.PARA: You will recall that one little conference of the Party in Surfers Paradise, more famed for the amount of booze that could be drunk per delegate than for any decision that was made. And the average was pretty high, because some of the players were pretty fantastic. The Queensland delegation actually distinguished themselves in an extraordinary matter. It was even too much for Egdo, he had to replace half of them after the last two days.

That is a disgraceful commentary on the Queensland Labor Party and the people in it who are now holding positions of power in the Government of Queensland. I find that sort of comment on the Queensland Government quite inexcusable. Even though it is a Labor government, I find it an insult to the people of Queensland that Senator Richardson should say that about the people who make up the present Queensland Government.

PARA.TAB: I also think it is outrageous that Senator Richardson should paint the Deputy Premier of Queensland as a racial bigot. That is what he did this morning. He called him a racial bigot. He said in this interview this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: But it was only in 1988 when Tom Burns stood at the rear of the hall, in a meeting of a group formed in Surfers Paradise to oppose, not foreign investment, but Japanese investment. He said that he had been, `ranting' was the word he used, about Japanese investment for 15 years, and he was delighted that public opinion had finally caught up with his views.
The interviewer said:
Senator Richardson had painted Mr Burns as a racial bigot.
Then Senator Richardson said:
That was the kind of vision with which Tom Burns was associated.
That sort of stuff should not be allowed to go on in the governments of Australia. The ABC interviewer said today:
Both Mr Burns, the Queensland Deputy Premier, and Mr Ian McLean, a Federal Vice-President—
he is a Minister in the Queensland Government—
have angered the Keating camp with their calls for the Treasurer to be disciplined. . .
Senator Richardson then went on to belittle those two members of the Queensland Government. He said this about Mr McLean:

PARA.TAB: The eyes of my two Left colleagues on that trip opened wide as they saw the grand socialist vision, the 30-foot high bronzed statues of the great leader. Whatever you think of Hawkie he hasn't come at that. Now, Ian McLean is saying that Paul Keating should be disciplined. This is the same man who campaigned for six months on the question of privatisation last year. You could not turn on AM without Ian McLean threatening parliamentary members of the Party with disciplinary action if they dared to vote against his views.

SPEECH.PARA: I also find it disgraceful that it should be alleged by a person in this Government that a person in another government was using his power improperly to get it to vote in a particular way on the leadership issues and on other matters of policy before this Government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Burns, in responding to the allegations by Senator Richardson, mentions Ravenshoe—a matter that I have been particularly interested in for some time—and accuses Senator Richardson of being run out of town and of running away from that. Let me quote the Queensland Deputy Premier:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say this to him—
this is to Senator Richardson—

If he wants to get personal up here in Queensland we had to go into Ravenshoe after he ran away from the rank and file up there over some of his policies. He was run out of town in Queensland because of some of the things he did and I was sent back along with some of my colleagues to tidy up and to put the thing in the right perspective.
Mr Burns continues:

It has taken them years to fix up the problems he created in world heritage. They only fixed up Ravenshoe mill just the other day. If Mr Richardson wants to get personal I will have no trouble in facing up to him. I remind people that he is one of these senators, him and Loosley, that get about 10 per cent of the vote and they are not worried about getting 51 per cent of the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Mr Tom Burns, the Queensland Deputy Premier—
—And former ALP Federal President.
—That is correct. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: What I have said and I say it again, Keating and those people who gave us—
and now he acknowledges it—

massive unemployment, who gave us high interest rates, are now spending all of their time, and Richardson is supporting them, attacking the Labor Government. And if that is the way Labor Parties operate, no wonder Richardson and them made a mess of New South Wales.

Then he says a few words about the New South Wales Right, which controls the Labor Party in that State. Of course, this is relevant and I might mention it later in relation to the leadership challenge and the interest of the Queensland ALP in that challenge. Mr Burns went on to say about this Government:

All of these people that are rushing out to defend Keating, you know, the New South Wales Right, have made up their mind to destroy the Government if they can't get the leadership. They don't care about the Labor Party, they don't care about the rank and file, they don't care about the unemployed, and they haven't done anything for the unemployed for years'.
That is a very perceptive statement by Mr Tom Burns, the Queensland Deputy Premier: that this Government does not care about the unemployed. It has done nothing for the unemployed for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what he said.
—That is what he said.
—It is not what he said. He said the New South Wales Right—

—He is talking about the Government. I will lend Senator Button my copy of the transcript if he wants it. He is talking about the people who control this Government. They do not care about the unemployed, and they have not done anything for the unemployed for years. Mr Burns went on to say, in answer to a question, that the only thing that stands between Mr Keating and the Lodge is Mr Keating's performance as Treasurer. Quite accurately, he continues to blame Mr Keating, and the Cabinet of which he was a member, for creating the high interest rates and the unemployment. They are not words of political rhetoric that I am using from an opposition point of view, or from a point of view of political opposition to the Government; they are the words of the Deputy Premier of a State government. The Deputy Premier of Queensland is perceptive enough and honest enough to acknowledge that it was Mr Keating and his policies, and the Cabinet of which Mr Keating was a part, that created the unemployment and the high interest rates.

PARA.TAB: Mr McLean, who was also defamed and accused quite roundly by Senator Richardson, responded with his attack on the New South Wales Right. I will read that into the record as well. Mr McLean says:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years the New South Wales Right and they have had a long period of success on the back of Neville Wran, but in recent years they've anointed various of their club and they've charged ahead, irrespective of the damage that might be done to the Party or to the respective Government's. They did that with Barry Unsworth. I think their arrogance through the whole of the Unsworth thing lead to the disaster that they had electorally and the workers of NSW are suffering for that now. They did the same thing with Stephen Loosley at the National Conference on the question of the Presidency instead of adopting a compromise candidate. And, I believe that they are hell bent on continuing the pressure in the interests of trying to make Paul the Prime Minister.

That is disgraceful stuff. That is the stuff that this Government, and the Labor Party senators in this chamber, are concerned about. It is the all-pervading issue concerning the Government at the moment. It is not unemployment; it is not interest rates; it is not the drought; and it is not the sick condition of the economy. It is about who is going to be the leader of a crumbling, failing government. That is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: As a Queenslander I have been concerned for some time—and I have said it in this chamber—at the number of Queenslanders in the Hawke Ministry. It is of concern to Queenslanders. I accept that Ministers should be appointed on merit, not because they come from a geographic part of our nation. By the same token, I consider that there are people in the ALP in Queensland who are equally as good as the people in the ALP in Victoria or the ALP in New South Wales, or even the Northern Territory. There is no Queenslander in Cabinet at all. Why Queenslanders have such a minuscule representation in the Federal Ministry is something that I have always been concerned about. It reacts badly on the State of Queensland. When we have 11 Ministers coming from the State of Victoria and only 2 1/2 from Queensland, we can be assured that the Victorian view and the Victorian problems—and they have plenty of them—receive greater consideration and greater interest from this Government because of their sheer numbers in the Ministry.

One has only to look at the sale of the State Bank of Victoria and the rorts that have occurred to try to get the Labor Government in Victoria out of the problems that it has got itself into. One may ask what this has to do with what Senator Richardson has done today. It is turning into a battle royal between the Queensland Labor members who are excluded from the Ministry and who, almost to a man, support Mr Hawke in the contest for the leadership—with a couple of exceptions—and the New South Wales Right and the people in New South Wales who are supporting Mr Keating in his leadership challenge. That is what it is all about. That is why Senator Richardson is so determined to denigrate the Queensland Labor people and the Queensland Deputy Premier. Senator Collins may have an interest in it as well. It may well be that he is frightened of losing his job if they put people with some competence into the Ministry. He would probably be the first to go. The Minister—not because Caucus wanted him or that he had any ability—is only there because Mr Hawke wanted him there to pay back a favour. The minute Mr Hawke goes, the Minister is finished, and he knows it. That is why it is so desperate.

Laugh you may, Minister. The Minister knows better than I that the numbers are gathering. One only has to see Senator Richardson's remarks this morning to know that is true. When Mr Keating takes over as Prime Minister shortly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have another nip!

—Senator Button would not even defend Mr Hawke yesterday. Three times the honourable senator was given the opportunity to say a fraction of a word in support of his Leader—and what did he do? He scuttled away; he ran away every time. That is what it is about.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins should enjoy his few remaining days in the Ministry because, when Mr Keating takes over, he can be assured that Mr Hawke and his cronies such as Senator Collins will be gone. And the numbers are getting there. That is why it is so important to Queensland, because it is Queensland Labor members versus the New South Wales Right. It is all about who is going to get the Ministries in the Keating government, who is going to get the power for the last few crumbling days of this Government.
That is a matter which requires enormous attention and interest from the people of Australia because they must have government rather than this petty competition.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a subject of considerable importance in terms of propriety of government and of economic policy setting. It is a subject which has received insufficient consideration in this place over recent months. I refer to two or three extremely important articles by Laura Tingle in the Australian over recent weeks. In an article this week, on Monday, 4 November, she asserts that the Federal Government tried to circumvent formal monetary policy-making processes before the last policy change in September. The article is referring to what was the last interest rate change at the time this article was written and it asserts that the Government placed intense pressure on the Reserve Bank to cut rates before the bank Board had met to discuss the issue.

PARA.TAB: That is a very serious claim by Laura Tingle and, to my knowledge, there has been no denial by the Government, by either the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), of the accuracy of that story. Indeed, the thinking behind it has been confirmed, I would have thought, by the decision this week of the Reserve Bank Board to lower the interest rates as of yesterday by 1 per cent. That was a decision that was taken by the Reserve Bank Board on Tuesday, of course, but it was taken after many days of speculating by the Prime Minister, by his Ministers, by leaders of the ACTU, in my view absolutely improperly, about interest rates. The speculation gave the strongest implication that interest rates would be cut at that Board meeting earlier this week.

Indeed, I find it extraordinary that the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, should have indulged in such improper speculation in the light of the fact that he is a member of the Reserve Bank Board. I find it totally improper for a member of the Reserve Bank Board to be speculating in the way that Mr Kelty did in the days leading up to this week's Reserve Bank Board meeting.

But my main purpose today is to come back to what happened in September with the reduction in the interest rates that was announced by the Reserve Bank after its Board meeting on 3 September. In the House of Representatives on that day the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, said, on the subject of monetary policy, that when he became Treasurer there were two things that he was very clear about concerning interest rates: the first was that he was not going to overreact to one month's figures; the second was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that I was intent on making sure that due process occurred.

All the evidence to date suggests that due process was flagrantly flaunted by the Treasurer and by the Prime Minister on the very day before the Treasurer made that statement in the House of Representatives. According to the report in the Australian—a report which, to my knowledge, has not in any way been denied—the Treasurer, acting on pressure from the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister's advisers, rang the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, and put it to him that rates should be lowered. Apparently, he asked Mr Fraser what would happen if he, the Treasurer, directed the bank to cut rates. Mr Fraser, to his credit, apparently replied in the strongest possible terms in opposition to that proposal, because the bank has a standing rule that it will observe due process when it comes to the setting of monetary policy. There is a longstanding convention—indeed it is perhaps more than a convention—that the Reserve Bank will only make changes to interest rates after proper process and after all the formalities of policy-making have been followed. That includes a standing decision by the Reserve Bank Board that rates not be cut ahead of meetings of the Board and that it is the proper process of the Reserve Bank Board to consider whether rates should be changed.

PARA.TAB: This allegation in the Australian raises very serious issues indeed. It raises issues of the gravest significance in terms of the role of the Prime Minister in trying to deliberately circumvent the proper processes of monetary policy setting. One will recall that the Prime Minister was under considerable pressure at that time from his Caucus to do something about the economic situation. He was facing considerable pressure in the Caucus meeting of that week and he wanted to demonstrate to Caucus that the Government was acting by easing monetary policy. That was the reason why he pressured Mr Kerin to put pressure on the Reserve Bank to circumvent the normal processes and accept standards of monetary policy-making to cut the rates without going through the normal Reserve Bank Board meeting process.

That is playing politics with monetary policy and with the economy, par excellence. Perhaps we should not be surprised about that. We have seen nothing but such opportunistic, populist, internal Labor Party division-ridden, economic policy-making for months and months. That is one of the fundamental reasons why this country is in the desperate state that it is in, with unemployment again today showing massive levels, employment having fallen, people having dropped out of the process of looking for jobs, with a further fall in the participation rate. They are matters on which I am sure my colleagues, in particular Senator Michael Baume, will be speaking later today.

They are the very reasons why we have the desperate economic situation and the tragedy and hardship for more than one million who are on the unemployment heap that we have in this country. If we are to get away from the proper processes and the proper conduct of monetary policy, that is a very damaging situation for this nation. It heightens again the importance of having a Reserve Bank that is independent of the government of the day. That is why the coalition has, in statements over the last year or more, laid so much stress on the need to increase the independence of the Reserve Bank, to cut the ties between the Reserve Bank and the Government, so that there is no prospect of a repeat of this disgraceful type of performance that apparently occurred prior to the September Board meeting of the Reserve Bank. As I say, this was done for purely internal Labor Party political reasons. If it had not been for the Governor of the Reserve Bank reacting very properly and very strongly to the actions of the Treasurer or, through him, the Prime Minister, we could have seen very much a violation of the proper processes of the formulation of monetary policy.

It is incumbent on the Government to answer this question raised by the article by Laura Tingle in the Australian of Monday this week. It follows a similar type of article she had in the paper a month earlier. The question to be answered is: are those articles alleging impropriety on the part of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer correct or are they not correct? It requires one simple answer on the part of the Prime Minister or the Treasurer if they are incorrect, but not one word has come from the Government, since the articles first appeared in early October, to in any way suggest that those allegations are incorrect. If those allegations are correct, I believe that is a matter of very grave significance for this country, because it once again puts the formulation of economic policy and the manipulation of economic policy and monetary policy and interest rate policy in the hands of a government which has shown that it is unfit to manage and to govern this country. I fully endorse the conclusion to be drawn, if those allegations are correct, from these articles by Laura Tingle. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's conduct of monetary policy over the past few months must raise serious questions about the fitness of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, to run economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 18.Schedule, page 8, before proposed amendment to subsection 33(2) of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990, insert the following amendment:

This amendment relates to the age discrimination element, which is being removed by Opposition amendments. The Government was also seeking to remove it by similar amendments. This particular amendment has a difficulty for the Government, in so far as it applies to the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Under our amendment all people on the board of that Agency, including the Chairman, would have been exempted from the requirement to retire at 65. The Minister has told me that he has a concern, in that it is possible under the Australian Sports Drug Agency legislation to have a full time executive chairman. It is not in the spirit of the amendments that the Opposition has been moving for full time executive chairmen to be excused from retirement at 65, whereas normal board members would be.

PARA.TAB: I will not deal with the merits of this case, largely because I guess I have a vested interest in the matter. My cousin Peter Baume is the Chairman of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I would leave it to Senator Chapman, who I think has some views on this, to deal with it. All I would say is that, on balance, we think there is merit in proceeding with our amendment; at the moment there is not a full time executive chairman and we cannot see why the Chairman of this organisation should be subject to any inhibitions that other board members are not subject to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the remarks of my colleague Senator Baume with regard to the Australian Sports Drug Agency, I make the point that it is unacceptable to the coalition to maintain age discrimination in any form. When we debated this issue a couple of weeks ago, the Government responded that in terms of non-executive chairmen it was accepting our position on age discrimination, but as far as executive positions—executive officers—were concerned, it would not accept the arguments and the proposed amendments of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Yet this in itself, apart from being a blatant continuation of unjustified age discrimination, is inconsistent with the Public Service Act itself, which allows public servants to stay on in their jobs beyond the age of 65 years. In particular, division 8A of the Public Service Act provides for secretaries to departments to remain beyond the age of 65 years, at the discretion of the relevant authority. Division 8B of the Public Service Act allows a similar discretion for senior executive officers of the Public Service to remain in office beyond the age of 65 years. Division 8C provides the same opportunity for other officers of government departments.

Section 33 of the Public Service Act, which relates to the application of the merit principle, provides that there should be no discrimination in the Public Service on the ground of age. Furthermore, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission regulations provide that it is an offence to discriminate on the ground of age, and that such offences may be heard by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner.

On those grounds we do not accept that, because the Chairman of the Australian Sports Drug Agency in particular may at some future time be a full time executive chairman, he should thereby be forced to continue the possibility of suffering age discrimination. We believe that age discrimination should be removed in all its forms.

The Government raised the argument that in particular circumstances it may not be appropriate for a person to remain in such a position beyond the age of 65 years. If the provisions of the Public Service Act are applied, in those circumstances the person would not stay on, because it is a discretionary decision that can be made for someone to remain beyond the age of 65. We believe that subsection 20(3), which does not allow the appointment of anyone over the age of 65, should be removed so that age discrimination does not continue, and then at least the discretion remains to allow the appointment of someone over that age, should he or she be a fit and proper person and competent to hold that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on rice produced in Australia to raise funds for a research and development program for the rice industry. This has been requested by the Ricegrowers' Association of Australia on behalf of New South Wales' rice growers and on behalf of the Queensland Rice Marketing Board, which represents Queensland rice growers.

The Government will provide funding to match industry levies up to 0.5% of the annual gross value of production in line with established policy of encouraging increased rural productivity and profitability through research and the commercialisation of research findings.

The Government's rural research and development policy, which encourages increased contributions by primary industry, was established by the Government in February 1985 and reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, "Research Innovation and Competitiveness".
Mr President, the Australian rice industry consists of a temperate industry located in NSW, producing about 95 percent of total production and a tropical industry located in Queensland.

The industry produces around 800,000 to 900,000 tonnes of paddy rice per year, with a gross value of production in 1989-90 of $148m. About 85-90 percent of production is exported to around 30 countries.
Domestically, sales (including value adding), exceed $60m. There is significant value adding involved, with the industry packaging and marketing its own branded product.

The rice industry has a major commitment to research in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. Research has, in the past, been funded primarily by growers with Commonwealth grant assistance also provided from the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation.
The establishment of a joint Commonwealth/industry scheme will broaden the industry's research funding base and assist in enabling the industry to achieve its full potential.
The levy will apply to those varieties included in the Schedule to the Bill but with provision for new varieties to be added and for varieties no longer produced to be deleted.

Under current industry research funding arrangements, both the NSW and Queensland rice industries fund research on a budget allocation basis. That is, the industry agrees on the total amount of contribution before the start of each financial year and, in fact, before the greater proportion of rice is harvested. This ensures a reliable flow of funds to the research program, whereas a volume based funding system would have reflected the swings in production which have occurred over the last few years. For example production fell from 923,000 tonnes in 1989-90 to a forecast 726,000 in 1990-91.

This arrangement will continue under the new scheme. In practice then, the operative levy rate per tonne will be determined following the decision by industry on the level of its bulk contribution. This rate will be calculated towards the end of the harvest but before the start of the financial year, when production can be accurately determined.
The industry may determine different rates for different rice varieties to account for differing research requirements in each season but cannot determine a rate of more than $2 per tonne.

Once the industry has determined a rate or rates, the Minister will be advised and will set those rates and have them published in the Gazette. The levy rate will be set by subordinate legislation because timing is tight between setting the rates of the levies and the first payment of levies. The levy will be collected from pool returns at the end of the season for the research program of the following year.
The levy will be payable by the grower and its collection will be in accordance with the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991.

Amounts equal to the levy and the Commonwealth's matching contribution will be paid into a separate sub-account under the management of the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. Based on the current level of funding by the industry, in some years its contribution will be greater than 0.5% of the gross value of production, which is the maximum the Commonwealth will match for funding purposes.

It is expected that total levy collections will remain constant from one year to the next, or perhaps increase slightly. The cost to the budget, in terms of Commonwealth matching expenditure, is expected to be $570 000 per annum in 1991-92 to 1994-95.

The Bill will come into force on Royal Assent and the levy will be imposed on rice produced and delivered to the processor after that time. It is intended that the levy will be imposed on rice produced in the 1991-92 season and the research program under this arrangement will commence in 1992-93.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Rice Levy Bill 1991 is to impose a levy on rice produced in Australia to support research into the industry. This levy is to be matched by the Commonwealth up to a maximum of the rice industry's gross value of production for the rice industry. This brings the rice industry into line with many other rural industries which have been successful in securing a dollar for dollar industry-government payment arrangement for research.

PARA.TAB: The history of the rice industry extends back to the early 1890s when the earliest commercial rice crops were grown by Chinese market gardeners in the Northern Territory. Rice was grown at Humpty Doo and Pine Creek in order to supply Chinese people working on the gold fields. Currently, production of rice is located mainly in New South Wales, where rice crops have been commercially grown since 1924, and more recently in Queensland, from 1967.

In the Riverina District of south-western New South Wales approximately 1,800 irrigated farms produce one crop per year and typically harvest around 800,000 tonnes of rice. New South Wales produces all types of rice, including approximately one-third of the total production of long grain rice. The main variety grown is Calrose, a medium grain rice.

In comparison, the north Queensland rice industry is centred on Home Hill and Mareeba, with two annual crops and a harvest size of approximately 25,000 tonnes of rice. Blue Bonnet, a long grain rice, is the only variety grown in Queensland.

During 1990-91, $585,000 of grower money was spent on research. Of this, $166,500 came from voluntary levies and the balance was taken out of the Ricegrowers Cooperative pool. The Commonwealth matched this voluntary levy and provided a $37,294 grant through the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation to take its total contribution to $203,848. The Commonwealth does not match the grower money taken from the pool for research and development.

Under the Government's rural research program, individual industries can obtain dollar for dollar matching funds from the Commonwealth up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the total gross value of production. This program is to encourage increased rural productivity and profitability through research and commercialisation of research findings. It is also to guarantee a higher level of industry contribution.

The Ricegrowers Association of Australia has requested this legislation so that it can obtain more Commonwealth funds and broaden its major commitment to research in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position.This legislation simply sets a maximum levy of $2 a tonne and the operative level will be set each year by regulation. This is necessary because the industry wants to continue with a firm budgeted amount at the beginning of each year, and it will not be until harvest time that it knows how much rice is likely to be produced and therefore how much levy needs to be applied to achieve its result. The swings in production are so pronounced that the industry believes that this is the only way to ensure a reliable flow of finance to the vital research program. It does mean that in some years the levy may be above 0.5 per cent of annual gross value of the product. In that case anything above 0.5 per cent will not be matched by the Commonwealth.

The decision to have the levy has been arrived at by the rice growers through the thoroughly democratic means of voicing their own opinions. All the rice growers are members of the cooperative. They have therefore all had the opportunity of voting at annual meetings on this levy. There were also 170 growers present at the annual meeting of the Ricegrowers Association of Australia last month and they voted unanimously to accept the recommendation of the research and development committee to introduce this levy.

Growers realise that they are already paying the money because, while there have been voluntary levies and some funds from government through the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, the extra funds needed for a research program have come from the pool. The difference is that it will now be out in the open and the Government will match it dollar for dollar.

The rice industry is an important industry. It is a world leader in efficient production, and 85 per cent of rice grown in Australia is exported. If fair access to international markets were given to Australian rice, production could expand quite considerably because the Australian industry can compete. However, rice is subject to restrictions in international trade. Japan is well known for its rice importing restrictions, as are Taiwan and Korea. There are also restrictions in other South East Asian countries. There is a general assumption that these countries would be able to produce rice more cheaply than Australia. They cannot. The cost of production of rice in Japan and I believe also in Taiwan is three to four times that in Australia.

This raises the importance of the Uruguay Round of GATT. Our focus in these discussions tends to be on Europe and the United States. However, if there is a successful GATT round, many of the restrictions on agricultural imports to South East Asian countries would be reduced and there would be a fairer trade for Australian goods.

The Australian rice industry is subject to import competition and there are no restrictions on that. It is interesting that some of those imports are from countries which subsidise their export and from countries that do not allow our rice to be exported back to them. Hopefully, the GATT round will sort that out. The coalition supports this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The levy on rice proposed by this Bill will provide funds for research and development for the rice industry. The Bill provides for the Government to match industry levies of up to 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production from the Australian rice industry. The industry in the Riverina area of New South Wales and in Queensland produces about 800,000 to 900,000 tonnes a year with a gross value of some $148m in the year 1989-90, most of which came from exported produce. The joint Commonwealth-industry scheme the subject of this Bill will broaden the industry funding base and help in enabling the industry to reach its full potential.

PARA.TAB: The levy rate per tonne will be determined after the industry decision on the level of its bulk contribution, calculated towards the end of the harvest when likely production can be determined. Different rates may be determined for different rice varieties and rice harvested in different seasons, but the rate may not exceed $2 per tonne. The Minister has not yet set the rate and will not do so until the rates for each variety have been recommended by the two State marketing authorities.

The likely cost to the Commonwealth in matching the industry levy would be $570,000, starting in the 1991-92 year. Previously, the Government had contributed only about $203,000. So, over a couple of years, there will be a significant increase in the amount of money available for research.

As I understand the arrangements, the levy is collected pursuant to regulations under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act and then it will be distributed under the regulations adopted pursuant to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act. The Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation will have control of allocation of the moneys for research and development grants, and it is my understanding that the Corporation will allocate to the various areas of rice production moneys in accordance with the levies collected from those areas and after consultations with the industry.

My colleague Senator Tambling has explained the Bill in detail, and I will not repeat what he has said. He has also made some comments on the rice industry in the Riverina area of New South Wales. The Riverina area produces by far the largest amount of rice in Australia and is the part of the industry that most Australians are aware of. But in the few minutes that are available to me in this debate, I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate the small but significant rice producing areas of Queensland in the Burdekin and Mareeba areas of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —It grows the best rice.
—Senator MacGibbon is certainly quite correct in saying that. It is an industry that I am proud to have been associated with as a legal adviser before I came to this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Rice has been grown in Queensland on and off for over 100 years, but the modern rice industry in Queensland commenced in 1968 when a small group of farmers, under the auspices of the Lower Burdekin Development Council, commenced growing long grain rice, which had been developed in the United States. I well remember those days when there were two groups growing rice in the area—it was a very small and infant industry—and the two groups were actually competing. Each ended up building its own mill. But since those days things have settled down and there is now one organisation, one operation, in the Burdekin area.

The annual throughput in the last 10 years of the Burdekin industry was about 20,000 tonnes of paddy rice, which in domestic and international terms is very small, considering that the total Australian industry is in the range of 800,000 to 900,000 tonnes per year.

Currently there are 17 growers of rice in the Burdekin and 15 in Mareeba, which is up on the Atherton Tableland. The areas under production in the Burdekin are 2,250 hectares, and in Mareeba, 1,000 hectares. Unlike the Riverina crop, in north Queensland there are two crops each year. There is the winter crop, which is the major crop because it has better yields of 6.5 tonnes to 7 tonnes per hectare, which occur because of better weather conditions and less insect infestation at that time. Approximately 20,000 tonnes of paddy rice is produced from that crop. The summer crop has lower yields, and it is also slightly less economic because of the higher watering costs, and because of more difficulty with pests. About 7,000 to 10,000 tonnes of rice are produced in the summer season. The winter crop is planted in July-August, and the harvesting commences very soon, and goes on for a couple of months. The summer crop is planted around this time, and again goes on for a couple of months and is harvested in April and May.

Rice is milled at the Cooperative's mill at Home Hill, and it operates very efficiently and provides employment for that small rural town. The Cooperative owns all of the assets of the mill and is the sole agent to mill and market rice on behalf of the Queensland Rice Marketing Board.

Approximately 50 per cent of the income earned from the Home Hill mill will be from overseas markets such as in Mauritius, Papua New Guinea, the Pacific islands, and, indeed, the Middle East. New value-added products have been successfully launched overseas by the Cooperative, and numerous new projects are being developed. Establishing new markets is made difficult because of high tariff rates in other countries, and by competition against subsidised rice with which we compete on overseas markets. I particularly mention the Thai rice industry, which is heavily subsidised and against which we compete. Also, in Japan, of course, there is a complete ban, a prohibition against Australian rice going into that country.

In the Burdekin area, all but 180 hectares of land producing rice is new land which has been opened up following the completion of the Burdekin dam—a project which, I am pleased to say, the Fraser Government was instrumental in establishing, and which has meant such a lot to, and is such a major project for, north Queensland.

The establishment of the rice industry has considerably assisted the productivity of the land opened up as a result of the Burdekin dam. It has also enabled the land there to be used for more than one crop. Rather than concentrating on sugar for all of the land that is watered by the Burdekin dam, rice has provided an alternative crop. In times when sugar prices fall, as they have in recent times, this means that growers have the alternative of switching to rice, or increasing their involvement in rice production. The rice industry recently invested an additional 8,000 tonnes of storage in its Home Hill plant, and this will now allow an increase in the annual production by about 50 per cent.

The international rice market and trade is relatively small, because most rice produced around the world is consumed in the country of origin. Less than 5 per cent of the total world production is exported and traded on the international market. This small market, with relatively few buyers and sellers, and its demand and supply, is relatively unpredictable and variable. Every tonne of increased production from the Burdekin will be exported.

The increasing recognition that north Queensland is becoming an integral part of the Asia-Pacific region will lead to the production of varieties of rice compatible with those markets. The high cost of freight will preclude our rice being marketed in many areas. However, numerous shipping links currently operating from Townsville will create niche markets for high quality varieties of rice, for which Burdekin and Mareeba are renowned.

The Queensland rice industry is able to compete head to head against similar imported products. The industry does this in spite of enormous disadvantages that it suffers such as higher freight and labour costs than apply overseas. Of course, that is one of the things which this nation has to address in its future economic plans. As with most other primary industries, the problems which the rice industry experiences from competition from corrupt overseas markets and subsidised competition can only be addressed if Australia is able to deregulate input costs such as labour, government charges and freight and waterfront charges. The industry is not only required to compete with subsidised imports but also to export into markets in competition with subsidised competitors.

The Queensland industry, as I mentioned, ships to Papua New Guinea, Mauritius, New Caledonia, New Zealand and other Pacific islands. The industry recently cracked a lucrative export market in Papua New Guinea by introducing a line of flavoured rice which was launched in Port Moresby by the Queensland Premier in August this year. That flavoured rice resulted from some work by the International Food Institute of Queensland which assisted the industry in finding flavours and spice mixes to add to the rice for sale in Papua New Guinea. It is a very popular product in Papua New Guinea because of that flavour adding. This export market also assists dramatically the increasing trade links between north Queensland and Papua New Guinea.

Some of the problems being confronted by the industry are: the need to improve grain quality; the need to identify market requirements of particular rice varieties; the need to develop various cropping regimes to ensure long term cropping for rice; the need to identify any influx of pests and diseases which may occur due to the tropical environment in which it is grown in the north Queensland areas; the need to improve technology, especially for by-products, and to improve technology for value adding; and the need to ensure environmental security, because the Burdekin crops in particular are being grown on new lands and it is necessary to quickly identify any agronomic or pest problems that might arise on that new land.

All of these problems will be able to be investigated by the Burdekin industry or by the north Queensland industry with the funds raised as a result of the Rice Levy Act. In the past, growers have voluntarily funded research and development of improvements in their industry but the passing of this Bill will formalise and guarantee those funds and will also lead to a substantial increase in the input from the Commonwealth general revenues towards research and development in the rice industry. The Liberal Party enthusiastically supports this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to go into the Rice Levy Bill in detail because my colleague Senator Tambling has already done so. There are a number of points that need to be made in relation to the rice industry, including the importance of research and development. As everybody in this chamber would know, the rice industry falls into two parts: the New South Wales portion of the industry and the Queensland portion of the industry. The two parts of the industry have somewhat different faces because in New South Wales the emphasis is on volume production and in Queensland the emphasis has been on niche market production and on dealing with specialist areas. But both parts of the industry will benefit from an improved investment in development and research.

PARA.TAB: First of all, those players who are involved in the bulk portion of the industry—the growers from New South Wales—will benefit from improved agricultural practices, and growers in Queensland will benefit from improved research into the treatment and processing of rice. This is very important because we have got to look to our export markets, and I do not believe that we have anywhere near tapped the potential for exports of rice. I just want to deal with a couple of areas to show why this is so.

Senator Tambling has already said today that it is important that we get access to Japan, Taiwan and Korea, which at the moment impose restrictions on sales of rice to their domestic markets. We only have to look at the number of people in these countries and the amount of rice that they eat to see what a lucrative export market this is. But we should not just think in terms of the rice that is put on the table in a bowl; the rice market is much bigger than that. I want to take a personal example of the way we have to think laterally when it comes to exporting rice.

Although the people in this chamber or the people listening may not be aware of it, the Chinese community around the world has a very significant festival every year, the August Moon Festival. Part of the process of the August Moon Festival is to eat moon-cakes. Moon-cakes are made substantially from processed rice. Just think about the fact that there are 20 million people in Taiwan, every one of whom will eat at least one moon-cake every year, and one can see the enormous market for processing of the rice into forms other than table rice. We are talking of probably about five million pounds of rice being eaten in Taiwan in the form of moon-cakes in just one day of the year.

That is why it is very important that we continue to put money into research and development for the rice industry, not only so that we are and remain the most efficient producers of rice, in terms of the grain itself, but also to ensure that we, as rice producers, are also the most efficient processors of rice. This is the crux, because the rice industry, especially in Queensland, is characterised by a group of people who control the production of the rice from the farm right through to the finished product. So all the improvements in processing efficiency will be passed back directly to the growers.

This is not a situation where we are talking about the Government and the growers funding research into processing and having the profits of that processing going in whole or in part to other parties. What we are looking at is a very efficient industry, and an industry where the growers have taken control of their future.

The imminent release of coconut flavoured rice in New Zealand, where there is a large South Pacific islander population, is one of the ways that industry members are grasping hold of the potential to sell rice into niche markets and to maximise return, not just to themselves but to Australia as a whole.

There is an increasing prospect for us to sell more exports.Taiwan is facing imminent entry into GATT. We know that Taiwan's market practices, its trade practices, have not been lilywhite in the past and that Australia has been on the receiving end of them. I have said in this chamber on numerous occasions that we have to be more up-front in our relations with Taiwan, and it is still of concern to me that our somewhat unsatisfactory treatment of Taiwan as a trade partner over previous years could discriminate against Australia in this new Taiwanese market. While the Taiwanese will be breaking down the legal barriers to entry to that market, there is no reason to believe that Australian exporters of rice or beef or anything else will get preferential treatment or even equal treatment as compared with our American competitors, because, while this nation and this Government refused to support Taiwan's entry to GATT, the Americans were supporting it with alacrity.

The result will be that Australian producers and exporters may well be discriminated against—if not legally, at least culturally—in terms of business relations between the two nations. This is why it is important that Australia look to all other countries where Australia has the potential to sell exports and make sure that everything possible is done to maximise those export sales.

The measures taken in this Bill are beneficial to the industry and will be good for promoting future profitability of the industry. But there is a lot more that this Government must do in terms of international relations, especially with countries like Taiwan, and especially in its trade relations with our other neighbours in South East Asia—such as Malaysia. Even though we are the most efficient producers, the Government must ensure that we are not discriminated against and must ensure that our producers get a fair go on the international market. That is all our producers ask. That is what this Government must do, and that is what we in the National Party call upon the Government to do.
I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I am very glad to see the return of the President.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition spokesman for supporting the Bill. I thank Tweedledum and Tweedledee from far north Queensland for their contributions, which were very valuable, as usual. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the statement by the Queensland Deputy Premier, Tom Burns, on the AM program this morning. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I just think that they have made up their mind down there that they are going to continue their fights and they couldn't care less about this nation at all . . . as long as they get their way and get their mate up, that will suit them . . .

How does the Minister explain to the Australian people, particularly the further 18,900 people thrown out of work in the past four weeks by this Government's recession, that the Australian Labor Party internal leadership crisis in the Government is completely distracting it from addressing the real issues like unemployment?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all let me say, in terms of the real issues like unemployment to which Senator Hill refers, that, although there is a great deal of debate about this issue at present, the levels of unemployment were predicted in the Budget forecasts and were, in fact, predicted before the Budget. The Government recognised at that time that we would be in difficulty with unemployment for a period and that the position would rectify itself or improve in the second half of this financial year. That is the position I have put on behalf of the Government on numerous occasions here and of which Senator Hill is quite aware.

PARA.TAB: I assume that there will be a question later in Question Time about the unemployment figures. The Government takes no particular comfort from the figures released today, but they certainly do suggest a probable bottoming of the recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to another 20,000 people thrown out of work.

—The figure was double that last month. As I said, one does not take any comfort from that. The figures as projected by people like Mr Reith are far in excess of the figure released today. In so far as comments made by Mr Tom Burns and other participants in the public debate about this issue are concerned, there are plenty of opportunities within the party for carrying on these debates and that is where I think they should be confined to in the interests of the Government and in the interests of the Australian people.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The real question is: how does Senator Button explain to this extra nearly 20,000 people who have been thrown out of work in the past four weeks that, instead of focusing on their issues and the issues of employment, the Government is focusing on this internal leadership contest—in Mr Burns's terms, the Government `Couldn't care less about this nation at all . . . as long as they get their way and get their mate up, that will suit them'—rather than facing up to its responsibilities as a government?
—That question involves an allegation, a subjective judgment, by Senator Hill about this issue, one which he seeks politically to make, and I understand that.
—Burns is one of yours.

—I have already declined to comment on what Mr Burns said and I have nothing to add to that. I do not want to enter into the particular remarks made by particular people in a debate which, in my view, should have been private.
—Tell Keating that. Keating is the one who is going public all the time.

—I have already answered a question about that. I think that Senator Kemp asked it, but he probably would not remember. The allegation which is made by Senator Hill in the course of the supplementary question is that the Government has suddenly started to neglect these issues. He relates that to unemployment.

PARA.TAB: I made the point earlier that months ago these unemployment figures were predicted as a consequence of the recession. Senator Hill is now seeking to capture some marginal political benefit from the deprivations which are imposed on people by unemployment by relating it to this issue, and I do not think he can do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given that Minister Beazley has proposed an inquiry to look into the possible establishment of a new free to air television station, could the Minister inform the Senate of what such a station could provide to the Australian public if it is to differ from existing stations?

—The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided me with the following information. The Minister anticipates that the new service could provide a range of non-commercial television services, including community access television, educational television, and televising of parliamentary proceedings—and that would have to be non-commercial—and an additional outlet for independent film producers.

PARA.TAB: Community access or public television means television services run on a non-profit basis by community based groups in the same form as public radio. Public television groups have been active in Australia for many years and have been able to conduct test programs since 1988. In general, the programming of public television has a strong emphasis on education, information and arts and is different from mainstream services.

Curriculum based educational services are not generally available on television. The use of broadcast television to provide these services and training programs directly to homes will reach individuals who have not previously been regular users of educational or training services. At present only Question Time is regularly televised by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, with extracts being occasionally used in news programs by other broadcasters. This channel could provide an additional means of televising parliamentary proceedings which does not compete for time with current services. The establishment of this channel as a non-commercial service could also provide exposure for the product of low budget program makers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to another aspect of the interview on the AM program this morning with Mr Burns, a former Federal President of the Australian Labor Party and now the Deputy Premier of Queensland. I quote Mr Burns as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I think what stands between Mr Keating and the Lodge is Mr Keating's performance as a Minister, as a Treasurer.
Does the Minister agree with Mr Burns and, if not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall, from just a brief reading of what Mr Burns said, that he said that Mr Keating had much to contribute to the Government. Senator Durack has omitted that part of Mr Burns's comment from what he has had to say. This Government collectively has agreed, has said publicly, that in terms of the longevity of the recession errors were made in 1990 by the Government. We have said that here, on numerous occasions I have been asked questions about it and it has also been said in public debate. Mr Keating was the Treasurer at the time and, as such, would share in that responsibility.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That leaves unanswered the question: does the Minister believe that that is what is standing between Mr Keating and the Lodge? If not, why not?

—That is a matter upon which I do not wish to comment. I have already indicated the position in answer to the substantial part of the question. I have already indicated that Senator Durack, in asking the question, left out some very important points in what Mr Burns said.

—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise what impact the waterfront reform program is having upon the efficiency of grain handling at our ports and how this affects the grain industry?

—I have advised the Senate previously that the reforms in labour arrangements for the stevedoring of bulk grain vessels have been significant under the waterfront reform program. These resulted in substantial reductions in shipboard labour requirements of between 50 per cent and 80 per cent in the middle of last year.
—You have got into Hansard, Nick.
—Senator Walters might like to hear what the Australian Wheat Board said about this yesterday.
—I have read it in the newspapers.
—Senator Walters obviously did not like it much then, and she will have it inflicted on her a second time.
—He is a big wheat farmer down there!

—I would have thought Senator Panizza, as a grain farmer, would have been pleased about this. The Australian Wheat Board recently publicised its assessment of the benefit to the grain industry flowing from these reforms and the industry's complementary investment in labour saving technology. I think it is important to place this on the public record of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Some of the gains listed by the Australian Wheat Board include a 50 per cent reduction in the cost of grain stevedoring nationally and a reduction of 70 per cent of the work force in grain terminals. Since 1988-89 the time taken to turn around grain vessels at Australian ports has been cut in half. This is the average figure, and the Australian Wheat Board describes the improvements at some ports as being more spectacular. For example, it cites Newcastle, where ship turnaround time has gone from five days to 1.6 days. The overall savings to the industry are estimated currently to be at least $10m annually.

The Wheat Board's Managing Director, John Lawrenson, comments that these excellent results are a direct benefit of the industry's constructive participation in the reform process. Instead of sitting on the sidelines and abusing the waterfront parties, as Mr Sharp continues to do, the AWB was prepared to cooperate with them and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority in the direct negotiation of the changes. I have given the Wheat Board public credit for this before.

This will obviously cause the shadow Minister for shipping and the Opposition a great deal of heartburn, given their reaction to the improvements in waterfront reform, which they have just responded to by continued carping criticism. I conclude by quoting the Australian Wheat Board's public statement. It said, `Australian ports are now among the most efficient grain loading ports in the world'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of a report in the Australian Financial Review of 4 November regarding fast tracking of projects which identifies a number of problems regarding this new move? In the light of that report, I ask: what reason can the Minister provide for giving preferred treatment to projects worth more than $100m over projects worth less, especially where smaller ventures may also value add exports and provide much needed jobs? Secondly, as the report indicates that many projects are still in the feasibility stage, how many realistically will get off the ground in the next 12 months and how many jobs will be created? Thirdly, in view of the report's assertion that most projects proceed under State legislation and regulation and that there is little scope for action or intervention by the Federal Government, what direct steps will the Government take to solve this apparent impasse with the States, given that the Prime Minister's vision of Commonwealth-State relations appears to be dead on arrival?
—Was that a question without notice?

—I thank Senator Newman very much. Senator Sowada asked her question in three parts. The first part asked how the new 45-day proposal would work. It would certainly not work if Ministers were swamped with proposals from a variety of small businesses around Australia; and it certainly would not work if Ministers were swamped with businesses throughout Australia contemplating investments of $80m or $90m. The whole process would be log jammed, as it were, by applications of that kind.

PARA.TAB: The process is concerned essentially about major projects in the resource processing industries. All of those involve substantial investments of undoubtedly in excess of $100m. In terms of smaller companies, to make it a workable system it has to be confined to larger investments. I make the point that larger investments carry with them all sorts of benefits for smaller companies because there are all sorts of service companies and supplier companies involved in any large investment project.

Senator Sowada then asked how many projects will get off the ground in the next 12 months and what will be the employment implications in respect of those projects. It is, of course, too early to say that. We have tried to set up a process which will facilitate some of these things. If that process is helpful in facilitation, a significant number of projects could well go ahead. I am unable to say what the employment implications of those projects will be, except to say that in the construction phase the employment implications are usually significant; in the longer term, direct employment in these projects is not very high. The indirect employment, of course, is very significant in terms of service industries of one kind or another—transport industries and things of that kind.

The third part of the question is, I think, a bit of a desperate effort by a new senator to fire her initial shot at the Prime Minister. I congratulate her on the ingenuity of it. The Government, of course, recognises that between State and Federal processes, and indeed in local government processes, there are overlapping bureaucracies which add to the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave local government alone.

—No, we do not leave local government aside. If Senator Panizza has any particular affection for local government I suggest that he espouse it elsewhere. There are plenty of local government regulations that affect investments in particular industries, businesses and so on.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the third part of the question, in terms of its being a facilitative process, it may help in getting some redirection away from layers of bureaucracy to deal with these processes more quickly. I think that is a very important thing to do. During the week I saw—I am sorry I do not have it with me—a three-page document from one of the States which looked like a printed circuit board. It was a diagrammatic exposure of what processes had to be gone through in that State. Trying to get that sort of issue resolved is part of the facilitating process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and I take the point regarding the first part of my question on the volume of projects under $100m. I really do not see that an arbitrary level of $100m should prevent the Government assessing projects worth, say, between $55m and $99m. Could the Minister explain why that would be a problem?
—I thought I had already done that. If Senator Sowada would like me to take her through it privately afterwards I will try to do so.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the strategy of the third runway and the staged development of Badgerys Creek still the most economically sound approach to meeting Sydney's future airport needs? What are the implications of proceeding immediately with a major airport at Badgerys Creek?

—The answer is yes. There continues to be a very significant amount of public coverage of the critics of the third runway. This issue has been raised again in today's press. We are told that the EIS fails to make out an economic case for the third runway and a new investigation and a new cost benefit analysis are advocated. The authors of these recent articles on the economic impact of the third runway have not thoroughly examined either the draft EIS or the supplement to it.
—Do you think they are political?
—We all are. The issues they raise have been dealt with very thoroughly indeed by both of these documents.

PARA.TAB: The EIS itself contains a comprehensive evaluation of the alternatives to the Government's strategy of construction of the third runway and the staged development of Badgerys Creek. The EIS clearly shows that this strategy results in the most cost-effective provision of airport capacity in terms of construction costs per passenger; lower airport construction costs in net present value terms than the Badgerys Creek alternatives; and a reduction of average annual delays at Kingsford-Smith Airport by a total of 127,000 hours, resulting in savings to airline operators and, therefore, their passengers of around $640m per annum. An amount of $320m for the construction of the third runway and associated work will be needed to get this benefit. I stress that again: a construction cost of $320m and annual savings to the industry and, therefore, the flying public of $640m. That is not a bad investment.

The third runway will also result in a lesser number of people being seriously affected by noise compared with the alternatives of a substantial domestic airport at Badgerys Creek. The comparisons are 26,900 with the third runway as compared with 34,800 without it.

The supplement also reviewed the Coopers and Lybrand cost-benefit comparison between the third runway and a substantial domestic airport at Badgerys Creek, prepared as part of the airport coordinating task force submission to the draft EIS. The review found that there was a net benefit of over $1 billion in favour of the third runway, as compared with $17m found by the Coopers and Lybrand study. Moreover, this review included an assessment of loss of social amenity due to aircraft noise and found a noise cost penalty of $98m for the immediate construction of a domestic airport at Badgerys Creek.

The EIS demonstrates that an airport at Badgerys Creek is unlikely to be commercially viable, as I have said before, until 2005 to 2010. Consequently, the immediate development of a regular public transport airport would need to be funded by the Australian taxpayer. In contrast, the third runway has been assessed by the FAC to be a commercially viable proposition on the basis of its own investment criteria and would be totally funded in a normal commercial manner by the FAC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the following comment by the Queensland Deputy Premier, Mr Tom Burns, recorded this morning on the AM program:

QUESTION.PARA: It has taken the Queensland Government years to fix up the problems that he—

He further said that Senator Richardson `ran away from the rank and file' up in Ravenshoe; and that `Over some of his policies, he was run out of town in Queensland for some of the things he did'. Mr Burns went on to say that he—Mr Burns—was sent back with some of his colleagues to `tidy the thing up'. I ask the Minister: first, why was he run out of town in Queensland by the rank and file of the ALP? Secondly, what had to be `tidied up' in Ravenshoe by Mr Burns and his colleagues after the Minister had `run away'? Thirdly, what have Mr Burns and the Queensland Government done to assist in fixing up the problems in Ravenshoe? Fourthly, is there anything else the Minister might like to say about Mr Burns and the Queensland ALP?

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the last one first.

—Do not worry, I will get to the last one. Let me take the questions in order; I hope I do not miss any out. I made a speech last night in which I touched upon a number of matters, including unemployment, but I did not actually refer to World Heritage. As to whether I was run out of town in north Queensland, many millions of people, not only here but also in Great Britain and the USA, saw me getting run out of town in Ravenshoe during what was a pretty disgraceful incident. Six Queensland policemen, urged on by the former Premier, sat on a car and watched what was happening. I do not think there were any members of the ALP in the crowd.
—How do you know?
—I am not aware of a really active Labor Party branch in Ravenshoe; I do not know whether some of my Queensland colleagues can correct me on that but I suspect there are not too many.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, when one takes a decision on World Heritage which will affect the livelihood of some hundreds of people and their families, tensions will rise. I took the view that, whether or not tensions were going to be high, I ought to go there and I have been back twice since then.

As a result of the concerns expressed to me, not just in Ravenshoe but across north Queensland, I took a package to Cabinet to give a boost to north Queensland, specifically Ravenshoe. That package involved some millions of dollars for the continuance of a mill. The money appears to have gone south and the jobs appear to have gone west.

That having been the case, the Government has been negotiating for some time with a potential purchaser of the mill in north Queensland. In the last couple of days it has announced, thankfully, that those negotiations have come to a successful conclusion. So the mill will reopen very shortly and it will again employ people in Ravenshoe.

In response to the very many requests that I have had from the honourable member for Kennedy, Mr Rob Hulls, and some geeing up from Senator Macdonald, I have organised for a meeting between me, Minister Kelly and some people from the forest industries. Those people will be able to speak to Mrs Kelly further about the question of the unsecured creditors in the town of Ravenshoe. I think that meeting takes place next week or the week after. I cannot recall the date but, naturally enough, I shall report on progress.

As to what the Queensland Government might have done to tidy up or fix up or whatever expressions are used in north Queensland, all I can say is that fortunately—given that it is a Labor government—it has undone the policies of the previous Queensland Government and has agreed to cooperate in the management of the World Heritage area. It will be running the management of that World Heritage area in conjunction with the Commonwealth. That strikes me as being a great thing.

As to anything else that Mr Burns may or may not have done in Ravenshoe, Senator Macdonald had better ask him. I cannot speak for all that the Queensland Government may or may not have done there. But I am certain that, given the competent government that it is and given the competent Minister that Tom Burns is, whatever it has done will have been for the betterment of people in north Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why the Government has decided to rejoin the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation, which is more often known as UNIDO, after withdrawing from that organisation in 1987?

—Australia's decision to withdraw from UNIDO was taken after an assessment of the administrative and operational effectiveness of the organisation, weighed against Australian priorities in funding multilateral organisations. Since 1987, however, UNIDO has established a reputation for the efficient and effective delivery of development programs and it has implemented and committed itself to a policy of zero real growth budgets.

PARA.TAB: In the 1991-92 Budget context, the Government accordingly reconsidered the question of our membership and was able to announce an allocation of funds to resume membership from 1 January 1992. This decision and the rejoining of UNIDO will complement Australia's foreign policy and our economic and trade objectives as well. Specifically, it will reaffirm our strong commitment to multilateralism and international cooperation for development; it will reinforce the Government's industry policy objectives to increase efficiency, international competitiveness and the export orientation of Australian manufacturing industries; and it will enable Australia to influence industry development strategies, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister explain why, if he remains loyal to Mr Hawke, the man who is to lead Labor into the next election—a statement the honourable senator has made publicly—he continues to fuel leadership speculation by making increasingly supportive comments about Paul Keating and increasingly derogatory statements about his critics, while refusing to condemn Mr Keating's attacks?
—Order! I do not really think there is anything in that question which relates to the portfolio of the Minister for Social Security. If he wishes to answer it he can; it is up to him.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Standing Orders make it clear that questions can be directed to matters of public interest and public importance. I would have thought, if Senator Richardson is going to wander around talking about everything but social security and doing everything but the job he is paid to do, at the very least we ought to be able to question him about some of the activities he has been undertaking which are crucial to the reasons why the Government is wallowing at the present time.

—Mr President, on the same point of order: on many occasions when questions from our side have implied even a discussion of Opposition policy Senator Alston has been the first person to jump to his feet. Any question must have some relevance to the portfolio of the Minister who is asked the question. Question Time is not a political general knowledge quiz.
—Mr President, could I just refer you to—

—Order! Past rulings have consistently stated that there must be an area of ministerial responsibility in the question. I said to Senator Richardson that he himself could determine whether he answered the question, which is the position that applies to every Minister and every question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. What you have done, Mr President, is not permit Senator Alston to put the answer to Senator Ray before you made your decision. Is there some reason why you did not want to hear the argument from this side of the chamber?

—Order! I heard two points of order and I can make a ruling at any time; I do not necessarily have to listen to every point of order. The question was clearly out of order and, as I have said, has been ruled on consistently in the past. That is the way I made the ruling.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek a ruling from you in light of standing order 72, which provides that at any time `questions may be put to Ministers relating to public affairs'. Are you ruling that it is not a matter of public affairs to ask a question which goes to the heart of the way in which this Government is being run or not being run and the way in which Ministers choose to conduct themselves?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have given a ruling. I refer honourable senators to page 306 of Australian Senate Practice. I will not read it all, but it states:

INTERJECT.PARA: On 18 March 1976, President Sir Condor Laucke ruled that questions must relate to matters within Ministerial responsibility.
