He allowed a question to go through to the Minister on the understanding that the Minister might reply only insofar as he considered it his responsibility in any area covered by the question.
That is a ruling I have carried out consistently ever since I have been the President of the Senate. Senator Richardson, do you wish to answer the question?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I don't.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You just read from the Australian Senate Practice. You did say that former President Laucke had also indicated that it was an area of his responsibility.
—He did not. Why don't you listen?

—Why did the Minister not listen to what the President read? Mr President, I believe Senator Richardson's behaviour is certainly part of his responsibility and, as such, I believe it does fall within the Standing Orders and is in accordance with Odgers's Australian Senate Practice.

—Order! There is no point of order. I suggest that if people want to canvass this issue I can bring down a statement later. But Senator Richardson indicated that he does not want to answer the question and it is clearly within his area of responsibility to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen a recent report concerning safety standards for fibreglass insulation? Does this report indicate that at a recent public meeting Mr Richard Munson from California claimed that fibreglass is carcinogenic to humans and poses a significant risk to members of the Australian work force? Can the Minister inform honourable senators whether Mr Munson's claim is soundly based? Can he further inform the Senate what is the situation regarding the safety of fibreglass and what is being done to address the problems, if any, associated with the product?

—Yes, I have seen the article in the Canberra Times of 4 November entitled `Fibreglass debate for Cup day forum' in which—I might say, in somewhat unduly respectful tones—we are informed that an American expert has an opinion on fibreglass. I do not know why the nationality of this so-called expert as an American should somehow elevate that person to a higher status than that of any other expert, but if one reads the column one seems to see a worshipful tone in the comments about this so-called expert.
—It sounds like Hawkie talking about Mr Bush, doesn't it.

—I do not know that the honourable senator would know anything about that. The expert is a Mr Richard Munson. What is not well known is that Mr Munson is also a consultant to a competitor product to fibreglass: a cellulose based product which is, ironically, a product mixed with borax—which, of course, is a highly toxic substance. Therefore, I think one needs to examine the comments by Mr Munson about the so-called carcinogenic properties of fibreglass against the background of his consultancy.

PARA.TAB: However, I thank Senator Beahan for the question. I am aware of the meeting that occurred in Sydney on Melbourne Cup day. This meeting involved representatives of the fibreglass industry and relevant unions and experts from my own agency—the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, Worksafe Australia. The purpose of the meeting was to hear what Mr Munson had to say and to clarify what was being done in Australia in relation to those claims.

The Government is well aware that exposure to synthetic mineral fibre, which includes fibreglass, can be a significant occupational health and safety issue. As a result of the concerns raised in Australia in 1987 regarding such products, Worksafe Australia commissioned a comprehensive expert review on the degree of worker exposure to these products and the health effects which may arise from such exposures. Following consideration of this report, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission declared a national exposure standard of 0.5 respirable fibres per millilitre of air for all forms of synthetic mineral fibre. This standard is the most stringent standard for this product anywhere in the world.

At the same time, the National Commission declared a code of practice which provides advice on eliminating or controlling hazards associated with fibreglass and other forms of synthetic mineral fibre in the workplace. The Commission, Worksafe, is of the view that if the safe work practices outlined in this code are followed they will ensure that there will be no ill-effects from exposure to synthetic mineral fibres in the Australian work force. I am pleased to advise that most States have adopted or are in the process of adopting this national standard and the code of practice that goes with it.

Mr Munson's claim that fibreglass is as lethal as asbestos was reported in the media earlier this year as a result of his previous visit to Australia in June. In response to those claims, on 3 July Worksafe convened a forum of independent experts to address concerns associated with the use of fibreglass in Australia. The experts unanimously concluded that any allegation that fibreglass is as lethal as asbestos is wrong, misleading and likely to cause undue anxiety in the community. They also said that, provided handling procedures as outlined in the code are followed, there is no risk to health from the use of fibreglass.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, who also, by the way, supports Mr Keating's push for power. Does the Minister's parliamentary colleague the honourable member for Blaxland yet have an acceptable vision for the environment in Australia? If so, when will it be articulated in accordance with Mr Toyne's invitation to Mr Keating to provide his alternative vision of the future of Australia, particularly in view of Mr Toyne's claim that Mr Hawke was only offering the rhetoric of change, not change itself? Will the Minister, the Minister he represents or her departmental officials be available to Mr Keating to work on developing a policy to attract green support?

—I have to say that I am quite happy to answer this question as the person representing Mrs Kelly and not as the person representing the honourable member for Blaxland. I was asked about whether Mr Keating has an acceptable vision for the environment. I do not intend to respond to that.

PARA.TAB: In terms of whether the Prime Minister was only offering the rhetoric of change, the Government's environment record since 1983 speaks for itself. It is second to none. It involves saving a range of resources from rainforests in north Queensland and wild rivers and 400-year-old trees in Tasmania to the stunning beauty of places like Shark Bay. Every single decision was opposed by those opposite. As far as I am concerned, I welcome anyone who wants to examine the record of this Government on the environment and who wants to compare it with that of the Opposition because the contrast will be stark. For those who are interested, let me say that during last night's speech I referred to one thing, and that was the enemy being the same enemy. I said it was a cold, cruel and vicious enemy, and I said that it was the Liberal Party.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for that non-answer and once again refer him to Mr Toyne's comments where Mr Toyne said:

QUESTION.PARA: What I find crushingly disappointing, however, is that he—
fails to go on and give his vision of what should be.

I ask the Minister once again whether he has any knowledge of the development of any vision for Australia and whether he has continued his close personal association with Mr Toyne which marked his period as environment Minister. What assistance is he giving Mr Keating in this area?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can speak for anything in which Phillip Toyne is crushingly disappointed. I am not sure of his list of crushing disappointments. They certainly are not part of my ministerial responsibility. I am quite sure that Phillip Toyne and I have remained, and will continue to remain, friends for a very long time. Whatever he wants to say to Mr Keating, I invite him to do so directly. It has naught to do with me or the Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and deals with the latest unemployment figures and the maintenance of standards of living. Has the Minister seen the latest unemployment figures, which indicate that the number of discouraged job seekers has risen and that the number of people looking for work has fallen, mainly because of women giving up the search for part time jobs? Has the Minister seen a report earlier this year of a study by researchers at Flinders University where one researcher, Dr Travers, indicated that real wages have declined so that people are working harder for less by virtue of the fact that the spouse has had to get an income to make ends meet? Do the latest figures mean that the recession is hitting hardest those women in those families? What will the Government do to redress that situation?

—Senator Harradine has asked a number of questions. Let me say first of all that he is right in drawing attention to the change in the participation rate, as it is called, which he referred to as discouraged job seekers—-
—That is one side of the question.

—Yes. The participation rate fell by 0.3 per cent to 63 per cent. It was 64.2 per cent last July, so there has been that change in this period. I have not read the paper prepared by the gentleman at Flinders University, but I will seek to obtain a copy of it. I may then be able to comment on the other issues raised in Senator Harradine's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the article by Laura Tingle in the Australian last Monday, 4 November, in which, amongst other things, she claimed in respect of the reduction of interest rates in September this year:

QUESTION.PARA: The pressure—conveyed to the Reserve Bank by the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, but widely understood by policy makers and advisers to be flowing from the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and his advisers—was designed to get a cut in interest rates in place before a crucial meeting of the Labor Caucus in early September.

I ask the Minister whether the article is correct, including whether the Treasurer's action resulted from pressure on him from the Prime Minister to circumvent the normal processes in the setting of monetary policy and in advance of the September meeting by the Reserve Bank board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Treasurer has already made some comment about this matter. I will seek to obtain a copy of that comment for Senator Short and advise him of it as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the further deterioration in the level of employment evidenced by today's unemployment figures, I ask the Minister: does the Government agree that the proposal put forward by the former Treasurer to grant assistance to businesses which increase their stock levels would yield 40,000 jobs in the short term? Is this proposal on the Government's quick fix list?

—I have not seen that proposal fleshed out in any detail. I have seen the costing of it of $300m, which was provided gratuitously; it is a very costly amount. Not having seen the proposal in detail, I cannot comment in detail, but I would have some very grave qualifications about that proposal because it would impact on the Australian economy probably for two quarters and is not a sustaining thing through a period of recovery.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I would have qualifications about it because the pattern of stockholding in Australian industry has changed significantly in the last few years. For example, many industries and companies operate on just in time systems and those companies which use just in time systems would not get the benefit of all the effort they have put into that under the proposal which Senator Kernot has referred to. Other companies which have been less—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a very supportive statement for your man.
—I am dealing with an issue; Senator Macdonald ought to try it some time.
—It is a chance for you to give him a bit of a free kick along. He needs it.

—Senator Macdonald has been playing the man during Question Time and before. He should try to deal with a few issues occasionally. I am dealing with the issues and I think he understands what I am saying. Senator Kernot has an intelligent interest in this matter, even if Senator Macdonald does not.I would have qualifications about it for that reason. I think it would probably be inequitable between sectors of industry and between companies.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Is the Minister aware of the decision by the CSIRO to place in mothballs for at least 12 months its sophisticated $16m fisheries research vessel, the Southern Surveyor, only 14 months after the vessel was originally commissioned? Further, is the Minister aware that both the CSIRO and Tasmania's professional fishermen have condemned the shortage of Federal funds which has caused the dilemma and placed in jeopardy an orange roughy fishery worth millions of dollars to our nation's economy? Does the Government consider it acceptable for a $16m taxpayer investment to be tied up for 12 months, or will the Government consider a reallocation of Federal funds to allow the Southern Surveyor to return to the ocean and its invaluable work? What assurances can the Government give the taxpayers of this country that this outrageous waste will not be allowed to occur?

—I did not know about that, but I will find out about it for Senator Calvert so far as the facts are concerned. I will deal with the pejorative parts of his question, namely, that it will prejudice a great industry like the orange roughy industry. Senator Calvert knows better than that. He knows better than I do that the orange roughy industry in Tasmania has had a very chequered career for all sorts of reasons which have not been associated with research. If I might say so, he gilds the lily a bit with his question. In relation to the facts, I will obtain an answer for him as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister comment on a variety of industrial relations policies which could open the door to greater vulnerability and exploitation of workers with poor bargaining strength? How would that help the Australian economy? Does there appear to be support in Australia for the industrial relations legislation of New Zealand and New South Wales?

—Given the clues in this question I can only imagine that Senator Giles is referring me to the Opposition's industrial relations policy. If one needs to identify a policy which opens the door to exploitation of ordinary Australian workers, that is, indeed, the policy that will do it. One of the problems with the policy is that Mr Howard has never actually made a full statement of all the details of it. He constantly tells us that this is a prime and key Opposition policy; that this is a policy that sets the Opposition apart from the Government; but he has never declared, and still declines to declare, what exactly that policy is.

PARA.TAB: One can only believe that he has taken a leaf from the book of the Leader of the Opposition who, at the National Press Club recently, said that it is his preference to declare these things at the eleventh hour. Therefore, I imagine that this distinctly different policy may be visited upon the electorate at the eleventh hour, just before the election, so that no-one in the field of industrial relations or the wider community can look at a comprehensive declaration of policy from the Opposition. If it is so good and if it is so different I say to Mr Howard, `Let us see it. Stop hiding your light under a bushel. Stop hiding behind platitudes. Stop hiding behind homilies. Stop hiding behind anonymous and unproven examples'. What we do know from what Mr Howard says is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.
—Dance down the pitch.

—Over the fence, too. Mr President, the Minister has had sufficient opportunity to address a serious question in the worst possible way because Standing Orders do not allow him to answer a question that asks for an expression of opinion. I would have thought that this was simply a very crude attempt to invite the Minister to comment on Opposition policies about which, presumably, he knows nothing because he is complaining that he has not been made aware of them. Therefore, I invite you to rule that that is not a proper question and not a proper answer.

—Order! If I recall correctly, the question asked the Minister to compare the industrial relations records of governments in New Zealand and New South Wales and asked whether this Federal Government would implement them. In that way the question was in order. I remind the Minister that that was the original question.

—Mr President, thank you for that summary of the question. I think it is an accurate summary of the question. The short answer is, not over my dead body. We will not enact policies that are similar to that of the New Zealand Government or the New South Wales Government. We will not do it for the reason that the policies of both those governments are aimed at setting aside the award system in Australia; aimed at setting aside the role of the Industrial Relations Commission; and aimed at diminishing the role and the purpose of trade unions.

PARA.TAB: It is a form of bargaining which the Opposition and the New Zealand Government hold to be fair in which an employer negotiates directly with a single employee for a so-called voluntary employment contract. One can hardly say that this is a meeting of equals. The bargaining power of the employee versus that of an employer—particularly in times of high unemployment like now—is hardly an example of fair dealing and, in fact, is an example of inviting exploitation. Indeed, that is what is happening in New Zealand and what will happen in New South Wales.

I conclude by saying that there are a number of things about the New Zealand and New South Wales industrial relations changes that could be canvassed in this chamber, but if one takes all the alterations together and comes to the bottom line, the bottom line is an industrial relations system that will drive the New Zealand economy further into recession and one that will cause the dispute level in New South Wales—which is already the highest per capita in Australia—to rise even higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Defence. I refer to this Government's proposal to the US that Australia take over and operate the North West Cape facility. How much will a takeover cost? What are the annual operating costs of the base? Will this funding come from the existing defence vote? Will the operating costs come from the existing budget? What will the effect be on the employment of Australian citizens presently living at the base? What will happen to those Australians who have been encouraged by the previous Defence Minister, Mr Beazley, to buy homes in Exmouth and who will now find themselves unemployed and in a real estate market where they are unable to sell their homes?

—There are a lot of presumptions in Senator Crichton-Browne's question which slightly colour any answers that I give. The present position is that the United States Government and the Australian Government have been negotiating over the transition from American to Australian control of the North West Cape. The most recent set of negotiations was completed some time in October. It is expected that in the near future there will be an exchange of letters between Secretary Chaney and me to finalise that agreement. Initially that was to have been signed at the Ausmin talks. Then we had the Bush visit substituted for the Ausmin talks, and Senator Crichton-Browne would realise that at the moment there is no formal process in that sense. It will be by an exchange of letters.

PARA.TAB: The funding for the North West Cape will come out of the existing defence budget. I cannot give an absolutely accurate total of running costs currently because the US picks up a fair bit of it, and the way it breaks up its programs makes it impossible to put a total running cost on it. I would expect that an Australian operation would be cheaper, but we have yet to determine whether we will be contracting out a lot of those functions to civilians. Until we make that decision I cannot give a figure for future running costs.

I might say, as I indicated to Senator Durack during the debate on Estimates in the Committee of the Whole, that I am more than delighted with the way negotiations have gone with the United States. Some of the claims as to the cost, either in residual value or otherwise, that have been bandied around in newspapers have not transpired. I think that the deal that we are about to enter into with the United States is one that is very good for Australia.

The honourable senator also asked about the consequences for housing. We cannot go to those consequences until we establish staffing levels and determine how many will be civilian and how many will be military. Also, wherever possible we are keeping our eye, from a defence point of view, on any other projects in the area—there are one or two floating around—that continue to see the expansion of the township. It would be a matter of concern to the locals that, with the Americans moving out and vacating a number of houses—I am not sure how many, but certainly scores of houses—this could have a depressing effect on the property market. We will keep that in mind. Indeed, though, if we do contract out it will mean more civilians being employed who, presumably, can take up the housing opportunities in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What are the other projects to which the Minister referred? Also, what percentage of the 450 Americans will be replaced by Australians, whether they be defence personnel or civilians, and when will the terms of the agreement be announced?

—Virtually all the 450 Americans will be replaced over time. Once the exchange of letters occurs, I will make a statement—I think it will be a parliamentary statement in this case—as to the terms and conditions. I will also make sure that a senior officer, probably at least at two-star level of the Navy, briefs the Western Australian Government, the Opposition and the consultative council we have set up as to the future of North West Cape.
—When is that likely to be?
—I am hoping some time in December, but sometimes these things take time to reach the desks of both of us, and it really relies on both of us having to sign it.
—Are there any other projects?

—In terms of the other projects, I do not want to detail their exact nature. There is one civilian communications project, for which North West Cape is a prime candidate at the moment, amongst a couple of others in the world. I do not want to raise expectations unduly by going into detail in case it does not transpire.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 4 September, Senator Chapman asked me as Minister representing the Treasurer a question about taxation on lump sum termination payments. The Treasurer has supplied a somewhat long and complex answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Up to 30 June 1991, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission had received approximately 335,000 notifications of benefits paid for which determinations were required to be made and sent to benefit recipients. Approximately 220,000 of them had been notified by 30 April.

The Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations provide that the Commission is to issue determinations by 30 June 1991, in respect of benefits notified by 30 April, and within 60 days of notification in respect of benefits notified thereafter.

Due to computer difficulties, there was some delay in issuing these determinations. Nevertheless, by 19 July over 172,000 determinations had been issued with a further 137,000 being sent to benefit recipients in early August. By 9 August, approximately 310,000 determinations had been issued in respect of notifications received up to 30 June 1991.

A substantial number of notifications in respect of benefits paid out in 1990-91 were received in July and August. Some of these notifications were late because they were made after the prescribed notification date.

A total of 490,000 determinations out of 515,000 required for 1990-91 have been issued to date and most of the remainder will be issued in the week commencing 4 November. This essentially completes the "first round" determinations for 1990-91 including those for notifications received late after 30 June 1991.
The Commission has also commenced processing the 75,000 determinations returned with an application for amendment. These will be progressively handled over the next few weeks.

In many cases the information provided to the Commission by payers of benefits was inadequate or incorrect. This resulted in over 56,000 cases to be resolved by time consuming validation and, in a few cases manual name matching, programs.

The Treasurer is aware that some people were facing hardship because they could not lodge their tax returns until they received determinations. The Commission has addressed this problem by dealing with them as special one-off cases.

The Commission has special arrangements with the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that no penalties apply for late lodgment of tax returns because of delays in issuing determinations. Taxpayers simply have to quote a reference number provided by the Commission.
In respect of 1991-92 and subsequent financial years, determinations will be issued before the end of the financial year so that the delays experienced in the last few months should not occur again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following a question yesterday from Senator O'Chee, I have a supplementary answer. The honourable senator asked me whether I had received any communication from the Consul-General in Shanghai about Senator Burns's discussion with a journalist on the subject of Tiananmen Square and, if so, whether I would table that communication. I am able to inform the honourable senator that a cable was received last Friday, 1 November. Having regard to freedom of information principles, I am prepared to table that cable, and I do so now.

PARA.TAB: Let me add this in further elaboration of the answer: Senator O'Chee was quite wrong in claiming, as he did in a press release issued on Tuesday which I have only just seen, that as a result of this communication from Shanghai, or indeed any other communication, I or my office knew of the alleged comments by Senator Burns before publication of the article in question, which appeared last Friday, 1 November. The first that I or my office knew of any discussion between Senator Burns and the journalist in question was after the fact, after the publication of the article in question, when the story in the Courier-Mail had been faxed to my office, later on the day of publication.

What happened then was that my office made a quick check by telephone with the Australian Consul-General in Shanghai to see whether he had any further information, in Senator Burns's continued absence from Australia, as to what the true story of the report may have been. My office was informed that a conversation between Senator Burns and the journalist had taken place at a reception at the Australian Consulate on 30 October, two days earlier. The Consul was unaware of the details of the conversation in question. The article was faxed to him by my office. He had a subsequent conversation with the journalist later that day, and also later that day the cable I am now tabling, confirming the substance of the conversation between my office and the Consul, was sent back to Canberra by the Consul.

I repeat: for Senator O'Chee to claim—and this seems to lie behind his question yesterday—that I somehow knew of these comments before they appeared in the press, which, by the way, Senator Burns has already said are not an accurate reflection of what he said, is to grossly distort the situation. There is nothing in the Hansard record that would give rise to the suggestion Senator O'Chee makes, nor is there any other factual foundation for it, and I suggest that it would be appropriate that he apologise.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on a proposal to amend the National Capital Plan, dated September 1991. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to provide the Government's response to the recommendations of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in its Report on a proposal to amend the National Capital Plan dated September 1991.

The National Capital Planning Authority has proposed an amendment to the National Capital Plan to encourage the redevelopment of Canberra City Sections 10, 37 and 62, which includes land presently occupied by the Civic Pool, the YMCA, the Olympic Bowl, the Army Training Centre and the ACT Government Engineering Depot. In particular, the amendment provides for office development on Section 10 and protects Section 37 for recreational and other uses compatible with the Civic Pool.

On 23 April 1991 I referred the proposal to amend the National Capital Plan to the Committee for consideration. In its Report the Committee supported the proposed amendment and confirmed that it provided a basis for redevelopment within the area in a manner consistent with the heritage and recreational value of this important area of the National Capital. However, the Committee made some recommendations on specific planning matters.
The Committee's four key recommendations have been accepted by the Government and reflected in the final amendment to the National Capital Plan. These recommendations were that:
'Offices' be permitted on that part of Section 10 not presently occupied by the Amdahl Building;
'Administrative Use' should be removed from the range of uses permitted on Section 37 and that such
uses within the study area be confined to Section 10;
the Civic Pool and its landscape setting remain the dominant use on Section 37; and
the Development Condition requiring `a strong built edge to Constitution Avenue' be removed.
There are 17 other recommendations that have either been accepted, accepted in principle or accepted in part. Only one recommendation has not been accepted at this time.

Three recommendations support the decentralisation of Commonwealth office employment. Although these recommendations are not inconsistent with the general intent of the Plan they require further study by the NCPA.
Two recommendations relating to environmental monitoring in Civic will need to be examined in conjunction with the ACT Administration.

The Committee recommends that a building height of less than six storeys be considered on London Circuit and at the Eastern end of Section 37. Although this is accepted in Section 37 it is considered that buildings of up to six storeys in height should be allowed on the frontage of London Circuit subject to certain standards.
The NCPA will address a number of the other recommendations which have been accepted in principle in consultation with the ACT Planning Authority.
The ACT Planning Authority has advised its unequivocal support of the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Substantially, this report deals with the operations of the Special Investigations Unit, which was set up by the Government and which has been investigating allegations of war crimes by residents in Australia for over four years. At the moment it has a funding guarantee from the Government until June next year, which will take this process through a period of five years.

PARA.TAB: The situation is causing some concern, because it is clear that this has become a very extensive and expensive operation indeed. The total expenditure of the special investigations unit up to 30 June 1991 amounted to $11.381m. In the last year it spent some $3.8m, and presumably it will spend that amount again next year.

It is not as though the matters that are referred to the Unit are running down, because it is reported here that in the current year, up to 30 June last, a further 137 suspects were referred to it. As at the end of 30 June 1991 there were reported to be 27 active investigations, which included the case that has now gone to trial—the one and only case in all these years of investigations that has gone to trial. But there are 15 others, and it is certainly clear that some of them may well yet go to trial.

The total cost of the Special Investigations Unit has been very great indeed. There are still large numbers of matters being referred to it. In addition, as I think we all know, the one and only case which was launched by the prosecution, went to the High Court which upheld the Act passed by the Senate at the end of 1988. The High Court upheld that Act and the prosecution case has now just commenced in Adelaide. Until that time there had been expended in costs by the Crown Prosecutor more than $300,000 and more than $600,000 in legal aid by the public defender acting for the defence. Because it was thought that the case might go to trial, the Director of Public Prosecutions was provided with $9.5m to conduct that case in the last financial year. However, only $300,000 was expended, largely because of the High Court proceedings. It is perfectly clear that the trial of that one case will be enormously expensive and any other trials are likely to be of the same order. These must be added, of course, to the very large costs of the special investigator to which I have just referred.

Therefore, the operation of the War Crimes Act, as contained in the report, of which I have given a very brief summary, causes a good deal of concern and alarm as to how long this Unit will continue to operate and how many prosecutions will be launched, if indeed any further prosecutions are launched. This is, of course, apart from the one that is now under way. The experience of the difficulties of bringing the evidence before the courts in Australia will reveal whether it is possible, in these circumstances, to really launch prosecutions. I hope the Government will give very close attention to the question of whether it should continue with this exercise.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is essentially the work of the Special Investigations Unit which was established following the passage of the War Crimes Amendment Act 1988. In turn, this was the consequence of a report of Mr Menzies—the so-called Menzies report—relating to the entry of suspected war criminals into Australia. The Director of the Unit is now Mr Blewitt who replaced the first Director, Mr Robert Greenwood, QC, who has since returned to private practice. The report confirms that the political changes sweeping Europe have directly affected the work of the Unit. While initially that work was interrupted on some occasions in Lithuania, Latvia, Yugoslavia and of course during the Gulf war, the investigators are now receiving more cooperation in countries where access to archives is now easier than it was before.

PARA.TAB: I also note with interest that New Zealand has passed legislation to conduct a war crimes inquiry, and that two units have been established in the United Kingdom: one in England and Wales; and the second in Scotland, with separate jurisdictions. During the last year alone, the Unit has received allegations of some further 137 suspects. The allegations now total 242. An indication that the investigations are being carried out with some care and due diligence is that a large number of these cases are not being proceeded with simply because the basic elements and the information concerning the allegations provided cannot be substantiated.

As at 30 June 1991, there remained 27 active investigations, including the case currently proceeding in Adelaide, of which 11, as the report says, are not promising and are likely to be suspended. The matter of cost has been raised by Senator Durack as being of concern. Whilst I appreciate that parliament must be accountable for every dollar spent, I believe the money spent in the current year, some $3.8m together with a further $325,000 spent by the Director of Public Prosecutions, is money extremely well spent.

We are dealing here not with crimes of a normal kind. We are dealing here with a principle that this country needs to establish—that war crimes are not crimes that we are in any way prepared to condone. War itself is something that will, hopefully, in due course become a thing of the past and naturally we will exert all efforts to achieve world peace. But if war does break out, if it is considered by those pursuing it that it is inevitable, then it is absolutely essential that it is conducted within civilised limits and that people who take advantage of the chaos or of power that accrues to them in these circumstances will be brought to justice. I believe the Nuremberg principle that was established, of individual responsibility, must be pursued. We are dealing in these matters not with people who are simply cogs in a machine, but people who committed acts on their own initiative and with a degree of persistence.

The other argument that is often advanced is the length of time that has elapsed, and certainly we have reason to question why it took us so long to establish this Unit when the initial War Crimes Act was passed in 1945. This is a matter for criticism of successive governments: it is not a reason for not doing anything at the moment.(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In the five minutes allotted to me, I shall deal with four of the matters mentioned in the report. Although the Australian Fisheries Council meeting was held in Wellington, New Zealand, and was attended by 30 to 40 people, it is no wonder that the fishing industry is in such a mess considering the number of issues that are under discussion and the state of inactivity. The Council appears to float issues along from one meeting to the next and then work out where the next meeting will be held.

PARA.TAB: The first important matter is the importation of goldfish. Frankly, I cannot accept the attitude of AQIS that the acceptable level of risk is `reasonable'. There is either a risk or there is not. If there is a risk, the answer is no, they should not be imported. All the report says is, `Insufficient evidence is available to justify a ban on defensible quarantine grounds'. If there is a risk, that is a ground of defensible risk.

The second matter is aquiculture. Apparently, the Australian Fisheries Council is still doing very little. But the report says, `Council NOTED the progress in the development of a National Strategy on Aquaculture'. At this stage, with aquiculture having grown in Australia for as many years as it has, it is pathetic to be still trying to work on the development of a national strategy. Surely, we can find enough people in the various departments at the State and Federal levels to do something about it now.

The third matter is that of recreational fishing. About a week ago I went to a national conference of recreational fishermen. I can certainly advise the Federal Government and the State governments that the recreational fishermen are years ahead of government when it comes to looking at the issues, assessing them and seeing what the future holds in store. I found them to be very much unanimous in their views and very well organised. I expect them to be moving to assist in the management of the Australian fishing industry and fishing generally to a much higher extent in the next months, I would hope, certainly not years.

The fourth matter is a rather frightening list raised by the Standing Committee of the major issues that still require attention. Notwithstanding all the Commonwealth staff and corresponding State staff around Australia, these items require resolution:
finalisation of the list of species
finalisation of the quota allocation formula
determination of the total allowable catches for the species to be managed by quotas and apportioning them between fisheries and users. . .
implementation of a policy on licence splitting for the fishery
finalisation of the State(s) monitoring arrangements
agreement on the transferability of quotas in the initial stages of the program
determination of the costs and how they will be met
agreement on requirements for complementary State legislation; and
handling of high-grading and bycatch.

SPEECH.PARA: There are all these sorts of things—and we are not there yet! What is the Council doing if these things are still awaiting attention? It is an important little document. I just hope that somebody will stir things up enough to see that something actually happens and that these Council meetings do not remain the main object of the Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear the remarks of Senator Archer because I agree entirely with what he has said. We have in front of us a document which records a meeting in New Zealand of the Australian Fisheries Council, of which the Minister for Fisheries in New Zealand was merely an observer. If there is an example of waste of financial resources, taking this vast number of people to New Zealand to swan around—I use the word quite deliberately—and simply `note' this and `note' that, and that is what the report says all the way through, and a Council which is supposed to be keeping an overview of an industry which is in dire straits with species after species heading towards extinction, certainly heading towards closure of large numbers of fisheries for very long periods of time if those fisheries are to recover at all, then the process we have described in this report is totally inadequate.

PARA.TAB: I note that the Australian Fisheries Council is made up of the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the State Ministers. If this report indicates their level of concern, then it goes some way to explain why so little is being done in relation to this very important industry which is in such terrible straits. Just to take one example, Senator Archer mentioned the importation of goldfish, which undoubtedly are capable of carrying, and undoubtedly do carry, diseases.

I agree entirely with Senator Archer that the risk of the importation of these diseases into this country should be a sufficient reason. There are no good reasons why goldfish need to be imported at all, particularly if they pose a threat to such an important indigenous industry. Picking up what the report says about the orange roughy stock on the Challenger Plateau:

SPEECH.PARA: Council NOTED—
and this is typical of what goes right through this report—

the outcome of recent consultations on the management of orange roughy stock which straddles the waters of the New Zealand Exclusive Economic Zone and adjacent high seas areas on the Challenger Plateau.
New Zealand ACKNOWLEDGED the contribution made by Australia and NOTED that it was also important to control the effort of other nations in the area.

A species which in the four or five years since it has been exploited has been pushed rapidly virtually to extinction in every area where that exploitation has gone on, yet here we have the Federal and State Ministers responsible simply noting the outcome of consultations and acknowledging a contribution made by Australia. This is a fishery which Australia moved into with totally inadequate knowledge of the life cycle of these fish and the great age—roughly 37 years—that they have to achieve before they get to sexual maturity. Australia moved in and grossly exploited them, yet the Australian Fisheries Council can merely `note' this and `note' that.

PARA.TAB: So it goes on with the other items. The southern bluefin tuna is another fishery stock which is certainly under excessive pressure and inadequately managed, and again we have the statement that Council simply `noted' a common desire to manage these. What we want in these reports is some more positive indication of how that management will be carried out. Presumably, this Council can make some decisions which would come back and be reflected in legislation.

In relation to driftnet fishing, the Council noted the imminent introduction of the package of legislation that we dealt with a few weeks ago in this place. It noted that New Zealand had ratified the international convention on driftnet fishing. It did not even bother to note that New Zealand had authorised a much more stringent driftnet fishing code than that in the international agreement. Clearly, that was an important lesson for Australia to pick up and, indeed, has been picked up in the legislation which we passed a few weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this discussion but, having heard comments made by my colleague Senator Archer and by Senator Coulter, I thought I should. I agree wholeheartedly with their comments about goldfish importation to my State of Tasmania. We have a very valuable, although very young, aquaculture industry. I am concerned about anything that could endanger that industry because it means a lot to Tasmania. We have not too much going for us down there industry-wise at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Comments have been made by AQIS about that and another matter that concerns me, namely, the importation of uncooked salmon to Australia possibly being allowed. This has the possibility of bringing in whirling disease, which would devastate our fledgling salmon industry. These concerns are shared not only by me, Senator Archer and Senator Coulter but also by people in the industry in Tasmania.

The reason I want to say a few words on this report is that, following a question I asked Senator Button today, it seems to me ridiculous that the Government in its wisdom has spent $16m on building a research vessel for the CSIRO so that it can investigate such things as the orange roughy fishery and other potential fisheries around Australia—not just around Tasmania—yet because of the lack of funding that vessel will be laid up in Hobart for the next year. This is happening for the sake of a million or so dollars. It is not just the money that counts but the timing. We will waste a year's valuable research time, which could be spent very profitably in investigating other areas of potential fishing grounds in Tasmania and other parts of Australia.

Senator Archer's friends from the north-west coast, the Rockliffs, found the original orange roughy fishery in that area. It has been a question of hit or miss and, as Senator Coulter said, no-one really knows that much about orange roughy. All that is known is that for some reason or other they come together when they are 50 years old, which is when they are caught. Unless we can research these fisheries, how can we keep our fishery industry going—an industry that is so important to all of Australia but particularly to Tasmania? I find it quite incredible that we have a modern up-to-date fishing research vessel just sitting tied up in the dock in Hobart.

When I was in the Soviet Union last year, Duncan Kerr, the honourable member for Denison, and I had quite lengthy discussions with representatives from fishing cooperatives in the Vladivostok and Nakhodka areas. It seems that some of the Russian fishing vessels may be coming to Tasmania from the Nakhodka Cooperative. We also had discussions with Professor Ernst Nosov, who spent 15 years not only with Russian research vessels but also working with the New Zealand Government. He has a great deal of knowledge of fishery areas around the continental shelf of Tasmania. I have been trying for the past year to arrange for him to visit Australia. I think he is coming on 14 November, but the communication difficulties with the Soviet Union have to be tried to be understood. It is incredibly difficult, and indeed almost impossible, to try to get phone calls and faxes through to Vladivostok. I hope that next week I will be able to take Professor Nosov and two colleagues to the CSIRO establishment in Hobart, where they are most keen to talk to him about the research he has done. The fishing industry is crying out for research and knowledge of our fish resource. When we know what the resource is, the Government will be able to take the appropriate steps to ensure that it is protected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Harradine, I received these documents only a little while ago and it would be difficult to respond to the content of the documents in some detail. I am aware of the intense interest that Senator Bourne of the Australian Democrats has in this area. I am

SPEECH.PARA: sure that she will address the detailed content of these reports when that opportunity arises in the program of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: However, I wish to take the opportunity to set down the framework of the concerns of the Australian Democrats in the area of overseas aid. I think it is important for us to be aware of the dimensions of the worldwide crisis. More than a billion people—one in every five—still live at this stage in absolute poverty. They struggle to live on less than about $500 a year, and most live in Asia and Africa. One in six people in developing countries still go hungry every day and one in three children under five suffer from serious malnutrition. The 40,000 children who die every day from preventable causes could be saved if the world gave the matter some priority.

While the West alone spent a billion United States dollars in two days on the Gulf war, the same amount spent over a year would have saved children dying from three diseases—measles, tetanus and polio. Some 50,000 children died from these diseases in the first week of the war. Poverty is the silent killer, attracting no media attention but inflicting as much grief and human suffering as more headline-grabbing tragedies. For this reason, the Australian Democrats' alternative Budget proposes an increase of some $340m for overseas aid, together with an additional $65m for the saving of rainforests the world over, because clearly care for the environment is part of the objectives of overseas aid.

It is useful to compare the situation between the rich countries and the developing countries in terms of the benefits in trade that we, as a country, receive. While we give just over $1 billion in aid, we receive some $13 billion in return from trade with developing countries. They contribute around $13 billion a year to our well-being. What is more, since some 85 per cent of the aid is actually spent on Australian supplies and consultants, our `generosity' is certainly open to question.

It is instructive to pay some attention to the level of overseas aid that Australia supplies. Since the Hawke Government came to power in 1983 Australian aid to developing countries has been cut. Aid has fallen from 0.51 per cent of gross national product to 0.33 per cent of GNP. Australia's aid is the same dollar value, allowing for inflation, as it was 20 years ago. Yet our per capita income is now at least 20 per cent higher. We have not become poorer as a nation, just a lot meaner.

In 1990-91, as I have said, the level remained at 0.33 per cent of GNP. But there were also real cuts of about $100m and, because payments to the international banks were large, other parts of the program have suffered. There has been a cut of about 7 per cent across most areas. It is instructive to look at some of these cuts. South Asia received a cut of 33 per cent which affected projects in Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Bhutan. In sub-Saharan Africa there have been cuts of 61 per cent. A major food project for workland rehabilitation and reafforestation has had to end. There have been cuts of 24 per cent in Ethiopia and cuts of 8 per cent to non-government organisations.

The United Nations program for women and children has suffered cuts over four years of 25 per cent. There have been cuts of 16 per cent to information and development education and cuts of 20 per cent to agricultural research centres.

This is not a proud record for Australia. Australia should be addressing the following priorities in respect of developing countries: primary education and adult literacy programs; primary health care, including family planning, water and sanitation; agriculture, especially food crops; primary environmental care; community development; and income generation.

There are many arguments why Australia should reverse the current trend and increase its aid. The first, and perhaps the most obvious, is the moral argument—the gap between the rich and the poor. The second is the international comparison argument. Norway contributes 1.02 per cent of GNP; Denmark one per cent; Sweden 1.98 per cent; France 0.79 per cent; Germany 0.41 per cent; and Italy 0.39 per cent. We are just about at the bottom of the ladder with 0.33 per cent.

There is the community support argument. Australians are generous people. Some two million people every year give to overseas aid programs which are run by non-government organisations. I believe that the Government should take some note of the will of the Australian people to assist those all over the world who have less. There is the mutual benefit argument, which I adverted to before, that if developing countries are receiving aid to enable them to run a stronger economy they in turn will be trading with Australia. There is the environmental development argument, which I have also mentioned before, that only countries which can satisfy the material needs of their people can set aside resources to save the environment and to ensure that their ecology is put on a sustainable level.

I conclude with a plea to the Government that these arguments should be taken into account and that the Australian Government should reconsider the level of foreign aid it sets aside for developing countries the world over. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: TAFE in the 1990s: Developing Australia's Skills

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have TAFE in the 1990s: Developing Australia's Skills recommitted.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a discussion paper produced by the Employment and Skills Formation Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training entitled TAFE in the 1990s: Developing Australia's Skills. At the outset, I refer honourable senators to the conclusions of the document on page 42, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: By the turn of the century Australia must have a vocational education and training system that meets the needs of people and of industry better than the system that we have today.

The document advocates freedom of movement between schools, TAFE, industry, universities and training programs, but TAFE most of all must respond to industry and social needs. The whole thrust of this document is to highlight the enormous importance of TAFE institutions for education and training in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Most honourable senators will be aware of the importance of TAFE. TAFE is the principal provider of post-secondary training opportunities for adults; TAFE provides vocational opportunities for a high proportion of our work force; TAFE caters for adults whose basic education has been inadequate; and TAFE retrains our workers and especially caters for individuals who do not receive training on the job.

Since we all agree on the importance of the TAFE sector, honourable senators may be disturbed to learn that this vital sector of education is in a critical condition. To 1987 there had been a steady growth in the participation in TAFE. However, in 1988 participation in TAFE began to fall and has continued to fall every year since then. The report indicates that this decline is the result of recurrent funding restrictions.

This document refers to the Deveson committee report entitled Training Costs of Award Restructuring. I remind the Senate that the report concludes that the Government's attitudes to resourcing TAFE are anomalous and unsatisfactory. The Deveson committee was concerned that the TAFE system lacked the capacity to meet not only the demands that are currently facing it but also training demands required as a result of award restructuring. Governments have recognised and accepted the need for funding of schools beyond post-compulsory secondary years and they have also accepted the need for additional funds for tertiary places in universities and how TAFE has not been so favoured.

In my own State of New South Wales, it has been estimated that next year TAFE may turn away up to 90,000 students because of budgetary constraints. The managing director of TAFE in New South Wales, Dr Gregor Ramsey, is concerned about the imbalance of resources available to universities and TAFE. For instance, he says that universities are training too many teachers and that we cannot employ all the teachers that we produce. On the other hand, TAFE cannot train technicians that are needed for trade courses. He says the problem is that training teachers is controlled by the Federal Government but training plumbers and electronics technicians in the States is under the control of the State governments, which have a lack of income.

This document recognises the problem and urges the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the recommendations of the Deveson committee for real term increases in TAFE recurrent funding of 5 per cent per annum. It also urges governments to redress the unequal treatment received by TAFE compared to schools and universities.

The document is particularly critical of the Government that has paid so little attention to funding issues raised by the Deveson committee report. It is sadly just another example of how this Government believes that it only has to set up committees to solve the nation's problems and does not have to take any notice of the findings and recommendations. This document also calls for governments to set targets for improving TAFE participation, since this has been done for school retention rates and higher education places. It also urges the Government to set targets for young people to achieve recognised skills as they enter the work force.

I urge the Government to carefully consider this report and the Deveson report and not to ignore the findings and recommendations. It must be ensured that TAFE's future and its role as the principal provider of post secondary training of adults is increased rather than diminished.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
