Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate —
(a)condemns the Government for its failure to provide direction and support to Australia's depressed rural sector, especially during the present devastating drought; and
(b)calls on the Government:

(i)to adopt policies to remove the obstacles which are preventing rural producers from operating effectively and efficiently, including a reduction in real interest rates, an efficient waterfront and transport system and a competitive tax structure, and
(ii)to pursue all opportunities to liberalise international trade to minimise the barriers confronting Australian primary industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the conclusion of the allotted time for debate on this matter on 17 October I was at the point of congratulating Senator Boswell for making moves to make it a little easier for our rural sector—our producers—to challenge whether produce was being dumped in Australia. Senator Boswell's efforts in that regard have been well publicised and I certainly wish him success in continuing to fight that fight on behalf of our rural producers. It is a pity that more assistance is not being given to him through models or examples which our Government could adopt. It seems so much easier for other countries to keep out items of trade which are suspected of being dumped on their domestic markets. The fact is that it seems easier for everybody else in the world to assist their rural producers than it is for us.

PARA.TAB: I was heading towards the conclusion of my remarks at the time that debate was interrupted. I had already pointed out that the Democrats agree with the general direction of Senator Panizza's motion, which contends that the Government has failed to provide direction for the rural sector. We would certainly agree with that. As a matter of fact, I would like to repeat my analogy, because it has not been challenged. My analogy showed that the control that is being exercised over our economy and over guidance in the rural sector is very much one of deregulation, hands off and non-intervention. The analogy that I drew at that time was that it was very much like a boy on a bike, riding downhill with his hands off and calling out, `Look, Mum, no hands'. It seems to me to be a most appropriate analogy for what is happening with our economy and the Government's degree of intervention on behalf of the rural sector.

The trouble is that much of this philosophy has been endorsed by the coalition. It is ironic that we see here today this particular motion by Senator Panizza from a group which has supported the deregulationist, economic rationalist model. The irony is one which, if it was not so serious with regard to the rural sector, I would like to spend some time exploring, but I will not.

I would like to point out that another philosophy associated with that is the one which we are constantly told Australia and the rest of the world should head towards. It is the one of the free trade concept which is, essentially, nonsense. That is why the Democrats will be moving an amendment to this motion. If it is supported, we will be able to support Senator Panizza's motion. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Subparagraph (b)(ii), omit "to liberalise international trade".

We move that amendment because, in essence, those words describe free trade, which we believe is a nonsense, because all trade throughout the world at the moment is distorted by the very fact that governments exist.

PARA.TAB: We contend that the very fact that governments exist and that they collect taxes and provide infrastructure does distort trade. Governments provide not only infrastructure in the form of physical infrastructure, but also community defence, law and order, education, public health, support for the arts, recreation and communication systems. We know what governments do, but every act they engage in is an act of support for the activities within their countries. It is the vehicle by which trade and productivity occurs within those countries and some countries place different priorities on different sections of it. Therefore, some industries or activities within nations receive greater support than they do in other countries. That is the distortion of trade. That is why the concept of free trade is a nonsense in our present world.

On the other hand, if a government abandons all of its responsibilities in these areas, it is no longer a government. Only then can it be truthfully claimed that we have free trade—total laissez faire, the hands off the bike completely. That would be the only situation where there would be no support for production, whether it be primary, secondary or tertiary production. Only then could we truthfully argue that there are no government subsidies for production.

Obviously we are not in that position; obviously we cannot get to that position. It is a fallacy to suggest that free trade is the panacea for all our marketing ills. It is an even greater fallacy to suggest that Australia should lead the world by abandoning any support, subsidy or assistance that government can give, especially to those of our rural industries. Those industries are suffering greatest at the hands of this silly notion that we should lead the world—lead with our chin—by telling the world that we will abandon all government subsidies and support and that we want the rest of the world to follow our example. What nonsense. How ridiculous. It cannot work that way.

We may be able to convince those nations which are overly subsidising some sectors to the economic disadvantage of the other sectors of their own economies—we may be able to convince them of the silliness of that—but we cannot convince them by abandoning our subsidies first and letting our producers suffer in the way that we are at the moment.

An example which is quite easily digestible, even by the coalition at the moment, is that provided by Australia's wool industry. On this very day we are at a point on the roller-coaster ride of wool prices that has been delivered to us with great uncertainty and a total lack of predictability. Anybody who can predict what the average indicative price, or any other price, for wool will be at our next wool sale, will be much cleverer than any of the other predictors who have preceded us over the last few months. They have all failed. Nobody has been able to predict what our prices have been. That is simply because we are in a situation where we could be subjected to manipulation by overseas speculators on our markets.

It is claimed that our wool market is of such a size that it is beyond speculation or manipulation. I would suggest that that is very far from the truth and that the situation it is in at the moment means that it is subjected to speculation, innuendo, gossip, rumour, fashion and a number of other things, over which Australia has no control whatsoever. One of the paths to resolution of that problem would be the reintroduction of our wool futures arrangement, whereby producers could at least hedge to some extent against market fluctuations. Obviously, that would not provide a total answer. I suggest that those proponents of a totally free marketing system would do well to observe the wool prices of the past few months, which have been the cause of extreme financial hardship to those people who have tried to predict and to judge the most appropriate time to put their wool onto our markets.

Before entering the market certain assumptions can be made, but when there is a variation in wool prices of 20c or 30c per kilogram, with tens of thousands of kilograms of wool, any assumptions made on the strength of a price that varies to that extent means a huge difference between predicted and actual returns to the producer. So much for the idea of liberalising trade. That is the justification for the Democrats' amendment. With the words removed as sought, we would be prepared to support the motion.

I mentioned the irony of this motion being moved by the coalition, and I also see a great deal of irony in what has transpired between the time when the motion was first moved and the debate that is occurring today. It was some months ago that an opportunity first presented itself for the coalition itself to provide some support and direction to Australia's rural community. The first opportunity was when the Democrats moved for the removal of the assets test from the Austudy scheme. To say that I was disappointed is the polite way to describe my reactions. I will stay with that description, but I must say that my reactions were stronger than that. A couple of days ago in one of our daily newspapers we saw the headline `Libs offer to ease Austudy assets test'. The article went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman on education, Dr David Kemp. . . said a coalition government would temporarily suspend the assets test for families in `extreme economic hardship'.

That was in regard to Austudy. What disgusted me about this is that that opportunity was presented to the coalition several months ago, when all it had to do was to support the Democrats notice of motion to disallow the regulation which imposed an assets test on the Austudy scheme. That opportunity sailed past the coalition and was not taken advantage of, and now we have the proposition that at some stage in the future a coalition government would support that very notion. I find this hypocritical to say the least, and certainly it is misleading to our rural community. Notwithstanding the irony in this motion, I think the best thing we can do is to support it, if our amendment is successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak to Senator Panizza's motion on the Government's failure to provide direction and support to Australia's depressed rural sector. The Government has paid too little attention to the difficulties being experienced in our rural and regional areas. There is no denying that, isolated as we are in Canberra, we fail to pay more than lip service to the real tragedy in the rural areas. I do not know how many honourable senators had the opportunity a few weeks ago to meet with members from the Isolated Children's and Parents' Association. They are the face of rural Australia. It is those people and others just like them that this Federal Government has ignored and has failed. I have often spoken both inside and outside this place in recent weeks on the rural crisis and on the twin evils of commodity collapse and drought and the Federal Government's inertia. In fact, I believe it is just outright scornful neglect for the rural sector of Australia. Let me establish the extent of the problem.

PARA.TAB: Farm incomes this year will drop to an historic new low. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics predicts that farm incomes will fall 24 per cent this year, and this follows the 34 per cent slide last financial year. For wool and summer crops, the outlook is absolutely bleak. Wool prices fell to their lowest level this century just recently and then rose again. Last month the ABARE predicted a 34 per cent drop, but it may well have to revise downwards some of its predictions. It is predicted that income from rice will drop 22 per cent and that sugar income will drop some 13 per cent. These are the lowest recorded farm incomes in real terms ever, and go beyond the figures for the period of drought in 1982-83, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claims was the time of our worst recession.

The ABARE annual farm survey is specific in its depressing outlook in its report. It has suggested, for example, that 50 per cent of sheep properties will have negative incomes and that another 25 per cent will have incomes below $13,000. Twenty-five per cent of beef properties, supposedly in comparative terms doing well, will have negative incomes, and another 25 per cent will have incomes below $10,900. In fact, across every sort of farming activity the ABARE predicts negative incomes for 25 per cent of all farms. Yet the Prime Minister suggests that this recession is not as bad as people believe, and in any case we are pulling out of it. Obviously, he must be pulling out of a different place from where the farmers are.

The data from one of his own Government departments clearly suggests that at least for the duration of this financial year a quarter of our farm sector will have negative incomes. This is a sector which traditionally has provided the bulk of our export income. I am pleased that at least the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has now acknowledged the seriousness of the problem and has admitted that Australia is facing its worst recession for 60-odd years. Despite all that, and despite the fact that in New South Wales and Queensland thousands of properties have been drought declared, with no feed, no crops and no prospect of anything growing for at least the next five months, even if it rains, the Federal Government is still just reviewing the matter.

Indeed, it was some 18 months ago that the Government's drought task force made its first report, yet today we are still waiting for a national drought strategy, although we have now been told by the Minister that at the end of February we will indeed have a national drought strategy. The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, on which Senator Crane, Senator Calvert and I represent this side of the chamber, and of which Senator Bell is also a member—and I note that Senator Bell is in the chamber at the moment—is looking at drought strategies and the drought problems and will report by the first sitting day in February. Hopefully, that will help the Federal Minister and the State Ministers at the Australian Agricultural Council meeting, which is to be held at the end of February, to formulate a proper drought policy and strategy for the future. At the moment, farmers do not quite know how they are placed in relation to drought assistance.

That is rather unkind to the people in the community who are fighting so hard against the elements at this time. Just this afternoon I was told that the problem with the blue algae moving down the river at Tilpa is adding another dimension to the drought, because even though water is there, it will not be any good for drinking by livestock or humans.

The Government suggested that the new part D, that was added to the rural adjustment scheme so that farmers would be able to receive the equivalent of unemployment benefits, would be of great help. The strategy committee suggested this, but even when that comes out, farmers will still be unable to receive unemployment benefits because they cannot meet the work test requirements. I mentioned that in this place recently. They cannot meet the work test requirements if they are back on the farm still trying to keep it viable. So, right across Australia there are farmers who have no money on which to live. Last week five very concerned people from an area regarded as one of the best and most prosperous farming districts in this country came into my electorate office in Tamworth with requests for assistance. I would hate to imagine what is happening in electorate offices in Dubbo and Broken Hill. The only activity in some of the western areas is wool growing. What is happening to these people and what help can they get? Obviously people in those areas are faced with worry and despair.

Recent newspaper reports suggest that up to 20,000 farmers will leave their properties in the next 12 months. I am told that in the area of north-west New South Wales, from the top north-west corner of the central tablelands to the far north-west, there will be 25 to 30 per cent of farmers walking off their farms. What will they walk off with? They will walk off with their furniture or what they can load onto their cars or trucks. They will receive nothing for the sale of their land because interest rates have wiped out any equity they might have had. I do not believe that farmers look for handouts or charity. They just want an understanding by people in this Parliament of what is happening out there. They want to be able to do what they do best: grow wool, crops and beef. But they must be given a fair go and allowed to get on with the job of doing it. It is good to see the Minister for Industrial Relations sitting in the chamber because he used to deal with primary industries matters in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still do.

—You still do? Well, without saying the wrong thing, I have to say that I hope the Minister is taking on board some of the problems out in those areas. It is of great concern to us on this side of the chamber. I am sorry I did not know that he was representing primary industries in this chamber; perhaps that shows that at the moment there is not enough effort and drive from the Minister's side of the chamber. If we do not keep the breeding herd and the sheep flock intact so that they will be there in some small measure after the drought has finished, obviously we will not be able to get out of the drought in the best way we could. I know that in the 1982-83 drought we had a very generous package from the Fraser-Anthony Government, of which Senator Durack, who is in the chamber at the moment, was a part. This made sure that breeding flocks and herds were retained so that when the drought broke the farming communities actually bounced back to produce the export income that was so necessary.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke Labor Government—or the Hawke-Keating Labor Government, or the Hawke-Kerin Labor Government, or the Keating-Kerin Labor Government, or whatever it is—in the past eight years has become absolutely bogged down and has not done what has been necessary to keep this country going. As the shadow Minister for industry and commerce suggested in the other place, it is time to get the lead out of the saddlebags. He was of course referring to the parlous state of our economy with its previous high inflation, which now has been dramatically reduced. I think that is great, but now we face some other problems: dismal productivity and centralised wage fixing which has knocked us for six. All of this has resulted in an economy which has to pay $16 billion a year or 20 per cent of its own export income to service its foreign debt. It has produced an economy with $29 billion of non-performing bank debt.

The Federal Government may and in fact does blame external factors for commodity price downturn and unfair protectionist trading policies of other countries. But it cannot apportion blame anywhere other than in its own inappropriate and misplaced interest rate policies for the disastrous damage it has caused to rural Australia. It is all right to say that interest rates are coming down very well now and therefore everything is good, that we have had the right policies in place to bring interest rates down. The problem is—and I have said this to people in this place over the past three years—that the high interest rates have now impacted on our input costs in running our farms, our properties and our businesses. I know that Senator Crane will talk about small businesses and businesses in country areas and the problems that they face. Those high interest rates have impacted and they are still causing us problems, even though the interest rate has come down just at the moment.

Even though Senator Collins tells us that he is making progress on the waterfront, this Government cannot make excuses for its archaic waterfront practices, the grossly inefficient transport systems or for our iniquitous tax regime—a tax regime which does not give any big reward for big effort. This is one of the problems that this Government has inflicted on this country. With the goods and services tax we will give people hope and an opportunity for those who work hard to achieve something in the future. That is a step in the right direction.

All these other things were the work of the Federal Labor Government. What is needed is massive reform and it just is not happening. If the Minister thinks that industrial relations are great in this country, why has he not done something about getting the productivity back to what it should be? On the news today I heard that in the northern part of New South Wales—and I hope the Minister gives some support to this—the shire engineers had put a motion to their central body that they all work an extra hour per day to help pull us out of the recession. If everyone took the same approach and worked a 40-hour week instead of a 35-hour week to try to get us out of the recession, it would be a step in the right direction.

One of the problems at the moment is the tax regime to which the Minister is a party. This means shearers stop shearing at lunchtime because there is no incentive to keep going. Having given their sweat and blood, they find that every sheep they shear after lunchtime on a Friday goes back to the Government to spend in the way it wants, rather than letting them have the money in their pockets to spend the way they want. That is what the Government will find with the GST—people will have more money in their pocket at the end of the week and more chance of spending it however they want.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the contractors being brought over from New Zealand undercutting Australian shearers, are they?

—I will come back to the drought policies. Minister Crean says that he will make an announcement at the end of the month about drought strategies. Actually, he has made one but he will make another later on in the year. We have the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and the former Treasurer all arguing about whether interest rates ought to come up, go down, stay put or go sideways. It was great this morning to see that interest rates have come down again, and that will help. I still make the point that this will not help to the extent that is necessary because the high input costs are still impacting on the community. We have people here in Canberra, members of the Government, just fiddling while stock are starving and farmers are getting deeper into debt.

PARA.TAB: Every day we have another farmer who is told he must sell up. Every day we have another property going to auction and no-one bidding for it. I cannot stress enough that what is happening in rural Australia is a disaster of such proportion and magnitude that I hope I never see anything like it again. An entire sector of our economy is about to collapse, and yet this Government—the Federal Hawke-Kerin-Keating-whatever-Government—is doing nothing about fixing it. It is still reviewing the matter, and it will not have to wait too long not to have to bother. There will be not much of a rural sector left to help us out of our problems. I support Senator Panizza's motion and join in his condemnation of the Federal Government's total disinterest in rural and regional Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support my colleague Senator Panizza from Western Australia in this motion. I wish to raise a number of things the Government could do. I am delighted that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, is present because I must pick up that interjection about New Zealand shearers. Apart from its being a naive, ill-informed comment, it surely must fly fair and square in the face of the CER agreement we have with New Zealand and the freeing up of trade between the two countries.
—I'm talking about breaking the law, not immigration problems.

—They are not breaking the law; they are not doing anything different in the shearing sheds—and I have worked there plenty of times—from what Australian shearers are doing. They do not make up the percentage that people such as the Minister and others claim from time to time.
—You ask the shearers in rural Australia whether they can get a job because of this. They can't because they are undercut by people who take unlawfully low wages.

—If the Minister is going to adopt that attitude, why does he not adopt the same attitude with regard to the pea growers in Western Australia, for example? That is totally different. I am very disappointed now—I said I was delighted—that the Minister is leaving, because there are some other things he should hear about.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has tried to apply a select position in regard to New Zealand and what has occurred with that country in recent years. The Minister claims that these people are breaking the law, when I would claim that they are doing nothing different from what hundreds and hundreds of shearers and people working in the shearing sheds in this country are doing.
Coming back to the basic thrust of the motion, I will take up where Senator West left off. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hasten to add that we have not heard addressed tonight any of the problems caused by the States. I need to look only at my home State and at how the policies of the Liberal Government there are impacting upon the people.

And so it goes on. She also referred to the Opposition not providing any ideas or thoughts or processes by which the position in rural and regional Australia could be improved. I hasten to add that many of the small businesses, as well as pastoral houses and their employees, in the metropolitan areas are also greatly affected by this recession or depression that we now have in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I particularly mention the grain handling charges that are levied by the New South Wales Liberal Government. My understanding is that they are levied by the Grain Elevators Board in New South Wales. If this is the case, it is up to the people involved to make sure that the Grain Elevators Board addresses the inefficiencies. It will never be able to address those inefficiencies unless the industrial system in this country is properly reformed, and I will deal with that matter in a moment or two. I emphasise that the industrial relations system must be properly reformed.

If we are talking about State governments and what they do, let us turn to my own State Government, the Lawrence Government, which recently placed another $45 on third party insurance for all vehicles in Western Australia. That particular charge has an enormous impact on rural Australia. The impact extends far beyond people who live in the cities or who are employed in a particular position. It is applied not only to the family car but also to the trucks, utilities, and other vehicles required to run business operations, and also to tractors, if one happens to have two properties that are separate. In many instances the owners of those properties have to pay eight lots of $45 because of the indiscretions of the current Government in Western Australia with regard to WA Inc., the SGIC and its misplaced investments. Of course, there are many winners out of that, but not the people Senator Panizza is addressing in his motion.

I turn now to the position of the Federal Government and some things that can be done. Earlier today we debated the report of Estimates Committee F on the Rural Adjustment Authority. We have recently seen some changes there. Those funds come from the pockets of the taxpayers. There is one thing in the financial arena that this Government could do tomorrow which would have a very beneficial impact on many of those business operations, whether they be farmers, small businesses or regional businesses, and that is to free up the credit lines available to the Commonwealth Development Bank.

Yesterday interest rates were again lowered. We can get commercial bills at about 9 per cent, with about a 2 per cent margin on top of that—about 11 per cent. Yet the Commonwealth Development Bank, because it does not have access to commercial bill lines, swap line facilities and financial facilities that other banks have, still has to charge between 16 per cent and 18 per cent to stay in the marketplace. That is one area where action could be taken.

It is particularly important in my State of Western Australia because in excess of 35 per cent of total borrowings are held with the Commonwealth Development Bank. When those borrowings were taken out, the position was very different from today. At that time the long term facilities it was going into were significantly cheaper than the short term market for 30-day bills, 90-day bills or 180-day bills, which can be locked in. This is one area where the Federal Government could give flexibility to the financial system, which would take significant pressure off the rural sector.

I turn now to another point in the motion—a competitive tax structure. We have made it quite clear that we will reform in toto the taxation system. That will involve a substantial lowering of income tax rates, it will involve getting rid of the wholesale sales tax, and it will involve the introduction of a goods and services tax. One aspect of a competitive tax structure is the cost of the current wholesale sales tax regime to the trucking industry. The trucking industry is a crucial part of the infrastructure of rural and regional Australia. Under the current tax regime, on a rig worth $250,000 in the first year the owner of that rig, with the various taxes on it, including the wholesale sales tax, will pay some $80,000 in tax for the privilege of owning and operating it. That does not include income tax if the owner happens to make a profit. In the current situation it is very difficult for such an owner to make a profit. Under our proposals, because these items are business input cost items, such an owner will not have to pay that tax as it will be a credit back to him.

That on its own will make a significant contribution to the cost infrastructure of transport. It will have benefits not only for rural and regional Australia, to which this motion relates, but for all Australians. There is little that we do in our lives which in terms of business costs does not contain some component that is not transported from one place to another during the life of its operation. In Australia there is little or nothing that does not involve some component of transport—a transport component which currently is very heavily taxed.

The other area where action could be taken to ease the pressure of costs is that of fuel excise. During the regime of this Government we have seen fuel excise move from a figure of slightly more than 6c a litre to a figure of 25c a litre today. I appreciate that diesel fuel used on farm is fully rebated but that is just one component of the fuel cost to the rural sector. The trucking industry carries this load, and only about one third of that tax is returned to the roads. It also has an on-farm impact in terms of petrol. The duty is not rebatable on petrol and many vehicles used on farm are petrol driven, particularly in the stock industries and the depressed wool industry at present.

What always staggers me is the fact that the rail system pays a fuel excise towards the building of roads. I have highlighted a couple of areas in which significant differences could be brought about to the cost inputs paid by the rural sector and others at present. It is worth noting that the fuel costs of our subsidised, highly assisted competitors in the United States are half the Australian costs. In view of the current availability of fuel in this country, particularly oils used in the production of diesel and petrol, it is not necessary that our fuel prices should be so high.

I am sorry that the Minister for Industrial Relations is not present because I now wish to deal with industrial relations reform. In doing so I wish to correct a number of misrepresentations that have occurred in this place in Question Time in recent days. I wish to mention what Senator Cook said in answer to a question on Tuesday of this week. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: They are talking about a removal of the award system. They are talking about a removal of the Industrial Relations Commission. They are talking about a removal of trade unions.

That is quite nonsensical and totally misrepresents our industrial relations policy. Reform of the industrial relations system is absolutely essential if we are to lift productivity. I welcome—as does John Howard but he was once again misrepresented by the Minister—what the Commission did last week, but it is only one small step in reforming our industrial relations system. Under current law it can go no further. That decision prevents employers and employees making their own arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it quite clear—and this has been spelt out many times and it is not necessary for the Minister to misrepresent the position—that under our policy people will have the option of staying in the current system or of making their own arrangements. The difference between our position and the Government's is that we will give people freedom of choice to enter into the sort of arrangement that suits them. Employers and employees will be able to negotiate their own workplace voluntary agreements. They will not have to be subject to big brother in the form of the unions, employer organisations and the Commission all looking over their shoulder. As I have said, they will have the option of staying in the current system or of moving out.

We will also be introducing into industrial relations policy the right of voluntary unionism. That is quite different from claiming that we will remove trade unions. It is not correct to say that we are talking about removing the Industrial Relations Commission when we are giving people the option of staying in the current system or of moving out. Therefore, it is impossible to remove the Commission.

Reform in the industrial relations area will lower costs, increase productivity and benefit the depressed rural sector, and indeed all other sectors. More than that, it will give employees the opportunity to be rewarded for improved productivity; it will give them the incentive to go out and work. It will also give employers and businesses the incentive to expand and to provide job opportunities. Surely everybody in this chamber will recognise the importance of this at this time.

In conclusion—and one could talk about this issue for hours on end—I wish to say that we will be accepting the Australian Democrats' amendment. But I want to say that it really is a pedantic amendment. It plays with words and does not alter the meaning of the motion. In my view, it is a fruitless exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that you were going to agree to delete the words `to liberalise international trade'?
—Yes. It does not alter the motion.
—I think it is pretty unfortunate, but it's up to you.
—It does not prevent the liberalisation of trade. All I am saying is that it is playing with words.
—It's the words that we can't agree to.
—It may be that the Australian Democrats cannot agree with the words but the amendment does not alter one iota the meaning of the motion.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that I have pointed to a number of areas where the Government could take action to assist the present situation. Those actions would not cost the Government more money but would increase productivity and improve efficiency. I strongly support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up on this motion of condemnation, I would first like to thank all the speakers who have taken part in this debate. Before I go on to deal with the finer points, I would like to put straight a few things that were said by people on the other side of the chamber or by interjection. The first relates to the speech made by Senator West on 17 October when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the only serious policy proposal we have heard tonight has been for troops on the waterfront.
I said:
Troops on the waterfront! Who said that?
She then said:
Senator Panizza said it; I have made copious notes.
I did not say that in this situation we would put troops on the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —She was having a bad dream.
—That is right; she must have been. I will reiterate what I did say. In making the point that the waterfront was not efficient enough and was not reducing the cost of handling rural products, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are still 600 or 700 people on the waterfront who are not producing, and something must be done.
Senator Cook interjected:
Would you put the troops in?
I said:
No, I would not put in troops just for this situation; we do not need troops there at present.

I will leave that matter there. I think Senator West should reread those remarks. However, I thank her for entering into the debate. She was the only one from the other side who had the gumption to do so. Perhaps she will make a good shadow Minister for primary industry when the John Hewson government is elected.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to put straight an interjection this afternoon by Senator Cook about New Zealand shearers. We agree that we are here to help primary industries. How better can we help than by getting costs down? Senator Cook said that New Zealand shearers were undercutting Australian shearers. For Senator Cook's information—I doubt whether he has had much to do with a shearing shed or shearers—New Zealand shearers are not undercutting Australian award rates. They are shearing for Australian award rates, which is taking the pressure off the Australian farmers to pay overaward rates to shearers. That is exactly what they are doing.

If any undercutting is done, it is the undercutting of overaward payments. We cannot call that undercutting; it is enterprise bargaining, but enterprise bargaining at award rates. That is what the New Zealand shearers are doing. I for one welcome the New Zealand shearers in Australia not only because they have kept the costs in line with award rates but also because, if it were not for them, we would probably not have enough shearers to produce the Australian clip. Obviously, few younger Australian shearers are prepared to come forward.

The Australian situation is getting worse by the day. In fact, it has got worse since we debated this matter last week. As late as today the grain industry commented on this issue. Statements have been made that the Australian grain industry is experiencing one of its worst seasons ever. Only Western Australia and South Australia will record production of any note, while yields in Victoria will be satisfactory.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics forecasts wheat yields for the current crop at 1.24 tonnes a hectare, which is about 25 per cent less than last year and 20 per cent below the average for the past five years. ABARE says that this is the lowest yield since 1982-83. Incidentally, this Government cannot blame Malcolm Fraser for that, as it blamed him for everything that happened in the recession of 1982-83, which was caused by the drought. Total winter cereal production—wheat, barley, oats and triticale—in 1991-92 is forecast at 15 million tonnes, 28 per cent less than last year. And so it goes on. I believe that the situation is getting worse by the day.

What is the Government doing? It is doing nothing but fiddling at the edges. Mr Crean was in Western Australia a couple of weeks ago to talk to the farmers. All he could do was announce a few small peripheral measures in the social security area. Farmers can now get the dole, and I suppose that is a welcome move, although my colleague Senator Brownhill pointed out that there are still some problems with that.

Since he has been Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean has continually told us that the way to go is to value add. I agree totally with him. But what happens when we start even to talk about value adding? I have some information with me about value adding because I was hoping to ask a question today. However, as I have already asked two questions this week, I knew that I would be scratching to get another. In Western Australia the Moora pulp mill is being set up to use straw that has been left behind in the paddocks. The Western Australian branch of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union—which has nothing to do with the Moora pulp mill because the mill is not even working yet—has members who currently work for two opposition pulp mills in Western Australia. The union has set about destroying the mill, which it was hoped would come on stream in the next 12 months.

Every honourable senator should have received a letter from this union. The union went to the bother of getting a professor—I cannot remember his name exactly—to undertake a study simply to destroy that mill. The biggest argument the union has is that the mill is importing pulp from Indonesia. A firm which will provide competition to the other two is importing pulp from Indonesia, but it has nothing to do with the Moora pulp mill. Using misinformation, the union is trying to destroy this pulp mill before it starts. If we can have value adding, let us have it. Let the unions help get these enterprises going and not destroy them.

In my motion I also referred to interest rates. I know that interest rates are lower now, but the fact is that the best rate a person can get as a lender to the bank is about 8.3 per cent, as of Monday. The rate has not come down because the banks anticipated it. On the same day the prime rate was 13.5 per cent. That is a mark-up of 63 per cent. If an item in a retail shop were to be marked up by 63 per cent, we would claim that the shop was having a lend of us. That is the prime lending rate. The banks are still charging farmers between 18 per cent and 19 per cent, which is a mark-up of 250 per cent. How are the banks helping the situation? What is the Government doing to encourage the banks to help the situation?

In relation to waterfront reform, Senator Collins told us today that wheat is put through the ports much more quickly. I agree, but it has been a long time coming. There are still 600 or 700 men idle on the waterfront. They are being paid, and they are being paid by the rural industries. Those 600 or 700 idle men should be the responsibility of the whole community, not just the community that is using the waterfront.

My motion states that we lack a competitive international tax structure. Last March the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) brought down a statement that contained some measures that could help the rural industries. One was sales tax on lubricants and hand tools used in agriculture. There was provision for a better depreciation schedule, but where is the legislation? The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who was responsible for bringing that statement into the Senate, is on duty in the chamber. I ask him: where is the necessary legislation? The statement was made in March—seven months ago—but we have not seen the legislation. The Government got the kudos for the March statement, which it said was the best industry statement ever. Where is the legislation to enable people to get the benefits of it? It has not been forthcoming. The Government makes these promises, they sound good in the press, but nothing comes to fruition.

My Whip is looking to me to wind up. I give an indication that I will accept the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. As Senator Crane pointed out, the amendment does not change the motion. I agree to delete the words `to liberalise international trade', for one reason. The motion of condemnation of the Government is not altered one iota. The fact is that we disagree with the Democrats, but we will debate that in this place at another time. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer should not tell me that we are backing down by accepting this amendment. At this point, I ask that the question be put.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

notes with dismay the closure of National Textiles spinning mill at Kotara, Newcastle, after its new owners Rocklea were able to obtain a government bounty for the production of yarn at the mill of $15.9 million;
condemns the Government for its incompetence in giving a bounty to a company and not providing proper safeguards for the way in which the recipient uses the bounty;
views with alarm the loss of 327 jobs in an industry that is a major employer of female workers in the depressed manufacturing sector in Newcastle; and

calls on the Federal Government to ensure that when bounties are given in future that there is legislative protection to ensure that money is put to the most productive use possible through the use of more efficient production techniques and retraining of staff rather than adding to the unemployment queue and increasing the profit levels of corporate raiders.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of Rocklea to close the National Textiles spinning mill at Kotara, Newcastle, is to be condemned, particularly in view of the fact that it has just been announced that the mill is to receive a capitalisation grant of $15.9m. It is typical of the mismanagement of this Government that a company can buy a cotton spinning mill, receive a grant in respect of that mill for such a large amount of money and then calmly close the mill down, putting 327 people out of a job in a period when unemployment in this country is a cause of enormous concern. Meanwhile, the Government of the day, and particularly the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), sits back and washes its hands of the matter like Pontius Pilate saying, `In truth, the fact is that Kotara is an old, outdated plant and, whatever the Government did, it would have to close at some stage'.

PARA.TAB: It is extraordinary that I have to point out to the Minister that the whole purpose of the capitalisation grants scheme is to provide—I quote from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority's annual report of 1989-90—`a further stimulus to the restructuring process'. Therefore, the entire purpose of the grant is to give industry an opportunity to restructure, to become more efficient and to contribute to the export potential of this country. Allowing a company to receive a grant and to then shut up the shop does not seem to be a tremendous stimulus for the restructuring process. The resulting action by Rocklea has in fact only served to harm the very people that it is supposed to be helping.

By approving this grant, the Government appears to have forgotten the entire purpose of the scheme, showing yet again the Federal Labor Government's blatant lack of regard for those people employed in the manufacturing sector, particularly those in the Hunter region where the livelihood of so many depends upon the productivity of our secondary industries. It is contemptible that the Government can continue to turn its back on the people who have traditionally supported it.

The Hunter region has the potential to be the engine-room of economic recovery in this country and to lead us out of the recession that Labor has decided to inflict upon us. When will the Government cease to betray the people of the Hunter region? Again and again, contract after contract has been awarded to cities other than Newcastle for purely political reasons, while the Labor Government shows a disregard for economic commonsense.

It is appalling that such a large amount of taxpayers' money, which was originally earmarked for an area which is most in need, can be granted to a private enterprise concern that can turn around and put it to a use in a way in which it was not intended to be used. It is of particular concern because the textile industry is a major employer of women in the Newcastle region. The closure of the National Textile spinning mill at Kotara will result in the loss of 327 jobs. These positions are predominantly held by women. The plight of women in the work force is arduous enough without the additional blow of having a large number of jobs for women in this region no longer available.

The people at the plant in Kotara, and the textile industry in general, can only watch in dismay as this Government slowly destroys the livelihood that they have struggled so long to maintain. `We blame the Government', the workers have been reported as saying. Another reaction of the workers is, `The Government says to buy Australian, but at this rate nothing will be made in Australia'. These people realise that this Government is not for the people. They quite rightly feel stunned that a Labor government can treat them with such thinly veiled contempt.

The situation is grave enough to provoke criticism from the more traditional supporters of the Labor Government, such as the union movement. The Newcastle Herald, in an interview with Ms Anna Booth, the Assistant Secretary of the Clothing and Allied Trade Unions of Australia, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It—
the awarding of the grant—

is absolutely not in the spirit of the bounty and industry development plan, which is for money to be spent to develop industries . . . For the grant to be given to a private company without any strings attached is against the letter of the industry development plan.

The Federal Labor Government has taken the people of the Hunter for granted by allowing a long established company and employer in the region to close down. The most remarkable aspect of this tragedy, however, is that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce had the means available to prevent this from occurring but neglected to do so, preferring instead to place ever more hardship on the people of the Hunter and increasing the already high number of unemployed people in this country. Upon approval of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the capitalisation grant provided the opportunity for eligible textile yarn producers to receive a one-off, up-front grant in lieu of continued bounty receipts. A company's application for the grant must be supported by a business plan.

PARA.TAB: The business plan must include stated business objectives in relation to the applicant's production of bountiable yarn; its export initiatives; occupational and environmental health safety issues; and the method of achieving these objectives with regard to restructuring, investment, research and development, financing, sales and marketing. This business plan, therefore, is very detailed. It provides the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority—and, through it, the Minister—with all necessary future projections and anticipated actions of the applicant. The TCF Development Authority, after considering the plan, recommends to the Minister whether to allow the grant. The key criteria by which these applications are assessed are whether the business plan will contribute to the restructuring and revitalisation of the textile, footwear and clothing industry and whether the grant will result in fewer budgetary outlays from the Commonwealth than would otherwise have been provided by ongoing bounty assistance.

If the grant is approved, which is the case with the National Textiles spinning mill, the applicant must enter into a capitalisation agreement with the Authority on behalf of the Commonwealth. The Minister has the authority to include in the agreement such terms and conditions as he sees fit in achieving the objectives of the business plan. The agreement must also specify the assets to be used by the applicant to achieve the goals of the business plan. Should the applicant wish to sell or lease any of these assets, permission must be obtained from the Minister.

To allow such a transaction as this to go ahead, the Minister must be satisfied that these assets are no longer required in meeting the goals of the business plan. Obviously, failure to meet the terms and conditions of the agreement will result in an amount of the grant having to be repaid. It would appear, therefore, that ensuring that the grant is properly bestowed would be a relatively easy matter, as most of what would be necessary for sensible people to administer the capitalisation grant program in a responsible fashion is already in place.

In looking at the details of the treatment of the manufacturing sector and the Government's lackadaisical approach in the monitoring of the most efficient and appropriate application of the $15.9m of taxpayers' money, it is obvious that there are only two possible conclusions to be reached regarding the decision to proceed with this grant. This is particularly so in the light of changes that must obviously have been made to the business plan and the capitalisation agreement. The first is that the Minister was fully aware of the plans of the new owner of the mill and therefore decided to put 327 people out of work, thereby pushing the role of women in the work force further into the background and adding to the woes of the people in the Newcastle region, so frequently neglected by this Labor Government. The alternative must be that the Minister is completely negligent in his responsibilities, as set out in the legislation introduced by the Government.

Assuming that the Minister is aware of the requirements of his position, the question must be asked: exactly what would prompt the Minister to approve a grant of $15.9m to a company when it is obvious that the whole purpose of the purchase of National Textiles mill by Rocklea was to seize the grant and to reallocate the expenditure as it saw fit? Why create a situation which leads to the shutdown of a factory in the Hunter Valley that employs 327 people, adding to the dole queue, thus continuing to rip large chunks out of the economy and the region? Why not upgrade the technology of the production process, thereby increasing the competitiveness of the plant and therefore improving its export potential for this country?

Of course, it is possible that the Minister is unaware of his responsibilities in the administration of the capitalisation grant program. If that is the case, it is appalling that this Government is taking such an indifferent attitude to the application of such an enormous amount of money that is supposed to be contributing to the revitalisation and reconstruction of the textile industry in this country. What is perhaps even more astounding is that the Minister, as reported in the press, has the gall to say that Rocklea should have consulted the workers before closing down the plant and that any future grants will depend on consultation with the unions. Does this mean that the grant in this case was originally given with no strings attached?

The Minister already has the power to ensure that the recipient of a textile industry capitalisation grant complies with the textile, clothing and footwear industries development plan. Was the Minister ignorant of this power or did he in fact make the mistake in his decision to approve the grant? Now that the mistake has been realised, will the Minister recall the grant to ensure that the money is actually put to the use that was originally intended?

What can clearly be observed is the need for tightening up the legislation involved so a no strings attached capitalisation grant—where the objectives of the grant can be ignored due to poor administration by the Government—can no longer be given out willy-nilly, thereby wasting taxpayers' money. Instead, an assurance has to be given by the Minister that he will do all in his power to ensure that this disgraceful misallocation of funds can never recur so that people in these industries are not further disadvantaged and so that the textile industry in this country is able to become more efficient without the blatant disregard of the people working in the industry that this Labor Government has shown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney has made some fundamental errors in the statements he has made in support of his motion. Clearly, he has tried to confuse this important issue with the Opposition rhetoric that has dominated that side of the chamber for so long. It surprises me that the Opposition continues to dwell on unemployment concerns when clearly the Opposition will never pursue policies that encourage long term job growth.

PARA.TAB: The grant that was provided to Rocklea was not provided to prop it up but to help it become an internationally competitive company. From the very beginning of the agreement pertaining to this bounty, the restructuring of the business and the closure of Kotara were being discussed.

The capitalisation grants scheme has two basic aims: firstly, to encourage the emergence of an internationally competitive textile industry in Australia; and, secondly, to achieve budgetary savings to the Commonwealth. The grants to the yarn industry have provided an important boost to this sector of the economy. The capitalisation scheme merely allows those allowances to be paid in a lump sum.

A grant of this nature in the form of the payment to YTM Pty Ltd—a subsidiary of Rocklea—actually saved the Commonwealth $2.8m because the grant was 15 per cent less than the total amount that would have to have been paid over the period that these bounties will remain. We must have in mind, of course, that they only continue until 1995. The decision to give this grant was made by the Government on the recommendation of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. In the development of a modern plant, which the grant will help establish, the company in question will be in a far better position to be competitive.

I draw the Senate's attention to some blatantly uninformed statements made by Senator Tierney. He claims that there are no safeguards in the issuing of this bounty and that there are no controls over the way that the money is spent. This is not the case, as the agreement at the time clearly stated that Rocklea had to maintain the aggregate production of the combined businesses—that is, Rocklea itself, plus National Textiles and Bradmill Textiles—until midway through 1995, which is the end of the bounty period anyway.

Under the bounty agreement, Rocklea had to also undertake a major modernisation program. If the company does not fulfil those requirements, it must pay the bounty back to the Government in full. Senator Tierney also states that the money should be put to the most productive use. That is what we are trying to ensure will happen. There are guidelines and rules, and Rocklea has to stick by them.

It is sad that workers were retrenched at this company, but it is obvious that, to fulfil the need to modernise and restructure, jobs will be made redundant. There is no longer any need for the Kotara plant. It has machinery that is 25 years old. There has been no investment in this factory for years. In fact, the Government has been injecting funds into this particular plant and subsidising it to the tune of 30 per cent to 35 per cent under the bounty scheme.

As part of the considerations in the restructuring of this enhanced Rocklea company, the retrenchment of employees was indeed taken into account and, after discussions and negotiations, a package for the workers from Kotara was decided upon. It provides sufficient notice of dismissal and a good financial package. Rocklea is also going to provide 30 new jobs that retrenched Kotara workers can apply for.

The Government does realise that there are complications when companies are involved in takeovers as far as employment issues are concerned. I certainly share the view of Minister Button that Rocklea should have consulted employees in a far more effective manner before and during the acquisition process that saw it gain control of National Textiles and Bradmill. Senator Button has written to the TCF Development Authority asking it to advise him of a more effective union consultation process in the restructuring of this sector. However, we must support our textile industry, and I see no reason why such a grant should not have been given.

The Opposition has long claimed that more support should be given to business and industry. We have the record, we understand the issues, and we want to create real jobs, not artificial jobs. That requires a long term strategy, a strategy that this Government has continually stuck by. It is this Government that has made the tough decisions while the Opposition continues to mock and be opportunistic. The Government remains committed to the restructuring of the textile, clothing and footwear industries, even at a difficult time of economic recession, and will endeavour to provide maximum assistance to displaced employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, to support the motion moved by Senator Tierney relating to the closure of the National Textiles spinning mill at Kotara, Newcastle. It is a disastrous event for people to lose their jobs anywhere during such severe economic times and our thoughts must go out to those families whose breadwinners may well end up on the dole queues next year. However, the loss of some 327 jobs from the Newcastle area is particularly alarming as the region has already suffered badly. More job losses in the Hunter region are a further blow to the morale of an already depressed community, hard hit by the erosion of its manufacturing base.

PARA.TAB: In addition, it is well-known that Australia has one of the most highly sex-segregated work forces in the world. Many women are employed in low status, low paying jobs and many of these jobs are to be found in the textile, clothing and footwear sectors. Indeed, some 65 per cent of the total employees in these industries are women. Hence, any job losses and contractions in the textile and clothing manufacturing bases will greatly affect women employees, as it has in this case.

The closure in April next year of the spinning mill at Kotara near Newcastle, and the subsequent loss of jobs in a city scarred by a severely depressed job market at a time when Australia is experiencing a dreadful recession, is an absolutely appalling situation. When one understands and realises that the company instigating all of this is the recipient of a bountiful $15.9m because the Government's textile, clothing and footwear plan allows companies to receive an advance on the subsidies for capitalisation, the situation worsens.

How can the Government allow this to happen? Where are the controls and conditions that should be in place when the Government gives taxpayers' money to industry? The levels of assistance to textile, clothing and footwear industries are the highest in Australian manufacturing. The Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority reported in 1990 that, despite adjustments being made, these industries remain some of the most highly protected industries in Australia and that more adjustments are required if textile, clothing and footwear industries are to become internationally competitive. Surely, with this enormous assistance, the Government would make sure that safeguards would be in place to prevent occurrences such as the one at Kotara.

The Government's March industry statement stressed the need for a rationalised, more competitive textile industry and announced that industry bounties would be reduced, ending finally in 1995. The Australian Democrats fully recognise the need to invest in new plant and equipment, to value-add our primary products and to engage in wide-ranging micro-economic reform to assist industry. But as the Metal Trades Industry Association has noted, cutting tariffs and bounties has exposed Australian manufacturing to international competition that it has not been prepared for.

Reform of Australia's transport infrastructure has not proceeded at the same pace and, whilst real gains have been made very recently on the waterfront, it is still plagued by inefficiency and outdated work practices at many docksides. The Government has sought to reform our industrial base from the wrong direction.

Indeed, we would submit that the Government's own economic policies have contributed to the closure at Kotara. Senator Button himself admitted that the Kotara spinning mill was `old and outdated' and that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this was the end result of the previous owner's failure year after year to invest in the plant and its future.

It is absurd for Senator Button to blame the previous owner for a failure to invest in plant, when for the last three years it has been government policy to maintain high interest rates. This is one of the major factors why business, and manufacturing in particular, has been hard-pressed to invest in new plant and equipment. Many small businesses in Australia are no doubt finding themselves in exactly the same situation as the previous owners of the Kotara plant.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats welcome the recent announcement of a one per cent cut in interest rates for business but would suggest that in the case of Kotara this is rather too late. I add that we believe this fall in official rates should be equally passed on to home owners, many of whom are no doubt now out of work owing to the Government's policies.

It was because the Kotara plant was old and run down that it was ripe for a takeover by Rocklea Spinning Mills which could then profit by the advanced bounty and improve its plant in Bendigo before the bounties ended in 1995. This is fine for the work force in Bendigo but the Newcastle workers have been abandoned. Certainly, Rocklea has offered them jobs in its Bendigo plant but many workers will be unable to move away for various reasons. To compound their misery, apart from brief advice to union officials in February, Rocklea had no further consultation with either the union or the employees before announcing the Kotara plant closure.

Although not specifically included in the guidelines for the capitalisation grants scheme under the textile, clothing and footwear plan, companies receiving assistance are now expected to have a labour management plan. The labour management plans have been mentioned by Senator Button and operate as follows: where employment reductions are involved, support will be conditional on recipients adopting a responsible labour management plan and minimising involuntary employment reductions.

The union's understanding of such a plan is that it should set out consultative arrangements between management and workers, how the project concerned will affect employment levels and how new changes in employment levels will be dealt with—including notification, redeployment, retraining, relocation, the use of labour adjustment packages and redundancy agreements. It should also deal with more general and ongoing issues such as consultation regarding work organisation, training and the introduction of new technology. Rocklea had no such plan. In the words of Senator Button:

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line in this is that a company receiving support from the taxpayer has a responsibility to consult openly about its plans.
It is too late for the workers at Rocklea's Kotara mill. Rocklea now has its $15.9m, yet it will close a cotton spinning plant and 327 people will be out of work.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats call for a complete overhaul of the guidelines for administration of the bounty system. Taxpayers' money must have strings and accountability attaching to its use. The Government must bear the responsibility in this instance and ensure that in future it has more information as to how the funds will be used. The textile, clothing and footwear plan still has four years to run and we must prevent this situation happening again.

In conclusion, I reiterate the support of the Australian Democrats for this motion and I hope that the Government learns from this bitter lesson. The people of Newcastle will not forget. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator Sowada for her very clear exposition of the problems that have been created in Newcastle by this amazing move and the lack of government supervision of what is happening with its own capitalisation program.

PARA.TAB: Senator Foreman claimed that I made a number of errors. I would not disagree at all with a number of the claims that he made. He talked about the need for the company to be internationally competitive, he talked about capitalisation being cheaper than giving out bounties and he talked about safeguards. I do not have a great deal of disagreement with those sorts of issues at all.

But let us return to the central issues of the Rocklea case. Senator Foreman has obviously not read the Newcastle newspapers or paid attention to other media outlets which have reported the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the local members of parliament about what has happened. They were appalled.

At a number of points in his speech, Senator Foreman seemed to claim that there was some sort of consultation. I will point out some errors in what the honourable senator has said. When did that consultation happen? There was no lead-up to this. Newcastle was not aware that this plant was going to close. It took the local members of parliament by surprise and it certainly took the unions by surprise. It suddenly appeared out of the blue in the city newspaper reports.

The plant happens to be located about 1,000 yards from where I live and local people were totally unaware that suddenly 300-odd jobs were going to disappear. I can assure the honourable senator that, when one tries to take jobs away from Newcastle, one knows about it in the media; just as the Government has known in the past in relation to the frigate contract, the submarine contract and even in relation to the AMSA—the sea safety centre—which it promised to give to Newcastle but, at the last minute, took away.

When governments do this sort of thing to Newcastle, it gets up in arms. The issue ran through the media day after day for weeks on end—yet previously we had heard nothing; it was a total surprise. The matter was described as some of the most appalling handling ever of an industrial situation in this country. Even honourable senators on Senator Foreman's side have said they could not believe that this sort of thing would continue to happen in this century. The problem is best summed up in a cartoon by Lewis in the Newcastle Herald.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have to be the Newcastle Herald.

—Yes, of course. Rocklea is associated with Sara Lee, which, as we all know, makes cakes and pies. The cartoon showed a cake shop with this big pie. The company throws the pie in the bin and picks up the cream and races out the door. That sums up exactly what has happened.

PARA.TAB: This company, without consultation, has acted like a corporate raider. It has taken over a company purely for the purpose of grabbing hold of this capitalisation grant. It then plans to transfer resources to Victoria away from Newcastle yet again and in the process shut down jobs in an area that is already massively depressed in terms of employment. The great tragedy in an industrial city where women find it very hard to get jobs is that 327 jobs that are mainly for women have disappeared. This Government, in the middle of a recession, should really hang its head in shame because through its lack of supervision it has created a situation where not only people including women have lost jobs but also this vital region has lost jobs.

If we look back to the whole way that this capitalisation grant scheme is set up, we can see that this should not have happened. We have a situation where a firm has to put forward a business plan. I detailed in my speech what was needed in that business plan. How can a government that is properly supervising what is going on allow a grant to be given out to a company that obviously has not submitted a proper business plan? If it did, the Government has not scrutinised what the company was doing. I certainly hope that this Government can stop the payment of the money to this group of corporate raiders and ensure in future that, when it is giving out capitalisation money, the money is spent in the way in which the Government intended.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who represents the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), I table an answer to a question asked of him during Question Time yesterday and seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The Solicitor-General was first appointed on 21 December 1983, for a seven year period commencing on 1 January 1984, at which time the Governor-General determined that, in respect of long leave and leave of absence on account of illness, the Solicitor-General held office on the same basis as a judge of the Federal Court of Australia and in respect of recreation leave, on the same basis as what was then an officer in the First Division of the Australian Public Service.

In 1988, the Governor-General amended this earlier determination to provide that the Solicitor-General held office in respect of all leave of absence, including recreation leave, on the same basis as a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. No retrospectivity was provided for the change in recreation leave entitlement.
On reappointment of the Solicitor-General in 1991, the Governor-General issued a determination which reaffirmed the conditions established in 1988.
Judges of the Federal Court are entitled to leave as follows:
Long Leave—a period of six months leave after five years service; and

Other Leave of absence—there is a fixed vacation in each year during the period from the beginning of the Monday before 24 December until the first Monday in February together with such other variable vacation or vacations as the Chief Justice determines, which in practice is four weeks during the year.

In response to your second question the answer is also no. Under the provisions of the Law Officers Act 1964, any payment in lieu of long leave which the Solicitor-General may be entitled to if he were to resign shortly after returning to duty, would be reduced by the period of long leave taken in 1992.
