SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 will amend several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature or which correct existing legislation. None of the amendments concern major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues.

PARA.TAB: Most of the proposed amendments will not have any financial impact, while the amendments to the Judiciary Act 1903 may result in savings on outlays by the Commonwealth, in so far as they reduce the potential for claims against the Commonwealth. The proposed amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill.

The Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Act 1991—the Act—establishes a code of conduct when Commonwealth offences are being investigated by State, Territory or Federal police. It also establishes a code of conduct for the Australian Federal Police in relation to investigations in respect of Australian Capital Territory offences.

At present, the Act applies when a Commonwealth offence created by an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament is being investigated and when an `applied' Commonwealth offence is being investigated. An `applied' Commonwealth offence is created when an offence that would normally be a State offence, such as armed robbery or assault, occurs on a Commonwealth place. To overcome an unintended consequence of the Constitution which did not allow State law to apply in those situations the Commonwealth Parliament passed the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970 which deems such offences to be Commonwealth offences. State police can then investigate and prosecute these `applied' Commonwealth offences, and they are treated as if they were State offences.

The Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Act 1991 has inserted Part 1C into the Crimes Act 1914. Now the substantive provisions of Part 1C are proclaimed, State police, when investigating these `applied' Commonwealth offences are bound by the provisions of Part 1C. In particular, they will be required to electronically record all police interviews with suspects because failure to do so renders any evidence obtained during such interviews prima facie inadmissible.

By combination of the commencement provision of this amendment—clause 2(3) of this Bill—and the insertion of subsection 5(2A) into the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act, Part 1C of the Crimes Act 1914 will be deemed never to have applied to State police investigating `applied' Commonwealth offences. The `applied' provisions are essentially State offences that have been artificially federalised for constitutional reasons. They are part of the States' criminal calendar, not the Commonwealth's and they are normally prosecuted by State, as opposed to Commonwealth, Directors of Prosecution. Sentenced accused are State prisoners, and any fines realised go to State revenue. Part 1C of the Crimes Act 1914 in its initial stages will cause some operational difficulties to the States and Territories. The impact of Part 1C on the States would be considerably lessened if this amendment were effected.

The amendment will in no way lessen the integrity of the provisions of the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Act 1991 in relation to true Commonwealth offences nor as a code of conduct for officers of the Australian Federal Police.

The Bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. Section 60H of the Family Law Act at present prevents the Family Court from exercising jurisdiction in relation to a child who is the subject of child protection orders under State or Territory child welfare legislation. The policy to date has been to give priority to this legislation which protects abused or neglected children.

However, the Family Law Council has recommended that the Family Law Act should allow the Family Court to determine custody, guardianship, maintenance and access disputes where this would not interfere with the protection of the child by child welfare authorities. Following discussions with State and Territory Governments, it has been agreed that the Family Law Act and State referral of powers legislation should be amended to give the Family Court power to make custody, guardianship or access orders in respect of children subject to State or Territory child welfare laws provided the written consent of the relevant child welfare officer is obtained to the institution or continuation of the proceedings. The Family Court is also to have power to make maintenance orders in respect of children subject to child welfare legislation. The Bill makes the necessary amendments to the Family Law Act.

Section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903 is to be amended to overcome certain problems arising from the operation of that section in the light of the High Court's decision in The Commonwealth v. Evans Deakin Industries Limited (1986) 161 CLR 254. The present terms of section 64 are that, in any suit to which the Commonwealth or a State is a party, the rights of the parties shall as nearly as possible be the same and judgment may be given and costs awarded on either side, as in a suit between subject and subject. As a result of the High Court's decision in the Evans Deakin case, the Commonwealth may, in civil proceedings, in effect become bound by State or Territory legislation by which the enacting State or Territory itself is not bound. This may mean, for example, that the Commonwealth could become liable for damages for breaching a duty imposed by a State law that does not in its terms purport to apply either to the Commonwealth or to the enacting State. This goes beyond what appears to have been the original intention behind section 64.
The effect of the proposed amendments will be as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: First, section 64 will not in effect make the Commonwealth subject to State or Territory legislation that does not bind the enacting State or Territory of its own force. This will remove the main anomaly exposed by the Evans Deakin case—that is, that the Commonwealth may in effect be bound by State or Territory legislation which the enacting State or Territory legislature has decided is not suitable to bind the State or Territory itself.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, section 64 will not make the Commonwealth liable for damages in an action for a breach of statutory duty under a prescribed law of a State or Territory. This will enable the Commonwealth, by prescribing a State or Territory law by regulation, to prevent itself from being sued for damages for breaching a duty under the law irrespective of whether the law binds the enacting State or Territory. A regulation prescribing a State or Territory law will only operate prospectively and will not remove any accrued rights against the Commonwealth. This mechanism is necessary to prevent the Commonwealth from becoming liable to possibly very large damages on the basis of new State or Territory laws which have been enacted primarily from a State viewpoint and without adequate regard to the Commonwealth's special needs or problems. A regulation will, of course, be subject to disallowance.

Thirdly, in a suit to which a State is a party, section 64 will not give to another party, as against the State, any right that the party would not otherwise have. This amendment is being made at the request of the States. Section 64 in its present form purports to alter the statutory law applicable to the States in civil proceedings in federal jurisdiction. The Commonwealth agrees with the States that this is inappropriate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to question the Minister further with regard to the changes in the charging structure of the Civil Aviation Authority and particularly his answers to questions that I asked. During the Estimates Committee hearings reference was made to the costs being offset in terms of the increased charges by the fact that the excise had been removed off avtur fuel which is used in certain aircraft. At that time I also referred to those aircraft that use avgas. My understanding is that the excise has not been taken off those aircraft that were using avgas and that they are subject to significant increases in charges. In fact, their charges have gone up significantly.

PARA.TAB: Returning to aircraft using avtur gas, I asked a question of the Minister in Estimates to which I have been given an answer. I do not find the answer satisfactory in terms of the information it gives. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it correct that charges on 5,000 kg aircraft flying 1000 hours per annum had risen from $8,300 in 1988 to around $120,000 by 1990?

In the answer that has been given to me a case has been made which suggests that the costs are very much the same but that in real terms, because we are living with dollars that are approximately four years down the track, there has been a significant decrease. I would suggest that the figures used in this answer to calculate the position as against the position today are not accurate.

PARA.TAB: When one works through the figures that have been given to us and compares them with actual information that has been given to me by air operators one sees that, in fact, the real cost of the operation today should be in the order of $110,000 to $120,000 per aircraft. I suggest that the figures presented here of $85,000 to $94,000 are an underestimate of the actual figures.

I have discussed this matter with a number of aircraft operators—particularly those operating in rural Australia because it impacts on the aircraft that are generally used there, not the larger ones—and the suggestion is that 1,000 flights each covering about 450 kilometres or 500 flights each covering about 900 kilometres is not a representative position. It appears that in terms of 1,000 hours of flying, the maximum that can be got out of these legs is about 400 trips, and that substantially changes the figures. If required I can table this example of the costs that arise.

I would like to move to the end of the question which states that if it is related to the position four years ago, the figures would range from $85,000 to $95,000. I believe there is a fundamental flaw in those estimations. When one works through the figures, a figure of 21.25c for excise has been used. In actual fact, at the time, the excise was of the order of 16c and there needs to be a recalculation. In fact, the position which arises is that the costs for the operations of these aircraft in this arena are significantly higher today than they were when the changes were made.

I have gone into some detail in putting this before the Minister. It may be necessary for the officers to do some recalculations. I do not believe that the figures that have been put before us represent the correct position. Nor do I believe that the basis on which the estimations have been made is realistic. I will let the Minister respond and then I will take up additional matters with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little confused and perhaps Senator Crane could clarify this. It appears to me that he may have been confused between avgas and avtur excise; avtur, of course, being for turbine aircraft and avgas for piston driven aircraft. The situation is different in each case. Could he clarify that?

—I am not getting confused. I said that I was led to believe by the answers I was given, in terms of the position at Estimates, that there was some confusion, but I said that I was returning to the position of 5,000-kilogram aircraft which, in fact, use avtur gas. I am talking in my detailed comments about aircraft using avtur.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that in the general sense, in real terms, the CAA has progressively decreased the charges that it is levying on the industry for each year that it has been in operation. I also know that not only is it the intention of the CAA, but also that it will have the capacity, to decrease each year, for the next few years, the overall level of charges levied on industry.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Crane would be aware, at the moment we are undertaking what is a difficult and very comprehensive complete restructuring of the Civil Aviation Authority. As I have said on previous occasions, most of the press and public attention is, probably not unreasonably, centred on the waterfront side of my portfolio. In fact, the changes that we are bringing about in the aviation area are just as unprecedented and as far reaching and, without question in my mind, as economically important for Australia as anything that is being done on the waterfront. I am sure that Senator Crane will be aware that there is a very substantial restructuring of the Civil Aviation Authority which is currently resulting in a very large number of its staff leaving and, of course, the installation of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of new technology over the next four or five years.

The reason I make that point is that the fundamental answer that the CAA has provided to Senator Crane is that the CAA has, in fact, produced a real saving to the industry of nearly $200m which was not the situation when it first took over four years ago. It asserts, as Senator Crane has indicated, that currently the level of charges that is being imposed on avtur aircraft is no greater than was previously imposed with the excise—the levy on the fuel.

Senator Crane is quite right, it is a matter of very great detail. I have read the response and I simply accepted the mathematics involved. I will certainly give Senator Crane an undertaking that we will double check the maths for him. The officers will have to do that, and I will respond to him as to whether these figures do stand up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this a little further. I do not see a lot of value in our having a debate over the figures on this aspect, but I would like a commitment from the Minister that I could present the costings as they impact on operators.
—Do you want to table them?
—Yes, I can table them.
—Certainly, just seek leave.
—I seek leave to table this document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also undertake to provide additional information to the Department or the Minister. I am not going to dispute the fact—in fact, I agree with it—that reforms of the Civil Aviation Authority and the waterfront are probably of equal importance and probably can provide equal savings and equal efficiency gains. The point I want to make is

SPEECH.PARA: that the result for individual operators is that the costs are significantly higher than those presented here. I will not make any further comment, other than to follow this through with the Minister to see whether we can get it sorted out and make sure that there are savings going through to the operators.

PARA.TAB: The next point I want to raise in regard to the Civil Aviation Authority concerns the position of operators who at certain times have problems paying the charges and fall behind. My understanding—and I would like this clarified—is that if an operator is having difficulties he can have his aircraft confiscated. What is the procedure in this situation? What leeway is given to people to allow them to catch up? This is particularly relevant to the case I have referred to, where an operator bought an aircraft which had some back payment debt on it. The debt to the Civil Aviation Authority went with the aircraft; it did not stay with the previous owner. The operator was unable to pick up the debt in time and he is now under threat of having that aircraft confiscated. In fact the debt really belongs to the previous operator. What is the policy position in that situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without knowing the individual details of the commercial transaction to which Senator Crane is referring—and in deference to the operator concerned, perhaps Senator Crane would like to discuss the matter with me privately—I would be astounded if that arrangement had anything whatever to do with the Civil Aviation Authority. I would be quite happy to accept that, in the commercial transaction that took place between the vendor and the purchaser of the aircraft, it may well have been part of the deal that the buyer would agree to—
—FAC?

—No, we are talking about CAA charges, not the FAC. It could well be that the seller of the aircraft had an arrangement with the buyer that the aircraft would be discounted by the purchaser being prepared to take responsibility for paying that debt. In another transaction in which I am involved fairly regularly—in the transfer of small businesses that have liquor licences, for example, where that is a real commercial asset and the original seller or the owner of the property may owe money to the liquor commission—it is not uncommon to have that taken into account. When the licence is renewed, the new owner then becomes obliged to pay that debt. I assume that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: To answer the first part of Senator Crane's question, the Civil Aviation Authority certainly has the power to place liens over aircraft. They only ever do so as a last resort.I can assure Senator Crane, from my experience with a number of matters involving small operators particularly that have come up while I have been Minister, that the CAA does go to considerable lengths to assist companies, provided it is within the overall context that these debts are owed to the CAA and have to be paid. In my experience, the CAA certainly goes to extreme lengths to assist people in the industry in organising payments. It is only as an absolute last resort that a lien would be placed over an aircraft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the opportunity to take this matter further with the Minister. Before concluding on this matter, I would like to read the first paragraph of a letter I have received from an operator. It states:

PARA.TAB: Further to my letter of 5 September 1991, I advise that the Civil Aviation Authority have taken their draconian powers another step further. I am advised that all of my aircraft are to be deregistered this month. I am at a loss to decide what to do, because it is not simply a matter of just going broke, as they have the liens over the aircraft for previous charges, which in some cases have absolutely nothing to do with me.

SPEECH.PARA: That is referring to the actual transfer. Clearly, when such a cost is included in the commercial transaction, I imagine that an operator with any business nous at all would offer a discount on the price to offset that, if it was being transferred. I would like to pursue this matter privately with the Minister to see whether we can sort it out. It seems to be an unusual practice and, on the surface, unsatisfactory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to accommodate Senator Crane privately in that respect. I make a general point to Senator Crane, although I am not suggesting for a minute that it applies to this particular case. First of all, I am obviously reluctant to speak in more specific terms because quite often in matters of this kind, as in the normal commercial world, legal action is afoot. As I discovered just recently in a matter that another senator was pursuing in relation to another organisation, not the CAA, in a series of questions that were asked—and I am not suggesting that this is the case with the matters raised by Senator Crane—the senator did not alert me to the fact that legal action was proceeding for recovery of the money and that the case was actually in court at the time the matter was being pursued. I subsequently discovered that. I think it is always wise, particularly having regard to the rights of the parties concerned, not to prejudice any legal action that might be afoot in canvassing these issues publicly.

PARA.TAB: There is a second general point I want to make, and again I am not suggesting that this applies to this specific case. It is often the case that, when aviation companies are in some financial difficulty, they deal on the basis of leaving the Government—that is, the CAA or the FAC or whoever—until last in trying to keep creditors from the door. As I have said many times before, it is an extremely difficult industry in which to operate successfully. I have said before that I would not personally be involved in it as an operator. One has to love flying. I regularly use some of the most efficient and professional operators, and I know that the overheads, the intense competition and so on in the industry mean that one has to be a good businessman to survive.

The difficulty for organisations such as the FAC and the CAA—and the bottom line eventually does have to be reached—is that they are expected to treat all operators in the aviation industry in the same way. I can assure the honourable senator, from personal representations I have occasionally received, that other operators in the industry who may be in direct competition with the company involved are not particularly happy to find out that arrangements, at least allegedly, are being made to provide something that may not be extended to them.

The difficulty is that at the end of the day, despite the best efforts of the CAA and the FAC to accommodate people who may be in this situation, because no-one wants to see anyone go to the wall if they do not have to, those organisations do have an obligation to levy the charges and recover the costs that all operators know they have to pay in order to use the facilities provided by these organisations and on which their business depends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate what the Minister has said, and I understand precisely what he is saying. In the case I referred to, I did ask whether there were any legal proceedings in place, because I was aware of that aspect. I was assured that there are not. I will pursue the matter from there.
—If there are no further questions on subprogram 1.6, we will regard consideration of subprogram 1.6 as concluded.

—The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee F which relates to the Department of Transport and Communications. The question is that the report by Estimates Committee F be adopted. When we broke for the dinner adjournment we suggested that we might come back to subprogram 1.5. Are there any matters in relation to 1.5?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I could give an explanation to the Committee and to Senator Tambling.
—Again?

—Yes, it is difficult. I did have a conversation with Senator Tambling briefly before I had to leave. I have just had to attend two meetings and I have literally not had a minute off since I left the chamber. I have just been to the Labour Advisory Council meeting and I have come from there: the meeting is still going on. The difficulty is—and Senator Tambling has agreed with this—that his request for a list of the concessionaires at the airports and for details of the progress, dates and conditions of the leases involves some commercial confidentiality. If those matters are made public, people might draw quite erroneous conclusions from the fact that some companies have executed leases and some have not. They may draw the wrong conclusions which may affect companies in terms of dealing with clients, particularly if they happen to owe money. Senator Tambling has conceded this point.

PARA.TAB: I apologise for this, but the difficulty is that I am literally the only person in my office who knows which bits to tear off and which bits to leave in the book, and I have just not had time. I wonder whether I could ask the attendant to take these papers to Senator Tambling. I have just torn out for him the lists of the concessionaires at both Darwin and Alice Springs airports. I have given an undertaking to Senator Tambling, which I will discharge, to give him, on a confidential basis, the rest of the page containing the remainder of the information he sought—that is, the dates that the leases have been executed and the actual state of each lease.

On the question of the cost to the FAC budget for interest or other costs to compensate concessionaires for the delays in opening Darwin and Alice Springs terminals, it is actually impossible at this stage to quantify that because the Federal Airports Corporation has conceded, in the Estimates Committee itself, that there may well be some compensation that has to be paid. I confirm that the Corporation is currently considering applications that have been made by two of the concessionaires as to claims for payments, but those negotiations are still under way. So the answer to Senator Tambling's question is that it is impossible to give a global figure at this stage because the matters are still under consideration. However, I can certainly give Senator Tambling an undertaking that, now that the dates of the opening of the two buildings have been set, the global figure—it will not be broken up into individual concerns—that is provided by the FAC in any negotiations that are concluded, will be provided to him publicly.

Without going into gory details, but to put it nicely in context for me, I must point out that recently I opened the airport terminal in Mackay, which is privately owned by the Mackay Port Authority. In Mackay I was interested to learn, quite independently of anything that had happened in the Northern Territory, that the negotiations between the Mackay Port Authority and the airlines over the leases to the buildings there were just as protracted and just as difficult as those over the leases for the Alice Springs and Darwin airport terminals. Perhaps Senator Tambling could jog my memory on the third matter raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The differences in costs between the north side and south side at Darwin airport for general aviation operators.

—I thank the honourable senator. There is in fact a schedule containing those amounts. Again, those figures are broken up into individual companies and, on the same basis and for the same reasons I have already given, I would much prefer to provide all that information to Senator Tambling on a confidential basis, which I will do. The general run of figures in an overall sense is that the valuations on the north side of the airport, which have been recommended by the Australian Valuation Office, range between $7 a square metre and $15 a square metre, depending on whether they are for heavy, medium or light use. Those figures cannot be relied upon because it is a matter of public record that the FAC, understanding the difficulties that some of the light aviation people are having, has made very significant offers of discounting and phasing in arrangements. I have no hesitation in saying again that until those negotiations have been completed with the companies concerned, first, it is simply not possible to give Senator Tambling an actual figure, because in some cases the figures have not yet been arrived at; and, secondly, in the case of the individual companies concerned, they would be commercially confidential.

PARA.TAB: However, those are the general terms of the north side leases which have been negotiated in that sort of range, and additional incentives are being provided to assist the operators in their move to the north side. That would compare with existing rental rates in what are, without question, compared with what is being offered now, very substandard facilities indeed. On the south side of the airport the figures are between $4 and $5 a square metre up to some higher figures, depending on what is provided by the FAC as part of those lease arrangements. Those are the broad figures and I have no difficulty in providing Senator Tambling with a breakdown of the detailed figures, company by company, on a commercially confidential basis.

In general terms, there has been a lot of publicity about this matter generated in the Northern Territory, a great deal of which has been inaccurate. I can fully understand the wishes of any company that is paying $X for anything not wanting to pay $X plus whatever it is. I can understand that. But as I have explained and demonstrated in the past, in the case of some operators who have claimed massive percentage increases for lease payments in moving from the south side to the north side of the airport, those percentage figures are totally misleading. Those operators have moved out of what are, in some cases, very grotty and cramped surroundings, and have asked not only for prime lots but also for areas of land that are five, six or 10 times in excess of the areas for which they are currently paying.

In conclusion, I can also advise Senator Tambling that I know of at least two operators who are in fact keen to move to the north side. They have already executed their arrangements with the FAC and paid deposits in terms of their commitment to move. I understand a third operator is also about to do that in the next 24 hours.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the information he has made available. I will briefly comment on each of the points that he has made. First, with regard to the list of tenancies at the Darwin and Alice Springs airports, I will be pleased to view privately the confidential information that the Minister has correctly withheld and I will respect that confidence. I ask that the same list that was handed to me here also be handed to the Committee Secretary so that it forms part of the official record of the Senate with regard to those particular concessions.

PARA.TAB: The second issue relates to the costs to the FAC budgets. The Minister has said that at the moment they are impossible to assess, but he will make publicly available the global figure when it is known, which I presume will be acknowledged when the dates of opening are finalised. The Minister has previously indicated that the opening date for Alice Springs will be 8 December and that for Darwin will be 14 December. I think it is important that that be acknowledged. There has been considerable speculation about the costs attributable to the various delays that have been caused by many factors in this whole area. It will be important for the public record that the additional costs are known so that people, including me, do not compound the figure unnecessarily. I appreciate that.

On the third issue, the Minister has outlined the ballpark figures relating to the lease charges that will be implemented for the movement of general aviation operators from the existing Darwin Airport site to the new north side facilities. I acknowledge that the facilities being provided are of a far superior standard to those that currently exist on the south side. It does concern me that on the figures that the Minister indicated, even after allowing for the various discounts and incentives that will be available, we will still be seeing the necessity, on a square metre basis, for lease costs to increase from between 50 per cent to 300 per cent.

I surely acknowledge that, if an operator chooses to take larger space than that from which he currently operates on the existing site, of course the operator will be up for the additional space allocation at whatever cost has to be negotiated. That is a reality of growth and changing to new facilities. But I think it will be of concern to many travellers, operators and business people in the Northern Territory that the operators, even if they took the same space requirement, would be up for additional lease rents, as I said, from 50 per cent to 300 per cent. That, of course, will be added to by the additional space that they take for their improved operations.

I am still concerned that, during the Estimates Committee hearings, the Minister, and I think some of the officers, indicated that there were problems in facilitating the move across of a number of the general aviation operators before March 1992, when the technical head leases with the Department of Defence expire on the existing sites. It will be very unfortunate if the operation of general aviation in the Northern Territory, Darwin in particular, has to be split between two locations over an extensive period of time, particularly if the operators are not able to negotiate special arrangements in the interim period with the Department of Defence.

During the Estimates Committee hearings I asked the FAC to attempt to accelerate and facilitate the moves and to ensure that even when it is no longer the landlord, after March 1992, no harsh and draconian actions are taken against any operator that would impact on the travelling public and which would affect so many people in northern Australia. This is important to the servicing of a large number of Aboriginal communities that use the general aviation facilities and also to a large number of tourists in the Northern Territory who access the general aviation tourist operations that currently operate.

I think we have had a long saga of change in getting the new facilities at the terminals in Darwin and Alice Springs operating. I do not want to rehash that ground because the Minister has now announced firmly the opening and operational dates. I acknowledge that it will be great when the travelling public will be able to use those facilities. I sincerely hope that we will not see an ongoing saga in the general aviation area that extends over an equally long period of time such as that which had to apply to the more commercial operations. In that regard, I acknowledge the information that the Minister has made available both here and on a confidential basis. There is one other issue, of course, which I presume the Minister is holding back in order to give me separate information on it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise Senator Tambling that I have been able to arrange for the drafting of a letter which will contain all of the commercially confidential information additional to what I have just given publicly. That will be in the chamber in half an hour and I will pass it to Senator Tambling. I am delighted to hear from Senator Tambling that he has been pressing the FAC to accelerate the move to the north side by the general aviation people. I must have been out of town that day and missed that statement, but I am delighted to hear that is his view; it is mine.

PARA.TAB: I have to take the entire blame for the delay that has been occasioned so far in the FAC accelerating this process. The FAC has been quite tense with me lately over this issue. It has soured otherwise good relations between us quite a bit. The FAC, I can assure Senator Tambling, has been consistent in wanting to accelerate this move of general aviation over to the north side of the airport. The one fly in the ointment consistently has been me and I freely confess it. Therefore, I am pleased to hear those words from Senator Tambling. I have been occasioning the only delay in that I asked the FAC to delay the official move until I had an opportunity to speak personally to operators, which I have done, and to ensure that the maximum amount of assistance was given to them. I have to say that I have been impressed with the steps the FAC has taken to assist the light aviation industry.

The reason that I make these points is that I received today what I consider to be a quite extraordinary letter on this issue from the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, Mr Finch. If I had it with me in the chamber, I would table it. Mr Finch indicated that he would be at the opening of the two terminals, whether he was invited or not. Perhaps in response to that, I could just say that I was astonished at the letter because of what I have said in the past. He made reference in the letter to my statement in parliament that I hoped he would not have the hide to turn up at the opening of these terminals, considering the five-year campaign waged against the FAC and these terminals. I want to make it clear that I have no role to play in the invitations that are being issued by the FAC. It is its terminal; it is its opening.

I have been invited to participate in the opening and have been delighted to accept. The invitations will be issued by the FAC and not by me, so I will have to refer Mr Finch's letter to the Corporation. It will be delightful to see him at the opening of the Darwin Airport terminal, in view of the fact that to this point he has never stuck his nose inside the building. I have always thought that was extraordinary considering, first, that he lives five minutes by road away from the front entrance of the building, and, secondly, that he came as far as the Northern Territory's road improvements. He was being watched by FAC employees at the airport who were taking bets on whether he would step across to the FAC side of the road to come up to look at the terminal.

I make no bones about saying that I think that it is one of the most small-minded performances from a politician that I have seen. Senator Tambling—and I have publicly acknowledged the efforts he has made over these airport terminals in the past—has gladly accepted the invitations that he has received and has visited both projects. I know that he was impressed with the buildings both at Alice Springs and Darwin. But the responsible Minister in the Northern Territory, Mr Finch, has railed against these projects for five years and deliberately has never set foot inside these buildings at any stage of their construction, despite the fact that he is the Northern Territory Minister most closely associated with these desperately needed airport facilities. I will not be inviting him because it is not my role to invite anybody, but I will be delighted to see Mr Finch at the opening of the Darwin Airport terminal because it will be the first time that he has set foot in this facility since construction work started.

The reason I make that point is that it has been a long hard slog to get these terminals established. We know what it cost the Labor Party politically. We had a rerun, by courtesy of the CLP, of the television pictures of the Prime Minister driving a bulldozer and turning the first sod in every election campaign thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's driven a dozer.

—Yes, and he did it well too. The facts are—and I have said this publicly before and do not mind saying it again—that the Alice Springs terminal is certainly a commercial terminal. The reason for that is that currently it does not require a very expensive international facility to be provided for what in Darwin are a relatively small number of international flights. Alice Springs has twice the passengers that Darwin Airport has because few are originating passengers. Alice Springs has become an extremely important aviation hub in Australia, I am delighted to say. It connects the west coast with the east coast and, indeed, the north coast with the south coast. It has become an attractive holiday package for people to transit through Alice Springs and to see the entire country by virtue of air travel in a matter of a week. Because of that the revenue from the terminal is good due to the extensive use of the terminal, but the facilities that have to be provided are not so great as they are in Darwin because they are mostly transit passengers through Alice Springs rather than originating passengers.

PARA.TAB: It was a very difficult battle indeed to get the FAC to accept Darwin on its list. In the end the Federal Government only did so through a lot of blood, sweat and tears. I personally put 10 years of political effort into this project, which no doubt is why I become a little agitated at times about the non-stop bucketing of it.

The facilities are there. I am pleased to say—and I know that Senator Tambling will agree with this assessment—that both buildings are magnificent. I am delighted that the design at Darwin has been so spectacularly successful. The arched roof entrance of the foyer, with a veranda style opening to the terminal, will make Darwin one of the more attractive terminals—I do not want to be too Top End parochial—in Australia. One cannot overstate the importance of these assets to one of our now most important industries, the tourist industry of the Northern Territory.

I know that I do not have to urge Senator Tambling to do so, but I would certainly urge on his colleague Mr Finch to stop his nonsense. This included an unbelievable performance only a couple of weeks ago when he declared that he, as Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, was to close one of the access roads into the airport.

There was an even more disgraceful performance—I can now fully tell the story for the first time; I could not tell it at the time—when in the middle of the project the firm of John Holland was desperately trying to finish as much of the exterior work as possible before the wet season, before the rain started, so that they could complete the internal work in the building, stories were peddled by Mr Finch and his office. I was told this personally by two Darwin journalists who had been the recipients of these stories. It was said that John Holland was about to go broke and this caused all the supplies to the airport terminals to be frozen for 24 hours by the suppliers. The opinion in John Holland at that time as to what went on was not fit to print. John Holland had done an extraordinary job on this airport terminal which was on budget, ahead of time and resulted in a beautifully finished building. This was at a time when the firm was racing the clouds and the wet season to get the work finished.

These stories were coming out of the relevant Northern Territory Minister's office, and I made that public. But what I have not made public is that the suppliers were so agitated at the source of these stories that they refused to release any supplies to the airport terminal construction site for a full day until the matter was laid to rest.

What I had to do, and I thought this was ridiculous, was to take a team of journalists out to the building with television crews so that they could actually film concrete being poured to counteract the stories that were being peddled from the Minister's office that all concrete pours had ceased at the building because John Holland was about to go under. On that occasion I even had to ring the Chief Minister's office to protest about it. I thought it was a disgraceful action for a Northern Territory Minister to take.

I hope that all those shenanigans and closing of roads will stop and that the Northern Territory Government will get behind the Commonwealth Government to make the opening of these terminals the same extraordinary success as the port authority in Mackay succeeded in doing, as Senator Macdonald will testify, when pretty close to 30,000 people turned out for the opening. It was a tremendous promotional exercise for the district. I hope that everybody cooperates in making sure that the opening of the terminals at Darwin and Alice Springs will be equally successful as a promotion for the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Tambling I remind honourable senators that we are dealing with reservations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully appreciate that, Mr Chairman, and the comments made by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) were by his own licence. They were not provoked or asked for. The issues dealt with in the last five or 10 minutes of conversation were not matters that I had raised.

PARA.TAB: The other issue on this topic that I would like to pursue with the Minister relates to the questions that we were discussing before the dinner adjournment on the remuneration of Dr Jean Battersby, the art adviser to the Federal Airports Corporation. As I indicated then, I did not consider the first part of the answer I received to be satisfactory, and I was looking to the Minister to provide information in regard to the details of the remuneration and the contract.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tambling has confirmed, he has been provided with the other parts of the answer—that is, the total expenditure on art acquisitions.

PARA.TAB: The question of Dr Battersby's remuneration has been declared to be commercially confidential. I can only reiterate that I support that position. I indicated before the adjournment that if Dr Battersby herself had no difficulty in having the matter disclosed I would have no difficulty. I said that for a very important reason. Dr Battersby operates in a highly competitive market of consultants who provide art advice to a whole range of organisations in Australia. It is a very competitive market indeed. It would be utterly detrimental to that individual in terms of her own business to have the rates that she has negotiated with the FAC made public. Her competitors would be delighted at that information being revealed. Despite Senator Tambling's assertion, I must assure him, as I thought would be obvious, that in a very competitive private industry the sorts of rates that are negotiated with clients can be of enormous value to one's competitors. That is the situation.

The FAC has assured me—and having seen the figures, I can certainly assure Senator Tambling that they demonstrate this to my satisfaction, although I have to say that Dr Battersby probably will not even like me delivering this—that the rates being paid to Dr Battersby are not only absolutely standard for the industry but are in the middle range of consultancy rates that are charged by other consultants in this highly competitive area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must take issue with the Minister on this point. The answer given to the Committee contained a statement by the Federal Airports Corporation that Dr Battersby's remuneration details were negotiated by her with the Corporation on the basis of similar contractual conditions currently applying in the art industry. Whilst the Minister has said that the rate is standard and in the middle range of other consultancies and, therefore, ought not invite any invidious comparison, he has not indicated whether Dr Battersby is in any way engaged on a percentage fee basis, whether a fixed salary or consultancy fee has been negotiated and how that applies with regard to the extent of the work.

PARA.TAB: In answers that I received some time ago about the Alice Springs and Darwin airports, I was advised that the budget allocations for the provision of art works were of the order of one per cent of the contract for those buildings. Whilst I have received in the second part of the answer the actual expenditure for the FAC throughout Australia, I have not received any breakdown of those figures or additional figures which relate to Dr Battersby's personal receipts or remuneration.

I do not share the Minister's concern about preserving confidentiality in this area. The Commonwealth Government negotiates with people in many other areas. Negotiations are always conducted on the basis of open tendering or contracting. Negotiations entered into by the Remuneration Tribunal or other organisations are open and information is available. I am not aware of any other statutory organisation or government department which keeps to itself the basis on which it engages consultants of this nature. I believe it is certainly not in the public interest for either the Minister or the Federal Airports Corporation to plead that information is in any way commercial-in-confidence.

Dr Battersby has been engaged by a public statutory corporation. The FAC would be well aware that it is common practice in all statutory corporations and government departments to make any of those contractual arrangements available in the appropriate parliamentary scrutiny forums or elsewhere. I merely indicate to the Minister that, if he believes that this matter requires this sort of secrecy, he will only invite further inquiry, whether by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or other bodies of this Parliament, and unnecessarily expose the Federal Airports Corporation to detailed inquiry into the entire program.

Art is an important part of any public building. But when taxpayers' funds or funds that are raised through loan borrowings, such as those of the Federal Airports Corporation, are used to pay for art work, I am very concerned that the Minister is not prepared to give this information. All I can say is: another time, another place and it would certainly become available.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to those comments. I do not know what the practice is in all government business enterprises. However, having sat on Estimates committees, I certainly know, for example, that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation does not provide individual figures for its presenters and so on. I have sat next to Mr Hill when he has provided a general range of salaries. I have given that information to Senator Tambling.

PARA.TAB: What I said was totally consistent with what Senator Tambling said. Dr Battersby is employed in the middle range in terms of indications of interest provided by other people in this area. I am happy to indicate to Senator Tambling the broad arrangements, without stating the figures. Dr Battersby, who is eminently qualified to do this job with her experience in the art world and her role for years on the Australia Council, has an arrangement with the FAC where she is paid a flat salary—it is a relatively modest amount, might I say—for which she is required to provide general consultancy to the FAC on art matters generally; that is, totally outside of selecting or providing the art works.

Dr Battersby is on a percentage of the art works acquired, which is also a standard arrangement in that industry with that kind of consultancy. She is on a daily retainer when she is actually engaged in providing art and supervising its erection, as she has done just recently in the Northern Territory. That is the fundamental basis of the arrangement with Dr Battersby. It is a fairly normal arrangement. I must also say that, having seen the art works in the Northern Territory terminals, I think Dr Battersby has been spectacularly successful. I think most people, when they come to the openings, will agree with that.

I just want to finish on a point raised by Senator Tambling before the suspension of the sitting for the dinner. I do not think he has thought it through sufficiently. He complained that more local artists should have their work included in terminals. I was actually lobbied by people in the local art community in Darwin who said that the art works should be provided exclusively by Northern Territory artists. That would be a very detrimental policy for the FAC to adopt. Indeed, I might say that it would be detrimental to Territory artists. It would be an absolute nonsense to suggest that only local artists could provide art works for the buildings in their regions. This would immediately deny the access that I know Territory artists have had to FAC terminals in other parts of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask the Minister to clarify one of the points that he has just made. He has indicated that Dr Battersby receives a percentage on the acquisition of art works by the FAC. TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the Estimates Committee, at some incredible hour in the morning when the officers of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation were required to be present, we pursued a number of issues with the Minister and the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr David Hill.

PARA.TAB: One of the points I raised and pursued related to the sale of housing owned by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I sought additional information with regard to a number of properties that had been sold. I asked for details of the values at which they had been sold, the dates on which they were sold, and how the calculations had been adopted. I received quite a comprehensive list of properties that have obviously been sold recently by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

What concerned me most was that the Corporation had sold a number of these houses with valuation dates quite some considerable time before the date of sale. This is an issue I have raised in other estimates, across a number of other statutory authorities of the Government and several Government departments, including the Department of Administrative Services. What came out of the various inquiries I made of the ABC, the other departments and the agencies of government is that there is no consistent policy relating to the manner in which government housing is sold.

Whilst there are some general principles that have been struck largely between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Trades and Labour Council, a number of the statutory authorities in particular have chosen to implement the sales schemes in different manners, particularly with regard to the date of valuation of a property. This concerns me. When we look at the various deals that have been struck under these arrangements with the Trades and Labour Council, we see that the great majority of properties have had valuations predated six months, 12 months or up to 18 months prior to the sale of the property.

In some cases, this has resulted in substantial differences between the contract value, or the sale price, and what ought to have been the current market value of the property at the date of sale. An example instanced recently affected the ABC in the Northern Territory where a property was sold for a figure in the vicinity of $90,000 but the valuation was just above $100,000. Because of several discounts and credits that were available under the schemes that had been negotiated, the sale price—given that it was a predated valuation—was about $90,000. From memory, the sale was consummated in April or May. Two months later, the staff member who purchased the property sold it on the open commercial market for $155,000—a 50 per cent capital gain. Of course, that issue received considerable media attention at that time.

I have been concerned that, because of the administrative delays that have been cemented into the contracts by various departments or agencies such as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, there have been considerable losses to the taxpayer. The purchaser has gained a particular advantage. In most of the schemes that have been put in place, they have the right to sell freely on the open market without constraint. I acknowledge that some departments have sales constraints on them. But when I analysed all the answers I received from the various statutory authorities and departments, those with constraints were in the minority; by far the great majority did not have constraints. In fact, the Department of Administrative Services has some 100 properties being offered for sale to tenants that are currently based on these retrospective valuations. The loss is quite considerable.

I believe that the principles in this sort of market sale situation have in effect been seriously eroded, and to a very large extent these special deals that have been struck between the Federal Government and the unions are unhealthy. I appreciate that I cannot in any way step in and alter any of these contractual situations that have been negotiated. However, I call on the Federal Government to review this valuation process. No State or Territory government would be allowed to adopt this sort of process under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement for the sale of their Housing Commission stocks, which must be sold at current market value on the date of application by the tenant. This creates a tremendous anomaly in the sale of public housing that is available. On the one hand, we have tenants of Housing Commission homes who have to pay full market value for the houses they purchase under the agreements and the arrangements; on the other hand, public servants or employees of statutory authorities such as the ABC are given a special privileged situation.

The other issue I raised with Senator Bolkus in one of the Estimates committees was that I do not believe that statutory authorities such as the ABC, or even Government departments, have yet fully acknowledged that they are probably going to have to foot the bill for fringe benefits tax. They have allowed valuations for housing sales to be retrospective and there has been a period in between.

When the Government or its agencies or its statutory authorities strike special deals with their employees and their unions, they should front up to their financial responsibilities under the fringe benefits tax, just as any private sector employer would have to do if it sold housing to its employees.I instance people who work for mining companies or people in remote communities who negotiate housing arrangements. There would be no way in the world that the Australian Taxation Office would not pursue with a vengeance any private similar stunt.

I believe it is incumbent on the Australian Broadcasting Commission to acknowledge and to recognise this. Has it discussed this matter with the Australian Taxation Office and has it had to pay any fringe benefits tax? Certainly, we need to be assured that, in any future sales of this nature that are negotiated around Australia, the Commonwealth does not avoid its proper responsibilities to the taxpayer, to the tenants of Housing Commission homes, and to the very employees it is seeking to serve.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to advise Senator Tambling that I do not have any information of that detail in my brief. Unfortunately, the officers present do not have that information either. I simply want to acknowledge the importance of the questions asked by Senator Tambling. I also have a healthy interest in them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Estimates hearings I asked Mr Hill a question on editorial control in Radio Australia. I asked whether, in terms of the broadcasts going out through Radio Australia, skilled journalists had the final responsibility for what went out. In reply to my question Mr Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: The newsroom decides on the stories and then the broadcast officer with the language skills translates and it is broadcast. That system is unchanged, except that there has been a very long demarcation dispute that we are trying to overcome, which means that you have two different unions handling copy. We are optimistic that at last we are going to break through there, but apart from reducing the demarcation system whereby the newsroom decides editorially the news copy and the translator translates, that system will stay.

I do not believe that that answer was strictly correct. In fact, there has been a substantial change in the position adopted previously by Radio Australia. I believe that editorial discipline and editorial control and responsibility are of extreme national importance, by virtue of the fact that Radio Australia broadcasts into the north Asia region, the south Asia region and the Pacific. There are international ramifications for Australia if the stories are not controlled, the disciplines are not there or we get the stories wrong.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that Mr Hill's answer was strictly correct because on 12 August 1991 there was a significant change to the procedure adopted by Radio Australia. Prior to 12 August a chief subeditor and a duty editor had the final responsibility for determining the final stories and the order in which they went out through Radio Australia. This matter was raised with me by a couple of journalists from Radio Australia and I have checked it with a couple of others independently. A letter to me reads:

SPEECH.PARA: You may be interested to know that under a system introduced to Radio Australia on August 12, 1991, the 50-year-old practice of experienced journalists deciding which stories are used by the foreign language services ceased. Since that date, the only control which Radio Australia journalists retain in determining the composition of foreign language news broadcasts is through the designation of certain stories as "must runs" i.e., that they must be used. However, we have been instructed to keep the number of `must run' stories to a bare minimum. The foreign language services are at liberty to select whatever other stories written by the journalists that they may wish to use from a common "pool" of stories. This amounts to a fundamental change in the operation of the newsroom and has resulted in considerable anguish among journalists about the appropriateness of some of the stories which have been selected for use in foreign language news broadcasts. It is a matter of great concern to the newsroom journalists at Radio Australia that foreign language broadcasts are now under the total control of persons who in many cases are not Australian citizens and who may not have Australia's interests at heart.

I am extremely concerned that these changes could sabotage the valuable role which Radio Australia can play in helping our nation to develop a better relationship with the countries of the Asia-Pacific region.

In addition to that, which is a journalist's interpretation, I also have a direction on information program coordinators which went out under the name of the General Manager of Radio Australia, Mr Broinowski. That spells out quite clearly that in future broadcast offices in each of the three regional services would carry out information program coordination in isolation from journalists.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the changes that have been made there are a lot more significant than Mr Hill led us to believe in the answer he gave to us in Estimates hearings. These changes concern me. I do not believe that, in the situation that exists now, there is a chief editor totally responsible for the selection of stories that go out through Radio Australia, as is indicated by the information I have presented. On top of that, I am also informed that, even with the changes that have been made, about 10 per cent of the `must run' stories have not been used under the current modus operandi. I regard that as being equally serious.

However, that is not my main concern. My main concern is that Radio Australia is now operating without a chief editor in control of the editorial content of the stories that are broadcast. I ask the Minister to examine this issue. It is very serious and should be addressed, because it goes beyond the shores of Australia. It goes to our near neighbours, particularly countries such as Indonesia and Thailand, to name just two, and from time to time relations between Australia and those countries are at best rather tenuous.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my answer to Senator Crane by commending and supporting Radio Australia on this particular change. It is an extremely sensible change which is designed to improve the attractiveness of what, I am pleased to say, is already an internationally renowned and very popular service in the areas to which it is broadcast. I understand perfectly the correspondence that the journalists in the newsroom have sent to Senator Crane. Indeed, I have seen a copy of it myself and I fully understand the reasons why they have done so. But I am sure that Senator Crane would appreciate the very sensible reasons why Radio Australia has chosen to change the arrangements in the way it has.

PARA.TAB: The most obvious comparison I can draw with this arrangement which may be familiar to Senator Crane—it is certainly familiar to a number of people in this building—is the AAP news scan service which we are able to access on the computers in our offices. As Senator Crane would be aware, AAP provides two levels of stories in that news service: high and low. The arrangements at Radio Australia are a lot tighter than this, but that is a reasonable comparison.

The stories are sent out on the wire to the hundreds of newspapers that take that copy. The reason it is done that way—apart from having a pool of journalists accessing the stories—is that the high priority stories are clearly flagged with `high' to draw the attention of editors, subeditors, chiefs of staff and so on to the particularly newsworthy stories. But the actual choice as to what stories from that pool appear—particularly stories from the secondary pool of low priority stories—is made by local journalists in the regions they serve because they are best equipped and trained to know what stories their readers would find most interesting and newsworthy.

That is precisely why Radio Australia has made this change, and it is a commendable one. These broadcasters are specially trained people, not only selected for their linguistic skills but also obviously selected for their intimate knowledge of the culture and the regions to which they are broadcasting.

I will conclude this answer by giving Senator Crane the statistical information which may be of interest to him and which is directly pertinent to his question. There are 38 broadcasters employed: 14 of them are in fact citizens of Australia; 23 of them are permanent residents of Australia, which means that they have actually been in this country for a significant period of time; and only one of these broadcasters is neither a citizen nor a permanent resident.

The `must run' stories are `must run' stories; the broadcasters are not allowed to alter any of the copy. They simply have to deliver it as it is written in the newsroom. All of the copy is prepared in the newsroom by Australian journalists, so the stories that are produced originally are all produced by Australian journalists. But the choice of which secondary stories to run is a matter for the skills of the broadcasters, who choose them according to what they believe would be interesting in the areas to which they are broadcasting.

I can assure Senator Crane that there is still overall editorial control of what goes out. I am concerned to hear his claim that 10 per cent of the `must run' stories are not run, because they must be run. If Senator Crane, or anyone else, can provide me with specific information supporting these claims, I can assure him that the matter will be investigated thoroughly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I find the Minister's answer extraordinary. I say that in the sense that it is quite different from Mr Hill's answer to the question that I put to him—of course, the Minister's answer was a lot more verbose as well. I want to come back to the central point because the Minister did not address it properly. Under the changed system, whereby there are a number of people determining what will go out through the system without having a chief editor in control, how can the discipline be maintained in management?
—I said there is one, Senator.
—He is not in control.
—Madam Acting Deputy Chairman, I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—I want to refer the Minister to the answer provided on the question of plagiarism in the ABC. I asked this question of Mr Hill and, to his credit, he did appear to take it quite seriously. The answer that has been provided is a lengthy one which deals in particular with the Copyright Act and, to a lesser degree, with the guidelines. But the significant thing is that the ABC editorial and program policy guidelines, as amended to June 1991, contain no specific reference to the issue of plagiarism.

PARA.TAB: The Minister will recall that I raised the question because it had become very topical in the print media, with a particular journalist with the Fairfax organisation in Melbourne losing his position because he had plagiarised an English article. There had also been other examples of plagiarism in the print media. Many of us who had been listening to an interchange that occurred regularly between Paul Lyneham and Andrew Olle noted that there was never any reference or source given for information which, quite clearly, sometimes came from the print media.

I have noted, on the odd occasion I have heard that interchange between those two gentlemen since I raised the point, that Mr Lyneham has in fact acknowledged a particular journalist's by-line. I cannot say it happens on every occasion because I do not listen frequently enough, but I have noticed that change and I am pleased the matter was taken seriously because I think it is reasonable that it should have been.

But I am still concerned that no part of the answer which has been provided says that the guidelines ought to, or will be, amended in a timely way—or whatever the expression might be—so that there is a specific provision in the guidelines which people can readily see. In saying that I have noticed an improvement and that I am pleased Mr Hill took the matter seriously and that it has been answered in a serious way, I still think it would be a better solution to go one step further and include it in the guidelines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am not the relevant Minister, I will be brave enough to say that I tend to agree with Senator Bishop. I can assure her that I will put that suggestion to Minister Beazley and he will put it to the ABC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not finished my previous questions, as I was a bit slow on the uptake. I want to make just one comment about the Minister's answer and the answer that was given by Mr Hill. Mr Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the newsroom decides editorially the news copy and the translator translates, that system will stay.

The Minister answered quite differently. He congratulated Radio Australia on the changes and said it was quite sensible because the people who, I guess, are in the outer reaches select the stories. He said that was advantageous because they knew what the local situation was, and such situations can be quite different.

PARA.TAB: I have a further question regarding Radio Australia. As I understand it, we now have a situation where contracted radio producers are coming in and preparing programs during the week which are then broadcast over the weekends. I understand that the reason behind that move is to avoid overtime and additional costs. If that is being done, it obviously means that the staff who used to work on the weekends would cease to have a useful function in preparing and putting together programs. Have there been any retrenchments with regard to the staff of Radio Australia because of the changed policy?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

—I want to pass a brief comment on the answer supplied in relation to the question of bias that I raised concerning the Paul Lyneham interview of Mr Andrew Peacock prior to the last election. PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—If there are no further questions on subprogram 2.2, we will move on to subprogram 2.5, `Broadcast operations'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

—We will now deal with program 4, `Land transport', and subprogram 4.1, `Road and rail policy development'.

—I have a question regarding country passenger services. I put the following questions on notice. Will AN maintain country passenger rail services and, if so, which ones? What is the subsidy provided to each service? In answer to the first two questions, the Minister said that the future of AN's former regional passenger service is under consideration following a determination by an independent arbiter who advised that the Adelaide to Mount Gambier line should not close. The Minister said that AN has advised that the existing rolling stock is life expired and cannot be used to reinstate service and consequently AN has been asked to provide advice on options available for the provision of a passenger service between Adelaide and Mount Gambier and other routes formerly served by AN's regional passengers. The Minister then went on to give the subsidy per passenger.

PARA.TAB: This independent adviser told the Minister that AN should not close the Mount Gambier service. However, when we get to Mount Gambier—I presume that is the Blue Lake service—we find that there is a subsidy per passenger of approximately $100. Considering the distance between Mount Gambier and Adelaide, one could just about fly that route for about $100. In the light of the rolling stock having been worn out, why does the Minister consider that that passenger service should be kept going?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

—We will now deal with subprogram 5.3.

—I have received an answer to a question on notice, the story of which concerns the fact that we have been told by the Minister on various occasions—I think Mr Sharp, the shadow Minister for waterfront reform, has been told once or twice a day—that we are now coming to the end of the program for restructuring the waterfront. We were advised as late as today of how more efficiently wheat has been handled and, of course, I read that in the newspaper this morning, as I told the Minister when he was answering a question.

PARA.TAB: The Government has now come to the stage where it has restructured the waterfront, it has said to itself that it is almost there, yet there are still 600 to 700 men idle on the waterfront each day. The Minister should stop shaking his head, because that is correct. I know this has come about because of the downturn in trade. I ask how the Government is going to handle that. If there are 600 or 700 men idle every day on the waterfront, I believe the responsibility for paying them should lie with the whole community rather than those who use the waterfront for freight purposes. Can the Minister tell me how he is going to handle that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was shaking my head to try to save time by not having to speak. I assure Senator Panizza, first of all, that there are no longer 600 or 700 people a day on idle time. That was the whole advantage of being able to conclude all the EBAs in Melbourne and Sydney. The numbers that have gone out have effectively removed that idle time problem.

PARA.TAB: To put this statement in context, I have said that the waterfront reform program is substantially completed in the capital city ports and, indeed, in the grain handling ports. We still have a significant amount of work to do in the regional ports. I am certainly confident, in particular from what I heard recently from Western Australia, that that process will also be effectively concluded. There is no major level now of excess labour in the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister give me a figure of what he thinks there is? He says he does not think there is any excess. Maybe it was 600 or 700 last week. Can he give me a figure of what it would be this week?

—I do not think I need to be more precise than to say it is currently around 200. That is, in fact, the sort of figure that one would expect to be the minimum needed on a waterfront. A level of idle time is always a component of waterfront operations because of the nature of the industry. The difficulty is that that is the case, and the reason why the option of casual labour is just not a workable option any more is that people no longer sling bags on their backs with hooks; they now operate very expensive and often very sophisticated equipment. The answer to the question is that it is around that figure which is quite a reasonable level for normal industry operations.
—Around what figure—600 or 700?
—No, it is around 200.
—We will now deal with subprogram 6.3.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to raise a matter of broad policy under the corporate area. I was going to say that the Minister is aware, but he may be aware, that earlier today I raised in the consideration of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy an issue of policy that was also jointly developed by the Department of Transport and Communications. This is the paper that was presented to us in the Estimates Committee which detailed the Government's responses to 24 recommendations arising from the special transport conference convened by Mr Snowdon, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, in Alice Springs in March of this year.

PARA.TAB: I was given a very comprehensive answer. I can only presume that, as it is headed, `Responses to recommendations, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy', officials of this Department and advisers to the Minister, in effect, worked on preparing the details of that Government response. It is a very comprehensive document—11 pages long. There are details with regard to all 24 recommendations that were the outcome of the March 1991 conference in Alice Springs.

I was unable to get a satisfactory answer from Senator Cook with regard to the initiatives of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I now ask whether Senator Collins is able to confirm, with regard to the work that has been done by departmental officials that was adopted by the Cabinet and the Government as the Federal Government's response to these 24 recommendations, that the initiatives and proposals that are to be put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Premiers Conference as a matter of policy in the area of transport later this month in Perth, are consistent with the comments on the 24 recommendations that were presented to us several weeks ago by this Department and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy jointly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)
