TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, with the best will in the world I cannot answer that question because I am not privy to the internal level of negotiations between the Prime Minister and the Premiers at the Premiers Conference. What I am happy to do is attempt to get from the Prime Minister's office whatever answer it can provide at this time. I imagine that will be constrained to some extent by the fact that these negotiations have not yet commenced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the negotiations with the Premiers will not be concluded until such time as the Premiers actually meet in Perth, which I think will be on 21 November. What concerns me is that the initiatives and proposals being presented to that conference by the Federal Government, by the Prime Minister, are, in effect, a reflection of the Cabinet decisions taken a month or so ago that resulted in a response to a report that was tabled in this Parliament as part of the official response to questions asked in the Estimates Committee. We asked the questions and that solicited and brought forward the 24 recommendations arising from Mr Snowdon's conference in March. The Cabinet must have addressed all of those 24 issues, because it has presented to us a Federal Government response on each of those initiatives.

PARA.TAB: What I am keen to establish is whether the officers of the Department, in the negotiations that they are having with other Federal departments and with Federal Ministers, are in any way altering the recommendations that the Government itself acknowledged. I am not asking for the detail of what might finally be in the agreement between the Federal Government and the States, as I appreciate that will be subject to all the negotiation and the argy-bargy that will take place at the Premiers Conference. However, I do want a guarantee that the Federal Government is at least speaking consistently in what it tables here as a response to a major community report and in relation to what the Prime Minister says to the Premiers as to how he sees the position of the Federal Cabinet.

I hope that there has been no compromise or no change in position by the Federal Government on this issue in the past month, given that we have before us a very important report of 24 points that the Federal Government saw as its initiative. I want to know whether there has been any change in that position by the Prime Minister, by the Minister for Transport and Communications, by the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, or by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, who was indeed the sponsor of this conference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot understand why Senator Tambling wanted to repeat his previous question at such tedious length, which is what he did.
—Don't compound the felony.
—I am trying to cooperate. I cannot add anything to my previous answer.

—I had a question on notice, under subprogram 6.2, asking when the finding on the Amann case was expected to be handed down. I was told in the reply that the case had been heard in the High Court in February this year and that judgment was expected later this calendar month—which I presume is this month, November. A sum of $6.3m was allowed, in case there was settlement. I ask the Minister how that $6.3m figure was arrived at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the answer given to Senator Panizza and I have nothing to add to that answer.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The Committee will examine firstly the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee A which relates to executive departments. The Chairman of Committees wants to make an opening statement so I shall hand over to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall make some brief comments before we begin consideration of the report of Estimates Committee A. In general, reservations to all committee reports for this series of Estimates have been well constructed. In mentioning this, I do not make any judgment about the scope of the reservations because it is not my role to do so. I would, however, mention that two reservations in Estimates Committee A are unusual in that they contain arguments about senators' particular reservations. There is nothing in the Standing Orders preventing reservations being attached to reports in this form. Nevertheless, I would ask honourable senators to consider listing reservations without debate in a similar way to the method used by the majority of other senators.

PARA.TAB: When the current system of listing reservations was introduced, it was envisaged that reservations would be succinct, mentioning the particular programs or subprograms which were to be subject to further examination by the Senate. Debate could then take place when the reservations were addressed in the Committee of the Whole.

Honourable senators may also like to consider that, if arguments are advanced in reservations, these arguments are on the record without, where applicable, any counter comments being associated with those arguments. Without in any way taking a partisan political stance, I must admit that I was concerned in places in relation to some of the comments made in the reservations to which I have referred. I would suggest that honourable senators and Committee staff consider the matter in relation to future reservations to Estimates Committee reports.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to this Bill be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. In relation to that Department and other departments to be considered in relation to Estimates Committee A, I would like to go according to the running sheet. I must mention that this was an innovation for this series of Estimates debates, and it has been a tremendous help to the Chair, and I am sure to honourable senators as well. I understand that before we start on the running sheet there is a matter to be dealt with that is not attributed to any portfolio, and it relates to the allocations of portfolios to Estimates Committees—and this is on page 6 of the report of Estimates Committee A. Is there any comment in relation to that matter?

—Mr Chairman, the structure and the way in which Estimates Committee A deals with its reports and its reservations is this: there is a draft report written and it is discussed at a committee meeting. That part of the material which is included and can be acceptable to all members of the Committee is included in the report. Those matters which the Government will not agree to or which the Opposition is not interested in having in the report are placed in a reservation, which, if you like, is a dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: The item that is in the report relates to the allocation of portfolios, namely, that we have more than other people, if you like. I do not know whether it was the intent of Government members of the Committee to have that dealt with as some sort of complaint. That was not my feeling at the time. From the point of view of Opposition members, we are quite happy to deal with the workload, and I would not wish that inclusion in the report to be construed in any way, shape or form as a complaint about the amount of work that is required to be done. To the contrary, it is important work and it is done with due diligence, certainly from the Opposition members. Perhaps, Mr Chairman, you could inform me whether or not I can comment on the statement that you made at the opening of this session.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I hope that the comments that I made were taken in the spirit in which I intended them to be taken, as helpful comments. I am sorry, I do not have a typed statement, but I think you gained the gist of it.

—Mr Chairman, it is just that I did not understand your comments. I did not know to what they were meant to allude; if they were meant to be helpful, that is fine. There are many reservations in here, which were done by different folk, and so far as the Opposition members of the Committee are concerned we write a dissenting report, or a reservation if you like, which reports on the findings as we see them and which we wish to bring to the attention of the Senate. So I do not really understand what your remarks were aimed at and I do not know whether I should take exception to them or not, because they were indeed rather oblique.

—I think I framed my words in such a way that honourable senators would not take exception to them because the comments were meant to be helpful. It may be that when my comments are typed, and you are able to look at them, they may make more sense. I will leave it at that but, if you have any problem with it, you will be able to check it with me.
—I can only take what you have just said, that your remarks were directed at—I do not quite know what.

—If you want me to be specific—and I did not want to be specific because I did not want to single out any particular honourable senators—the two reservations to which I referred were the one by yourself and Senator Short, and the one by Senator O'Chee. I did make the point when I spoke that there is nothing in the Standing Orders preventing reservations being attached to reports in the form that they were in this case, but I did make some suggestions about them. I invite you to have a look at my comments in detail. I was just trying to be helpful.

—I will leave it after this, but I did have a sort of suspicion that it might have been a backdoor version of trying to make a point along the way. However, I accept the point that you make, that it is quite in accordance with the Standing Orders. Certainly, Senator Short and I signed our particular reservation quite deliberately—Senator O'Chee signed his because he had to go overseas and was not present when the signatures had to be made available—and with full knowledge of what we were saying. We considered them to be quite proper. Now perhaps we will just move on.
—I invite you to look at my comments when they are typed because I think they should be helpful to honourable senators.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously when we come to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button will be handling it. However, I wanted to make a very brief response to the question to which you, Mr Chairman, and Senator Bishop made reference concerning the allocation of departments to Estimates committees. I do not want to divert us on to that now, but I simply indicate that I do have some concern about what seems to be a misallocation of resources. Senator Bishop asked whether I wanted to complain about the volume of work; I do not expect the volume of work to change, but I think we may need to have a serious look at the allocation of the work, given that one committee is doing twice as many hours as all the others. That does not seem to be efficient use of staff time or of senators' time. But that is not an issue for debate here. However, given that it has been raised, I put it on the record as a matter that can be discussed at some appropriate time between now and the next time when we refer portfolios to Estimates committees.

—Just so that no-one can say that we acquiesced in Senator McMullan's belief that somehow the use of time made by Estimates Committee A was not efficient, I stress that I believe that it was quite efficient, and I believe the public response that comes to matters elicited is becoming more and more widely known and people are appreciating the fact that there is scrutiny in the Parliament. I would not wish to have a statement that, because the Committee took longer to sit than other committees, it was somehow less efficient. In effect, it is most efficient and the time was well spent.

—To support Senator Bishop's remarks in that respect, I read with interest an article by Senator McMullan in the Canberra Times two or three weeks ago about the role of Estimates committees. It generally came down to the line, `Well, there was a bit of effort in them, but really they are a pretty tiresome bore'. I guess if I were in government, if I were in Senator McMullan's shoes, I might feel a bit the same way. But I think it is quite an extraordinary thing to say because, as Senator Bishop has said, over the past few years the Estimates committee process has really proved itself to be an extraordinarily beneficial one—and not just for the political parties. I guess it always tends to help the Opposition rather than the Government, but it is not totally a one-way street. As a Senate, we have elicited a lot of information of great benefit to the general public. Indeed, one of the great problems in being a politician is that you spend your life being snowed by people who do not want you to know things that you ought to know if you are to represent your constituents properly. So, I must say I took some slight offence, some surprised offence, at Senator McMullan's remarks on the Estimates process. I thought it was a fairly inept thing for him to say. We all have the opportunity to be as time efficient as possible, and I think we all try to do that. As Senator Bishop says, the time spent in relation to particular Estimates committees is often simply a reflection of the significance of the matters with which we are dealing. We did take longer in Estimates A than the other committees, but what came out of that, right across the board in terms of all the departments and agencies with which we dealt, showed that it was really a time efficient process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92, at end of motion, add:

",subject to the following request for amendment to the House of Representatives: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the bill by reducing the vote for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce by $989,000, being the amount of payments in respect of the Multifunction Polis for the second half of the financial year 1991-2.".
In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1991-92, at end of motion, add:
``, subject to the following amendment:
That the vote for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce be reduced by $2,772,000, being the amount of payments to South Australia in respect of the Multifunction Polis.".
I have been feeling unwell all day and I very much appreciate the opportunity to move these amendments together and to get home as soon as this is over.

PARA.TAB: Both of the amendments which I put relate to the multifunction polis. They are covered on pages 120 and 121 of the program performance statement of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I think that over quite some time now I have stated my concern about the so-called MFP in Adelaide. We have seen recent reports in which the Japanese interests have indicated that they want guaranteed profits. We have seen other statements, both by the Premier of South Australia and by Japanese interests, that without some further inducement the MFP will not proceed. Prior to that and going back quite some considerable time I asked Senator Button a question in the Senate to which he replied that no government money would be spent on the MFP. For all these reasons, not least because a number of members of the Opposition, some in the South Australian Parliament—notably Jennifer Cashmore—and some in this Parliament to whom I have spoken privately, have expressed the sorts of concerns which I have expressed, namely, that the MFP is nothing more than a brave attempt to support the Premier of South Australia in his bid for the next election.

The two amendments that I have moved are to prevent good money going after bad. In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1), only a request can be made to the House of Representatives. This is a request to reduce the total amount. In relation to that, the total program element listed on page 120 is $1.978m. We are assuming that because the year is half over approximately half of that money would have been spent. So, clearly, we could not make a request that the total amount be removed. Accordingly, the request in this amendment is for a reduction to an amount of $989,000.

The other amendment is to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) and refers to the amount of $2.772m for a feasibility study into the multifunction polis which, we understand, has not yet commenced; therefore, no money has been expended. Accordingly, we are seeking the total removal of that $2.772m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to put the two questions separately. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Coulter in relation to Estimates Committee A's report on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put the second question. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Coulter in relation to Estimates Committee A's report on Appropriation Bill (No. 2) be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now deal with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. We will begin with program 1, `Industry Sectors', and go to subprogram 1.3, `Light industries'.

—This might be an appropriate time to deal with this matter. When we were dealing with consultants' reports as they were listed, we were having some difficulty in finding any report that did anything useful and was beneficial from a taxpayer's point of view. Instead of going through each consultancy one by one, I made the Minister an offer: choose any three of these reports and present a report to the Committee going through the steps of how and why it was commissioned, what was done with it and what happened as a result of its dissemination, and name three people who benefited in a material way from the publishing of the report. In fact, three such reports were chosen, one relating to the Australian Space Office.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that the three reports that were chosen do not satisfy any of the criteria. There is no benefit to any individual cited and it just confirmed what I thought, that the reports were almost a make work program. I am disappointed that we could not find a single beneficiary, including the Australian Space Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are no further questions on subprogram 1.3, I shall move to subprogram 2.1, `Innovation'.

—I just note with regard to the IR&D Board that a process had been instituted some years ago whereby lists of people who had been successful in obtaining grants were published every six months. I think we have agreed that a report of any interest which any board member may have in a particular applicant which ought to be disclosed will now be made every 12 months, as distinct from every six months, still requiring any declaration of interest to be made and reported upon. The Minister might confirm whether his recollection is the same as mine.
—Yes.
—As there are no further matters on subprogram 2.1, we will move to subprogram 2.7, `Commission for the Future'.

—I think it is important to note that we had some difficulty in garnering the presence of people from the Commission for the Future. However, the Minister did agree to their appearing subsequently. I think it is important to note that we would expect someone from the Commission for the Future to continue to appear as that organisation is funded from the Budget by way of appropriation, even though an intent was expressed that there may be a run off over three years and it may then not receive any funding by way of appropriation. In the final analysis, that could not be established as the way in which things would proceed. It may well be that at the end of three years it will get a further appropriation. It is important to adhere to the principle that if an agency is funded it must present for Estimates hearings.
—As there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 2.7, we shall deal with program 4, `Australian Customs Service', and subprogram 4.1, `Industry assistance'.

—As indicated here, the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989 as well as the 1980 Act are dealt with. In looking at the regulations that were made pursuant to the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 and the requirements in the 1989 Act, we see the requirements for registration of a firm to be eligible for a bounty set out and that those requirements are in fact very strict and, in the first instance, are requirements that the Minister shall meet. The Comptroller of Customs has general administration of the Act and is responsible for verifying eligible costs.

PARA.TAB: There are several things which have to be established in order that registration for bounty payment purposes occur. One of those is that the Minister shall not register an applicant unless the Minister is satisfied that the applicant has the necessary technical and financial management skills to complete construction, has access to a waterfront site, carries out at least 75 per cent of his activities on vessels between 150 and 10,000 gross construction tonnes and employs at least 40 persons.

I am concerned that, in the case I have raised regarding the building of the boat The Other Woman for Mr Cantor, the firm Runmere Pty Ltd that was registered for the purposes of bounty payment, and in fact received the first bounty payment of $2.8m in respect of The Other Woman, came into existence only in the middle of 1987 and went into liquidation in September 1989. In other words, the firm existed for a bare two years.

According to the last statement I have been able to obtain from the liquidators, it left debts of $4.5m. The boat yard, which was a major asset of the firm, was encumbered and subsequently sold at auction to none other than Mr Cantor, who bought it for less than its value. The owners of Runmere had to make up the difference out of the sale of their houses to satisfy the debt to the bank.

Bearing in mind that the bounty payments were in the vicinity of millions of dollars and that there is a requirement that the Minister shall be satisfied that a boat builder has the necessary technical and financial management skills to complete the construction—in this case it did not complete the construction; in fact EFIC was obliged to pay out at least $2.23m, if not another $1.5m, because it could not complete the boat—I want to know how on earth one can say that the requirement regarding the necessary technical and financial management skills for the purposes of registration for obtaining a bounty was satisfied.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we dealt with this issue at the Estimates Committee hearing. Let me just make the point again. What happened with the shipyard was that when the yard building the boat failed financially there was a transmission of the company assets to the new shipbuilder. There was the same site, the same yard and the same work force. In those circumstances, having received advice from the Australian Customs Service about the matter, I was satisfied. I am told that, in Queensland, Customs engages the services of a former master mariner to make these assessments and, on the basis of that assessment, I was satisfied within the criteria laid down in the relevant Act.

—Minister, we did not deal with this matter in Estimates. We dealt with many other matters but we did not deal with the question of whether the Minister has carried out his responsibilities under the Act in ensuring that companies which are registered as receiving bounties have the necessary technical and financial management skills to complete a construction.

PARA.TAB: As a matter of fact, the company that was registered—Runmere Pty Ltd—did not have those skills. It failed in just over two years, went into liquidation and left massive debts. In just a moment I will go to the question of whether the Minister's attention should have been alerted to one particular director who had a history that might have led to the matter being queried. What methodology is used by the Minister, and the people to whom he presumably delegates authority, to ensure that people have technical and financial management skills—the sorts of skills that have not been evidenced in this case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to draw a painful analogy but Senator Bishop is making allegations with the wisdom of hindsight. The evidence of absence of financial skills is there in the failure of the company. I can remember people in the Senate talking about the great financial skills of Alan Bond and Christopher Skase.
—It was your Prime Minister, actually.
—No, people on Senator Bishop's side, too.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—He was your Prime Minister's great mate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop should not get upset about this; she is on her special tonight and she should not stray. Dozens of companies have failed due to a variety of economic circumstances which no-one would have suspected.
—And your monetary policy.

—That was a cheap shot. Companies failed like crazy when Senator Baume was in government and they are failing now—I concede that. For a variety of circumstances, companies fail and no-one would suspect for a moment that there was inadequate financial management. That is not the test in terms of the requirement under this Act.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Button)—by leave—agreed to:
That standing order 64 be suspended to enable new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put this day.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering subprogram 4.1.
—When we stopped for that little interlude—I am sure that it was quite convenient for the Minister, actually—Senator Button was attempting to answer a question and he was not doing very well.
—Oh, get on with it.

—Interjections by Senator Faulkner are not worth answering. I was asking Senator Button a question about the methodology employed in his Department—methodology that he is required by legislation to oversight. What degree of proof does he require to ensure that people meet the test laid down in the legislation? There is a specific requirement for the Government to satisfy itself.

PARA.TAB: There is evidence that a registered company failed. It is not good enough for the Minister to say that lots of companies failed simply because of the Government's mismanagement of the Australian economy. There is a special legislative requirement on the Minister to satisfy himself as to proper administration. I want to know what methodology the Minister has put in place to ensure that that occurs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to argue the point ad infinitum about company failures and so on. Other shipbuilding companies which are in receipt of the shipbuilding bounty have failed from time to time. There are certain criteria in the relevant bounty legislation. A shipyard will not be registered if it does not meet with those criteria.

PARA.TAB: All applicants are required to provide an independent auditor's report that they have the financial capability to undertake the construction, modification and repair of bountiable vessels. I deal with these matters on the basis of reports which are formally provided for me by the Department, on the advice of the shipbuilding group. They are fairly thorough reports. If I am satisfied with those reports, I approve the bounty.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister registered a company which failed in two years. That company received a $2.8m bounty. Perhaps the best way to deal with this matter is for the Minister to table in this place a copy of the report that he has just told us he received so that we can see the degree of investigation that he does in order to satisfy himself that the criterion in the Act has been met. Will the Minister agree to do that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not agree to do that. But I will table a sample pro forma of this type of report, showing the questions that are asked and the answers that are given. I am not going to table documents which are commercial-in-confidence to particular firms.

—The Minister cannot claim commercial-in-confidence with respect to this company because it has gone broke—it has gone bust. The Minister has no legitimate reason for claiming that the document is commercial-in-confidence. This is the Minister's standard response when there is something that might embarrass him. It would be reasonable for this chamber and for all those Australians who are interested in this case to have on record a copy of the report made to the Minister so that we can see how the people who administer this Act got it so wrong that a company that clearly was not structured and able to meet the criteria was registered and received that money.

PARA.TAB: To go a little further, I would particularly like the Minister to address the question of why it seems that people who had failed before were involved with a company which, although funded by the Minister's Department with taxpayers' money, failed.

I fail to see how the Minister can continue to argue that a company which has failed and gone into liquidation would somehow be disadvantaged by our seeing a report that his officers had made upon it. If the Minister is going to continue with that illogical argument, I would like to see how appraisals are made of individual directors of companies that apply to have shipyards registered for bounty purposes. I want to see the methodology. Is there any such methodology?
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I have not made myself clear, I will explain the first point to Senator Bishop. I said I would not table the details in this statement because there are matters in it which were commercial-in-confidence. Senator Bishop says that cannot be so because this company has gone bust. I am sorry, but that is so. If Senator Bishop is so good on these issues, she should listen to some of the principles for a minute. When one administers anything one cannot depart from the rules. Other shipbuilders cannot be told, `Senator Bishop might ask a couple of questions and then all of your material will be in the Senate'. That is not the way to run a system. We cannot do that. Every time I listen to this, I think, `God help us if ever this lot were elected to government and were required to administer things'.

PARA.TAB: The second point is how we assess the characters of individual directors of companies. We do not: there is no requirement that we do so in the shipbuilding Act, and there will not be. If we think of any company in Australia, governments do not go around making assessments of the characters of directors; that would be highly intrusive. It is not the Government's business. It would be an invasion of the privacy of those people. I wonder what Senator Short thinks about this. I wonder whether he would go around assessing the characters of directors in Australia. He would be busy if he ever tried to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I am making is that, if a person who is a director of a company seeking bounty payment has in fact been a director of a company which has sought and gained bounty payment previously, and that company has gone bust and has a record of going bust, under the Minister's criterion, he would give Alan Bond's shipyard a bounty payment and a registration under the Act. What a stupid statement it is—
—Ask him if he would.

—I will. If Alan Bond bought a shipyard and he applied to the Minister for bounty payment, would the Minister feel it was incumbent upon him to satisfy that he had both the technical knowledge and the financial management skills to handle that?
—Try Christopher Skase.
—I will, because he is quite relevant to this case.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 4.1?
—I have asked a question. I am awaiting an answer.
—It was a hypothetical question which has nothing to do with this appropriation.

—It is not a hypothetical question, because there was a director who is common to Christopher Skase's company—Lloyds, which was taken over by him, one of the companies which the Minister has registered for bounty purposes. Does the Minister think that matter ought to have required investigation?
—No.
—So the Minister thinks it is not incumbent upon him to consider the character of any director who is applying to him for bounty payments under any circumstances; is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made my position on this matter clear. But I think Senator Bishop ought to try to understand the question of payment of bounties. Bounties are paid for work done. Nobody receives bounty money until the work is done. It is a bounty payable on production. It is a production bounty. One does not get paid until the work is done. In that circumstance, the examination of the character, the colour of the eyes, the sexual behaviours of the directors of the company are not relevant matters.

—For the Minister to say that the commercial record of a director of a company is not relevant is just poppycock. If that is the way in which the Minister administers his Department, it is just as well he is leaving. It is just not good enough. Let us go back to the facts of the matter. Yes, bounty payment is made once the work is done, but the point is that before one can get to the position of being paid for work done one must be registered in accordance with the Act and the Act requires the Minister to do certain things. At the moment there is no evidence that the Minister complies with his own legislation.

PARA.TAB: Was there not a shipbuilding company which built a boat for Mr Eliadakis? Bounty payments were made and an EFIC loan was made. Mr Eliadakis and the boat and the loan and the repayments disappeared. A further loan of $10m was to be advanced to the same shipbuilding company, part of that payment was made, and the boat was never built because the person disappeared, yet one of the people who is involved in that subsequently became a director of companies which are in receipt of bounty payment. Does the Minister think that spells out a good track record for himself? Does the Minister think any reasonable man or any court of law might think that is a proper way in which to administer an Act for which he has responsibility? A simple yes or no will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bishop thinks any court of law would say anything different from what I am saying about this matter, I ask her to take me there sometime. If she says what she has just said outside the House, I will take her there. That is what will happen.

—Senator Button knows as well as I do that the reason that we have privilege in this place is so we can air matters which could otherwise be stopped by the use of stop writs. That is precisely the reason we conduct our business here under privilege, as the Minister well knows. To plead the coward's plea that `If somebody would only defame me outside I could be a rich man' is not worthy of Senator Button, although perhaps these days it might be. Getting back to the case before us, I have been provided by way of supplementary material with the names of officers in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce who are responsible for carrying out work pursuant to delegated authority under the relevant Acts.

PARA.TAB: In the case of Runmere and the boat called The Other Woman, I have spoken with the liquidator of the first company and I have ascertained that it has a good claim for about $5m to $6m for alterations to the contract and work done in pursuance of that contract that was never paid for. I would like the Minister to confirm, or I would like some information provided to the contrary, that the alterations carried out that were not paid for were in fact subject to bounty payment. In other words, bounty payment has been paid to the owner of the boat now for work that he caused to be done, which one could argue caused the first company to be sent into liquidation, yet he has been paid for that work himself. I would like to see the records that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has as to how those alterations were dealt with for the purpose of bounty payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the people Senator Bishop mentioned are satisfied they have a good case, they will take it to the courts. At that stage they would be able to have discovery, presumably, of relevant documents. That is as far as it goes, I am afraid. Senator Bishop has made the matter sub judice as far as I am concerned.

—To the contrary, the action cannot be taken because the firm is in liquidation and—surprise, surprise—has no money. So, even if there were a good cause of action that lies, it will not and cannot be taken. I can only assume that the Minister refuses to substantiate or answer the question whether he administers the Act properly and oversees his officers to ascertain if it is properly administered. There is a prima facie case here that it is not done properly, that it is done in a sloppy manner and that the criterion has not been met. The Minister offers nothing in answer to the evidence that is on the record except bluster and frivolous comment that he is doing a great job.

—I have to pick up a comment Senator Button made when he said that a claim against a company was sub judice. That is not strictly correct. In fact, I must support what Senator Bishop has said, because the fact that the company is in liquidation means that the claim against the company is a provable debt and is not, in a strict legal sense, sub judice because the admissibility of the proof of debt is something on which the liquidator rules. Clearly, because of that, Senator Button's argument is incorrect and the defence he has mounted against the very severe and important accusation by Senator Bishop is of course invalid. I think there is a lot of truth and a lot of importance in what Senator Bishop has said. For Senator Button merely to dismiss it by saying it is sub judice when that is not the case I think does Senator Bishop and the importance of this matter a grave disservice.
—I expect a response from the Minister which will explain why he will not provide any evidence as to the manner in which he administers that Department.
—The honourable senator began her last remarks by saying, `I assume'. Her life is full of assumptions. I cannot deal with her assumptions, so I have nothing to add.

—The interesting thing is that the directors of the company that has gone into liquidation, Blue Corp Pty Ltd, which was a Christopher Skase company which became Lloyds, are the same as the directors of Australian Yacht Builders, which is the shipbuilding company which has taken over the shipyard—they are Mr Cantor and his brother. They bought that company for a price less than the outstanding debt of the mortgage.

PARA.TAB: The thing that really concerns me is that, according to my information, Mr Cantor has been very active again. Mr Hardy, who is running the boat yard for him, has been involved previously in two companies which have gone into liquidation and he is now running this shipyard. It seems that Mr Cantor has come back to EFIC and asked for more money to be loaned to what he terms `potential clients', for guarantees to be given by EFIC, and for more bounty payments to be made because, according to his own evidence when he was interviewed on Channel 9, without EFIC, Austrade and the bounty payments he simply could not do business.

Mr Cantor made an approach to yet another person in the shipbuilding industry and wanted to place equity in that company. On the promise of so doing, he was introduced to certain individuals in Indonesia who may have been interested in having boats built. Upon his making those contacts, Mr Cantor was suddenly no longer interested in making the equity investment in the Australian design company. In fact, he went to an American company to use its design when, incidentally, the design company in Australia had been in receipt of an R&D grant—yet more government coffers.

Mr Cantor has an interesting background. He was convicted of a bribery charge, but a letter which was sent to me by solicitors in Queensland informed me that it was not such a bad criminal conviction after all. That is in addition to the other charges concerning racketeering which were laid and then dropped. I have asked the Minister again and again to give me an undertaking that the likes of Mr Cantor will not be given more taxpayers' and government money; that he will not be given further loans; or, more particularly, that loans will not be made to people who will do business with him or the shipyard that he now has control of which is registered for bounty payments; and that he will not be paid the bounty payments from taxpayers' money in order that he can enjoy the lifestyle that we, as Australian people, seem to be providing him with. Will the Minister now give that undertaking that no further loans or bounty payments will be made to such a person?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of Senator Bishop's remarks about Mr Cantor's character, if EFIC were to reach agreement with some of her conclusions, I am sure it would not extend Mr Cantor any more export finance assistance. If, on the other hand, the provisions of the bounty shipbuilding legislation were complied with in respect of a yard in which Mr Cantor had some ownership, the bounty would be paid on completion of a vessel or at certain stages during the building of the vessel as appropriate, because that is what the Act requires.

—I have a problem with that. Mr Cantor is an American. I am further informed by other suppliers who have done business with that shipyard previously that Australian firms which are meant to be the beneficiaries of the Government's bounty program are in fact no longer receiving contracts and that Mr Cantor is bypassing the Australian firms and ordering direct from overseas. So the bounty payments are in fact assisting the competitors of Australian companies. I again ask the Minister, in terms of his own policy administration: how can he justify not properly oversighting the way in which this program is administered, and how can he justify refusing to give the chamber any proper material that will convince us that there is proper administration and oversight by him of the entire program?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bishop has another look at the bounty legislation—I thought she would know it back to front by now—she will find that bounty is payable on value added in Australia; it is not payable in respect of imported components. So the question is a little superfluous.

—That is precisely why I am asking the question about verifying the administration. In fact, what happens is that the component parts are made overseas and an Australian firm imports them, deals with them and sells them and is therefore eligible. But when parts are brought in direct by the boat builder, I would like to know what method is used by the Department to discern between those parts which have come in via the Australian firm and those which have come in direct. I would like some advice as to how that is taken into account.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters are supervised by Customs officers who make checks on the progress in the building of ships and who make assessments of these matters.

—There is plenty of room for improvement in Customs as a whole. We have had the opportunity to have a closer look at the investigations branch of the Australian Customs Service. When we come to that part we will find that there is no minimum education standard for the officers who are granted great powers; that most of them—something like 70 per cent of them—do not have any tertiary qualifications; and those who do have only certificates which are of a fairly mean level. Yet those officers are exercising great powers and are responsible for great sums of money. I would like to be assured that the people who are oversighting this part of the Customs Service have a better track record. I would be interested to know what sort of staff and qualification standards are required by the Minister and his Department in this area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ignore that general smear of the Australian Customs Service. In so far as the point of the question is concerned—in so far as it seems to have a point—people who build ships do not have tertiary education qualifications. As to the people who inspect this work in Queensland, one of those involved is a former master mariner with engineering skills and qualifications. However, I am sure he does not have a PhD.

—There was no general slur; there was a very specific statement of fact. The Minister has officers within his care and control—we will come on to this a little later so we will not deal with it in depth now—who are dealing with extraordinary powers, greater powers than the Australian Taxation Office and the police, yet they have no qualifications that go hand in hand with those responsibilities. But that matter is for slightly later on in this program.
—Does Senator Bishop want me to deal with it now?

—No, I would like to finish first. I would like to know and be assured of the methodology used to disburse taxpayers' money, and that the benefit is going where it ought to go, which is to Australian firms; and indeed, as I ask again and again and the Minister refuses to give, I would like evidence that the criteria laid down in the Act are being met.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop says that Customs officers have greater powers than tax officers and the police. I do not know whether that is correct; I must tell Senator Bishop that I have met plenty of policemen and taxation officers who do not have PhDs. However, that is perhaps superfluous to the point Senator Bishop was trying to make.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the administration of the bounty legislation, there is a system which, as I have said, is set out in the Act. It is administered by Customs officers. None of the bounty legislation applies only to Australian companies. For example, IBM is the beneficiary of bounty legislation. Many foreign firms in Australia are beneficiaries of bounty legislation.

What is Senator Bishop's smeary point? Is it that the employees do not have tertiary education or that the bounty is given to foreigners? What is the point she is trying to make? The bounty is paid in respect of production; all bounties are paid in respect of production. We do not look at the character of the directors or at the nationality and passports of the employees of the firms involved. If it is implicit in what Senator Bishop is saying that a Liberal government would do that, I am going out on the road show tomorrow to tell Australian industry that that is what it would do. I will do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister deliberately misinterprets. The point I made was that the Government's policy is allegedly aimed at assisting Australian industry. That is its alleged policy. Indeed, the point I was making to him is that Australian firms which have developed businesses supplying particular boat yards are being bypassed and things are being imported directly. Whether duty is being paid on them I do not know. I can only presume that officers are diligent and that it is indeed paid.

PARA.TAB: When the intent of the policy is to assist Australian industry, and it is taxpayers' money that is being given away, I want to know and the Australian taxpayers want to know that there is value for money. Many Australians are quite incensed by the fact that such largess can be handed out to somebody like Mr Cantor and that apparently the Minister could not care less, EFIC could not care less and the Australian Customs Service could not care less. I would be delighted if the Minister could give me one piece of assurance that when he is administering this policy he has any concern for the Australian taxpayer and the Australian taxpayer's interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 4.1, we will move to subprogram 4.5, Coastwatch.

—A number of matters were raised in respect of Coastwatch and I note that some further investigation was to be done. Members of the Committee will be aware that after I raised these matters during the Estimates hearing further information was provided by Skywest, which I made a point of tabling for the purposes of inclusion in the record to ensure complete information on this and both sides of the story.

PARA.TAB: It is still of interest to me how the Australian Customs Service could have assured me that it had analysed the operations of the company in great detail and yet nobody, for example, knew of the financial status of the company. Given that Customs has had some time in the intervening period to consider it and given that Mr Kelly assured us during the hearings of the Committee that that was monitored regularly, could any explanation be given now as to why there had not been proper supervision of the financial status of the company?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator O'Chee's concerns about Coastwatch. I do not know where the information Senator O'Chee is talking about comes from, but in fact there are nine officers in Coastwatch whose sole purpose is to monitor this contract. They also monitor the outcomes of all contract flying. Two officers are involved with the assessment and payment of accounts. Four officers are located in the same northern regional centres as Skywest and fly regularly with the crews to check the serviceability of aircraft and equipment and the performance of the crews as they work. Two Canberra-based officers also fly regularly to check the four regional checking officers for consistency. Those two Canberra-based officers also share the responsibility to provide surveillance and other specialist training to Skywest personnel.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that hands-on monitoring, Coastwatch officers in Broome, Darwin and Cairns also keep very close contact with Skywest-based personnel to ensure that Coastwatch flight programming and deployment requirements are fulfilled. This involves monitoring CAA requirements of pilots and crews.

Ultimately, a judgment must be made about the extent to which we duplicate or multiply this sort of effort. The main purpose is to see that the services are meeting their objectives. The fact is that the customs, fisheries, quarantine and immigration authorities are satisfied with the service they are getting. That information is additional to what Senator O'Chee had before in terms of monitoring efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the additional information. In view of what the Minister has told me, I wonder whether it would be appropriate now to raise a number of matters Mr Kelly said at the hearing he would investigate and which I let rest at that stage upon Mr Kelly's undertaking. The Minister says that a number of officers are employed to ensure compliance with CAA guidelines. Is there any information to hand or can the Minister or his departmental officers now give advice as to how many trained electronic observers are required in Cairns for Skywest to meet its obligations in respect of the contract?
—There are nine trained electronic observers in Cairns.
—Is that the requirement or the number currently present?
—Both.

—One of the other matters that I raised was the fact that 418 additional charter hours were expended, in part on Mr Kelly's advice, because of the fact that the SeaScan aircraft were not available on the day on which they were supposed to commence operations and this incurred an additional cost to the Commonwealth. At the hearing Mr Kelly admitted that he believed that none of that had been expensed to Skywest. He said he would look into that matter. Is it possible for the officers to advise the Minister as to how many of those 418 charter hours are attributable to the fact that the SeaScan aircraft were not ready to commence operations on the contract date and, therefore, what sum of money has been, or will be, charged to Skywest so that it meets its financial obligation under the contract?
—Of the 418 hours, 13 were attributable to the unavailability of SeaScan but the contract is a contract for service and it gets paid for what it does, so it got paid for 13 hours, not 418.
—Does that mean that there has been no additional expense to the Commonwealth as a result?

—I am sorry, I probably misrepresented that. The truth is it gets paid for what it did under the contract. It was not 13 hours, the 13 hours was payable in respect of other services. I cannot tell the honourable senator the number of hours which it got paid for; that is not available at the moment.

—It might be simpler if I just asked whether it appears as though the unavailability of the SeaScan aircraft on the date on which they were to commence service has resulted in a cost to the Commonwealth over and above that which would have been paid had they been available? If so, has any attempted calculation of the resulting cost been made for the purposes of recovering that money from Skywest?
—As it turned out, because of the splendid administration of Customs, it was cheaper because the aircraft which were used were cheaper to operate than SeaScans.
—I thank the Minister. Suffice it to say that this is obviously something in which I will continue to take an interest and will take an interest at subsequent Estimates hearings.
—We will deal with subprogram 4.7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to two items dealt with in the Estimates hearings. I have already foreshadowed one which relates to the investigations branch and the statement in the subprogram that 532 cases were investigated during the year with suspected fraud involving $54.9m, and 45 commercial prosecutions were completed, returning $3.9m. The Committee considered that this was not exactly a

SPEECH.PARA: very good return. That prompted the question of how cost effective the investigation branch is, with the costs that are run up. We have ascertained that in simply challenging an AAT appeal, as was evidenced in one or two cases we have dealt with before, costs of around $15,000 can be run up to recover something in the vicinity of $200 to $300.

PARA.TAB: The concern was that here were these investigations and a not very satisfactory outcome. The answer supplied is really less than satisfactory as well. I asked for a breakdown of costs of individual cases that were brought and I was told that, according to Customs, that is not really very meaningful at this stage. I disagree. It is, in fact, very meaningful. I asked how much each investigation has incurred to date—how much was involved. I ask the Minister whether he would instruct his Department please to provide the information as requested, that is, how much did those investigations cost per case? If proper records are being kept it should not be very difficult.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably not as simple as that. These questions were raised at the hearing on 23 September. Some parts of them were taken on notice and answered. I will make a few points which might be helpful. The investigation subprogram has three separate functions: investigations, intelligence and prosecutions. In this last area of prosecutions there seems to be some misunderstanding. That section processes all briefs of evidence prepared by the whole operational area of the Australian Customs Service including those which are passed on to the Director of Public Prosecutions or the Australian Government Solicitor for prosecution. Talking about aggregate figures, and trying to work out what this investigation subprogram costs and appropriate those costs individually to the results of individual prosecutions, is an exercise which cannot be done in the way Senator Bishop tried to do it in the course of the Senate Estimates, because of that much wider function of the prosecutions branch.

PARA.TAB: In respect of one or two other matters I can give the chamber further information. True, 532 investigation subprogram cases were initiated in 1990-91, of which 247 related to quarantine, fauna, prohibited imports and non-commercial revenue cases of that kind. These were not fraud cases at all. I remember that the former Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, brought in some seeds once and Customs questioned him about that. That was essentially a quarantine matter. It had to be investigated. It might have led to a prosecution. That is an example of the 247 cases to which I referred. Taking 247 from 532 leaves 285 which were commercial fraud cases initiated in the year, with an estimated $23.9m in revenue being avoided.

These fraud cases typically take more than one year to complete, and the majority of them have not been completed at this time—or at any particular time. It is not meaningful to discuss costs and outcomes in respect of the fraud cases, just looking at it on a yearly snap like that. The figure of $54.9m that has been mentioned by Senator Bishop in respect of fraud cases relates to all cases handled or partially handled during 1990-91. It includes, for example, a major investigation still proceeding into the illegal diversion of spirits, with an estimated $20m in revenue avoided. Again, it is meaningless to compare fraud estimates with results achieved during the year, because many of the cases have just not been completed.

I said earlier that this program is broken down into three components—investigation, intelligence and prosecution. The cost to run the investigation subprogram was $14.8m. In 1990-91, 327 commercial cases were completed in total. As well as the 45 cases that proceeded to prosecution, there were cases that were settled or handled by other means, such as administrative penalty or call up of duty owing. There were 130 cases where the evidence available did not justify action. I hope that is of some help to the honourable senator in understanding the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say to the Minister is that that was nicely read from volume 5 of the additional information provided. However, had the Minister bothered to reconcile that answer with page 227 of the program performance statements, as prepared by his Department, I presume, he would have found that the two do not tally. Let me remind the Minister what is in the program performance statements, and I quote:

PARA.TAB: Program performance
Outcome for 1990-91
The subprogram initiated 532 investigation cases during the year, with suspected fraud involved totalling $54.9m.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not, as the additional information says, 285 commercial cases; this says that it initiated 532 cases during the year, with suspected fraud totalling $54.9m. It is not 285, as stated, and not with the remainder of them, that is, 247, concerned with quarantine, prohibited exports, fauna, et cetera. The program performance statement goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The subprogram focus is now on large scale fraudulent and illegal activities. The administrative penalty option which was introduced in July 1989 has been used to handle the majority of smaller cases. Investigation cases on hand in 1990-91 tend to involve far higher fraud, are more resource intensive, and will take longer to resolve than the average case handled in previous years.

SPEECH.PARA: It then goes on:

PARA.TAB: Other customs prosecutions completed during the year total 538. Types of prosecutions involved include quarantine (303), prohibited imports (73), fauna (16), revenue—non commercial (83) and illicit stills (46).

SPEECH.PARA: It is not, as set out in the additional information, 247 cases, presumably to be subtracted from the 532, and not concerning any of the $54m potential recovery of fraud. The program performance statement continues:

PARA.TAB: Information concerning suspect or unusual activity is reported in the normal course of their duties by officers throughout the ACS to the intelligence area of investigations. A total of 17,645 such reports were received in 1990-91. This information is assessed for its relevance, urgency and potential, and is distributed to other interested areas. Some form the basis of further research in the intelligence area and lead to the issue of more detailed and integrated intelligence reports. A total of 255 intelligence reports were prepared during the year.

Five major `Strategic Threat Assessments' were completed (two conducted jointly with the Australian Federal Police) during 1990-91, and a further four are in progress. These assessments enable senior management to focus on perceived areas of threat and consider options and strategies available to counter them and improve operational effectiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: Very simply, the program performance statement deals quite succinctly with the three arms the Minister has just described, but none of those change the fact that his Department set out in these notes the information that 532 investigation cases were initiated during the year, with a total value of $54.9m, but that it managed to bring only 45 cases. In the event, as the Minister says, that some cases take longer to investigate and to bring to prosecution—and we were told that we could expect to see details of those in the statements for the coming year—equally it would apply that investigations commenced within the past two years ought to have come to fruition in this current year. In other words, whichever way we look at it, 45 out of 532 is a pretty lousy average, and to recover $3.9m when the Department is looking for $54.9m really is not a great batting average either.

PARA.TAB: I want to know how much was spent on investigations of those fraud cases, as distinct from the 538 quarantine, et cetera, cases and as distinct from the intelligence gathering. I want to know how much has been spent in plane flights, hotel bills, people being brought on as consultants, whatever the costs incurred are, to investigate those 532 cases. I want to know how much it cost to prosecute the 45 cases that were successful in getting back $3.9m, so that once again we can answer to the taxpayer the question: does this Government oversight its departments to get the taxpayer value for money?

To get a response from the Department that is at odds with its own program performance statements—which says that either statement is a lie—will not do. Will the Minister direct his Department to answer those questions as to how much those investigations cost?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should have another look at this. I listened to what the honourable senator had to say and I followed what she read. I think she is confused. I think she needs time to sort that out, and it may be that she should take a day or two. I do not know why the honourable senator objects to my reading an answer here. I can read; I thought she objected usually to the fact that I did not read. The honourable senator certainly objected to the fact that some Customs officers may not be able to. However, I followed what the honourable senator said. I do not regard it as an inconsistency between the briefing and what I have just read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Minister's powers of comprehension are so lacking. Far from the frivolous answer the Minister has just given, I ask him again: will he please direct his Department to answer the questions that were asked? How much did each fraud investigation case cost to prosecute? What was the total cost to Customs of the investigation of the 532 cases? This will enable us to see whether or not in any shape or form there is value for money coming out of the Department the Minister is administering. A frivolous answer is not satisfactory. I ask the Minister again: will he ask his Department to supply the correct answer? I suspect that we could indeed get to the situation where the cost of the investigation is far greater than the return that it brings to the Commonwealth.

—I have already read out that the cost of the subprogram investigation was $14.8m. I provided the honourable senator with the other information in some detail and I think, if she checks it through, she will find that it is adequate and correct; I am satisfied it is.
—Will you clarify the position of the cost—$14.9m, did you say?
—I have done that.

—No, you have not: that is merely an appropriated figure. I want to know the cost incurred, including airfares, hotel bills, and investigation expenses. I want to know what those costs added in amount to so that we can see whether we get value for money. This is so we do not get the situation we had previously where to prosecute a case worth $300 one can run up a bill of thousands of dollars. The Minister admits to $5,000 per case.
—That will take a considerable time. Their efforts have been made to extract the data for the fraud cases.
—That is what I asked you for.
—No, it is not what you asked me for.
—Indeed, it is.
—Do not stand over me: if you want to come into this kitchen you will get burnt if you do that.
—She is terrified.
—Not of anybody. We are not either.
—I am very pleased to hear that the Minister will extrapolate that information and we can expect to receive it. I thank you for that.

PARA.TAB: The reason we went on to deal with the question of educational requirements or job specifications for people who are recruited into the investigation service is that, if we are not getting the satisfactory result, it is valid to look at the composition. It may well be that we are desperately in need of more qualified people to get a better result. That is a point we can explore in another place. I suppose one could be excused for not expecting there to be a job specification when I recall that the Minister gave us evidence that he employed a deputy secretary without even having a job specification. Perhaps I could recommend a new publication by CCH which is on how to recruit properly; it might be useful to the Department.

I now turn to the question of triple dipping and the answer provided by Customs on this practice. To refresh people's minds as to what that practice is: it is where the appropriate form has been filled out with an error in it concerning the import of goods. The error is registered against not only the Customs agent as the individual who signs the form, but his firm as well and, more particularly, the importer himself. This practice was to be tested as to whether or not it was valid. That question was conveniently avoided by Customs granting a 100 per cent remission and therefore denying the AAT any jurisdiction.

However, we were informed that Customs has ceased this practice as and from the Walker case which was decided at the end of 1990. Indeed, the answer that is provided contains one of those nice equivocal points and says, in effect, that triple dipping no longer occurs where one of the parties accepts responsibility. Of course, the immediate question that comes to mind is what happens where no party admits responsibility. Presumably then, the triple dipping exercise still continues.

In fact, I am informed that triple dipping has occurred as late as in the case of Hanimex v. The Collector of Customs which was heard on 6 June 1991 and in Grain Processing Machinery Pty Ltd v. The Collector of Customs which was heard on 10 July 1991. There is a list of other cases. Indeed, even the cases that have been dealt with in the Minister's answer, where he says the action was commenced prior to the Walker case, the decision or hearing may have occurred after that time as in some of the cases I could go on to cite. The Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1990 the ACS changed its practice of automatically reporting the responsibility of an error against each of the parties involved, the so called triple dipping registration scheme, to only recording the error against the party who has accepted responsibility for the error.
What is the position where no party accepts responsibility for the error?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, where the importer and the Customs agency cannot agree to the responsibility, then Customs has no alternative but to record that the commission of the error subject to penalty involves both parties. That is a matter of fact. I should also add the Customs agency executive has been urged by Customs to pursue this with its members and it has done so by way of information.

—As I said, the answer and the way it was couched was, to say the least, ambiguous, and I thought the answer would be as the Minister gave it. It is not a matter of fact: it is a matter of the way in which the system is administered. Why on earth, when only one signature appears on the document, should three parties be penalised? The way in which they are penalised, just to refresh the Minister's memory, is that, when any of the people who have been a party to that particular transaction come up again, the number of black points tallied against that name determines the size of the remission that may or may not be given. It is not a question of fact: it is a question of administration. I ask the Minister whether he thinks the practice is still legitimate and satisfactory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one party ever penalised—`penalised' is the word Senator Bishop used—but there are two parties—
—Three.

—Two parties are held responsible in the manner to which I referred earlier, and ultimately one party is penalised. Senator Bishop asked me whether the system works totally satisfactorily. I think the answer to that question is that I cannot say, but I think the changes that have been made need the opportunity to work. I will keep an eye on the system.

—I am grateful that the Minister will keep an eye on it. It is not two parties, it is three: the individual agent; his firm; and the importer. It is not the case that only one party can be penalised. All three can be penalised because the black mark goes against all three—as the Minister has now established—where there is no agreement as to who is the responsible party. So, perhaps when we next meet on this issue, we could ask Customs to keep a list of those instances where no party accepts the particular responsibility and the practice still continues. It would be useful to know the number of cases where this occurs because there are people who have drawn to my attention the fact that this has happened to them and placed them in hardship. One particular gentleman is involved, with the sum of $1,700 for an error which has never been his. He is placed in particular hardship and his situation has been exacerbated as a result of the recession that this Government has designed. Could I have a confirmation that the Customs Service will keep a register of the number of cases, and the particular cases where there is no agreement as to who is responsible, and the process of triple dipping continues?
—I referred to two parties—the agency and the importer. Customs does keep such a list as the one referred to.
—Customs now keeps the list under the new regime.
—Yes.

—It would be very helpful if we could have a copy of that list. I can understand it if the Minister does not want to give us the list with names of firms, but could we have the number of cases and the dates on which they occurred?
—It would be appropriate to ask for that information in the Supplementary Estimates. I will see that it is ready in advance for Senator Bishop.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—If there are no further matters on subprogram 4.7, we will move to program 5, Australian Trade Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the period intervening between the Estimates hearings and today, I endeavoured, firstly through the Committee Secretary, Mr Hamburger, to obtain a copy of the Austrade report, at least in draft form. After much discussion one way and another, it was agreed that Austrade would make available to the Committee copies of the draft report after it had been seen by the board. That was to follow the return of the new Managing Director, Mr Evans, from overseas at the end of the October. I received the draft on Monday of this week.

PARA.TAB: I was quite surprised when I went through the report to find that it had no financial statement in it and no list of consultants. I thereupon asked Mr Hamburger to inquire further as to when we could expect this material. He was told, and subsequently told me, that the financial statements were not in an appropriate form and Austrade had no intention of publishing a list of consultants. I decided to speak directly with an officer of Austrade and did so. After some deliberations, we were successful in obtaining a copy of the financial statements.

However, the question of the list of consultants is somewhat more difficult. I was told that it could not be made available for some days. I then said that I presumed Austrade would keep a list of consultants and I would be happy to receive, for the purposes of the Committee of the Whole, a list of all those people who had been employed as consultants and the cost, and that if the board subsequently wanted to sanitise or otherwise—again that wonderful phrase `commercial-in-confidence' —the purpose or the subject of the consultancy undertaken we could perhaps wait a few days for that if it was a difficult matter. That I thought was agreed to, until this morning, when I received a most amazing document that listed no names of consultants but simply the areas of consultancy. They add up to $6.869m; not a bad little consultancy bill—nearly $7m. There was a discussion as to why I thought the Committee and the Senate were entitled to see these lists. In report No. 309 tabled in this Parliament by the Public Accounts Committee, recommendation 5.31 acknowledged:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that Commonwealth departments are required to report on the engagement of external consultants in their annual reports, providing details about the number of consultants engaged, the total amount paid to consultants and a description of the project that consultants were engaged to perform.
Recommendation 5.32 says:
The Committee considers that similar reporting provisions to those required by departments should be required only for statutory authorities that are budget-dependent.

To date, the Government has not, by way of a Finance minute, replied to this report; but the findings of the Committee were well researched and represent the views of both sides of the House. I presume that the Government will deal favourably with that report. Accordingly, I felt that it was only proper to be asking for that list, because that is the expression and the will of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: We have come to the stage where we are looking at the appropriation for Austrade. I came upon another piece of information this morning that, quite frankly, appalled me. Mr Downer, my colleague in the other place, the shadow Minister for trade, had found it unusual that Mr Evans, the new Managing Director, and other officers in Austrade would not speak with him. He could think of a variety of reasons why that may be the case, except that one of those officers happened to be a friend of his and he would not speak to Mr Downer either. He found this very curious.

As and from 1 November, suddenly all those officers were quite available to speak to Mr Downer. What happened? On 1 November, Austrade moved out of the area of responsibility of DITAC and Senator Button and went into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. What he ascertained, and what I have ascertained, is that Senator Button instructed officers of Austrade not to speak to Mr Downer at all. I find that utterly preposterous. I ask the Minister: on what basis can he justify an instruction to officers in the Public Service not to speak to an elected member of this Parliament and somebody who is charged with the responsibility in that area?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that a bit preposterous too. In my recollection, the Chairman of Austrade sought an appointment not so long ago to have lunch with Mr Downer, an appointment Mr Downer did not keep; he did not turn up. That was the first recollection I have about contact between Austrade and Mr Downer.

PARA.TAB: The second point I wish to make is that if a shadow Minister wants to talk to officers of my Department or officers of statutory authorities in my portfolio and in any other portfolio, most of them observe the courtesy of writing to me or the relevant Minister saying, `I would like to meet with these officers of the statutory authority or these officers of the Department'. Senator Bishop is not on the front bench, but I would like to let her know that most shadow Ministers do that. If a shadow Minister writes to me making such a request, I say yes as a matter of practice and principle. That never happened.

It is true that Mr Evans, as the new chief executive of Austrade, in the presence of some other Austrade officers said to me, `We think we should give a briefing to Mr Downer'. They approached Mr Downer about giving him a briefing. That was about the start of October, or late September.

I said, `No. Mr Downer has not sought a briefing'. I discussed it with Dr Blewett, under whose aegis Austrade was to come on 1 November.
