We agreed, as Ministers, that as soon as Dr Blewett took over responsibility for Austrade, Mr Downer, who had not requested a briefing of me, would be offered one by Austrade officers. That is what happened. So when Senator Bishop starts off by saying that what I have done, presumably, is preposterous, I apply that same adjective to the allegations which she has just made.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all very well, except that the Minister did, in fact, give an instruction that officers were not to speak to Mr Downer. That even applied to somebody who was a friend who could then not have even a social conversation. That was the tenor of the instruction. As I said, amazing things happened on 1 November, and that meeting between Mr Downer and Mr Evans will, in fact, take place on Tuesday. So no water has flowed under the bridge and I can hope that the administration of Austrade in its new portfolio will somewhat improve. But, of course, we are still left with a situation where EFIC, which has been the financial arm of Austrade, remains in DITAC. We have some things that we want to ask now in that area as well. When I say now, I mean following matters that I want to raise out of the Austrade report.

PARA.TAB: The first matter that I want to raise is very relevant to the question of consultants. It relates to the terms of termination of employment of the previous managing director and the provisions that were made following his agreement to stand down from that position. Firstly, I want to know whether the Minister was personally involved in either negotiations or approval of the package that was paid to Mr McAlister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I would like to deal with. Mr Downer is seeing Austrade officials on Tuesday because I arranged it. It is a very cheap point such as I am not unused to. Senator Bishop is magnificent in firing her guns when her ship is sinking. She started off with a set of outrageous assertions. They were proved wrong yet she repeats them. It is an extraordinary performance for somebody who, I think, has a university degree.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that I did not have any say in negotiating any package between Austrade and Mr McAlister. The negotiations of the terms and details of the package were carried on between, I think, the Chairman of Austrade and Mr McAlister.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were carried out between Mr Ferris and Mr McAlister. Did they come to the Minister then to have the terms of the package approved or were negotiations concluded without his knowledge?

—I think there was one part which required my approval. Certainly the extension of Mr McAlister's housing loan entitlement came to me for approval. I said earlier the package was negotiated between Mr Ferris and Mr McAlister. It may have been Mr Ferris, but I am not sure; it was a representative of the board and I think it was the Chairman.

—I am just trying to find the relevant page on which the conditions of the termination are set out. I recall that the extension of that housing loan—which, I understand, goes through to 1993—in fact provides that Mr McAlister will continue to enjoy a subsidised interest rate. The interest only payments that he will make in respect of that loan over the remaining period of the loan will amount to some $80,000. I would like to know what the size of that loan is and, indeed, whether Mr McAlister was the only Austrade employee to have such a loan.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter is on the public record already, so we each need to refresh our memories perhaps. My recollection is that the Deputy General Manager and the Manager of Corporate Affairs—the honourable senator will remember his name is Mr Hemple—get housing loans. That is all on the public record, in Hansard or somewhere. Four or five EFIC officers temporarily seconded to Austrade were also in receipt of housing loans by virtue of their employment with EFIC.

—As I understand it, all those loans are not on the public record. There was a question asked originally about loans to Austrade officers. The answer that came back was very limited because nobody answered for the EFIC loans. I would like to know the source of those loans for the officers of Austrade and for the EFIC officers. Where did those capital loans come from? I understand that, in the case of EFIC, EFIC provides the funds that are the subject of the loan. What is the source of those funds?
—Loans in respect of the EFIC officers are funded from EFIC cash reserves, I think in the same way as most financial institutions do it in order to attract senior people.

—I know that the Minister likes to purport or pretend that EFIC is a commercial institution. It is not. It receives appropriation funds for subsidised interest rates. It carries insurance rates that commercial companies will not. Indeed, there is a very interesting note, which I will deal with in a moment, concerning the operation of EFIC having acted without power concerning certain borrowings.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister says that the moneys are provided to officers of EFIC out of cash reserves, am I to take it that those cash reserves are the ones that are accumulated by way of notional profits, or are they, indeed, out of the capital reserve? Would that include the capital reserve to which the $200m which has been made available to EFIC to increase its capital base? Even though it has not been paid, it is available to be drawn upon. But within the terms of the Act the capitalisation ratio is said to include that $200m. From what particular source does that come and where will I find it in the financial statements? Where will I find provision for those loans in here?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The $200m capital facility is not used for purposes such as this. It is what it is said to be.
—I just said that. It was to increase the capital base.
—I know Senator Bishop said it, but I do not know whether she understood it. The amounts are payable out of retained earnings of EFIC.
—So it is from retained earnings. Can the Minister tell me where I will find that in the financial statements?
—There is a line entry of $6.9m.
—Is that under receivables? Perhaps the Minister could simply refer to the page. It might be easier for him.
—We do not have the document in front of us. We will provide the honourable senator with that information.

—At the same time, perhaps the Minister could tell me where provision is made for the fringe benefits tax to be paid in respect of those loans. I received a nod from the Minister's officers in their box, but I do ask that I be informed where there is provision for the fringe benefits tax that is paid on those loans. I take it that, by the line item, the size of the loans that have been lent is $6m. Is that right?
—The figure was $6.9m.
—The sum of $6.9m has been made available to officers of Austrade and EFIC for their personal housing. Is that right?
—No. Senator Bishop knows that is not right.
—I do not know. The Minister told me there was a line entry. Perhaps he can tell me what else is in it.

—The honourable senator knows that is not right. That line entry relates to EFIC officers. I have already said—I do not know whether I have to go through it again and again—that there are four or five EFIC officers seconded to Austrade on a temporary basis who were beneficiaries of EFIC loans. I said that only three minutes ago.
—I want to know the amount.
—I do not know why Senator Bishop is the only person in the chamber who does not remember that. Hands up anybody else who does not remember that!

—I asked the Minister for the amount of money involved. I was told there was a line item covering those loans to those officers and that the amount of money in that line item was $6.9m. The Minister cannot tell me precisely where it is in the accounts, so I would like a description and I would like to know whether that full $6.9m is in fact attributed to those loans. Are there other perks as well that we have not yet got onto? Does it include the FBT? If not, where is it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, on the basis of experience, the honourable senator would not remember the answer I gave two minutes ago, which was that I will provide her with that information. The amount is $6.9m; it is in the cash reserves from retained earnings of EFIC. That amount is attributed to housing for officers. In so far as Senator Bishop requires a little more detail, I undertook two minutes ago to provide that. I do not know whether this is a question period or just a talkfest, but I have already answered all of those questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the fact that the Minister's answers are not generally memorable, I do recall the information that he deemed to impart. In fact, he has now given me an answer which is, yes, all $6.9m is attributable to those loans. That is quite a sizeable sum. I want to move onto note 16 to the accounts.
—I hate to interrupt Senator Bishop, but I have found that entry.
—The Minister means someone found it for him.
—Yes, that is right. The amount is in fact $6,707,000. It is to be found on page 23. In respect of loans secured by mortgage, fringe benefits tax is payable. The system has been operating since 1979.

—I am looking at page 23. I take it that the provision for fringe benefits tax could not be in that same line item. No doubt the Minister will provide me with the information as to where it is. Note 16 on page 27 of the accounts deals with borrowings. The report says that the reschedulings and borrowings were authorised by the Commonwealth and approvals for the borrowings were given by the Treasurer under section 79 of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985. However, subsequent to the execution of the borrowing documentation, the Attorney-General's Department issued a legal opinion in which it advised that it was outside the functions of the Commission to borrow to fund the Commonwealth's share of liabilities under national interest contracts. Although the contracts entered into remained valid pursuant to section 96 of the Act, the Commonwealth has reaffirmed its intention to indemnify the Commission against all losses incurred in relation to default under the forgiveness of such rescheduled debt and all costs relating to the borrowings. The report goes on to say that the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Act, which went through this chamber only recently, in fact will empower EFIC to borrow in relation to the national interest contract.

PARA.TAB: I have a problem with that statement. Section 96 of the Act, as I read it, can in no way validate an act by the old fund which was not authorised in the enabling legislation. Indeed, because I was of that view, I investigated the matter a little further. I understand that there was not a single legal opinion issued by the Attorney-General's Department as this note states; that in fact competing legal statements exist; that indeed it was DITAC that obtained the first legal opinion which stated that the borrowings were illegal. It obtained that opinion because of its exposure to the Kuwaiti loans.

However, I understand that another opinion was then sought from a more junior member of the Attorney-General's office which purports to say that maybe section 96 saves the borrowings. I ask the Minister to make both those legal opinions available to this chamber because it seems to me that what is required is further legislation to validate those borrowings. I ask that both those legal opinions be tabled. I understand one opinion is by Mr Peter Clay. I do not know the name of the author of the other opinion, except that he is more junior. I would further ask why the statement in these financial statements is not in fact correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best I can do in respect of that is to provide the honourable senator with an opinion as to why we do not need legislation, if that is the position. That is the point of the question.

—No, that is not the point of the question. The point of the question is that these statements are misleading in that they say there is a single opinion which finds that the borrowings were illegal and that they are saved by section 96. They in fact are not. The opinion is silent, as I understand it, so I want to see the first opinion. I would also like to see the competing opinion to see whether it in fact expresses a view that section 96 operates in any way to save those borrowings. The only way this can be determined is for us to see those opinions.

—One of these opinions to which Senator Bishop refers was in 1988, which I scarcely see as being a topic of these estimates. These accounts have all been passed and approved by the Auditor-General. I made an offer but, if Senator Bishop does not wish to accept it, I will withdraw it.
—The Minister says that they have been passed by the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General said in his statement at the back of the account:

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with section 63(h)(2) of the Audit Act I now report that the statements are in agreement with the accounts and records of the Commission and in my opinion the statements are based on proper accounts and records. The statements are fair and financial transactions for the year to the end of June 30 1991 and the state of affairs of the Commission at that date, except as indicated in Note 16. . .

In other words, the Auditor-General has accepted the statement of the board that there is an opinion—one opinion—that says that borrowings were illegal or outside the function but were saved by section 96 of the relevant Act. In fact, that is not so. Therefore, not only are we being misled but so is the Auditor-General. I believe that this chamber is entitled to see both those legal opinions so that we can discern—as I understand this covers borrowings all the way back to 1986—whether remedial legislation is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Auditor-General is instructed to have regard to the opinion of the Department and that provides the necessity for the inclusion of a reference to the opinion in the accounts. As is further indicated in that note, the opinion does not affect the validity of the borrowings as between the parties. That is noted there.

—I am telling the Minister that that note, note 16, has misled this chamber, it will mislead every reader of the annual report, and it misled the Auditor-General. I am asking that we see those two legal opinions, the first of which, I understand, does not do what the note says. In fact, if one reads section 96 one sees that it provides that, if the Commission, as it then was, failed to comply with a provision in the Act, that would not make the action itself invalid. That does not save the Commission in a situation where it has acted outside its powers. It cannot be saved by that provision.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that we may require additional legislation. Already the draftsman has taken the care to insert into the new EFIC Bill provision to give power for those borrowings. It is because of the borrowings that took place post-1985 until the splitting of Austrade and EFIC and the efficacy of the new Bill that we have a problem. I do not see why the Minister should deny that information to this chamber.

I again ask the Minister whether he will supply those opinions so that we may make a decision or an appraisal and come to an opinion as to what action should be taken, or will the Minister simply say no?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have told Senator Bishop what I will do. I will give her an opinion as to whether any legislation is required.

—Will the Minister explain what it is he has to hide? What is the problem? Why will the Minister not come clean? Why will he not release the documents? He cannot use commercial-in-confidence this time. What is the reason? I think we are entitled to one, Minister. Mr Chairman, I think it is a reasonable question for me to ask the Minister. Would you mind directing him to answer as to why we are not to be allowed to have those two opinions?
—Order! It is not the role of the Chair to direct the Minister. Are there any further questions on the program?

—I could stand here and go on asking this ad infinitum, if that is the only way we can get a response. I ask the Minister what he has to hide. Why can we not have the legal opinions? What is his problem? What is the cover-up?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated that I have nothing to hide. I do not see the relevance to this Committee of opinions provided in 1988, with an initial one I think in 1986. I do see the relevance of the question as to whether there is a required amendment to the relevant legislation. I have agreed to advise Senator Bishop about that matter. I think the purpose of these Estimates committees becomes somewhat clouded with this browbeating approach to ancient documents. I will provide Senator Bishop with the relevant advice which she originally sought.

—I have a real problem with that answer. The Minister says that this particular piece of advice was dated 1988. That means that he knowingly allowed EFIC to go on borrowing in an illegal fashion without having any remedy. That is perhaps precisely the reason he does not want to release the opinion—it would show that he was not competent in this area. Is Mr Peter Clay's opinion dated 1988?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know which opinion is which. These opinions were obtained by EFIC, which is a statutory corporation, from the Attorney-General's Department. I have never seen them. The issues that they relate to have never been referred to me and it is not within my province to direct EFIC on these matters. For these reasons, I have not seen them.

—On the contrary, the Minister knows very well that he has a power of direction under the legislation. He has told us previously that he has never made a direction, yet in the annual report it is noted that he did make one direction. The Minister does have power. I understand that the opinion was obtained not by EFIC but by DITAC, the Minister's own Department. I sometimes wonder what the Minister is aware of in his own Department.
—Are there any further questions?

—I thought that the Minister was finding out which opinion it was. If he is seriously telling the Committee that there was an opinion dated 1988 which said that EFIC had no power to raise borrowings on the national interest account, he has allowed that Department to go on raising borrowings illegally for the period up until when the new EFIC Bill was introduced, and that is a very serious matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to get precise dates in respect of these opinions and provide Senator Bishop with an answer but obviously I am not in a position to do so now. I think I may have misled Senator Bishop to one extent. The opinion from Mr Clay was in 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —That still leaves us in the position where there was still a period when illegal borrowings were being raised. I really do think it is a most serious matter. There was no retrospective effect in the EFIC Bill, where a remedy could have been effected. I will wait until I see the material that is provided, and I thank the Minister for that.

PARA.TAB: I just want to revert to the remuneration package that was put together for Mr McAlister's departure. I read from the annual accounts:

SPEECH.PARA: Following the resignation of the managing director, the Commission entered into a consultancy arrangement with the chairman to act as change manager until appointment of a new managing director. During the 1990-91 financial year, the chairman was paid $36,268 in his capacity as change manager. The former managing director's remuneration package included part payment of an interest only housing loan until 31 July 1993. The estimated total payments applying interest rates existing at balance date for the period 1 July 1991 to 31 July 1993 is in the order of $80,000. Subsequent to his resignation, the former managing director entered into a consultancy agreement with the Commission in the amount of $50,000 plus expenses which was paid in the year ended 30 June 1991.

Investigations that I have made indicate that there is no precedent for this sort of package, unless we can cite the extraordinary package that was negotiated by the Attorney-General for an officer of his who was in the news only yesterday. I would like to know why the cost of this package was so high and from where the precedent, if any, was sought and precisely who was it who negotiated that whole package.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure which package Senator Bishop is referring to, because she has referred to two. Assuming that she is referring to—
—The package has two bits.
—No. Senator Bishop is referring to two different packages. Let us deal with Mr McAlister's package.
—That is the one I am talking about.
—Senator Bishop read out something in relation to a package for Mr Ferris and a package for—
—No.
—She did read that out; I heard it. There was a package for Mr McAlister and one for Mr Ferris. It is no good Senator Bishop bobbing up and shaking her head. That is what she read out.
—Minister, you did not listen.
—Order! Senator Button has the call.

—I will deal with the package in respect of Mr McAlister, which, of the two packages which Senator Bishop has raised with me, I apprehend to be her major concern. In respect of Mr McAlister's package, I have already answered—because Senator Bishop asked me—what element of the package I authorised. I told Senator Bishop the answer to that question about eight minutes ago. The answer to that question about eight minutes ago was that I had to approve the housing loan element of the package. That was referred to me. In so far as the other elements of the package are concerned, they were negotiated between Austrade and Mr McAlister. The details were all negotiated between them. I think that is as far as I can take the answer to Senator Bishop's question. But no doubt Senator Bishop will have another one.

—The Minister is right. I asked: where is the precedent for—call it two packages if the Minister cares to—the negotiating of such packages? Was the Minister's concurrence required to allow Mr Ferris to take on the additional position of change manager, and did the Minister have to approve that remuneration?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no precedent, because Austrade is an organisation which is five years old. Mr McAlister was the one and only Managing Director of Austrade. There is no precedent. Let me say that Austrade was established as a statutory corporation, independent of the Public Service. Mr McAlister was paid a salary and conditions which, at the time of his appointment—not by me—were consistent as far as possible with the sort of commercial packages which were paid to chief executives in major companies, which Mr McAlister was before he came to Austrade. As far as that package is concerned, there was no precedent.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the second part of the question, as to whether I approved of Mr Ferris, as Chairman of Austrade, effectively acting in the managing director role between the time of the departure of Mr McAlister—as I recall, it was in December 1990—and July of this year, yes, I did. I approved of that. I felt it was the best way to handle the management of the organisation until a new managing director was appointed by the board of Austrade. There are many reasons for that.

As to the negotiations of Mr Ferris's package, if we can call it that, the details were not in any way before me. They were matters between the Austrade board and Mr Ferris in his capacity essentially as acting managing director. Austrade employed him; I did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, before you ask your next question, you may be able to help the Chair. I am just trying to find what reservation you are referring to at the moment.
—They are questions that remained outstanding concerning Austrade. There is a section in the reservation entitled `Austrade, EFIC loans and guarantees and matters pertaining thereto'.
—I beg your pardon. I am sorry, I did not hear you.

—I said that there is a section in the reservation entitled `Austrade, EFIC loans and guarantees'. At the stage that we are dealing with, EFIC was part and parcel of Austrade. It was not split up until after these hearings. Indeed, Mr McAlister was the Managing Director of both EFIC and Austrade, in the one position. At that stage the Chairman, Mr Ferris, and the board were common to both organisations.

—I rise on a point of order. The reservation refers to EFIC loans and guarantees, a topic about which we have talked for about two hours tonight. The issue which is being dealt with now is questions relating to remuneration packages for officers of Austrade. I do not think it has much to do with EFIC loans and guarantees.

—I do have some problem here, Senator Bishop. I am in no way trying to stifle debate, but I am trying to ensure that the debate is in relation to the reservations that are in the Committee's report. It was because of the types of matters which Senator Button has just mentioned that I originally asked which reservation you were referring to.

—I would ask, Mr Chairman, that you also take into account that at the time of the Estimates hearings, again and again we asked for the annual reports and the financial statements. They were not made available. They have become available only this week.
—In draft.
—Precisely. They have been made available specifically so that they can be dealt with in the Committee of the Whole.
—Come on. Pimples on tongues.

—I asked for them to be dealt with, and indeed the rather vigorous conversation I had with the Austrade officer was that I found it unacceptable that Austrade would make the documents available after the Committee of the Whole had sat and concluded its business. He saw the sense of that point.
—I must admit that I am finding some difficulty.
—Would it not be better to finish the matter concerning Mr McAlister which Senator Bishop is raising, rather than spending half an hour debating points of order?

—I am not trying to stifle debate in any way, but it seems to me that if we do not have a reservation here, we are going over ground that we should not be going over. If we can relate it to the reservations, that is fine. Let us get on with it. Are there any further questions in relation to program 5, which I understand is what we are on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I understand that in the reservation there is mention of the fact that the Austrade report was not supplied. It is material that has been mentioned in the report and received subsequent to the tabling of the report, which would place it in the same category as questions that are answered after the tabling of the report.
—You will have to direct me to the matter to which you are referring.
—If we look at the heading `Austrade', I think it will do us just fine. We can deal with the question of consultancies of former Austrade officers:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee examined the consultancy totalling some $30,000 for the former managing director of Austrade to visit Berlin and Hawaii even though he had only recently resigned from Austrade and the Government already had representation in Berlin in the person of Dr Charles, the former head of DITAC.

We then go on to discuss the matter of Mr David Combe. The next question I want to ask, which is directly relating to that consultancy payment, is this: was that payment of a further $30,000 by way of consultancy payment, as set out in the reservation to the report, in addition to the termination package that was paid to Mr McAlister? What was the reason? We have never had a satisfactory reason for the payment of that consultancy fee. Are there any further consultancy fees of which we are not aware, because we have not yet got the list?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in addition to the formal termination package paid to Mr McAlister. As I understand it, the Austrade board felt that it could profitably use the services of Mr McAlister in respect of that consultancy. I believe there were no other consultancies for Mr McAlister. I believe there were no other consultancies, but I will have that checked.

—From the Minister's answer, do I understand that it was the Austrade board that decided to make that additional consultancy payment? Do I also understand from his answer and his dissertations with the officers that there were some other forms of payments made?

—I will just clarify that. On termination, the Austrade board decided to pay Mr McAlister a retainer for one year at $20,000, and there was one consultancy—the consultancy to which Senator Bishop and I have both referred.

—When I ask these questions relating to the termination package and the granting of the consultancy, I am not doing it in any way to reflect upon the ability of Mr McAlister. In all of this I have had the problem that I do not understand how it is, when the McKinsey report was so scathing of Austrade and its operations, that Mr McAlister seems to have been made the scapegoat and the board, which oversaw the entire sorry mess, remained in place. I am asking these questions because I fail to understand the way this package was negotiated and the way Mr Ferris negotiated a package not only for Mr McAlister but for himself and yet remains chairman of the board. These curious relations went on and Mr McAlister was made the scapegoat.

PARA.TAB: Has the Minister ever asked himself, and got a satisfactory answer, how it is that the General Manager had to wear the entire flak for the catastrophe when the board was clearly a hands-on one? Has the Minister ever asked himself that question? If so, has he had a satisfactory answer?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop asked me whether I have asked that question of myself. I must say that, if I asked questions of myself, I would keep the answers to myself. I think she means to ask whether I have ever asked anybody else that question. The answer to that question is no. Senator Bishop described the board as being `hands-on'. It consisted of the Chairman, Mr Ferris, and the Deputy Chairman at relevant times.

—Without having received the other list of consultancies, we are unable to look at the expenditure of $6m on external consultancies. I understand that I will get that information next week. We will have to deal with that material at a different time.

PARA.TAB: The only point I would like to place on the record is that the accounts show that EFIC has written off $8m in losses for the year; it has recovered only $0.8m of previous losses. It appears to have some $22.5m worth of non-performing loans. I see no provision for assets that it may have repossessed pursuant to some of its loan agreements. How many repossessions under loan agreements have there been, in what areas, and what is the present state of those seized assets?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know that EFIC had written off $8m—that must be one of the best performances of any financial institution in Australia recently. With respect to the information that Senator Bishop requires about assets, I will obtain it for her and supply her with an answer.

—I thank the Minister. While he is doing that—this is my final question in this area—last year there was some $16m written off as the result of fraud that was perpetrated on EFIC concerning payment of guarantees that it made in respect of phoney sales. Can the Minister report to us whether any headway has been made in the recovery of any of that money or whether it has been given up as lost? What action has been taken against the people who perpetrated the fraud?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The position is, as Senator Bishop points out, that provision has been made for the writing-off of that amount, though not necessarily in one year. It is unlikely that that money, or part of it, will be recovered. The matter is still the subject of police investigation, both here and in the United States.

—Perhaps when the Minister is keeping us up to date as to those investigations, he might also inform us as to the state of investigations concerning Mr Eliadakis and the boat that he was particularly involved with, as well as the advance against the second approved loan for the boat that was never built.
—Are there any further matters in relation to program 5?
—Does that mean that the Minister will provide that information?
—You did not ask me whether I would provide it. I am not going to answer that.
—I asked the Minister whether he would provide us with an update as to what action has been taken concerning Mr Eliadakis.
—You said, `Perhaps he will provide me with information'.
—Pardon me for using soft language. I will go back to more direct and harsh language. Would the Minister be so kind as to provide the Senate with that information?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is useful information available at the time of the Supplementary Estimates in February, we will make it available.
—There being no further questions, we will move to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and deal with subprogram 6.4, the Office of the Resource Assessment Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator O'Chee will be speaking on the Office of the Resource Assessment Commission. Does that mean that all the officers related to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, except those to do with the Office of the Resource Assessment Commission, are now finished with and can leave?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of matters in relation to the Resource Assessment Commission and I hope that with a bit of luck we will be able to proceed through them in a fairly short time. Perhaps the best starting point would be in relation to the question that was taken on notice concerning the advices provided by the research section of the Resource Assessment Commission. These relate substantially to the contingent valuation survey and the validity of its findings and methods. Firstly, I ask Senator McMullan whether the Resource Assessment Commission plans to continue using the contingent valuation method as a part of future studies.
—I am advised that the answer is yes and that there is a contingent valuation survey under way as a part of the forestry inquiry.

—I accept the fact that the Resource Assessment Commission is committed to a contingent valuation survey in respect of the forestry inquiry. But excluding the forestry inquiry, does the Resource Assessment Commission intend to continue using the contingent valuation survey method for subsequent inquiries?
—That is a matter about which no decision has been made.

—I asked that question because of the alarming comments contained in the advices that seem to have flowed from various parts of the Resource Assessment Commission and the inconsistency of some of the results as compared with the statements that had previously publicly been made about the validity of the survey and its findings.

PARA.TAB: In discussing the Resource Assessment Commission, references I shall make to pages shall relate to pages as enumerated in volume 3 of the additional information received. It is interesting to note that at page 103 of volume 3 of the additional information it was first identified in about December 1990 that there was some sort of peculiarity in the values that people assigned to the area in question. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a little disturbing, although not absolutely implausible, that those who have actually visited Kakadu value it less highly than those who haven't visited it, at least for the minor scenario.
It goes on to offer a number of possible explanations.

PARA.TAB: This matter remained all the way through the life of the examination of the contingent valuation survey. For example, it was subject to a discussion in a paper that appears to have been prepared in around April 1991. At that point the officer who produced this minute paper, at page 69 of volume 3, went into some detail about other contingent valuation surveys that had been conducted in Australia and the relationship between place of residence and the willingness to pay which is, of course, the basis of the contingent valuation survey.

It is interesting to note that visitors to Fraser Island were identified as being more willing to pay than those who had not been there. Visitors to the Great Barrier Reef were more willing to pay to prevent the crown-of-thorns starfish than those who had not visited the reef. Yet in the minute paper from the Assistant Secretary of the research branch dated 2 April 1991, and contained on pages 67 to 68, it is noted that those who had not visited Kakadu National Park were willing to pay significantly less than those who had. And in this particular case the figures were $24.60 and $95.56 respectively.

Could the officers provide the Minister with some explanation as to the discrepancy between the Kakadu contingent valuation survey and the other contingent valuation surveys that have shown that people who have actually visited were more willing to pay for the preservation of these sites than those who had not. It seems in this particular case that Kakadu displays certain statistical peculiarities that are certainly not common to the others. Are the officers in a position to provide Senator McMullan with an explanation as to why the Kakadu survey is so different from the other ones?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no agreed explanation for the discrepancy it threw up in the survey. It struck people as unusual, but there is no agreed explanation for it.

—That is of concern. Clearly, from the information provided to the Estimates Committee, this has cost a lot of money in terms of both direct expenditure and allocation of staff resources. The sheer mass of information contained in these advices and the period over which they took place show that a lot of taxpayers' money was expended on it. If this method is going to be used in future studies by the Resource Assessment Commission, it is very disconcerting that faith is being placed in a method of survey that cannot even replicate its results from one survey to another.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that, in the advice dated 2 April 1991 from Mr Clive Hamilton, the Assistant Secretary of the research branch, appearing on page 68 of the additional information, he suggests that one of the explanations may be that people close to the resource are more likely to know about the resource. If Mr Hamilton is indeed correct in proposing that explanation, that would seem to contradict the validity of the contingent valuation survey in respect of the Kakadu conservation area. In particular, it would tend to argue against the validity of that survey in respect of the mining of Coronation Hill.

We get to a situation where either the survey method, because it cannot replicate itself, is meaningless and irrelevant, or the survey method is accurate and shows that in the Kakadu inquiry we had sheer ignorance outweighing knowledge and preventing the extraction of a very valuable resource on behalf of all Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The two options Senator O'Chee outlined are possible interpretations of the facts, but it was not an exhaustive list of the options. It is important to get the contingent valuation survey into some sort of perspective. It is an internationally accepted technique for attempting to measure the value people place on factors such as the environment. It is a technique the Resource Assessment Commission feels it has an obligation to assess and continue to endeavour to apply in the Australian context.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to suggest that in any way it has been a major element of decision making by the Resource Assessment Commission or the Government in this matter. It is simply a tool of analysis which the Commission has tried on one occasion, is trying again, and may choose to use in the future, but I do not think it ought to be got out of proportion. It is merely an analytical tool, like many others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that comment. As a result of the inquiry and the contingent valuation survey on Kakadu National Park, I think even the Resource Assessment Commission is saying that it is merely a tool, and not a definitive tool. But this was also the subject of discussion which was contained in the advices given by the Resource Assessment Commission. It is interesting to note that at some stage prior to the final report being brought out there was discussion in a memo from, I believe, Mr Clive Hamilton expressing some concern as to how it should be treated in the final report.

PARA.TAB: I cannot find the particular advice at hand immediately, and I will not delay the Committee over long by looking for it. From recollection, Mr Hamilton said, `We can't dump the contingent valuation survey because we'll look silly, but the results are peculiar and we can't put all our weight on them as well'. It seems very clear from that that at least within the Commission there were two schools of thought as to the value of this survey. Given that there were clearly two schools of thought as to the value of it, I think we need to have a very close look at whether we continue to use it.

But I must take issue with a comment that Senator McMullan has made as to the wide use of the contingent valuation survey. Certainly, it has been widely used, but from the evidence contained in the advice of Ms Leanne Wilkes on 5 April 1991, it certainly has not been widely relied upon. I think there is a difference between its being widely used and being widely relied upon. For example, Anne Fisher who was interviewed on 12 March 1991—she is from Pennsylvania State University and, interestingly enough, is formerly from the Environmental Protection Agency in the United States—said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are relatively few examples in the US where CV results have actually influenced government decisions.
A report of another interview conducted with Mary Jo Keely on 28 February 1991 stated:
According to Ms Keely, despite the fact that the US government funds many CV studies, this does not necessarily translate into the direct use of CV data for policy making.

It is very clear that although this stuff is done and the surveys are conducted in other places, they are not used as the basis of decision making. The question I raise, and the question I think many concerned taxpayers would raise, is: if they are not going to be used, why bother doing it at all?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the strangest instance of someone taking issue with me that I have seen. Senator O'Chee said, `I will take issue with Senator McMullan claiming that these are widely used' and then he started by saying that they certainly are widely used. I would have thought that should probably have been the end of the contribution. Nobody has claimed they are widely relied upon; it is a tool under international assessment as part of the tools of analysis used by decision makers as bodies around the world are endeavouring to grapple with the very complex elements of decision making in the areas into which we are all having to go due to the demands of the 1990s and beyond in order to balance environmental and development factors and other things.

PARA.TAB: Whatever predisposition we might have about the merit of this method, to turn one's back on it and say, `We are not going to try it' seems to me to be rather Luddite. I do not advocate that as a course of action, any more than I would advocate seizing it as the only method of decision making at this time and relying extensively upon it. But I think the Resource Assessment Commission is saying that it considers it to be a tool worthy of further investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How important a tool does the Resource Assessment Commission see it as being?
—That is a pretty useless question which I really cannot answer. It is not capable of quantitative response.
—It may be capable of some sort of qualitative response. The question is: how important a tool does the Resource Assessment Commission see the contingent valuation survey method as being?
—All I can say is that it is useful enough to try at least once more in the existing forestry survey; after that, we will see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Resource Assessment Commission concludes its forestry survey, I assume it will make some evaluation—having had two bites of the cherry—as to whether it will use the method again. At that stage, will the Resource Assessment Commission produce some sort of public document or guideline as to the basis upon which it will be used in the future? If it is going to be used, then it is very important that everybody understand exactly what weight and importance the Resource Assessment Commission places upon it. It has obviously been a very high profile tool, although its value is clearly dubious.
—Yes.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary and the officers of the Resource Assessment Commission for that response. My only remaining concern is that we are apparently locked into the use of a contingent valuation survey in the timber industry inquiry. I now ask: what is the potential value of the timber industry, or the area of the timber industry which is subject to the inquiry and which could be affected by the results of the inquiry? We have to know exactly how much is on the line when we are talking about using a method that the Commission does not even know the validity of.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan—Could Senator O'Chee repeat the question?

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I said that it appears that we are now locked into the use of the contingent valuation survey for the forestry industry inquiry. I want to know this: what is the value of the forestry industry or that portion of the forestry industry which could be affected by the results of this contingent valuation survey that is being conducted? Obviously we need to know how much is on the line when it is being subject to the results of the survey, the value of which is unknown to the Resource Assessment Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that such an analysis will be in a study to be released by the Resource Assessment Commission fairly soon. I cannot provide a specific date, but in the relatively near future a report will be released by the Resource Assessment Commission which will contain some of those figures.
—On a point of clarification, is it correct that an analysis of the value of the timber industry is to be brought up shortly?
—I do not think that the document is just that, but the document that is to be released will include the data which Senator O'Chee just requested.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary. Whilst we are talking about reports and studies that are to be released, I note that at the time the additional answers were given to questions on notice—I think that the date in question was 14 October—it was not possible to release the Lynch-Blosse consultancy report. I accept the fact that I have been absent between that time and now. In the interim period has the Lynch-Blosse consultancy report been released?
—No, it has not been released, but it will be. Some consultation is occurring with regard to it.

—I thank Senator McMullan. At the time we had the hearings it was estimated that the report would be released in a couple of weeks. Of course I accept that estimate was made in good faith. Are the officers now in a position to make a somewhat better estimate of the date of release of this consultancy report? Some of us are quite interested in it.
—Provided that Senator O'Chee accepts this best assessment on the same basis as the last one, the Resource Assessment Commission advises me that it is hoping to get it out in about four to six weeks.

—I thank Senator McMullan and the officers of the Resource Assessment Commission. Perhaps I could be given a copy when it is released. If I could be given a copy as soon as possible thereafter, I would be very grateful.
—Autographed.
—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary very much. His generosity at this hour of the evening is truly astounding.
—It might become a collector's copy.

—Indeed, it may. The matter I wish to raise now is of a somewhat more administrative nature and relates to cars. I have perused the information contained in the advices that were supplied as part of the additional information that was contained in the material given to the Committee. From what I can gather from the information contained here, the question of a car is, I believe, subject now to discussions with the Department of Industrial Relations. I ask whether that is correct.
—I understand that the view of the Minister for Industrial Relations is being sought on this matter.
—How long will it be before a final result is arrived at?

—It is neither in my hands nor those of the Resource Assessment Commission. I understand it is before the Minister at the moment. You will appreciate that he has a couple of other matters on his table as well and this may not be the one to which he is giving the highest priority, but it is before the Minister at the moment.

—My concern is that it is also my understanding that the period of employment of the gentleman who happens to have one of these cars concludes in February 1992. At this current rate it may be that, if the matter is not dealt with before February next year, he will get to keep the car irrespective of the fact that it is not his entitlement. Everybody here would be concerned that this situation may arise.

PARA.TAB: Can I be given an undertaking that it will be dealt with speedily? It is already six weeks since the matter was raised in the hearings. Christmas is rapidly approaching, as is the silly season in the first part of January and the Public Service holidays. The next thing we know it will be the middle of February, when this gentleman's contract expires. Will the matter be dealt with in a speedy fashion and certainly before the end of the year?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that at the moment the middle of February seems a very long way away. It is actually 31 March that the officer concludes his appointment, but that does not change the substance of your point. Of course, I cannot give a guarantee that someone else will do something, so I can only give you a guarantee that I will raise it with the Minister.

—I thank Senator McMullan. I have relied on his undertakings in the past and he has not let me down. For the record, this is a matter of great seriousness and of great importance. Of all the matters that were raised in the hearings, I certainly believe that everybody in this chamber would want to rest assured that this matter will be dealt with speedily, and that the whole thing will not be allowed to slip until the gentleman's appointment terminates due to natural causes, because that would defeat the whole process of this Estimates Committee.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 6.4?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I regret that I was not in the chamber when some of the earlier sections of the Department were dealt with. I wonder whether I could claim your indulgence and that of Senator McMullan to go back a little. There were some questions I wished to ask in the area of Federal-State relations which come within a variety of areas in our report, including the growth of the Department of PM and C. This has been with the Secretariat for the Federal-State relations exercise and is part of that. There are also other aspects in our Committee's report which make it relevant. I would appreciate it if I could have the opportunity to ask a few questions in that area.
—I do not like going backwards, but seeing as you are a fellow seventy-fiver, Senator Short, let us give it a go.
—Your magnanimity at this stage of the evening is enormous, Mr Chairman.
—You do realise that the officers have gone, do you?

—Yes, I do. Perhaps I could raise a few matters, and if Senator McMullan can handle them that will be great; if not, they might have to be taken on notice. I refer to the discussions that we had in the Estimates Committee with officers of the Department, and in particular with Mr O'Sullivan, First Assistant Secretary, Commonwealth-State Relations Secretariat—Hansard of 9 September, pages A140 to A149. Senator McMullan will remember that in that discussion we discussed the probable agenda and content of the November Special Premiers Conference. At that stage the date had not been determined, except that it was suggested that it would be the third week in November, and we now know that was about right, as it will be held on 21 and 22 November. I discussed with Mr O'Sullivan in particular what would be on the agenda and what would be discussed. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: It is expected though, is it not, to the extent that there are major decisions in the area of vertical fiscal imbalance, tied grants and those sorts of things, plus all the other non-Commonwealth-State financial relations, that those major decisions, if they emerge, will be taken at this third conference?
Mr O'Sullivan replied:
Yes, that is correct, we would expect that.
His response to my next comment was:

Our expectation would be that there will be ongoing work after November; that the November conference will be one at which very major decisions will be taken, particularly in the areas you mention of Commonwealth-State financial relationships. . . But we would expect the broad decisions on that Commonwealth-State financial relationship to take place in November.

I then said that I assumed that one of the options being considered would be the return in whole or part of income taxing powers to the States and asked him whether that was correct, to which Mr O'Sullivan replied:
That would be one of the options that would be put on the table.

Is that discussion that took place a couple of months ago, on 9 September, still relevant, and will those issues be discussed in Perth? Will the major decisions which it was thought at that time would be taken in December in fact be taken?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have anything very new to add to that which is already public. An officials' paper has been prepared and that has now been provided for consideration by both the Commonwealth Government and the State governments prior to the Special Premiers Conference. It deals with the full range of options that it was requested to deal with, and the Government is considering its views with regard to that report. The report is listed as a subject for consideration at that meeting. No-one can predetermine what, if anything, is going to be decided there, but it is scheduled to be considered.

—Thank you for that. I was going to say that in other words Senator McMullan is confirming that the conversation that took place in September still holds, but I do not think in fact he is doing that. The issues that were stressed several times in the September Estimates discussion as being two of the critical issues to be decided in Perth were the questions of whether the States could have income taxing powers returned to them and/or whether there may be some tax sharing arrangements based on the States getting a fixed share of income tax revenue.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it—and it is, I admit, very confusing—the Prime Minister earlier this week appears to have ruled out either of those options as being ones that the Commonwealth would canvass. So far as the return of any income taxing powers to the States is concerned, he has been reported as saying—indeed, I think in the House of Representatives two days ago—that any return of income taxing powers is, to quote him, `not on'. Is my understanding of what the Prime Minister said this week correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no intention of reinterpreting the Prime Minister's remarks. They are in the Hansard.

—Does that not mean that one of the two options that Mr O'Sullivan said in an Estimates debate were to be decided in Perth is no longer, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, a matter for decision, that decision already having been taken?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the Hansard of Mr O'Sullivan's remarks here, but from my recollection of them and those which Senator Short quoted—which do not contradict my recollection, although of course they are more specific—I understood him to be saying that the report will be considered at that meeting, that is the formal place for it and no decision can be made before the meeting. To say `We will make a decision about that' implies he might be going to say `No'; it does not mean he will necessarily say, `Yes'. As a matter of logic, if the report comes before that body for decision, it is open to that body to make a decision which is, `No, we will not do that'. So I do not think one can assume there is not going to be a decision. As I understand it, the Prime Minister simply conveyed his view about what the decision is likely to be.

—I put it to Senator McMullan that if the Prime Minister gets up here in the Federal Parliament in Canberra and says that, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, the return of any income taxing powers to the States is not on, then it is absolute nonsense to say that the question of whether there will be any return of income taxing powers to the States is a matter for decision in Perth. That is just ridiculous if the Commonwealth has already said, through the Prime Minister, that so far as it is concerned it will not be a party to any such decision. So where does that leave the Perth conference in relation to that fundamental aspect?

—It is not really a matter for me to comment upon. I do not think the State Premiers have regarded themselves as struck mute in the lead-up to the conference in that they do not regard themselves as unable to comment on the matters for discussion, and I would not have thought they would regard the Prime Minister as unable to comment. I do not intend to try to expand here in this Committee on the things the Prime Minister said. They are quite clear and they are open for public interpretation and debate. I do not think we will increase the sum of human knowledge very much by pursuing it here.
—Does that mean that it is possible that there could be a decision in Perth to give the States some income taxing powers if such a decision has not been taken?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. As a matter of logic, it does not necessarily mean that at all. The formal decision will be taken at Perth. The Prime Minister has expressed his view with regard to the matter and I do not intend to add anything to that.
—Senator Short, I am having some difficulty finding the reservation to which you are referring. If you could assist me, I would be grateful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, Mr Chairman. Page 9 of the Estimates Committee report contains part of the reservations made by Senator Bishop and me. We listed other matters. In the opening paragraph of the subsection on the Prime Minister's portfolio we discuss our concern about the growth in some areas of the Department, particularly those with responsibilities also covered by other Government departments. Also, under the subsectional heading `Other matters' we deal with growth in the Department, the duplication of tasks and advice provided by other departments, and so on. Those are relevant matters. All of the matters that I am now raising, particularly the financial matters, are the responsibility of other departments. So it is in that context that I raise these matters.

—I think we might be drawing a long bow there. I mention this only because we are bound to deal with the reservations that we have before us. If we stray from them we will introduce extraneous matters. I would like the honourable senator to be aware of that.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Chairman. I am very conscious of that. In the discussion that we had in September—and I refer to page A149 of the Hansard—I quoted from the communique of the second Special Premiers Conference which was held in July. Under the subheading of `Review of Commonwealth and State Government and Taxation Powers', the communique said, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Leaders and representatives restated the commitment made at the October special Premiers' Conference to address the question of vertical fiscal imbalance with a view to reducing that imbalance while recognising the necessity for the Commonwealth to have adequate means to meet its national responsibility for effective macroeconomic management.
The communique went on to say:

Leaders and representatives noted that work is progressing as planned for the final report to be presented to the November special Premiers' Conference. Although the examination of issues is not yet complete, some preliminary conclusions are.
The first issue relates to the following:

PARA.TAB: a very large reduction in the existing degree of vertical fiscal imbalance between the Commonwealth and the States could be made before the existing arrangements for horizontal fiscal equalisation would be called into question.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Sullivan, in response to my question, said that all heads of government had agreed to all parts of the communique; that there were no qualifications; and that that would include all the Premiers and, of course, the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator McMullan whether I can take it that, in light of the events of recent days and statements by the Prime Minister, the Commonwealth still subscribes to that communique of the second Special Premiers Conference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not speaking on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with regard to matters other than the estimates. In so far as what Senator Short said was a quote—that one could reduce the vertical fiscal imbalance without removing the capacity to resolve problems of horizontal fiscal imbalance—I do not think that is a matter of recent contention. I have not heard any argument about that matter. I have not heard any confirmation of it either, but I have heard no reason to challenge it. Beyond that, I cannot say any more.

—A meeting of officials was arranged for next week in Sydney to draft the communique for the Perth Premiers Conference. That meeting has been postponed. Can the Minister tell me when it has been postponed until?
—I do not know the answer, but it is a very long bow for the Estimates.

—I am sure the Parliamentary Secretary would agree with me that we are talking about a very important and topical issue and a matter of concern to both the Federal and State governments, and therefore to all Australians. It was a subject that we dealt with in some detail at the Estimates hearings. Therefore, with respect, I suggest that it is relevant. Perhaps if he does not know the answer, he could take it on notice. At the same time—I presume this question cannot be answered either—perhaps he could tell me why next week's meeting has been postponed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am willing to take them both on notice. I have grave doubts about whether the questions properly relate to what is before us. I do not want to start a debate about that right now. In the interests of cooperation, I will take them on notice.
—I agree with Senator McMullan. In fact, I would go further; I do not think they are before us. If we can keep to the appropriations, it would be helpful.

—I want to put on the record my thanks for your allowing me, Mr Chairman, to come back to that subprogram. I wish to reiterate my understanding of what Senator McMullan has said tonight, or perhaps in some ways has not said. My understanding is that the events of recent days, in particular the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), mean that, contrary to what was said in the Estimates hearings only two months ago by the First Assistant Secretary in charge of the Commonwealth-State Relations Secretariat, namely, that the income taxing option of giving the States back some income taxing powers would be considered in Perth, that option is no longer an option.

PARA.TAB: Any suggestion that the Perth conference will make major decisions in relation to income taxing powers and, therefore, the fundamental question of financial relations between the Commonwealth and the States and the correction of the vertical fiscal imbalance is nothing more than a mockery. That is the only conclusion I can draw from the events of recent days and this discussion. I will not pursue it at any further at this stage. I thank you, Mr Chairman, for your indulgence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —If summing up statements are where we are at at the moment, I acknowledge Senator Short's view. It is not mine, but at this stage he is entitled to express it.
—There being no further matters in relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, we turn to the Department of the Treasury. (Quorum formed)

—I put a question on notice during the hearings. We have received a reply to that question today. The question was whether it would be possible to provide the Committee with updated data for the micro-economic model, including access to the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Department of Social Security data input. I also asked in what form the updated database would be made available. As I say, I have received the answer to that. It seems to have been left open whether the data will be made available. I want to ask why that is the case and when it will be known whether that data will be available?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question was provided in response to a previous question, which I will just get for Senator Short. Just so that I am clear on what is required—there are a couple of different aspects—is Senator Short talking about the availability of data that is used as inputs or the model or the results of the analysis? Which is Senator Short pursuing in this particular question?
—In this particular question I was pursuing the availability of the input data.

—We are saying that the form in which the data might be available would be negotiated by the purchaser and the Treasury. The raw data is based on ABS data and information on commodity taxes. It is feasible to make available some part or all of the detailed database on request. There might be a charge for it. There is still some consideration about that process. I think that the current trend of thinking—it has not been finalised, as Senator Short said—is that it should be possible to make part or all of the database available. It is a new concept, a decision about which has not yet been finalised.

—Whilst that raw data has come basically from the household expenditure survey, plus the information on commodity taxes held within Treasury, the Minister will notice that the first paragraph of the answer says that this data has been subject to significant statistical manipulation by Treasury. Of course, unless one knows what significant statistical manipulation has been done, the use of the data to anyone else is limited at best. I am trying to ascertain whether the significantly manipulated data will be made available.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a previous question of Senator Short's which did not arise in the Estimates—I think it was a question on notice, if I read this sheet correctly—we said that it was intended that full details of the modelling methodology would be published once the model is up and running. So we are getting away now from the data to the methodology, and I think that relates more to that point.

—Yes, I think that does relate to the methodology rather than the data. Therefore, I come back to the data. There are at least three things: there is the raw data; there is the manipulation—to use the Treasury's own words—that is done to the data; there is the modelling; and then there is the final outcome. Unless there is stage 2, which is the manipulation done to the raw data, it is not possible for anyone else to follow the process or to be able to examine and understand fully any modelling or any outcome result. Unless the Department is prepared to make available the manipulation and what has been done to the data, then it is not really providing anything worth while at all, in my view. I want to know whether that will be made available.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot go beyond what I have said. As Senator Button said in response to Senator Short's question on notice, it is intended that full details of the modelling methodology will be published once the model is up and running. That is the information that is available at the moment. There is also the material provided today concerning the data, and I think that has gone a fair way towards meeting Senator Short's concerns. It is always possible to envisage that something could slip between the cracks; as I see it at the moment, that is unlikely. One cannot disprove things in advance but, putting together the various answers, I think we are getting towards meeting Senator Short's concern and we will see whether there are any further problems as it develops. I cannot say anything more at the moment.
—When will the model be up and running?
—I cannot give a final answer on that.

—I think it was Mr Fraser, or one of the Treasury officers, who said in response to a question of mine in Estimates on 25 September that it was expected that the model would be sufficiently in place to be able to do its core work within about four weeks. That time period has elapsed now. Was that timetable met?

—I cannot be assured that that is the case. The information I have does not indicate that it is now up and running, which would be the case had that timetable been met. The officers concerned are not here, but in so far as I can get information from the officers available, it does not seem to me that it is up and running at this stage.
—Could Senator McMullan take this on notice and let us have that information as soon as possible?
—I am happy to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, have a question relating to that model. I was fascinated to find among the answers that were provided today a paper entitled `Background briefing for Senator McMullan'. It is called a progress report, and it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The micro-economic model being built by Treasury is still under development. The data requirements of the model are very extensive and the work is continuing on assembling the database. The analytical specification of the model is currently being tested.
As Senator McMullan has been briefed on how the database is proceeding, could he tell us just how extensive that database is and precisely what it includes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you have the same briefing note that I have.

—Yes, but I do not have access to the rest of the information that Senator McMullan has. With respect to his answer to Senator Short's question—when he said that he was not quite sure when all the data will be assembled, and up and running—I cannot help wondering whether the original timetable which was set was meant to coincide with the Opposition's timetable for releasing its tax package and goods and services tax, and that what is holding up the operation of the Government's model and the conclusion of its database is the fact that it does not yet have our material which it intends to test. Can Senator McMullan tell me whether, in that extensive material, the Government is including—as he told us in the Estimates hearings—material which will enable it to test our costings on the goods and services tax, and where that data is coming from?
—Your enthusiasm for a conspiracy theory says more about you than me.

—It is not a conspiracy theory; it is simply an analysis of the answers that Senator McMullan gave us on a previous occasion. Here he is, being kept up to date and told of the extensive work of the database. Is Senator McMullan telling me and Senator Short that in all honesty he, who has responsibility in this area, does not know what is being included on the database? I find that almost incredible.
—I do not have responsibility for this area, nor the information which you seek, nor is there a conspiracy, but if you wish to see one, go right ahead.
—Perhaps Senator McMullan can refresh our memories very quickly with his title and job specification in this area.
—No, I won't.
—So Senator McMullan's attitude is that on this occasion—
—My attitude is that this has nothing to do with the Estimates Committee, so get on with it. It is too late for this rubbish.

—I realise that Senator McMullan is getting testy. We get testy, too, because the Government is having public servants do paid party political work which we find offensive, and so do they. That is why we ask specific questions about the model that the Government is building; what, precisely, it is putting on the database; what access we will have to the material that the Government has; and, indeed, just how honest Senator McMullan is being in the answers we are being given now. He has given us very short answers which have not denied what I have said but are merely gratuitous and insulting comments. I ask again whether Senator McMullan has no knowledge at all of what material is being included on the database to be used on the model that the Government is building?
—The information I have is publicly available; it is the material I provided to the Estimates Committee. That is all the information I have.
—Was the background briefing note that Senator McMullan received done at Senator McMullan's behest or was it simply gratuitously supplied? Is it the only briefing note that he has received?
—I did not request it, it is the only one I have received.
—I ask whether the officers who are with us tonight are in a position to give Senator McMullan any further information in relation to these matters.
—I have taken the questions on notice and I will provide the information as soon as I can. Although they are cooperative and helpful people, these are not the officers responsible for that area.

—We discussed income taxing powers and Commonwealth-State relations in the Estimates Committee. The Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Cole, is on record as saying that income taxing powers could be handed back to the States without any adverse effect on the ability of the Commonwealth to control the macro-economy and that, indeed, was reflected in the communique of the July Premiers Conference. What was unusual at that time was the fact that the Treasury was expressing this view. Could Senator McMullan tell me how long the Treasury has been of this view?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any information with regard to that. I understand the point Senator Short is making, but I have nothing before me to indicate that it is a collective departmental view or that there was previously a different view—and, if so, when the change took place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a report in the Australian Financial Review on 12 October, a few days after we had discussed these matters in Estimates, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Treasury's opinion shifted decisively towards an historic acceptance of State income taxes at a closed seminar of the department's bureaucrats last April.
Could Senator McMullan let me know whether that is correct and whether there was such a seminar at that time?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there was a seminar in April, but I do not have any information about conclusions to which it might have come.
—Would the Treasury officers know what briefing would have been provided to the Treasurer following that seminar? If not, could they take it on notice?
—No. I do not even know whether there was any briefing, but I will take it on notice and see whether I can find some useful information.

—I would appreciate it if Senator McMullan, in doing that, could let me know what form the briefing for the Treasury—assuming there was some—took; that is, whether it was an oral briefing or a written report was prepared for the Treasury.
—I am assuming that that is part of the question. I was not bothering to respond; I was taking it for granted.
—At the Estimates hearings the Treasury officials said, at page 518:

SPEECH.PARA: Following the July Special Premiers Conference . . . the Prime Minister and the Treasurer at the press conference indicated that the study to date had shown—
and this is reflected in the communique, but it is also reflected in the transcript of the press conference that was held after the conclusion of the Conference—
there were not insuperable macro-economic considerations that would stand in the way of providing greater taxing powers to States . . .
certainly, the Treasurer—
then Mr Keating, of course—
reiterated those points made at the press conference in July.
