The Treasury officials tended to deny that there had been any change of heart at Treasury, which tends to conflict with the question that I asked before. Can Senator McMullan throw any light on that? Had there been any change of heart?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am becoming a bit unclear about what I have already taken on notice to provide and what I have not, but I thought I had already undertaken to try to provide that information, and I will. If I had not previously done so—which I thought I had—I will do so now.
—The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his speech to the National Press Club on 22 October, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not recall anyone in Treasury putting this view to me while I was there.

That view was that we can transfer significant revenue sources to the States and have that as quite compatible with effective Commonwealth economic management, because changes to spending or taxes over the cycle, or in response to external shocks, are `marginal'.

PARA.TAB: In the advice that the Minister is going to get for me—for which I thank him in advance—can he also include whether the Treasurer had ever been briefed on this matter by the Treasury to the effect that one could hand back revenue powers and revenue raising responsibilities to the States without in any way damaging the Commonwealth's role and responsibility for macro-economic management?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be cooperative, but with regard to a large number of these questions that I am taking on notice—and this one most explicitly—we are straying very close to the line of departmental policy advice to Ministers, which is not normally part of material provided at Estimates hearings. But, within that normal constraint, I will get such information for Senator Short on these matters as I can.

—Senator McMullan will recall that in the Estimates hearings we spoke about the ecologically sustainable development project and Treasury's involvement in that. I refer to the Hansard at page 541 of Estimates Committee A. I think it is fair to say from that debate that the Treasury officers were pretty ambiguous in their responses concerning whether they had prepared any analysis of long term impact on the Australian economy of the Toronto agreement on limiting greenhouse emissions by the year 2000. They said they would wait to see what resulted from the ESD process before advising the Treasurer. I note that in Estimates Committee C hearings a couple of weeks before that, DASETT officials said that they have in fact commenced work on the issue of a carbon tax in the context of the ESD project and that the other main department involved in this research was Treasury. What studies has Treasury done on the implications of a carbon tax in Australia?
—I cannot find a reservation that relates to that, either. Nevertheless, I will see what information I can provide. But I do not think that even comes close to one of the reservations.

—I am a little concerned. Honourable senators should make sure that the questions they are asking relate to one of the reservations contained in the report. Is there anything further on subprogram 1.4?
—Mr Chairman, I do accept your point. I thought that there was a comment in the report in relation to ESD. Given that I have now asked the question, can the Minister at least take in on notice?

—I did indicate that I would try to find something out. My only concern is that we keep putting extra demands on the officers to provide information and we keep opening up new areas. That is why I drew attention to it, and I do not want to pursue it any further. But if there is something I can get that seems, on the face of it, to be a straightforward enough question to which there should be a simple answer, and if it starts to take a lot of administrative time, I may come back and advise accordingly. But otherwise, if I can cooperate easily, I will.

—As there is nothing further in relation to 1.4, we will move to program 2, `Financial System'. Subprogram 2.1 is `Financial System (Insurance and Superannuation Commission)'. We have `Difficulties in measuring the efficiency of control of the financial system' as a reservation from Senators Bishop and Short. We then go on to subprogram 2.1. Are there any matters there?

—In view of the late hour, I do not wish to pursue this too much. I would like to ask one question, though, in relation to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, that is relevant to this section. According to press reports, the Federal Government is reported to be likely to exempt State governments from having to pay up front the superannuation guarantee levy when it comes in as of July next year. Could the Parliamentary Secretary let me know whether that report is correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that there is a White Paper imminent. Because there are no officers here from the ISC, I am really doing this off the top of my head and I apologise if I am subsequently proved not to be correct. The best information I can provide at the moment from my recollection is that a Government position paper is to be released, though I am not sure if `White Paper' is the appropriate title. I imagine that information would be in there. I do not think I can get anything for Senator Short before that is released, but I think it will be public—I have to be general—reasonably soon. The officers are not here and it is not my personal area, but that is my recollection of the situation.

—The next program where there are matters to be raised is program 6 `Taxation Administration'. There are some general matters there. Are there any matters to be raised in subprogram 6.1, `Income Tax'?

—I think that Senator Watson, in particular, and I have some questions that we would perhaps have asked on another occasion, but it is late and I understand there are no members of the Tax Office here. Is that correct?
—That is correct.
—I think that we will perhaps deal with them on another occasion.

—There being nothing further in the Department of the Treasury, we will move to the Department of Finance. I will again go through the running sheet. There are some general matters mentioned. I normally find that these general matters are subsumed in the later programs, so it might be best to start off at program 1, `Budget Development and Management', subprogram 1.1.

—Senator Bishop and I did put in a reservation in relation to the provision of Forward Estimates of revenue and expenditure information,. Officers of the Department of Finance said during our discussion within those parameters that the Department prepares its own estimates of forward revenue, albeit `very broad brush work'. That raises a number of questions.

PARA.TAB: Does the Department of Finance have any difficulty in obtaining information on forward revenue estimates from the Department of the Treasury? I realise that there was some discussion about this during the Estimates Committee hearings, but I would like to pursue the matter a little further. In particular, in that context, I would like to know what arrangements there are between Treasury and Finance for Finance to receive that information.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there are regular discussions, for example, in the Joint Economic Forecasting Group, as one would expect. As the honourable senator would also be aware, revenue estimates are not primarily the responsibility of the Department of Finance; they are the responsibility of the Treasury. But Finance does participate in regular discussions in bodies such as the Joint Economic Forecasting Group, in which such information would undoubtedly be discussed from time to time.

—I do not quite understand that. Given that the Treasury does, as you say, have responsibility for making forward estimates of revenue, and given the importance of those estimates to the Department of Finance, why is that information apparently not available to Finance? Presumably it is not available, otherwise Finance would not be having a go at its own broad brush approach to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a question of circumstances in which the Treasury refuses to supply the information to Finance. It is simply that the timetables of the two departments may not coincide: the time at which Treasury may be updating its estimates may not coincide with the time at which Finance feels it needs updated information. It therefore develops its own broad brush—I think that was the phrase you used—estimates. I think that is probably a logical outcome that one would expect from a competent economic department. I have had drawn to my attention the response by Mr Holmes to the honourable senator's question which appears on page 481 of the Hansard. Mr Holmes, from the Department, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not that there is anything wrong with the Treasury information. It is just that for the purposes of briefing our Minister it may not be available or it may not be timely.

By `available', the Department is not implying that it Treasury had refused to supply the information, but rather that the relevant information might not be available at the time at which it is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Department of Finance is very much responsible for the preparation and presentation of the Budget documentation generally. Of course, forward revenue estimates are not published any longer, although they were some time ago.
—I do not think they ever were.

—I thought they were for a limited period, but I stand to be corrected. Irrespective of whether they were, New South Wales and Tasmania have commenced publishing Forward Estimates, which of course helps enormously in understanding the budgetary and financial economic position of those governments. Is the Federal Government giving any thought to following the lead of Tasmania and New South Wales and, if not, why not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were in a position to provide the information, it would have come from the Treasury. If such a thing happened, it would be a Treasury responsibility—but I am not trying to duck using the rules. In any event, any such decision would be a policy decision made by the Cabinet, not by departmental officers. Obviously they would be involved in presenting a paper or something, but it would not be a decision made at that level. Probably it is the wrong place to ask it but, in any event, the answer would be same.
—If there is nothing further on program 1 or subprogram 1.1, we will now deal with program 5 and specifically subprogram 5.3, which is entitled, `Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales'.

—I have a couple of questions on the Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales. It appears—but perhaps I could have a confirmation from the Parliamentary Secretary—that the Government is proposing to make the airlines sale a trade sale.
—Be more explicit.

—It appears that it is looking for another airline or airlines to buy into Australian Airlines and Qantas rather than putting them out to the general public or using other sale techniques. Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an option being considered. To the best of my knowledge and on the advice I have received there is no decision as final as that at this stage. I have seen the same media speculation as Senator Short which says that that is an option under consideration. But, to the best of my knowledge and advice, no final decision has been made to do that.

—Can I expect that the task force or the Government will take a decision on that? I presume that unless and until such time as the Government does take such a decision there is no way it will sell the airline.

—I cannot give Senator Short a particular answer. If I can subsequently get something more than I am about to hypothesise, I will provide it to him. I am not sure of the state of the negotiations. It would seem to me quite logical that there would be two processes going on at the same time, one of which is assessing the interest while the other is assessing the most appropriate method of sale. As Senator Short would understand, the two are not unrelated. If there is some more information that I can make publicly available without cutting across the possible success of the Commonwealth sales program, I will try to make it available to Senator Short.

—I notice that CS First Boston is the financial adviser to the task force on the sale of the airlines. I also note that CS First Boston may be involved in the initial preparations for any public float that might eventuate. Has the task force ensured that there is a clear demarcation between the role of CS First Boston as financial adviser on the one hand and its potential to act as an underwriter for any prospective buyer on the other? If so, what has it done to ensure that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Department of Finance has certainly been conscious of this and has made arrangements which it believes protects against that potential conflict of interest. As I am advised, CS First Boston's current contract relates only to the first stage of that, which concerns the consultant's role about the nature of the sale. There is no decision about stage two. There is a consciousness of the issue that the honourable senator has raised.

—I understand that CS First Boston had a couple of its team working on the underwriting of the Air New Zealand sale, and, of course, Air New Zealand may well be one of the potential bidders for our airlines. Does the Minister acknowledge that it would appear, at least prima facie, that there would be considerable potential for a conflict of interest in that regard?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any detailed information on the role of CS First Boston with regard to the Air New Zealand matter. I can only say that the Department is conscious of the need to avoid any real or apparent conflict of interest. I am sure that that would apply to the issue that the honourable senator has just raised. I will draw the honourable senator's concern to the attention of the Department. However, I am advised that the officers there are already conscious of making sure that any real or apparent conflict of interest is avoided.

—I would have thought that it would be very important to ensure that CS First Boston has totally severed its interests with Air New Zealand, if it is going to be involved in the way in which it appears that it may be involved in the Australian airlines sales, and I think it is important that the Minister ensure that that severing has occurred and that the Senate be reassured that all steps have been taken to ensure that there is no conflict of interest in this situation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned, and I know the Minister is concerned, and I am certain that the task force is concerned, to ensure that there is neither any possible conflict of interest nor even any appearance of a conflict of interest. The honourable senator knows the area very well and would understand that many of these companies are involved in advising in so many arrangements that it may be impossible to avoid some remote link. However, I accept the thrust of the honourable senator's point and I will seek to provide such information as I can to reassure myself and the Senate that there is no danger of or even appearance of a conflict of interest.

—It seems to me, and certainly to the coalition, that one of the very important things that ought to be done in any privatisation is to involve the employees. It is a part of coalition policy that any privatisation policy have as an essential part of it an opportunity for employees to obtain equity at a favourable price. There would appear to be no automatic provision at all in the case of the airline sale proposals for employee share participation. I would like confirmation on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confirm this, but my recollection is that there has been some indication of a willingness or intention to proceed in the direction of employee participation. However, a number of such issues have been discussed and my memory might not be sufficiently precise on this. I shall seek some further information. As the honourable senator would be aware, the only actual on the ground example, with regard to the Commonwealth Bank, did involve significant arrangements for employees, and that is an indication of the broad direction in the thinking on this matter. However, if there is any detailed information yet available in relation to the airlines—and it might be too soon—I will make that available.

—My recollection, which may not be 100 per cent either, is that it was said—there was some discussion of this in the Estimates—that there may be some share left over in which case, after trade sales and the like, the thought may be given to employee share participation. My point is: why is such participation not a mandatory condition of the sale? To privatise the airlines, or any other government business undertaking, and to not make automatic provision for favourable employee share participation is, in my view—and certainly in the view of the coalition—a very significant detraction from the real advantages of privatisation, one fundamental value of which is to increase the spread of share ownership throughout the general community, and particularly to assist in the workplace participation and involvement of employees. It is quite extraordinary that it has not been made mandatory in this case. If it has not been made mandatory, I hope that the Government would look at changing its view on that very important situation.

—I do not think the honourable senator would appreciate that, while there is some similarity of action with regard to some of these particular matters, we approach these issues sometimes from a different policy perspective. I do not think this particular sale has got to the stage where a decision has been made about whether certain shares are to be made available to any particular group. —I want to point out, and have it on the record of the Senate as a whole, how concerned I am—I know Senator Bishop as well as the coalition are concerned—at the inordinate, inexplicable delay in the legislative timetable to bring in the changes to the whole legislative structure of the Audit Office. It is a very debilitating situation as regards its ability to carry out its work. PARA.TAB: It is a major slippage from the Government's earlier proposals. I guess we cannot be sure that there will not be further slippage. PARA.TAB: With the devolution of power and decision making in the current system, the place of the Auditor-General becomes more vital. TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

PARA.TAB: The reason I am concerned is that there is ample evidence supplied by a report written by Mr Cleaver Elliott, Clerk-Assistant (Management), on 20 October 1988, and a further report which was sought on 10 December 1990 from Mallesons Stephen Jaques and the manner in which these two reports were dealt with. The last page of Mr Elliott's report dated 20 October 1988 says:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the corroborated findings of offensive acts with a dildo and waiting outside the toilets for—
the person named—

these findings must be placed in context. The context was after hours off duty, in a bar area to which entry was entirely voluntary and optional. In such circumstances I do not however propose to recommend charges. I do not condone these acts and it is clear that they do not reflect well on—
the gentleman who is accused of the harassment. Mr Elliott went on to recommend that this person, who is still employed in this building in a position of seniority, be admonished for these matters.

PARA.TAB: That matter was then referred to the Clerk who made a note that he was to be admonished. The provisions of the Act, as I understand them, say that that can be done only by a departmental head or by a Presiding Officer. In fact, it was meted out by a security controller.

Failure to take action has resulted in stress for the person concerned. She was finally put in a position where she had to take action. On 10 December, Mallesons Stephen Jaques reported in response to a request from Mr Vander Wyk for an appraisal of the evidence on both standards of proof—that is, balance of probabilities, which is the standard of proof applicable for harassment, and beyond reasonable doubt, which is the criminal standard that is applicable, as I said, for matters of a criminal nature.

I would like to table, and perhaps have incorporated in Hansard, the findings of Mr Richard Arthur. He found the facts proven in respect of two particular items of distinct harassment, one of which was of a physical nature. He found these matters proven on the balance of probability standard; he also found some of the charges proven on the higher beyond reasonable doubt standard. And yet still this matter was not dealt with in an expeditious manner and the person who perpetrated the offence is still employed in the same position.

My concern is, as I said, that the matter has been dealt with in such a way that the Department has incurred additional cost. Although a settlement was effected, it could have been done a lot earlier. I am concerned to see that this sort of thing does not happen again.

Since the matter has become public, other people have talked to me. One could say that there is general unrest among people who fall within the administration of our own House. I find that gravely concerning; I find it personally distressing.

We have had many examples of deficiencies with regard to security. There does not seem to be any proper reporting structure. There seems to be this mishmash of some for the Senate, some for the House of Representatives and some for the Joint House. Something has to be done to solve the problem. —I think it might be perhaps to the benefit of the Committee if the whole of Mr Elliott's document was tabled.

—I do not have the rest of it. I would be delighted if Mr Elliott would table it. SPEECH.PARA: . . . a Parliamentary Security Attendant Grade 1 and an employee of the Senate. The grievance has been considered pursuant to regulations 6 and 22 of the Public Service (Parliamentary Officers) Regulations.

Noted. Please advise the parties of the findings and provide them with a copy of the report. The action suggested in your last para was obviously necessary and should proceed as soon as possible.

As I said, the provision is for who should issue the admonishment. It seems to me that something has to be done about management so that we have a work force here that is more efficiently managed and that has some sensible form of reporting.

PARA.TAB: For three years—1988 to 1991—to have gone by is just not an acceptable way to handle this distressful case. It is distressful for all concerned—officers of the Senate, the people who have suffered the indignity and the person who has perpetrated it. We have to have a better system of management.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I would like to say is that I believe the matter has been handled properly by the Department. It was settled at the request of the complainant and a comprehensive report was provided to Estimates Committee A. I listened carefully to what Senator Bishop said. I do not believe that that was an accurate summary of the report of Mallesons Stephen Jacques, but I will look at the Hansard tomorrow. Mallesons found that a sexual advance had been made, but the report did not find that it constituted sexual harassment under the meaning of the Act. PARA.TAB: I do not want to go beyond the report that has already been provided to Estimates Committee A. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important, just for the purpose of replying to what was, in fact, found. After dealing with the evidence, the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, I consider that the incident occurred. The varying accounts given by K make it difficult to establish exactly what occurred. However, I do not regard those variations as being sufficient to put the incident as a whole into doubt. The proper finding must be that the incident was of a substantial nature and broadly as K alleges.
There are further findings through the report. It says:

S did make an advance in K's room which was rejected by her. I consider that the circumstantial evidence of the events, both before and after the incident, do not leave room for doubt that K's account is substantially true. I have doubts that the incidents occurred as K alleges in her most detailed account, but I am satisfied that beyond a reasonable doubt S made a significant sexual advance to K in the room.
The findings are pretty straightforward. Finally the report says:

. . . except to say that the application of a higher standard of proof in relation to certain allegations may well be appropriate in the context of section 56 of the Public Service Act, although I accept that proof on the balance of probabilities only is required in relation to a formal complaint of sexual harassment. In any event my own findings were reached firstly on the application of proof of the balance of probabilities and then subsequently beyond reasonable doubt. I did not approach the evidence with a variable standard.
Indeed, the report criticises the earlier report by Mr Elliott that I mentioned on the basis that different standards of proof were applied. The report further says:
The terms of section 78 of the Sexual Discrimination Act make it clear that it was not appropriate to apply the rules of evidence in relation to a complaint under that Act.
That is where the problem of administration lies. An officer was applying rules of evidence and standards which were not appropriate to the offence as it was reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have here a memorandum on additional issues arising in relation to sexual harassment. It was prepared for the Department by Mr Richard Arthur of Mallesons. I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further questions on the Department of the Senate, we move to the Parliamentary Library. There are a number of general matters listed on the running sheet.

—The matter I raise relates to the problems of the management of the Library mentioned in the reservations. I do not want to take the time of the Committee now, but I have a copy of an audit report from the Australian National Audit Office dated 24 September 1991, dealing with the fact that the Library breached section 83 of the Constitution in that the Library simply ran out of money to pay its salaries. It subsequently did apply for a further advance from the Advance to the Presiding Officers, but the problem is that the payment was made before the advance was sought.

PARA.TAB: The significant feature was that the Library did not know it had run out of money; it only knew it had run out of money when the Department of Finance rang up and told it. It is a serious matter that needs to be added to the other matters we dealt with. We are in the process of having that management put in order, and I think this sort of matter needs to be dealt with and have attention paid to it by the new set of management that is now in the Library. That is why I have raised the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Bishop has just said is correct. The Australian National Audit Office has qualified the financial statements of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for the financial year ended 30 June 1991. The qualification relates to expenditure by the Library at the end of the 1990-91 Supply period which was in excess of its warrant authority and appropriation under the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1990-91. A breach of section 83 of the Constitution and the Audit Act 1901 therefore has occurred.

PARA.TAB: Warrant authority pursuant to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act (No. 1) 1990-91 was not received until 11 December 1990. The Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1990-91 had appropriated, in line with usual practice, five-twelfths of the anticipated 1990-91 administrative expenditure of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, plus salaries based on the paydays which would fall in the period for which Supply was expected, based on previous years experience, to be needed—that is, to the end of November. Because of the lateness of appropriations becoming available, Supply period funds were required to cover 12 paydays, as opposed to the 11 originally anticipated. The failure was in not monitoring expenditure closely and relating that to the clearly slower than usual passage of the Appropriation Bills through the Parliament.

On Wednesday, 5 December 1990—the day before the additional payday—an approach was made to the President and the Speaker by the Parliamentary Librarian for an allocation of $300,000 from the joint advance to meet salary payments due on 6 December 1990. However, the salaries expenditure had already been processed by the Department of Finance on 3 December 1990, along with other expenditure, which combined to cause the breach of the Constitution and the Audit Act. The qualification affected approximately $200,000 of the Parliamentary Library's 1990-91 expenditure, or 2 per cent of the total. During this Supply period, Library expenditure against appropriations is being closely monitored by Library management and a similar situation will not arise in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bills and move:

The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
BILL 1991
This Bill would enact a number of changes which would be the basis for reforms to ensure that Medicare remains a sustainable, equitable, and efficient universal health insurance system.

This Bill would adjust the Medicare benefits arrangements to encourage more appropriate use of medical services and more efficient use of health resources and to provide improved protection for families from high out of pocket gap costs for private medical services. The Bill would also ensure ongoing support for those general practitioners who choose to bulk bill.
The major problem facing Australia's health care system is the growth in use of medical services per person. This growth means that every 20 years the number of medical services per person doubles.

That growth is not caused by Medicare—the National Health Strategy has shown that that growth has been occurring fairly constantly since at least 1976. The cause is an open ended fee for service system underwritten by insurance—whether public or private.
The result has been that as doctor numbers have grown so too has the use of medical services.
The National Health Strategy has indicated that an integrated approach—that addresses the demand and supply sides together—could have a major impact on growth in use of medical services.

That is what the Government proposes. Details are set out in Budget Related Paper No. 9. This Bill would implement the first parts of the package of measures the Government envisages. Further measures will be discussed with the medical profession over coming months—with the Government intending to implement further changes from 1 July 1992. As a result of the Caucus working party review of the reforms to Medicare, the Government has now agreed to commit up to $12 million to demonstration general practice grants in 1991-92, keeping in mind the general aims of the formal program due to commence on 1 July 1992.

The measures contained in this Bill have been subjected to a comprehensive review process and have been refined as a result of this process. I am therefore confident that the revised package of reforms will provide a sound basis for containing health expenditure and encouraging the more efficient use of health resources. It will address the problem of inappropriate service patterns and encourage a more selective use of medical services through the introduction of a judicious price signal while providing improved protection for families, the chronically ill and heavy users of medical services. Finally the reforms provide a clear signal that the Government supports the ongoing role of bulk billing.
The Bill would amend the Health Insurance Act 1973 in order to:

PARA.TAB: reduce benefits for out of hospital general practitioner attendance items provided to non cardholders and permit doctors who bulk bill non cardholders to raise charges (copayments) for the same services;
provide additional protection for concessional beneficiaries in circumstances where they cannot produce their card to a doctor as evidence of their status;
introduce provisions for an additional payment to be made to doctors each time they bulk bill a non cardholder for these services;
expand the Medicare safety-net, and to permit "gap" costs for families to count towards the existing safety-net threshold of $246;

include transitional provisions to protect individuals when the existing safety net arrangements which apply on a financial year basis are replaced retrospectively by a calendar year accounting period; and
provide for the indexation of certain amounts in the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare benefit for prescribed out-of-hospital general practitioner consultation items for non-concessionary benefits would be reduced by $3.50 from 1 December 1991. This reduction would increase to $5 from 1 November 1992 and be indexed annually from then on. For bulk-billed services where the benefit is reduced, general practitioners would be able to charge non-concessionary patients a co-payment of up to $2.50. When the additional $1.00 fee for bulk billed services is added to the $2.50 maximum copayment, the net income for a doctor who bulk bills remains unaffected by these changes.

The Government recognises the administrative efficiencies and lower costs which result from processing bulk billed claims compared with patient billed claims for general practice services. It also acknowledges that there are broader benefits which result from bulk billing in terms of cost control and in access to affordable medical services. The introduction through this Bill of an indexed $1.00 additional payment (known as the transaction fee) for each bulk billed service affected by the reduced benefit will recognise these advantages and send a clear signal to doctors that the Government supports bulk billing.
The attendance items affected by these reforms are defined in the Bill and would be prescribed in detail in regulations and would include the following:

PARA.TAB: all vocationally registered general practitioner items for consultations in the surgery, home visits, and consultations in institutions and nursing homes;
all parallel consultation items for attendances by other than vocationally registered general practitioners;
emergency after hours attendances; and
GP attendances involving acupuncture.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits for other items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule are unchanged by this Bill.

There would be exemptions from these changes for a range of concessional beneficiaries and, in most cases, their dependants and for those persons and families who become eligible for increased benefits in any year under the safety-net arrangements. Concessional beneficiaries are similar to those under the Pharmaceutical Benefits arrangements but will also extend to those persons entitled to medical care under sections 85 and 86 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
The following concessional beneficiaries and their dependants would be exempt;

PARA.TAB: Social Security and Veterans' Affairs pensioners, including those persons who have retained some entitlements under the deeming provisions for savings introduced in the 1990 budget;
most Social Security beneficiaries;
persons receiving family allowance supplement in respect of a child;
disadvantaged persons under the Health Insurance Act; and,
pensioners within the meaning of the National Health Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Persons with treatment entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act would also be exempt but this exemption will not extend to their dependants.

The Parliament has enacted the Social Security (Disability & Sickness Support) Amendment Act 1991 which will replace the sheltered employment allowance, the rehabilitation allowance and the invalid pension with the disability support pension and to replace sickness benefit with sickness allowance from 12 November 1991.

Social Security legislation which provides for necessary consequential amendments to the Health Insurance Act has been introduced into the Senate and certain provisions of that Bill are dependent on the passing of this Bill.
The Bill deals with new safety-net arrangements which are designed to protect families and individuals from excessive medical costs.

Currently individuals who incur out of pocket costs for gaps between the Medicare benefit and the Schedule Fee for out of hospital services totalling more than $246 (indexed) in a financial year are entitled to benefits to cover their gap costs up to 100% of the Schedule Fee for out of hospital services for the remainder of the financial year.

The threshold would from 1 January 1992 apply to gap expenses incurred by a family as a whole rather than by each individual member of the family. The definition of a family would be that currently used for the safety-net applying in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Enrolling as a family would be voluntary.
The current safety-net threshold of $246 for individuals would not change for persons who are not members of families and anyone who chooses not to be counted as part of a family.

The safety-net year would change from the existing financial year to a calendar year basis. This would ensure the extra protection applies as soon as practicable. It would also bring the arrangements into line with those which apply to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The safety-net threshold would remain at its current level of $246 for 1992 and would be indexed thereafter annually. The level would be the same for both individuals and families.

This represents a substantial improvement in protection for families. Under the current arrangements some families continue to pay gap costs for out of hospital services for some family members even when one or more members have exceeded the threshold figure. The new arrangements should bring relief to those families where one or more members has a chronic condition or who face unexpected high costs because of sudden serious illness in the family.
The change would reduce the maximum costs for out of hospital private medical services of a couple with two children from $984 to $246 a year where their doctors charge Schedule fees or less.

The transitional provisions within the Bill provide for the protection of individuals for the period where existing safety net provisions, which apply on a financial year basis, would be overlapped by new provisions, applying retrospectively for the calendar year commencing 1 January 1991. The transitional provisions would take into account the reduction in benefit and the copayment which will apply from 1 December 1991 to 31 December 1991. These provisions also ensure that the potential for "double-dipping" is avoided as a result of the transitional overlap in safety net periods.

The Health Insurance Commission would recalculate the totals of individuals' patient contributions back to 1 January 1991 and then apply the current threshold of $246. Retrospective adjustments would be made, where necessary, to claims already processed for individuals who achieve the safety-net threshold under this transitional arrangement. People who received increased benefits after reaching the threshold in the period 1 July 1990 to 30 June 1991 would not be required to repay those benefits.

The Bill would also provide for indexation of the following: the maximum gap between the Schedule Fee and the Medicare Benefit; the safety-net threshold; the reduction to benefit for the prescribed GP services; the maximum copayment; and the additional fee for bulk billed services. Both the maximum gap and safety-net threshold are indexed under current legislation.

The package of reforms provided for in this Bill represent future changes foreshadowed in the Budget papers; the most significant changes to Australia's health system since the introduction of Medicare. In order to ensure that the community understands the reasons for these changes and what effect they will have on the quality and efficiencies of general practice, $4 million has been allocated over the next two years for patient information and education purposes.

Clearly there are serious concerns about the cost to the community and the quality of care provided in general practice. The Government has commenced discussions with the medical profession to see how funding arrangements might be further amended to assist the profession in its appropriate role of improving standards of practice.

The aim of the discussions is to enable both the profession and the Government to pursue their legitimate roles while ensuring that there is a greater synthesis between the two. It is the responsibility of the profession to set and supervise standards. It is the responsibility of the Government to ensure the financing mechanisms permit access to necessary medical services while constraining costs to ensure the long term sustainability of Medicare and assisting the profession to provide high quality care.
Discussions with the profession will centre around the following:

First, the use of practice grants to complement fee for service reimbursement. A practice grant would provide some remuneration to those general practices which choose to reduce their reliance on fee for service.

This would better target health benefits, since it would offer appropriate financial incentives for practices to engage in best practice care, provide financing arrangements to encourage better integration with the health system and to involve GPs in a wider range of activities. These could be funded through a trade off between providing funds for practice grants and providing funds for Schedule fee increases for GPs' services.
Up to $12 million will be provided in 1991-92 to enable demonstration practice grants to be introduced as soon as possible.

Second, trialing of the use of practice budgets. Under this arrangement a budget is allocated to general practices to cover the costs of diagnostic services and pharmaceuticals. This could build on the Government's other reforms in pharmaceuticals, pathology and radiology. It could also facilitate the trade offs which GPs make between different approaches to the care of their patients and support the role of the GP as the co-ordinator of a network of care. It would be a different approach from that at the moment which relies on counselling by the Health Insurance Commission for doctors who by comparison with their peers appear to use excessive amounts of these services.

Third, accreditation of general practices. The Government sees this as a natural development of the vocational registration arrangements. Those arrangements are a form of accreditation, but of individual practitioners. Accreditation would be a matter for the profession, but it could provide a framework within which many steps could be taken to address quality of care issues in general practice. These might include improved quality of training provided to GP trainees through links between accredited practice and academic Departments of general practice in medical schools. Similarly improved continuing education and quality assurance programs could result from these links.

Fourth, supply and distribution of medical practitioners. There are four major aspects for discussion. These are: medical immigration; output of medical schools; the distribution of medical practitioners; and developing alternatives for GPs to help reduce the oversupply problem in urban areas.

Many other countries have acted to deal with excessive medical immigration. The situation in Australia is now such that it can no longer afford to permit relatively unrestricted entry of overseas medical practitioners.

Fifth, information technology. Information technology could substantially enhance the diagnostic and patient education roles of General Practitioners as well as improving the business management of practices. However, as with other diagnostic equipment the current structures of general practice mean that few practices have sufficient capital base to provide these facilities.

Over $400,000 has been provided in the 1991-92 Budget to support the work of the Review of Professional Indemnity Arrangements for Health Care Professionals. The Review, established by me in April 1991, will examine and report on current arrangements relating to professional indemnity insurance for health care professionals. It will also examine current experience with compensation for medical misadventure and any difficulties with these current arrangements including problems with service quality, coverage and benefits.

The Review will prepare a discussion paper, undertake widespread consultations and prepare a final report, with recommendations for reform, for consideration by the Government in the context of the 1992-93 Budget.

The resources provided in the 1991-92 Budget will enable the Review to prepare its discussion paper, develop options, undertake national consultations, conduct a number of research projects and develop sound costings for possible reform options.

Reform of arrangements for compensation for medical misadventure could assist doctors to significantly improve the quality of care to patients while avoiding unnecessary diagnostic costs which arise from the practice of defensive medicine.
Conclusion
I reiterate that this Bill is to enact a number of changes designed to ensure that Medicare remains a sustainable, equitable, and efficient universal health insurance system.
It is the first step in addressing difficulties that exist not so much in our health insurance system as in our health care system.

The reforms contained in this Bill have been subjected to a comprehensive review process, and as a result of that process have been refined to ensure that they represent the most effective means of dealing with these difficulties.
I look forward to the co-operation of the medical profession in addressing these difficult and complex issues.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I now present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT BILL
As part of the Government's 1991-92 Budgetary measures, I bring before the House a Bill to amend the Health Insurance Act 1973.

The Bill rectifies what has previously been a deficiency in the Legislation, that enabled Medicare benefits to be paid when a medical practitioner rendered a medical service outside the scope of that medical practitioner's limited or restricted State or Territory registration.

The Bill also includes a new provision which ensures that a patient is fully informed concerning the non availability of Medicare entitlements before a medical service is rendered outside a medical practitioner's State or Territory registration. The Bill includes a provision which requires that a medical practitioner, before rendering a medical service outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration, will be required to give to the patient a notice advising that a Medicare benefit is not payable in respect of such a service.
The Bill introduces a penalty provision where, if a medical practitioner who is required to so notify a patient fails to do so, then a penalty, set at a maximum of $2000 may apply.

Also included in the Bill is a discretion for the payment of Medicare benefits, to ensure that patients are not disadvantaged by the proposed new arrangements. This will enable the payment of Medicare benefits for a medical service which is rendered by a medical practitioner outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration and where the medical practitioner fails to inform the patient that Medicare benefits are not payable. For example, such a provision would enable Medicare benefits to be paid where a medical practitioner acting outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration, was required to provide an emergency service.

Honourable Senators will be aware, that for some time, the Government has been reviewing the key elements of the Medicare arrangements and, in particular, concerns related to excessive servicing by some medical practitioners.

The Bill introduces a new penalty provision and new referral powers to a Medicare Participation Review Committee, which are considered necessary as deterrents to medical practitioners who render excessive services. These amendments are part of the Government's broad initiatives to control the costs of Medicare.

Medical practitioners, under the current legislation, may be required to appear before a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry, which is a committee of medical colleagues, to justify the necessity of the medical services rendered. To the extent that a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry finds that the medical practitioner has excessively serviced, that medical practitioner may be required to repay such Medicare benefits to the Commonwealth or the Commonwealth may not be required to pay Medicare benefits for such medical services. The Bill introduces a penalty, in addition to the non-payment or repayment of Medicare benefits, equal to the value of the Medicare payments in respect of those services, which have been found by a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry to have been rendered excessively.

The current legislation provides for the establishment of Medicare Participation Review Committees. Such Committees are empowered to review the continued participation of a medical practitioner in the Medicare arrangements, in certain circumstances, and may disqualify a medical practitioner from the Medicare arrangements for up to five years. The Bill introduces new provisions requiring that where a medical practitioner has been found to have rendered excessive services by a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry, and has incurred a penalty, on two or more occasions, then such a medical practitioner will be referred to a Medicare Participation Review Committee.

On 1 December 1991 new Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table) Regulations will be implemented. From these Regulations, it has been common practice to produce the Medicare Benefits Schedule, which is used by medical practitioners in relation to billing patients under Medicare. The Australian National Audit Office, Efficiency Audit Report No. 26, on the Administration of the Medicare Benefits Schedule made four recommendations regarding presentational changes to the Medicare Benefits Schedule. The recommendations regarding the Medicare Benefits Schedule were, in substance, that it be restructured with more logical and appropriate headings to enable easier identification of the Medical Services Items, and thus be more `user friendly'.

To implement the changes, the Bill introduces two technical amendments. These amendments will exclude the restrictive references in the current Legislation to the words "Parts" and "Divisions" to enable more appropriate terms to be used in dividing up the various medical services in the Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table)
Regulations. These changes do not effect in any way the substance of the medical services that are itemised in the current Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table) Regulations.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I now present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: LAN Tender

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current status of LAN implementation at the department's Tuggeranong, ACT, offices.

(2) Will the implementation be completed and operate to the original specification, if not, why not and what will be the expected budgeting over-run for the implementation at its completion, compared with the original tender.
(3) What was the total cost of the tender for implementing LAN and which organisation won the tender.
(4) How many tenderers were there and was the winning tender the cheapest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A Request for Quotation (RFQ) to install a Local Area Network (LAN) at Tuggeranong was issued on 14 February 1991. The Request for Quotation was issued to cover 700 users—just over half the number of staff moving to the new complex. Staff not connected to the LAN would continue to be connected to a Wang network.

The final group of moves from the Woden offices to Tuggeranong occurred on the weekend 12/13 October. This move saw the completion of the physical connection of users to the LAN. Some minor adjustments were made to take account of changes in the number of staff moving into the

ANSWER.PARA: building modules where the LAN was to be installed. Some 770 users were in the event connected to the LAN.

PARA.TAB: Although the physical connection of users has been finalised there is now a three month support period and a minimum of 12 month warranty from the date of acceptance.

(2) The implementation of hardware and software has been completed. As can be expected with new technology some problems have occurred during the settling in period and are progressively being resolved as part of the support arrangements.

The facilities will be upgraded and expanded to meet the Department's requirements with regard to the remaining users in the National Administration. The timetable for this extension has yet to be determined.

There was no budget over-run for the implementation of the facilities described in the Request for Quotation. The additional 70 users were supplied with equipment from a small LAN which was previously operating in Woden.

(3) The total cost of the RFQ for the LAN is $2,098,606 for hardware, software and services. The Request for Quotation, which was issued in accordance with DAS Contract PE40, was awarded to Siemens/Nixdorf.

(4) There were ten respondents to the Request for Quotation. Five bids were set aside as failing to meet mandatory conditions. A further two bids were not taken further after testing. The selected response was the `cheapest' of the three final bids taking into account the total cost of ownership including maintenance, network management support and training.
